('75', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. RAJKOT
('75', 0, 2, 3, 52) The struggle in Rajkot has a personal touch about it for me.
('75', 0, 2, 4, 113) It was the place where I received all my education up to the matricul ation examination and where my father was Dewan for many years.
('75', 0, 2, 5, 247) My wife feels so much about the sufferings of the people that though she is as old as I am and much less able than myself to brave such hardships as may be attendant upon jail life, she feels she must go to Rajkot.
('75', 0, 2, 6, 462) And before this is in print she might have gone there.
('75', 0, 3, 7, 517) But I want to take a detached view of the struggle.
('75', 0, 3, 8, 569) Sardar’s statement 2, reproduced elsewhere, is a legal document in the sense that it has not a superfluous word in it and contains nothing that cannot be supported by unimpeachable evidence most of which is based on written records which are attached to it as appendices.
('75', 0, 3, 9, 841) It furnishes evidence of a cold blooded breach of a solemn covenant entered into between the Rajkot Ruler and his people.
('75', 0, 3, 10, 963) 3 And the breach has been committed at the instance and bidding of the British Resident 4 who is directly linked with the Viceroy.
('75', 0, 3, 11, 1094) To the covenant a British Dewan 5 was party.
('75', 0, 3, 12, 1139) His boast was that he represented British authority.
('75', 0, 3, 13, 1192) He had expected to rule the Ruler.
('75', 0, 3, 14, 1227) He was therefore no fool to fall into the Sardar’s trap.
('75', 0, 3, 15, 1284) Therefore, the covenant was not an extortion from an imbecile ruler.
('75', 0, 3, 16, 1353) The British Resident detested the Congress and the Sardar for the crime of saving the Thakore Saheb from bankruptcy and, probably, loss of his gadi.
('75', 0, 3, 17, 1502) The Congress influence he could not brook.
('75', 0, 3, 18, 1545) And so before the Thakore Saheb could possibly redeem his promise to his people, he made him break it.
('75', 0, 3, 19, 1648) If the news the Sardar is receiving from Rajkot is to be believed, the Resident is showing the red claws of the British lion and says in effect to the people: ‘Your ruler is my creature.
('75', 0, 3, 20, 1835) I have put him on the gadi and I can depose him.
('75', 0, 3, 21, 1884) He knew well enough that he
('75', 0, 4, 22, 1912) 1 Kasturba Gandhi was arrested at Rajkot on February 3 on entering the State to offer satyagraha.
('75', 0, 4, 23, 2010) 2 Vide Cold Blooded Breach of A Solemn Covenant 3Vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 26 1 1939, and also “The States”, 4 E. C. Gibson 5 Sir Patrick R. Cadell
('75', 1, 0, 1, 2166) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 1, 1, 2, 2206) had acted against my wishes.
('75', 1, 1, 3, 2235) I have therefore undone his action in coming to terms with his people.
('75', 1, 1, 4, 2306) For your dealings with the Congress and the Sardar I shall teach you a lesson that you will not forget for a generation.’ Having made the Ruler a virtual prisoner, he has begun a reign of terrorism in Rajkot.
('75', 1, 1, 5, 2515) Here is what the latest telegram received by the Sardar says:
('75', 1, 2, 6, 2577) Becharbhai Jasani and other volunteers arrested.
('75', 1, 2, 7, 2626) Twenty six volunteers taken at night to a distant place in the Agency limits and brutally beaten.
('75', 1, 2, 8, 2724) Volunteers in villages are similarly treated.
('75', 1, 2, 9, 2770) Agency police controlling State agency and searching private houses in civil limits.
('75', 1, 2, 10, 2855) The British Resident is repeating the performances of the British officials in ‘British India’ during the civil disobedience days.
('75', 1, 2, 11, 2986) I know that if the people of Rajkot can stand all this madness without themselves becoming mad, and meekly but resolutely and bravely suffer the inhumanities heaped upon them, they will come out victorious and, what is more, they will set free the Thakore Saheb.
('75', 1, 2, 12, 3249) They will prove that they are the real rulers of Rajkot under the paramountcy of the Congress.
('75', 1, 2, 13, 3344) If, however, they go mad and think of impotent retaliation and resort to acts of violence, their state will be worse than before and the paramountcy of the Congress will be of no effect.
('75', 1, 2, 14, 3531) The Congress paramountcy avails only those who accept the banner of non violence, even as the paramountcy of Britain avails only those who subscribe to the doctrine of ‘might is right.’ What then is the duty of the Congress when the people of Rajkot have to face not the Ruler and his tiny police but the disciplined hordes of the British Empire?
('75', 1, 2, 15, 3878) The first and natural step is for the Congress ministry to make themselves responsible for the safety and honour of the people of Rajkot.
('75', 1, 2, 16, 4016) It is true that the Government of India Act gives the ministers no power over the States.
('75', 1, 2, 17, 4106) But they are governors of a mighty province in which Rajkot is but a speck.
('75', 1, 2, 18, 4182) As such they have rights and duties outside the Government of India Act.
('75', 1, 2, 19, 4255) And these are much the most important.
('75', 1, 2, 20, 4294) Supposing that Rajkot became the place of refuge for all the goondas that India could produce, supposing further that from there they carried on operations throughout India, the ministers would clearly have the right and it would be their duty to ask the Paramount Power through the British Representative in Bombay to set
('75', 2, 0, 1, 4617) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 3
('75', 2, 1, 2, 4659) things right in Rajkot.
('75', 2, 1, 3, 4683) And it will be the duty of the Paramount Power to do so or to lose the ministers.
('75', 2, 1, 4, 4765) Every minister in his province is affected by everything that happens in territories within his geograp hical limit though outside his legal jurisdiction, especially if that thing hurts his sense of decency.
('75', 2, 1, 5, 4973) Responsible government in those parts may not be the ministers’ concern, but if there is plague in those parts or butchery going on, it is very much their concern; or else their rule is a sham and a delusion.
('75', 2, 1, 6, 5182) Thus the ministers in Orissa may not sit comfortably in their chairs, if they do not succeed in sending 26,000 refugees of Talcher to their home with an absolute assurance of safety and freedom of speech and social and political intercourse.
('75', 2, 1, 7, 5424) It is insufferable that the Congress, which is today in alliance with the British Government, should be treated as an enemy and an outsider in the States which are vassals of the British.
('75', 2, 1, 8, 5612) This wanton breach, instigated by the British Resident in Rajkot, of the charter of the liberty of its people is a wrong which must be set right at the earliest possible moment.
('75', 2, 1, 9, 5790) It is like a poison corroding the whole body.
('75', 2, 1, 10, 5836) Will H. E. the Viceroy realize the significance of Rajkot and remove the poison?
('75', 2, 1, 11, 5917) BARDOLI, January 30, 1939

('75', 2, 3, 13, 5961) 2. THE MODERN GIRL
('75', 2, 4, 14, 5980) I have received a letter written on behalf of eleven girls whose names and addresses have been sent to me.
('75', 2, 4, 15, 6087) I give it below with changes that make it more readable without in any way altering the meaning:
('75', 2, 5, 16, 6184) Your comments on the letter of a lady student captioned ‘Students’ Shame’ and published in Harijan on the 31st December, 1938 1 deserve special attention.
('75', 2, 5, 17, 6339) The modern girl, it seems, has provoked you to the extent that you have disposed of her finally as one playing Juliet to half a dozen Romeos.
('75', 2, 5, 18, 6481) This remark which betrays your idea about women in general is not very inspiring.
('75', 2, 6, 19, 6563) In these days when women are coming out of closed doors to help men and take an equal share of the burden of life, it is indeed strange that they are still blamed even when they are maltreated by men.
('75', 2, 6, 20, 6764) It cannotbe denied that
('75', 2, 7, 21, 6788) 1Vide “Letter to Akbar Hydari”, 26 12 1938
('75', 3, 0, 1, 6831) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 3, 1, 2, 6871) instances can be cited where the fault is equally divided.
('75', 3, 1, 3, 6930) There may be a few girls playing Juliets to half a dozen Romeos.
('75', 3, 1, 4, 6995) But such cases presuppose the existence of half a dozen Romeos, moving about the streets in quest of a Juliet.
('75', 3, 1, 5, 7106) And it cannot or should never be taken that modern girls are categorically all Juliets or modern youths all Romeos.
('75', 3, 1, 6, 7222) You yourself have come in contact with quite a number of modern girls and may have been struck by their resolution, sacrifice and other sterling womanly virtues.
('75', 3, 2, 7, 7384) As for forming public opinion against such misdemeanours as pointed out by your correspondent, it is not for girls to do it, not so much out of false shame as from its ineffectiveness.
('75', 3, 3, 8, 7569) But a statement like this from one revered all over the world seems to hold a brief once more for that worn out and unbecoming saying ‘woman is the gate of Hell.’
('75', 3, 4, 9, 7732) From the foregoing remarks, however, please do not conclude that modern girls have no respect for you.
('75', 3, 4, 10, 7835) They hold you in as much respect as every young man does.
('75', 3, 4, 11, 7893) To be hated or pitied is what they resent much.
('75', 3, 4, 12, 7941) They are ready to mend their ways if they are really guilty.
('75', 3, 4, 13, 8002) Their guilt, if any, must be conclusively proved before they are anathematized.
('75', 3, 4, 14, 8082) In this respect they would neither desire to take shelter under the covering of ‘ladies, please’, nor would they silently stand and allow the judge to condemn them in his own way.
('75', 3, 4, 15, 8262) Truth must be faced; the modern girl or ‘Juliet’, as you have called her, has courage enough to face it.
('75', 3, 4, 16, 8367) My correspondents do not perhaps know that I began service of India’s women in South Africa more than forty years ago when perhaps none of them was born.
('75', 3, 4, 17, 8521) I hold myself to be incapable of writing anything derogatory to womanhood.
('75', 3, 4, 18, 8596) My regard for the fair sex is too great to permit me to think ill of them.
('75', 3, 4, 19, 8671) She is, what she has been described to be in English, the better half of mankind.
('75', 3, 4, 20, 8753) And my article was written to expose students’ shame, not to advertise the frailties of girls.
('75', 3, 4, 21, 8848) But in giving the diagnosis of the disease, I was bound, if I was to prescribe the right remedy, to mention all the factors which induced the disease.
('75', 3, 4, 22, 8999) The ‘modern girl’ has a special meaning.
('75', 3, 4, 23, 9040) Therefore there was no question of my restricting the scope of my remark to some.
('75', 3, 4, 24, 9122) But all the girls who receive English education are not modern girls.
('75', 3, 4, 25, 9192) I know many who are not at all touched by the ‘modern girl’ spirit.
('75', 3, 4, 26, 9260) But there are some who have become modern girls.
('75', 3, 4, 27, 9309) My remark was meant to warn India’s girl students against copying the ‘modern girl’ and complicating a problem that has become a serious menace.
('75', 3, 4, 28, 9454) For, at the
('75', 4, 0, 1, 9466) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 5
('75', 4, 1, 2, 9508) time I received the letter referred to, I received also a letter from an Andhra girl student bitterly complaining of the behaviour of Andhra students which from the description given is worse than what was described by the Lahore girl.
('75', 4, 1, 3, 9744) This daughter of Andhra tells me the simple dress of her girl friends gives them no protection, but they lack the courage to expose the barbarism of the boys who are a disgrace to the institution they belong to.
('75', 4, 1, 4, 9956) I commend this complaint to the authorities of the Andhra University.
('75', 4, 1, 5, 10026) The eleven girls I invite to initiate a crusade against the rude behaviour of students.
('75', 4, 1, 6, 10114) God helps only those who help themselves.
('75', 4, 1, 7, 10156) The girls must learn the art of protecting themselves against the ruffianly behaviour of man.
('75', 4, 2, 8, 10250) BARDOLI, January 30, 1939

('75', 4, 4, 10, 10294) 3. JAIPUR
('75', 4, 5, 11, 10304) The reader should know the distinction between the Jaipur struggle and the Rajkot one.
('75', 4, 5, 12, 10391) The Rajkot struggle is frankly for responsible government within the State and is now for redeeming the Ruler’s promise to his people.
('75', 4, 5, 13, 10526) Every man and woman of Rajkot, if they have any stuff in them, will be reduced to dust in resisting the dishonourable conduct of the British Resident.
('75', 4, 5, 14, 10677) The Jaipur struggle is on a very small and narrow issue.
('75', 4, 5, 15, 10734) The one political association of Jaipur has been virtually declared illegal for the offence of pleading for responsible government, and its President, himself a resident of Jaipur, has been put under a ban.
('75', 4, 5, 16, 10941) The civil disobedience struggle will cease the moment the bans are lifted and the right of free association, holding public meetings, etc., is conceded.
('75', 4, 5, 17, 11094) But here again the British lion has opened out his big claws.
('75', 4, 5, 18, 11156) The British Prime Minister of Jaipur had a chat with Barrister Chudgar, legal adviser of the Rao Rana of Sikar.
('75', 4, 5, 19, 11268) He reported to Seth Jamnalalji the following purport of the talk:
('75', 4, 6, 20, 11334) I understand it my duty to inform you that during my interview with Sir Beauchamp St. John, Prime Minister of Jaipur, in connection with Sikar affairs on the 9th inst.
('75', 4, 6, 21, 11502) (January), at about 11 a.
('75', 4, 6, 22, 11528) at his bungalow Natanika Bagh, I had some discussion with him regarding the Jaipur situation.
('75', 5, 0, 1, 11622) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 5, 1, 2, 11662) following is the substance of the discussion:
('75', 5, 2, 3, 11708) I told Sir Beauchamp that the ban against your entry into Jaipur State territories came as a painful surprise to millions of people all over India, particularly because you are well known to be a man of peace andyour mission was to supervise and direct famine relief activities in the famine stricken parts of Jaipur State.
('75', 5, 2, 4, 12032) To this Sir Beauchamp replied that he agreed that you are a man of peace, but you and your men’s visit, he thought, would bring you and your men in contact with the masses in the famine stricken areas, and this he did not like for obvious political reasons.
('75', 5, 2, 5, 12290) I told him that you cannot be expected to submit to the order for an indefinite period, and that it would be better in the interests of the State and the people, in view of the statement you have published in the Press after you had been served with the order, if the order were recalled so that unnecessary trouble may be avoided.
('75', 5, 2, 6, 12622) He was adamant, and he said that he was prepared to meet any situation that might arise if you disobeyed the order.
('75', 5, 2, 7, 12738) He said that the Congressmen are out for a revolution by means of a non violent struggle.
('75', 5, 2, 8, 12828) But non violence, he said, was a force as powerful or perhaps more powerful than violence.
('75', 5, 2, 9, 12919) He further said Indians were playing upon the humane instincts in the English race, but if there was Japan or Herr Hitler instead of the English in India we could not have succeeded so well with our non violence.
('75', 5, 3, 10, 13132) He then said that it was his considered opinion that non violence, however strict, must be met by violence, and his reply to the non violent movement in Jaipur would be the ‘machine gun’.
('75', 5, 3, 11, 13320) I pointed out to him that all Englishmen were not of his way of thinking and even the English race as such would not agree with him.
('75', 5, 3, 12, 13453) He said, “That may or may not be so,” but personally he was of the opinion that there was no difference between non violence and violence, and that there would be nothing wrong in using violence against non violence.
('75', 5, 4, 13, 13670) If you or Mahatmaji desire to make use of this statement, I have no
('75', 5, 5, 14, 13738) objection.
('75', 5, 5, 15, 13749) I considered this to be so startling that I referred it to the Prime Minister in the following letter (18 1 1939): 1 The Prime Minister replied as follows (20 1 1939):
('75', 5, 6, 16, 13917) I write to acknowledge your kind letter of the 18th instant, enclosing a copy of a letter from Mr. Chudgar to Seth Jamnalal Bajaj.
('75', 5, 6, 17, 14048) Your hesitation in publishing it before you had ascertained the correctness of its contents was a wise step, which I personally much appreciate, as I am now able to inform
('75', 5, 7, 18, 14220) 1 For the text of the letter, vide ”Note to Amritlal V. Thakkar St. John”
('75', 6, 0, 1, 14294) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 7
('75', 6, 1, 2, 14336) you that its description of my views is completely erroneous.
('75', 6, 1, 3, 14398) I am unable to understand how Mr. Chudgar so misunderstood me, as I may say that this incident confirms me in my hesitation to grant any such interviews in future.
('75', 6, 2, 4, 14562) Now that you are aware of the facts, I am sure your reluctance to publish such a letter will be confirmed.
('75', 6, 2, 5, 14669) Should, however, you decideotherwise, I shall be glad if you can inform me as soon as practicable so that I can take suitable action.
('75', 6, 3, 6, 14803) With renewed thanks for your consideration.

('75', 6, 6, 10, 14982) I am sure you will sympathize with me in my natural hesitation to make a record of an interview which was understood to be private and personal when the other party to the interview has already threatened to publish an erroneous version.
('75', 6, 6, 11, 15220) Such a procedure can, as I am sure you will agree, only lead to acrimony, and so far as I can see, serve no useful purpose.
('75', 6, 7, 12, 15344) Should, however, Mr. Chudgar see fit to publish his erroneous version, I am sure you will give me due warning so that, as I have already said, I may take suitable action.

('75', 6, 9, 15, 15710) I have read the correspondence between Mahatmaji and Sir W. Beauchamp St. John ending with Mahatmaji’s letter to him dated the 27th inst.

('75', 6, 9, 17, 15908) again, and I say that what I have stated in that letter is a substantially correct reproduction of the conversation between me and Sir Beauchamp.
('75', 6, 9, 18, 16054) The Prime Minister’s letters have made strange reading.
('75', 6, 9, 19, 16110) I had asked for bread, he has sent me a stone.
('75', 6, 9, 20, 16157) He will pardon me if I believe Shri Chudgar’s version, unless he can give his own.

('75', 8, 4, 6, 17880) 6. ‘KICKS AND KISSES’
('75', 8, 5, 7, 17902) The reader will read with painful interest the following account, said to be authentic, of the meeting recently held in Bombay of the Chamber of Princes:
('75', 8, 6, 8, 18056) H. H. the Maharaja of Bikaner opened the discussions by narrating the events at Rajkot where, he said, the trouble was due to the absence of influential jagirdars, the want of demarcation between the Privy Purse and the State Expenditure, and the smallness of the Kathiawar States.
('75', 8, 6, 9, 18338) It was regarded as a test case by the Congress, and they had selected Rajkot for various reasons, the principal ones being that Rajkot, small and with limited resources, would not be able to withstand for long the onslaughts of the Congress, that the ground was ready for the delivery of such an attack, that the Congress was virile and active in Kathiawar and Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel was near at hand to direct operations and conduct the campaign.
('75', 8, 6, 10, 18788) H. H. the Maharaja of Bikaner then mooted the suggestion of a common Police force for a group of States, as the resources of individual States, particularly of small ones, are not extensive and, therefore, totally inadequate to face the common danger.
('75', 8, 6, 11, 19040) Such also was the indication of the Paramount Power and of its representatives.
('75', 8, 6, 12, 19120) No great reliance, he said, could now be placed on co operation and help from adjoining British territories as Congress was supreme there and they naturally would not like to help Indian States.
('75', 8, 6, 13, 19315) On the other hand their sympathies either tacitly or actively are on the side of Indian State subjects or foreign agitators.
('75', 8, 6, 14, 19440) This was actually evidenced by the attitude of the Orissa Government when help was demanded by the States in Orissa which had to face this trouble.
('75', 8, 7, 15, 19588) Continuing, he stated that the Congress would devote increasingly greater attention to Indian States.
('75', 8, 7, 16, 19690) Up to now its policy, as embodied in the resolution of the Haripura session and before, was of non intervention and the Indian States people were directed to be self reliant.
('75', 8, 7, 17, 19865) The reason is manifest.
('75', 8, 7, 18, 19889) The Congress was actively busy with British Indian problems, and it wanted to generate strength in Indian States subjects and foster self help in them.
('75', 8, 7, 19, 20041) Now the Congress had practically established its sway in British India and would naturally mobilize its energy and influence towards Indian States.
('75', 9, 0, 1, 20189) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 9, 1, 2, 20230) There was another point.
('75', 9, 1, 3, 20255) In order to distract attention from the differences that are creeping into Congress ranks, it is necessary to unfold the plans of a campaign.
('75', 9, 1, 4, 20397) This is a subtle but short dictum of statecraft.
('75', 9, 1, 5, 20446) This is one of the reasons of the Italian conquest of Abyssinia and the Austrian and Sudeten campaigns of Germany.
('75', 9, 1, 6, 20561) It enables the powers to draw attention away from cleavages in the party and creates enthusiasm amongst its followers.
('75', 9, 1, 7, 20680) We have also to bear in mind the attitude of the Paramount Power.
('75', 9, 1, 8, 20746) In this connection reference must be made to the recent utterances of Mr. Gandhi on this subject.
('75', 9, 1, 9, 20844) In my opinion greater reliance should be placed on our own strength than on any outside agency whose support is, at best, precarious and inadequate.
('75', 9, 2, 10, 20993) After a survey of Rajkot affairs, His Highness discussed the problems of the Rajputana States and outlined for the benefit of the Princes the policy he pursued with regard to his own State, Bikaner.
('75', 9, 2, 11, 21192) He stated that he started the State Assembly in 1913, and it discussed the State expenditure.
('75', 9, 2, 12, 21286) Bikaner had a Raj patra—State Gazette.
('75', 9, 2, 13, 21325) He discriminated between the agitators from outside and from amongst his own subjects.
('75', 9, 2, 14, 21412) This, he said, was important and the distinction must ever be borne in mind.
('75', 9, 2, 15, 21489) Foreign agitators, who have no stake in the State and who assume this role merely to be dubbed leaders and to be in the public eye, deserve short shrift.
('75', 9, 2, 16, 21643) No consideration should be shown to them.
('75', 9, 2, 17, 21685) Their continued activities are a menace to the State; their presence constitutes a danger.
('75', 9, 2, 18, 21776) The remedy is deportation from the State and their entry should be banned.
('75', 9, 2, 19, 21851) The agitators in the State, though equally obnoxious to the State and its ordered peace and progress, however, stand on a slightly different footing.
('75', 9, 2, 20, 22001) They have an interest in the land; they probably sometimes advocate grievances which are to a certain extent legitimate, and such should be redressed as far as possible so that the wind may be taken away from the sails of their agitation which they advocate and foster.
('75', 9, 2, 21, 22271) Legitimate grievances so far as possible should be redressed and agitation should be silenced.
('75', 9, 2, 22, 22366) If the agitators are genuine and come from the ranks of the educated unemployed, an effort should be made to give them suitable State employment and to close their mouths, acting on the adage “it is better to sew the mouth with a morsel.”
('75', 9, 3, 23, 22605) The question of Praja Mandals was then discussed.
('75', 9, 3, 24, 22655) In this connection H. H. the Maharaja of Bikaner, Sir Kailashnarain Haksar, R. B. Pandit Amar Nath Atal of Jaipur, Pt. Dharmanarain of Udaipur and Major Harvey of Alwar made valuable contributions to the discussions.
('75', 9, 3, 25, 22872) Mr. Robertson of Bundi and Mr. McGregor of Sirohi also asked a few questions.
('75', 9, 3, 26, 22950) Mr. Atal narrated at great length the origin and growth of the Praja Mandal at Jaipur.
('75', 9, 3, 27, 23037) It was evident that the founders and promoters of these Praja Mandals were disgruntled subjects
('75', 10, 0, 1, 23133) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 11
('75', 10, 1, 2, 23176) and dismissed petty officials of the State.
('75', 10, 1, 3, 23220) A note of caution and warning was sounded.
('75', 10, 1, 4, 23263) It was agreed that they should be watched very carefully and their activities, however slight or extensive, should be fully reported.
('75', 10, 1, 5, 23397) It was stated that these Praja Mandals should be crushed immediately and that they should not be allowed to gather strength or to attain the status of an influential body.
('75', 10, 1, 6, 23569) If they had gained any, an effort should be made to direct adroitly their activities into social channels such as the Sarda Act, etc.
('75', 10, 1, 7, 23703) On the other hand it was urged that the formation of genuine and healthy advisory bodies of the States people should be encouraged.
('75', 10, 1, 8, 23835) which should form the nucleus for the training of the people for so called responsible government in the States.
('75', 10, 1, 9, 23948) The Praja Mandals located outside the States should be ignored.
('75', 10, 2, 10, 24012) As regards responsible government in the States advocated by Congress leaders like Messrs Gandhi and Patel, it was felt that the States people are not at all ready for it, and to concede it, therefore, would be detrimental to the States and the people and fatal to ordered progress and peace.
('75', 10, 2, 11, 24305) The position was summed up in the dictum, ‘Be responsive, but no responsible government.’ H. H. the Maharaja of Bikaner was emphatic in his policy towards the Congress, and his words can be crystallized in the following mottos: Be just, but be firm; follow the policy of repression and reconciliation as stated in the famous letter of Lord Minto in 1908, ‘the policy of kicks and kisses’.
('75', 10, 2, 12, 24694) It will require all the tact and discretion possible to adjust when to be gentle and when to be firm and how to mix the two.
('75', 10, 2, 13, 24819) The decision must depend on the situation which confronts the State and the merits of the individual problem.
('75', 10, 2, 14, 24929) It was, however, very clear in their discussions that the Praja Mandals, as such and as political bodies, should never be allowed to be formed in the States, and if in existence, should be crushed and banned and their activities very carefully and closely watched.
('75', 10, 2, 15, 25194) No hard and fast rules could be laid down as to how they should be repressed.
('75', 10, 2, 16, 25272) Individual States will devise and evolve their own plans and lay down the modus operandi.
('75', 10, 3, 17, 25362) The tentative conclusions arrived at were: 1. Group Police for States; 2.
('75', 10, 4, 18, 25436) Praja Mandals to be crushed immediately; 3. Legitimate grievances to be
('75', 10, 5, 19, 25508) redressed; 4. Foreign agitators to be severely dealt with and deported; 5.
('75', 10, 6, 20, 25583) Encourage social activities but not political; 6. Encourage genuine States
('75', 10, 7, 21, 25658) People’s Advisory Bodies; 7. Policy of ‘Reconciliation and Repression’; ‘Be
('75', 10, 8, 22, 25734) just, but be firm’.
('75', 10, 8, 23, 25754) If the report is an accurate summary of the speeches delivered at the Conference, it shows that there is a nefarious plot to crush the movement for liberty which at long last has commenced in some of the States.
('75', 10, 8, 24, 25966) Kisses are to go hand in hand with kicks.
('75', 10, 8, 25, 26008) This reminds me
('75', 11, 0, 1, 26024) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 11, 1, 2, 26065) of the Latin proverb which means: “I fear the Greeks especially when they bring gifts!” Henceforth Rulers’ favours are to be suspected.
('75', 11, 1, 3, 26201) Reforms when they are made are to be made not for the sake of making the people happy, but in order to sew the mouth with a morsel.
('75', 11, 1, 4, 26333) But man’s proposals are often confounded even though his may be a crowned head.
('75', 11, 1, 5, 26413) God has been found often to have disposed of his proposals in a way contrary to his expectations.
('75', 11, 1, 6, 26511) If the people have shed fear and learnt the art of self sacrifice, they need no favours.
('75', 11, 1, 7, 26600) Kicks can never cow them.
('75', 11, 1, 8, 26626) They will take what they need and assimilate it.
('75', 11, 2, 9, 26675) BARDOLI, January 31, 1939

('75', 13, 1, 2, 28914) beginning I was decidedly against his re election for reasons into which I need not go.

('75', 13, 1, 7, 29344) I am nothing if I do not represent definite principles and policy.
('75', 13, 1, 8, 29411) Therefore, it is plain to me that the delegates do not approve of the principles and policy for which I stand.
('75', 13, 1, 9, 29522) I rejoice in this defeat.
('75', 13, 1, 10, 29548) It gives me an opportunity of putting into practice what I preached in my article 1 on the walk out of the minority at the last A. I. C. C. meeting in Delhi.
('75', 13, 1, 11, 29706) Subhas Babu, instead of being President on the sufferance of those whom he calls rightists, is now President elected in a contested election.
('75', 13, 1, 12, 29848) This enables him to choose a homogeneous cabinet and enforce his programme without let or hindrance.
('75', 13, 1, 13, 29949) There is one thing common between majority and minority, viz., insistence on internal purity of the Congress organization.
('75', 13, 1, 14, 30072) My writings in the Harijan have shown that the Congress is fast becoming a corrupt organization in the sense that its registers contain a very large number of bogus members.
('75', 13, 1, 15, 30246) 2 I have been suggesting for the past many months the overhauling of these registers.
('75', 13, 1, 16, 30332) I have no doubt that many of the delegates who have been elected on the strength of these bogus voters would be unseated on scrutiny.
('75', 13, 1, 17, 30466) But I suggest no such drastic step.
('75', 13, 1, 18, 30502) It will be enough if the registers are purged of all bogus voters and are made fool proof for the future.
('75', 13, 1, 19, 30608) The minority has no cause for being disheartened.
('75', 13, 1, 20, 30658) If they believe in the current programme of the Congress, they will find that it can be worked, whether they are in a minority or a majority and even whether they are in the Congress or outside it.
('75', 13, 1, 21, 30856) The only thing that may possibly be affected by the changes is the parliamentary programme.
('75', 13, 1, 22, 30948) The ministers have been chosen and the programme shaped by the erstwhile majority.
('75', 13, 1, 23, 31031) But parliamentary work is but a minor item of the Congress programme.
('75', 13, 1, 24, 31101) Congress ministers have after all to live from day to day.
('75', 13, 1, 25, 31160) It matters little to them whether they are recalled on an issue in which they are in agreement
('75', 13, 2, 26, 31255) 1 Vide “That Unfortunate Walk Out” 2 Vide “Internal Decay”
('75', 14, 0, 1, 31314) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 15
('75', 14, 1, 2, 31357) with the Congress policy or whether they resign because they are in disagreement with the Congress.
('75', 14, 1, 3, 31457) After all Subhas Babu is not an enemy of his country.
('75', 14, 1, 4, 31511) He has suffered for it.
('75', 14, 1, 5, 31535) In his opinion his is the most forward and boldest policy and programme.
('75', 14, 1, 6, 31608) The minority can only wish it all success.
('75', 14, 1, 7, 31651) If they cannot keep pace with it, they must come out of the Congress.

('75', 14, 4, 15, 32209) BARDOLI, January 31, 1939 Appeals are being made to me not to precipitate matters in the States.
('75', 14, 4, 16, 32306) These appeals are unnecessary.
('75', 14, 4, 17, 32337) After three months of non violent struggle by the people of Rajkot an honourable understa nding was arrived at between the Thakore Saheb in Council and Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel representing the people, and the struggle was closed amid general rejoicings.
('75', 14, 4, 18, 32592) But the noble work done by the Thakore Saheb and the people has been undone by the British Resident.
('75', 14, 5, 19, 32693) Honour demanded that the people should fight unto death for the restoration of the covenant between the Thakore Saheb and his people.
('75', 14, 5, 20, 32827) The struggle now is not between the Ruler and his people, but in reality it is between the Congress and the British Government represented by the Resident, who is reported to be resorting to organized goondaism.
('75', 14, 5, 21, 33039) He is trying thereby to break the spirit of innocent men and women, who rightly resent the breach of faith.
('75', 14, 5, 22, 33147) It is a misrepresentation to suggest that Rajkot has been made a

('75', 27, 1, 2, 52644) 30. DISCUSSION WITH TEACHER TRAINEES 1
('75', 27, 2, 3, 52683) February 3/4, 1939
('75', 27, 3, 4, 52702) It is the fashion these days to talk of the rights of minorities.
('75', 27, 3, 5, 52768) Therefore, although those who understand English only are here in a hopeless minority, I shall speak today in English.
('75', 27, 3, 6, 52887) 2 But I warn you that I shall not do so at the next meeting.
('75', 27, 3, 7, 52948) You must go back with a firm resolve to learn Hindustani.
('75', 27, 3, 8, 53006) It is impossible to put into practice the idea of basic education—an idea which is calculated to answer the educational requirements of our millions—if the mind works only through the English medium.
('75', 27, 4, 9, 53206) A number of questions were put to him by the delegates.
('75', 27, 4, 10, 53262) The first question expressed a doubt as to whether the Wardha scheme was likely to stand the test of time, or if it merely was a measure of temporary expediency.
('75', 27, 4, 11, 53424) Many prominent educationists were of opinion that sooner or later the handicrafts would have to give place to whole hog industrialization.
('75', 27, 4, 12, 53563) Would a society educated on the lines of the Wardha scheme and based on justice, truth and non violence, be able to survive the severe strain of the process of industrialization?
('75', 27, 5, 13, 53742) GANDHIJI: This is not a practical question.
('75', 27, 5, 14, 53786) It does not affect our immediate programme.
('75', 27, 5, 15, 53830) The issue before us is not as to what is going to happen generations hence, but whether this basic scheme of education answers the real need of the millions that live in our villages.
('75', 27, 5, 16, 54014) I do not think that India is ever going to be industrialized to the extent that there will be no villages left.
('75', 27, 5, 17, 54126) The bulk of India will always consist of villages.
('75', 27, 6, 18, 54177) “What will happen to the scheme of basic education if the Congress policy changes as a result of the recent presidential election ?” he was asked next.
('75', 27, 7, 19, 54329) Gandhiji replied that it was misplaced fear.
('75', 27, 7, 20, 54374) A change in the Congress policy was not going to touch the Wardha scheme.
('75', 27, 7, 21, 54448) It will affect, if it at all does, higher politics only.
('75', 27, 7, 22, 54505) You have come here to undergo three weeks’ training course, so that you may be able to teach your students along the Wardha method on your return.
('75', 27, 8, 23, 54652) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Wardha Scheme under Fire”.
('75', 27, 8, 24, 54708) About seventy five delegates from all over India had attended a three weeks’ course at the Teacher Training Centre at Wardha.
('75', 27, 8, 25, 54834) Before leaving for their respective provinces they met Gandhiji.
('75', 27, 8, 26, 54899) 2 Gandhiji, at the suggestion of Asha Devi, had started to speak in Hindi and some of the delegates had not been able to follow.
('75', 28, 0, 1, 55028) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 29
('75', 28, 1, 2, 55071) should have faith that the method will answer the purpose intended.
('75', 28, 1, 3, 55139) Although schemes for industrialization of the country might be put forth, the goal that the Congress has set before it today is not industrialization of the country.
('75', 28, 1, 4, 55305) Its goal is, according to a resolution 1
('75', 28, 2, 5, 55346) passed by the National Congress at Bombay, revival of village industries.
('75', 28, 2, 6, 55420) You cannot have mass awakening through any elaborate scheme of industrialization that you may put before the kisans.
('75', 28, 2, 7, 55537) It would not add a farthing to their income.
('75', 28, 2, 8, 55582) But the A. I. S. A. and A. I. V. I. A. will put lakhs into their pockets within the course of a year.
('75', 28, 2, 9, 55684) Whatever happens to the Working Committee or the ministries, personally I do not sense any danger to the constructive activities of the Congress.
('75', 28, 2, 10, 55830) Although started by the Congress, they have been having an autonomous existence for a long time, and have fully proved their worth.
('75', 28, 2, 11, 55962) Basic education is an offshoot of these.
('75', 28, 2, 12, 56003) Education Ministers may change but this will remain.
('75', 28, 2, 13, 56056) Therefore, those interested in basic education should not worry themselves about Congress politics.
('75', 28, 2, 14, 56156) The new scheme of education will live or die by its own merits or want of them.
('75', 28, 2, 15, 56236) But these questions do not satisfy me.
('75', 28, 2, 16, 56275) They are not directly connected with the scheme of basic education.
('75', 28, 2, 17, 56343) They do not take us any further.
('75', 28, 2, 18, 56376) I would like you to ask me questions directly pertaining to the scheme, so that I may give you my expert advice.
('75', 28, 3, 19, 56489) Before going to the meeting, a friend had asked him if the central idea behind the scheme was that teachers should not speak a word to the pupils that could not be correlated to the takli.
('75', 28, 3, 20, 56678) Gandhiji, answering this question in the general meeting, remarked: This is a libel on me.
('75', 28, 3, 21, 56769) It is true I have said that all instruction must be linked with some basic craft.
('75', 28, 3, 22, 56851) When you are imparting knowledge to a child of 7 or 10 through the medium of an industry, you should, to begin with, exclude all those subjects which cannot be linked with the craft.
('75', 28, 3, 23, 57034) By doing so from day to day you will discover ways and means of linking with the craft many things which you had excluded in the beginning.
('75', 28, 3, 24, 57174) You will save your own energy and the pupils’ if you follow this process of exclusion to begin with.
('75', 28, 3, 25, 57275) We have today no books to go by, no precedents to guide us.
('75', 28, 3, 26, 57335) Therefore we have to go slow.
('75', 28, 3, 27, 57365) The main thing is that the teacher should retain his
('75', 28, 4, 28, 57418) 1Vide “Notes”, sub title “Hindustani Only”
('75', 29, 0, 1, 57461) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 29, 1, 2, 57502) freshness of mind.
('75', 29, 1, 3, 57521) If you come across something that you cannot correlate with the craft, do not fret over it and get disheartened.
('75', 29, 1, 4, 57634) Leave it and go ahead with the subjects that you can correlate.
('75', 29, 1, 5, 57698) Maybe another teacher will hit upon the right way and show how it can be correlated.
('75', 29, 1, 6, 57783) And when you have pooled the experience of many, you will have books to guide you, so that the work of those who follow you will become easier.
('75', 29, 1, 7, 57927) How long, you will ask, are we to go on with this process of exclusion?
('75', 29, 1, 8, 57999) My reply is, for the whole lifetime.
('75', 29, 1, 9, 58036) At the end you will find that you have included many things that you had excluded at first, that practically all that was worth including has been included, and whatever you have been obliged to exclude till the end was something very superficial that deserved exclusion.
('75', 29, 1, 10, 58308) This has been my experience of life.
('75', 29, 1, 11, 58345) I would not have been able to do many things that I have done if I had not excluded an equal number.
('75', 29, 1, 12, 58446) Our education has got to be revolutionized.
('75', 29, 1, 13, 58490) The brain must be educated through the hand.
('75', 29, 1, 14, 58535) If I were a poet, I could write poetry on the possibilities of the five fingers.
('75', 29, 1, 15, 58616) Why should you think that the mind is everything and the hands and feet nothing?
('75', 29, 1, 16, 58697) Those who do not train their hands, who go through the ordinary rut of education, lack ‘music’ in their life.
('75', 29, 1, 17, 58807) All their faculties are not trained.
('75', 29, 1, 18, 58844) Mere book knowledge does not interest the child so as to hold his attention fully.
('75', 29, 1, 19, 58927) The brain gets weary of mere words, and the child’s mind begins to wander.
('75', 29, 1, 20, 59002) The hand does the things it ought not to do, the eye sees the things it ought not to see, the ear hears the things it ought not to hear, and they do not do, see, or hear, respectively, what they ought to.
('75', 29, 1, 21, 59207) They are not taught to make the right choice and so their education often proves their ruin.
('75', 29, 1, 22, 59300) An education which does not teach us to discriminate between good and bad, to assimilate the one and eschew the other is a misnomer.
('75', 29, 2, 23, 59433) Shrimati Asha Devi asked Gandhiji to explain to them how the mind could be trained through the hands.
('75', 29, 3, 24, 59535) G. The old idea was to add a handicraft to the ordinary curriculum of education followed in the schools.
('75', 29, 3, 25, 59640) That is to say, the craft was to be taken in hand wholly separately from education.
('75', 29, 3, 26, 59724) To me that seems a fatal mistake.
('75', 29, 3, 27, 59758) The teacher must learn the craft and correlate his knowledge to the craft, so that he will impart all that knowledge to his pupils through the medium of the particular craft that he chooses.
('75', 30, 0, 1, 59949) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 31
('75', 30, 1, 2, 59992) Take the instance of spinning.
('75', 30, 1, 3, 60023) Unless I know arithmetic I cannot report how many yards of yarn I have produced on the takli, or how many standard rounds it will make, or what is the count of the yarn that I have spun.
('75', 30, 1, 4, 60210) I must learn figures to be able to do so, and I also must learn addition and subtraction and multiplication and division.
('75', 30, 1, 5, 60332) In dealing with complicated sums I shall have to use symbols and so I get my algebra.
('75', 30, 1, 6, 60418) Even here, I would insist on the use of Hindustani letters instead of Roman.
('75', 30, 1, 7, 60495) Take geometry next.
('75', 30, 1, 8, 60515) What can be a better demonstration of a circle than the disc of the takli?
('75', 30, 1, 9, 60590) I can teach all about circles in this way, without even mentioning the name of Euclid.
('75', 30, 1, 10, 60677) Again, you may ask how I can teach my child geography and history through spinning.
('75', 30, 1, 11, 60761) Some time ago I came across a book called Cotton—The Story of Mankind.
('75', 30, 1, 12, 60832) It thrilled me.
('75', 30, 1, 13, 60848) It read like a romance.
('75', 30, 1, 14, 60872) It began with the history of ancient times, how and when cotton was first grown, the stages of its development, the cotton trade between the different countries, and so on.
('75', 30, 1, 15, 61045) As I mention the different countries to the child, I shall naturally tell him something about the history and geography of these countries.
('75', 30, 1, 16, 61185) Under whose reign the different commercial treaties were signed during the different periods?
('75', 30, 1, 17, 61279) Why has cotton to be imported by some countries and cloth by others?
('75', 30, 1, 18, 61348) Why can every country not grow the cotton it requires?
('75', 30, 1, 19, 61403) That will lead me into economics and elements of agriculture.
('75', 30, 1, 20, 61465) I shall teach him to know the different varieties of cotton, in what kind of soil they grow, how to grow them, from where to get them, and so on.
('75', 30, 1, 21, 61611) Thus takli spinning leads me into the whole history of the East India Company, what brought them here, how they destroyed our spinning industry, how the economic motive that brought them to India led them later to entertain political aspirations, how it became a causative factor in the downfall of the Moguls and the Marathas, in the establishment of the English Raj, and then again in the awakening of the masses in our times.
('75', 30, 1, 22, 62040) There is thus no end to the educative possibilities of this new scheme.
('75', 30, 1, 23, 62112) And how much quicker the child will learn all that, without putting an unnecessary tax on his mind and memory.
('75', 30, 1, 24, 62223) Let me further elaborate the idea.
('75', 30, 1, 25, 62258) .Just as a biologist, in order to become a good biologist, must learn many other sciences besides biology, the basic education, if it is treated as a science, takes us into interminable channels of learning.
('75', 30, 1, 26, 62466) To extend the example of the takli, a pupil teacher, who rivets his attention not merely on the mechanical
('75', 31, 0, 1, 62573) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 31, 1, 2, 62614) process of spinning, which of course he must master, but on the spirit of the thing, will concentrate on the takli and its various aspects.
('75', 31, 1, 3, 62754) He will ask himself why the takli is made out of a brass disc and has a steel spindle.
('75', 31, 1, 4, 62841) The original takli had its disc made anyhow.
('75', 31, 1, 5, 62886) The still more primitive takli consisted of a wooden spindle with a disc of slate or clay.
('75', 31, 1, 6, 62977) The takli has been developed scientifically, and there is a reason for making the disc out of brass and the spindle out of steel.
('75', 31, 1, 7, 63107) He must find out that reason.
('75', 31, 1, 8, 63137) Then, the teacher must ask himself why the disc has that particular diameter, no more and no less.
('75', 31, 1, 9, 63236) When he has solved these questions satisfactorily and has gone into the mathematics of the thing, your pupil becomes a good engineer.
('75', 31, 1, 10, 63370) The takli becomes his Kamadhenu—the ‘Cow of plenty’.
('75', 31, 1, 11, 63423) There is no limit to the possibilities of knowledge that can be imparted through this medium.
('75', 31, 1, 12, 63517) It will be limited only by the energy and conviction with which you work.
('75', 31, 1, 13, 63591) You have been here for three weeks.
('75', 31, 1, 14, 63627) You will have spent them usefully if it has enabled you to take to this scheme seriously, so that you will say to yourself, ‘I shall either do or die.’ I am elaborating the instance of spinning because I know it.
('75', 31, 1, 15, 63840) If I were a carpenter, I would teach my child all these things through carpentry, or through cardboard work if I were a worker in cardboard.
('75', 31, 1, 16, 63981) What we need is educationists with originality, fired with true zeal, who will think out from day to day what they are going to teach their pupils.
('75', 31, 1, 17, 64129) The teacher cannot get this knowledge through musty volumes.
('75', 31, 1, 18, 64190) He has to use his own faculties of observation and thinking and impart his knowledge to the children through his lips, with the help of a craft.
('75', 31, 1, 19, 64335) This means a revolution in the method of teaching, a revolution in the teacher’s outlook.
('75', 31, 1, 20, 64425) Up till now you have been guided by inspectors’ reports.
('75', 31, 1, 21, 64482) You wanted to do what the inspector might like, so that you might get more money yet for your institutions or higher salaries for yourselves.
('75', 31, 1, 22, 64624) But the new teacher will not care for all that.
('75', 31, 1, 23, 64672) He will say, ‘I have done my duty by my pupil if I have made him a better man and in doing so I have used all my resources.
('75', 31, 1, 24, 64796) That is enough for me.
('75', 31, 2, 25, 64819) Q. In training pupil teachers, would it not be better if they are first taught a craft separately and then given a sound exposition of the method of teaching through the medium of that craft?
('75', 31, 2, 26, 65011) As it is, they are advised to imagine themselves to be of the age of 7 and relearn everything through a craft.
('75', 31, 2, 27, 65122) In this way it will take them years before they can master the new technique and become competent teachers.
('75', 31, 3, 28, 65230) G. No, it would not take them years.
('75', 31, 3, 29, 65267) Let us imagine that the
('75', 32, 0, 1, 65291) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 33
('75', 32, 1, 2, 65334) teacher when he comes to me has a working knowledge of mathematics and history and other subjects.
('75', 32, 1, 3, 65433) I teach him to make cardboard boxes or to spin.
('75', 32, 1, 4, 65481) While he is at it I show him how he could have derived his knowledge of mathematics, history and geography through the particular craft.
('75', 32, 1, 5, 65618) He thus learns how to link his knowledge to the craft.
('75', 32, 1, 6, 65673) It should not take him long to do so.
('75', 32, 1, 7, 65711) Take another instance.
('75', 32, 1, 8, 65734) Suppose I go with my boy of 7 to a basic school.
('75', 32, 1, 9, 65783) We both learn spinning and I get all my previous knowledge linked with spinning.
('75', 32, 1, 10, 65864) To the boy it is all new.

('75', 32, 2, 14, 66230) Q. A boy who has passed his matriculation can go to college if he wishes to.

('75', 32, 3, 17, 66586) He would not feel helpless when he goes to college as matriculates often do.
('75', 32, 4, 18, 66663) Q. Seven has been put down as the minimum age for admission of children to a basic education school.
('75', 32, 4, 19, 66764) Is it to be a chronological or mental age?
('75', 32, 5, 20, 66807) G. Seven should be the average minimum age, but there will be some children of a higher and some of a lower age as well.
('75', 32, 5, 21, 66928) There is physical as well as mental age to be considered.
('75', 32, 5, 22, 66986) One child at the age of 7 may have attained sufficient physical development to handle a craft.
('75', 32, 5, 23, 67081) Another one may not be able to do so even at 7. One cannot therefore lay down any hard and fast rules.
('75', 32, 5, 24, 67184) All the factors have to be taken into consideration.
('75', 32, 5, 25, 67237) Many questions show that many of you are filled with doubts.
('75', 32, 5, 26, 67298) This is the wrong way of going about the work.
('75', 32, 5, 27, 67345) You should have robust faith.
('75', 32, 5, 28, 67375) If you have the conviction that I have, that Wardha education is the thing required to give training for life to millions of our children, your work will flourish.
('75', 32, 5, 29, 67539) If you have not that faith, there is something wrong with those in charge of your training.
('75', 32, 5, 30, 67631) They should be able to imbue you with this faith, whatever else they may or may not give you.

('75', 33, 1, 2, 67766) Q. The basic education scheme is supposed to be for the villages.
('75', 33, 1, 3, 67832) Is there no way out for the city dwellers?

('75', 33, 6, 24, 69445) The boy under the scheme of basic education does not go to school merely to learn a craft.

('75', 33, 6, 27, 69815) The latter when he goes to a banking school will be ill at ease because all his faculties will not have been trained.

('75', 33, 6, 29, 69954) I will have done a good day’s work if I have made you realize this one central fact that the new education scheme is not a little of literary education and a little of craft.
('75', 33, 6, 30, 70129) It is full education up to the primary stage through the medium of a craft.
('75', 33, 7, 31, 70205) Q. Would it not be better to teach more than one craft in every school?
('75', 33, 7, 32, 70277) The children might begin to feel bored of doing the same thing from month to month and year to year.
('75', 34, 0, 1, 70378) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 35
('75', 34, 1, 2, 70421) G. If I find a teacher who becomes dull to his students after a month’s spinning, I should dismiss him.
('75', 34, 1, 3, 70525) There will be newness in every lesson such as there can be new music on the same instrument.
('75', 34, 1, 4, 70618) By changing over from one craft to another a child tends to become like a monkey jumping from branch to branch with abode nowhere.

('75', 36, 10, 31, 74095) I understand that some of the tribes in Assam are being taught to read and write through the Roman script instead of Devanagari.

('75', 37, 3, 25, 76399) Harijan, 11 2 1939
('75', 37, 4, 26, 76418) 37. NO APOLOGY
('75', 37, 5, 27, 76433) I have two letters from Jewish friends protesting against a remark of mine in a dialogue reported in Harijan over the Jewish question.
('75', 37, 5, 28, 76568) Here is one of the letters:
('75', 38, 0, 1, 76596) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 39
('75', 38, 1, 2, 76639) My attention has been called to a paragraph 1 in Harijan of December 24th, 1938, in which you are reported to have said that “The Jews called down upon the Germans the curses of mankind, and they wanted America and England to fight Germany on their behalf.” I can hardly doubt that you have been misreported, for there is nothing that could possibly justify such a statement.
('75', 38, 1, 3, 77015) But as the paragraph muchdistressed me, I should be glad to receive from you a word of reassurance I am sorry to say that I cannot give the reassurance required.
('75', 38, 1, 4, 77177) For I did make the remark put into my mouth by Shri Pyarelal.
('75', 38, 1, 5, 77239) Hardly a paper comes to me from the West which does not describe the agony of the Jews who demand retribution by the democratic Powers for German atrocities.
('75', 38, 1, 6, 77397) Nor do I see anything wrong in the attitude.
('75', 38, 1, 7, 77442) The Jews are not angels.
('75', 38, 1, 8, 77467) My point was they were not non violent in the sense meant by me.
('75', 38, 1, 9, 77532) Their non violence had and has no love in it.
('75', 38, 1, 10, 77578) It is passive.
('75', 38, 1, 11, 77593) They do not resist because they know that they cannot resist with any degree of success.
('75', 38, 1, 12, 77682) In their place, unless there were active non violence in me, I should certainly call down upon my persecutors the curses of Heaven.

('75', 42, 5, 12, 84154) 44. INTERVIEW TO SOUTH AFRICAN INDIAN STUDENTS 2
('75', 42, 6, 13, 84203) BARDOLI, [Before February 6, 1939] 3
('75', 42, 7, 14, 84240) “What should we, South Africa borns, do to preserve our Indian culture in our country of adoption?” they asked Gandhiji.
('75', 42, 7, 15, 84361) “What other languages would you ask us to learn besides English ?”
('75', 42, 8, 16, 84428) Gandhiji answered by first twitting them for giving the first place to English.
('75', 42, 8, 17, 84508) He advised them instead to learn Hindustani, which should contain all words of Sanskritic as well as Persian or Arabic origin, that are used by the man in the street.
('75', 42, 8, 18, 84675) The Hindus dared not neglect the study of Sanskrit, nor the Muslims of Arabic, not only because the study of these languages was necessary to give them access to their scriptures in the original, but also because these two tongues contained the grandest poetry that the world has ever produced.
('75', 42, 8, 19, 84970) He concluded: But above all you should jealously retain the essential simplicity and spirituality which is the hallmark of Indian culture.
('75', 42, 9, 20, 85109) Their other question was whether they should carry on the struggle for their rights in South Africa through satyagraha or through constitutional agitation.
('75', 42, 10, 21, 85265) 1 The note is written on the back of a telegram from Damodar to Bachhraj, Wardha, dated 5 2 1939. 2 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “A World in Agony II”, 6 2 1939. The students were in India to pursue medical studies and wanted Gandhiji to help them gain admission in medical college.

('75', 43, 1, 3, 85703) I am hoping that some day from among Indian youths born in South Africa a person will arise who will stand up for the rights of his countrymen domiciled there, and make the vindication of those rights his life’s mission.
('75', 43, 1, 4, 85924) He will be so pure, so cultured, so truthful and so dignified in his bearing that he will disarm all opposition.

('75', 43, 3, 9, 86674) 45. MAHATMA’S STATUE 1
('75', 43, 4, 10, 86697) Correspondence has been pouring in upon me protesting against the Mahatma’s statue said to be in course of construction on the Congress ground at a cost of Rs. 25,000. I know nothing of this statue.
('75', 43, 4, 11, 86896) I have enquired about it.
('75', 43, 4, 12, 86922) But I must not wait for confirmation.
('75', 43, 4, 13, 86960) Assuming that such a statue is in course of construction, I reinforce the protest of my correspondents and I agree with them that it will be waste of good money to spend Rs. 25,000 on erecting a clay or metallic statue of the figure of a man who is himself made of clay and is more fragile than a bangle which can keep by preservation for a thousand years, whereas the human body disintegrates daily and undergoes final disintegration after the usual span of life.
('75', 43, 4, 14, 87425) I have learnt from my Muslim friends, among whom I have passed the best part of my life, my dislike of statues and photographs of my figure.
('75', 43, 4, 15, 87566) And I should like the Reception Committee, if the report is true, to desist from the unfortunate enterprise.
('75', 43, 4, 16, 87675) Let them save what money they can.
('75', 43, 4, 17, 87710) If it is a mere rumour, let these lines serve as a warning to those who want to honour me by erecting statues and having portraits of my figure, that I heartily dislike these exhibitions.
('75', 43, 4, 18, 87898) I shall deem it ample

('75', 44, 3, 5, 88315) 46. WHY KASTURBA GANDHI?
('75', 44, 4, 6, 88340) I had not intended to say anything about my wife having joined the Rajkot struggle.
('75', 44, 4, 7, 88424) But some cruel criticism I have seen about her intervention prompts an explanation.
('75', 44, 4, 8, 88508) It had never occurred to me that she should join it.
('75', 44, 4, 9, 88561) For one thing she is too old for such hardships as are involved in being in civil disobedience struggles.
('75', 44, 4, 10, 88667) But strange as it may appear to critics, they must believe me when I say that though she is illiterate, she is and has been for years absolutely free to do what she likes.
('75', 44, 4, 11, 88839) When she joined the struggle in South Africa or in India, it was of her own inner prompting.
('75', 44, 4, 12, 88932) And so it was this time.
('75', 44, 4, 13, 88957) When she heard of Manibehn’s arrest, she could not restrain herself and asked me to let her go.
('75', 44, 4, 14, 89053) I said she was too weak.
('75', 44, 4, 15, 89078) She had just then fainted in her bathroom in Delhi and might have died but for Devdas’s presence of mind.
('75', 44, 4, 16, 89184) She said she did not mind.
('75', 44, 4, 17, 89211) I then referred her to Sardar.
('75', 44, 4, 18, 89242) He would not hear of it either.
('75', 44, 4, 19, 89274) But this time he melted.
('75', 44, 4, 20, 89299) He had seen my grief over the breach of faith by the Thakore Saheb induced by the Resident.
('75', 44, 4, 21, 89391) The reader must realize my ancestral connection with Rajkot and the intimate personal relations I had with the present Ruler’s father.
('75', 44, 4, 22, 89526) Kasturba is a daughter of Rajkot.
('75', 44, 4, 23, 89560) She felt a personal call.
('75', 44, 4, 24, 89586) She could not sit still whilst the other daughters of Rajkot were suffering for the freedom of the men and women of the State.
('75', 44, 4, 25, 89713) Rajkot is no doubt an insignificant place on the map of India.
('75', 44, 4, 26, 89776) But it is not insignificant for me and my wife.
('75', 44, 4, 27, 89824) As a child she was brought up in Rajkot though born in Porbandar.
('75', 44, 4, 28, 89890) And, after all, neither she nor I can be unconcerned in a struggle which is based on non violence and in which so many reliable co workers are involved.
('75', 44, 4, 29, 90043) The success of the struggle in Rajkot will be a stage forward in the fight for freedom.
('75', 44, 4, 30, 90131) And when it ends in success, as it must sooner

('75', 45, 2, 5, 90490) Harijan, 11 2 1939
('75', 45, 3, 6, 90509) 47. WORKING OF NON VIOLENCE
('75', 45, 4, 7, 90537) I have been very much interested in reading the recent numbers of Harijan and your observations on the European crisis and the N. W. F. Province.
('75', 45, 4, 8, 90683) But there is one aspect of the non violence problem, which I should have discussed with you at Segaon 1 if there had been time, to which you seldom or never refer.
('75', 45, 4, 9, 90847) You say that non violent non co operation, as you have developed it, is the answer to the violence which is now threatening the whole world with ruin.
('75', 45, 4, 10, 90998) There is no doubt as to the immense effect such spirit and action could produce.
('75', 45, 4, 11, 91079) But must not the non violent spirit of selfless love for all, enemies and friends alike, express itself, if it is to succeed, in a liberal, democratic and constitutional form of government?
('75', 45, 4, 12, 91269) Society cannot exist without law and government.
('75', 45, 4, 13, 91318) International peace cannot exist unless the nations accept a system of constitutional government which will give them unity and law and end anarchy among them.
('75', 45, 4, 14, 91478) No doubt some day the law of God will be so “written on the hearts and minds” of men that they become individually the expression of it, and will need no human law or government, But that is the end.
('75', 45, 4, 15, 91678) The beginning of progress towards that heavenly goal must take the form at first of a willingness among races, religions and nations to unite under a single constitution, through which their unity and membership one of another is established, the laws under which they live are promulgated after public discussion and by some form of majority decision and are enforced, where it is not voluntarily obeyed, not by war but by police force, where persuasion and example have not sufficed.
('75', 45, 4, 16, 92164) As between sovereign nations the operation of a constructive non violence spirit must lead to some form of federation.
('75', 45, 4, 17, 92283) It cannot succeed until it has done so.
('75', 45, 4, 18, 92323) The proof that it exists effectively will be the appearance of a federal system.
('75', 45, 4, 19, 92404) Thus the only real solution for the European problem is the federation of its 25 peoples and nations under a single democratic constitution which will create a government which can look at and legislate for the problems of Europe, not as a set of rival and conflicting nations but as a single whole with autonomous parts.
('75', 45, 5, 20, 92726) 1 Lord Lothian was at Segaon from January 18 to 20, 1938; vide “Discussion with Lord Lothain”, 20 1 1938
('75', 46, 0, 1, 92831) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 47
('75', 46, 1, 2, 92874) same way the only solution to the Indian problem is the substitution of a democratic constitution for the control of Great Britain.
('75', 46, 1, 3, 93006) And what is true for Europe and India is true, in the long run, for the whole world and is the only final method of ending war.
('75', 46, 2, 4, 93134) Non violent non co operation may be the best, perhaps the only, method of bringing about the change of mind and heart which will make acceptance of a federal democratic constitution by the nation possible.
('75', 46, 2, 5, 93340) But attainment to democratic federation is the necessary attainment whereby its success is assured and without which it cannot succeed.
('75', 46, 2, 6, 93476) It is always a matter of interest and indeed of surprise to me that you appear to think that non violent non co operation is enough in itself, and that you never proclaim that a democratic system of government unifying men, races, religions and nations is the goal to which it must lead, though that attainment is only possible as the result of a spiritual change of heart and cannot be reached by force or violence or chicanery.
('75', 46, 3, 7, 93906) I do not write this as a kind of indirect argument for the Indian constitution, though it obviously has a bearing on that problem also.
('75', 46, 3, 8, 94042) The Government of India Act is clearly a very imperfect application of the principle of democratic federation and must necessarily evolve rapidly if it is to work.
('75', 46, 3, 9, 94206) The main argument I have always urged for it is that in present conditions it represents the only constitutional compromise uniting Provinces, States, Muslims and Hindus which can be made to work and that it has far more seeds of evolution within it than is generally recognized.
('75', 46, 3, 10, 94486) If your spiritual gospel informed the people, it would rapidly and easily evolve.
('75', 46, 3, 11, 94568) My object is not to elicit any opinion from you about the constitutional problem but an answer to the larger question set forth in the early part of the letter.
('75', 46, 3, 12, 94729) Thus writes Lord Lothian.
('75', 46, 3, 13, 94755) The letter was received early in January, but urgent matters prevented my dealing earlier with the important question raised in it.
('75', 46, 3, 14, 94887) I have purposely refrained from dealing with the nature of government in a society based deliberately on non violence.
('75', 46, 3, 15, 95006) All society is held together by non violence, even as the earth is held in her position by gravitation.
('75', 46, 3, 16, 95110) But when the law of gravitation was discovered the discovery yielded results of which our ancestors had no knowledge.
('75', 46, 3, 17, 95228) Even so when society is deliberately constructed in accordance with the law of non violence, its structure will be different in material particulars from what it is today.
('75', 46, 3, 18, 95400) But I cannot say in adva nce what the government based wholly on non violence will be like.
('75', 46, 3, 19, 95492) What is happening today is disregard of the law of non violence
('75', 47, 0, 1, 95556) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 47, 1, 2, 95597) and enthronement of violence as if it were an eternal law.
('75', 47, 1, 3, 95656) The democracies, therefore, that we see at work in England, America and France are only so called, because they are no less based on violence than Nazi Germany, Fascist Italy or even Soviet Russia.
('75', 47, 1, 4, 95854) The only difference is that the violence of the last three is much better organized than that of the three democratic powers.
('75', 47, 1, 5, 95980) Nevertheless we see today a mad race for outdoing one another in the matter of armaments.
('75', 47, 1, 6, 96070) And if when the clash comes, as it is bound to come one day, the democracies win, they will do so only because they will have the backing of their peoples who imagine that they have a voice in their own government whereas in the other three cases the peoples might rebel against their own dictatorships.
('75', 47, 1, 7, 96374) Holding the view that without the recognition of non violence on a national scale there is no such thing as a constitutional or democratic government, I devote my energy to the propagation of non violence as the law of our life—individual, social, political, national and international.
('75', 47, 1, 8, 96661) I fancy that I have seen the light, though dimly.
('75', 47, 1, 9, 96711) I write cautiously, for I do not profess to know the whole of the Law.
('75', 47, 1, 10, 96782) If I know the successes of my experiments, I know also my failures.
('75', 47, 1, 11, 96850) But the successes are enough to fill me with undying hope.
('75', 47, 1, 12, 96909) I have often said that if one takes care of the means, the end will take care of itself.
('75', 47, 1, 13, 96998) Non violence is the means, the end for every nation is complete independence.
('75', 47, 1, 14, 97076) There will be an international League only when all the nations, big or small, composing it are fully independent.
('75', 47, 1, 15, 97191) The nature of that independence will correspond to the extent of non violence assimilated by the nations concerned.
('75', 47, 1, 16, 97307) One thing is certain.
('75', 47, 1, 17, 97329) In a society based on non violence, the smallest nation will feel as tall as the tallest.
('75', 47, 1, 18, 97419) The idea of superiority and inferiority will be wholly obliterated.
('75', 47, 1, 19, 97487) It follows from this that the Government of India Act is merely a makeshift and has to give way to an Act coined by the nation itself.
('75', 47, 1, 20, 97622) So far as Provincial Autonomy is concerned, it has been found possible to handle it somewhat.
('75', 47, 1, 21, 97716) My own experience of its working is by no means happy.
('75', 47, 1, 22, 97771) The Congress Governments have not that non violent hold over the people that I had expected they would have.
('75', 47, 1, 23, 97880) But the Federal structure is inconceivable to me because it contemplates a partnership, however loose, among dissimilars.
('75', 47, 1, 24, 98002) How dissimilar the States are is being demonstrated in an ugliness for which I was unprepared.
('75', 47, 1, 25, 98097) Therefore the Federal structure, as conceived by the
('75', 48, 0, 1, 98150) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 49
('75', 48, 1, 2, 98193) Government of India Act, I hold to be an utter impossibility.

('75', 54, 10, 25, 106044) 63. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 54, 11, 26, 106073) WARDHA, February 8, 1939
('75', 54, 12, 27, 106098) The following telephone report 2 has been received about Seth
('75', 54, 13, 28, 106160) 1 The statement was also published in The Hindu and The Bombay Chronicle of February 9 and in a slightly modified form in Harijan of February 11 under the heading “Barbarous Behaviour”.
('75', 54, 13, 29, 106346) It turned out, however, that the report used by Gandhiji in the statement was not wholly accurate; vide “Statement to the Press”, 12 2 1939 2 The report was in Hindi, which Gandhiji translated; vide “Statement to the Press”,12 2 1939
('75', 55, 0, 1, 106580) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 55, 1, 2, 106621) Jamnalalji who, when he was arrested a second time, was accompanied by his son, his secretary and a servant: Seth Jamnalalji was detained at Ajmer Road station, 50 miles from Jaipur, and kept in the dak bungalow there.
('75', 55, 1, 3, 106840) Mr. Young went to Sethji in person and asked him to enter his car.
('75', 55, 1, 4, 106907) Sethji declined saying, “You wish to put me out side the border of Jaipur State.
('75', 55, 1, 5, 106988) I wish to enter Jaipur.
('75', 55, 1, 6, 107012) I will not accompany you.” Mr. Young thereupon said, “We are taking you to Jaipur.
('75', 55, 1, 7, 107095) Come with us.” Sethji replied, “I cannot rely on your word.” Mr. Young then said, “I have orders.
('75', 55, 1, 8, 107193) You will have to come with me.” Sethji asked to be shown the order, but it appears that there was no order in Mr. Young’s possession.
('75', 55, 1, 9, 107327) At length, Mr. Young again told Sethji that he would be taken to Jaipur.
('75', 55, 1, 10, 107400) “If we do not take you there, you can have it printed in the newspapers that after promising to take you to Jaipur, we took you elsewhere.” Sethji was not inclined to believe anything that was said to him.
('75', 55, 1, 11, 107606) He said, “I will not accompany you willingly.
('75', 55, 1, 12, 107652) You can take me by force, if you so desire.” This conversation took nearly an hour.
('75', 55, 1, 13, 107736) In the end, five men forcibly put Sethji in a car and took him away.
('75', 55, 1, 14, 107805) In this process of using force, Sethji was injured on his left cheek below the eye.
('75', 55, 1, 15, 107889) He was taken to Alwar State.
('75', 55, 1, 16, 107918) Sethji here said, “You cannot act like this.
('75', 55, 1, 17, 107963) You are not at liberty to deposit me in another State.
('75', 55, 1, 18, 108018) If you do so I will run a case against you.” On this Mr. Young brought Sethji back again into Jaipur State.
('75', 55, 1, 19, 108126) But we do not know his present whereabouts.
('75', 55, 1, 20, 108170) The only remark I have to offer is that this is barbarous behaviour.
('75', 55, 1, 21, 108239) The sacredness of person, legal procedure and liberty are thrown to the winds.
('75', 55, 1, 22, 108318) That a British Inspector General of Police should resort to deception and then to personal injury to one who was his prisoner is what I call organized goondaism.
('75', 55, 1, 23, 108480) But I know that nothing will break Jamnalalji’s spirit.
('75', 55, 1, 24, 108536) He will enter Jaipur either as a free man or prisoner.
('75', 55, 2, 25, 108591) The Hindustan Times, 9 2 1939

('75', 57, 9, 19, 110281) 69. LETTER TO SHARDABEHN G. CHOKHAWALA
('75', 57, 10, 20, 110320) SEGAON, WARDHA, February 9, 1939
('75', 57, 11, 21, 110353) BABUDI, Marriage is a sacrament.
('75', 57, 11, 22, 110386) It should, therefore, lead not to indulgence but to restraint.
('75', 57, 11, 23, 110449) We have four stages of life.
('75', 57, 12, 24, 110478) 1 Vijayalakshmi Pandit 2 The addressee had wanted to meet Gandhiji to discuss the affairs of the Princely States in Orissa.
('75', 58, 0, 1, 110602) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 59
('75', 58, 1, 2, 110645) Grihasthashrama 1 is the second stage.
('75', 58, 1, 3, 110684) In family life enjoyment has no place but service has an important place.
('75', 58, 1, 4, 110758) Service and begetting of progeny cannot go hand in hand.
('75', 58, 1, 5, 110815) Progeny, however, has a place in married life.
('75', 58, 1, 6, 110862) If there is an intense desire for progeny sexual union is permitted.
('75', 58, 1, 7, 110931) This union should result from deliberation, not passion.
('75', 58, 1, 8, 110988) If this principle is accepted, husband and wife should not share the same bed.
('75', 58, 1, 9, 111067) There should be no love play.
('75', 58, 1, 10, 111097) Nothing should be done which would turn their minds to the sexual act.
('75', 58, 1, 11, 111168) In these days it is a difficult dharma.
('75', 58, 1, 12, 111208) May God grant you both the strength to perform it.
('75', 58, 2, 13, 111259) Blessings from BAPU
