('75', 59, 4, 33, 113564) 72. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 3
('75', 59, 5, 34, 113593) WARDHA, February 9, 1939
('75', 59, 6, 35, 113618) Critics of my recent writings on Rajkot and Jaipur have accused me of being guilty of untruth and violence.
('75', 59, 6, 36, 113726) I owe them an answer.
('75', 59, 6, 37, 113748) Such accusations have been made against me before now, indeed since
('75', 59, 7, 38, 113816) 1 Sir J. G. Laithwaite, Private Secretary to the Viceroy 2 Vide “Letter to the Press”, 9 2 1939 3 This was also published in The Bombay Chronicle and The Hindu of February 10 and in Harijan of February 18 under the heading “Not Guilty”.
('75', 60, 0, 1, 114053) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 61
('75', 60, 1, 2, 114096) my entry into public life.
('75', 60, 1, 3, 114123) I am happy to be able to say that most of my critics have later been obliged to acknowledge that I had not been guilty of either untruthful or violent language and that my statements were based on my belief in them and made without malice.
('75', 60, 1, 4, 114363) Even so is the case in the present instance.
('75', 60, 1, 5, 114408) I am fully aware of my responsibility.
('75', 60, 1, 6, 114447) I know that many of my countrymen put implicit faith in my statements.
('75', 60, 1, 7, 114518) I have been asked for proofs in support of my statements I have given them.
('75', 60, 1, 8, 114594) Sardar Patel has reproduced in his statement 1 on Rajkot the remarks of the Resident reported to have been made by him about the Congress and himself.
('75', 60, 1, 9, 114745) The memorandum of the conversation between the Resident, the Thakore Saheb and councillors, including Sir Patrick Cadell, is in my possession.
('75', 60, 1, 10, 114888) It is too long to be published, but it will be, if occasion requires it.
('75', 60, 1, 11, 114961) As for organized goondaism, the facts have been published.
('75', 60, 1, 12, 115020) 2 I connect the Resident with it, because he has sent the Agency police to the State and must be held responsible for the acts of his agents.
('75', 60, 1, 13, 115162) Similarly, the British Prime Minister is responsible for every thing that is happening in Jaipur.
('75', 60, 1, 14, 115260) The making of Seth Jamnalalji a football to be kicked out of Jaipur every time he dares to exercise the right of entering his birth place is surely worse than unseemly.
('75', 60, 1, 15, 115429) I am not guilty of violence of language when I correctly characterize action.
('75', 60, 1, 16, 115507) I would be guilty of violence if I harboured any ill feeling against the Kathiawar Resident or the Jaipur Prime Minister.
('75', 60, 1, 17, 115629) For ought I know, they may be most estimable men to meet, but their being estimable does not help the people of Rajkot or Jaipur.
('75', 60, 1, 18, 115759) As a votary of truth and ahimsa, my business is to state the naked truth without fear but without ill will against the wrongdoers.
('75', 60, 1, 19, 115890) My non violence does not require any gilding of a bitter pill.
('75', 60, 1, 20, 115953) I must, therefore, plead not guilty to the charge of racial animosity.
('75', 60, 1, 21, 116024) I cannot succeed in weaning people from the path of violence by hiding or dressing the naked truth; I hope to wean them by telling them and, what is more, showing by my conduct that it is not only right but profitable to wish well to the wrongdoer in spite of his wrongs, however grievous these may be.
('75', 60, 1, 22, 116327) Protection of the Princes is a duty the Paramount Power owes to
('75', 60, 2, 23, 116391) 1 Vide “Cold Blooded Breach of a Solemn Covenant” 2 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 3 2 1939
('75', 61, 0, 1, 116483) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 61, 1, 2, 116524) them, but surely it is equally its duty to protect the people living in their jurisdiction.
('75', 61, 1, 3, 116616) It seems to me that it is also their duty to withhold support from Princes when it is proved that a ruler is guilty of breach of faith with his people as in Rajkot or when it is proved that his people are denied ordinary civil liberty and one of his citizens is driven from pillar to post and practically denied access to courts of justice as in the case of Jaipur.
('75', 61, 1, 4, 116982) The more I think of what is happening in the States in India, I see nothing but a dark future for this unhappy land, if the Paramount Power remains a helpless witness to the tragedy that is being enacted in the Princes’ India.
('75', 61, 1, 5, 117209) For what is happening in Rajkot and Jaipur is but a sample of what is going to happen presently in the other States.
('75', 61, 1, 6, 117326) The Maharaja of Bikaner was right when he advised concerted action among the Princes.
('75', 61, 1, 7, 117412) 1 Only His Highness gave the wrong lead.
('75', 61, 1, 8, 117453) The doctrine of kicks and kisses will lead the Princes nowhere.
('75', 61, 1, 9, 117517) It has sown bitterness and strife.
('75', 61, 1, 10, 117552) The people of States may not be able to take concerted action as the Princes can, but the latter will not be able to treat the people from States other than their own or those from British India as foreigners.
('75', 61, 1, 11, 117762) There is sufficient awakening among the people of the States to withstand the pressure even from a concert among the Princes.
('75', 61, 2, 12, 117888) The Hindustan Times, 10 2 1939

('75', 66, 2, 3, 123397) February 11, 1939
('75', 66, 3, 4, 123415) KRISHNACHANDRA, So long as you have not acquired equimindedness it is best to observe the restraint I have suggested.

('75', 66, 6, 8, 123744) 84. HYDERABAD
('75', 66, 7, 9, 123758) Hyderabad State Congress people are getting restive.
('75', 66, 7, 10, 123811) As they have been acting under my advice some of them came to me and said, “We have suspended civil disobedience at your and other leaders’ instance.
('75', 66, 7, 11, 123961) You had held out the hope that, if we suspended civil disobedience, most probably the prisoners would be released and the State Congress recognized.
('75', 66, 7, 12, 124110) Neither the one nor the other has happened.
('75', 66, 7, 13, 124154) How long are we to remain out and vegetate while our co workers are rotting in the State jails where life is none too easy?
('75', 66, 7, 14, 124278) What will you have us do?” As these friends have to deal with a large number of colleagues I had better give a summary of my answer to them.
('75', 66, 7, 15, 124419) I said: I sympathize with you.
('75', 66, 7, 16, 124450) In your place I should feel like you.
('75', 66, 7, 17, 124488) But satyagraha is not a simple affair.
('75', 66, 7, 18, 124527) It is a way of life.
('75', 66, 7, 19, 124548) It requires discipline.
('75', 66, 7, 20, 124572) It demands infinite patience and capacity for uttermost suffering.
('75', 66, 7, 21, 124639) Civil disobedience, which is but a phase of satyagraha, has to be suspended even though colleagues may have to suffer imprisonment, hardships attendant upon jail life, and even worse.
('75', 66, 7, 22, 124823) And they have to do all this with good grace, joyfully and without malice towards those who are responsible for subjecting them to such suffering.
('75', 66, 7, 23, 124970) Remember, too, that a true satyagrahi, being outside, goes through greater mental suffering than the one who has gone behind prison bars.
('75', 66, 7, 24, 125108) The latter has done his task for the time being.
('75', 66, 7, 25, 125157) His mind is free.
('75', 66, 7, 26, 125175) He fulfils his immediate mission if he behaves like a model
('75', 67, 0, 1, 125235) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 67, 1, 2, 125276) prisoner and cheerfully submits to the sufferings he might have to go through.
('75', 67, 1, 3, 125355) Whereas the former has to bear the brunt of managing the struggle, thinking out plans, and responding to the programme as it may be given from day to day.
('75', 67, 1, 4, 125510) I have to ask you to prolong your suspension if only for the simple and decisive reason that two bodies are offering civil disobedience for purposes wholly different from yours, however worthy their purpose may be.
('75', 67, 1, 5, 125725) The Arya Samaj civil disobedience is purely religious in the sense that it is being offered for the vindication of the exercise of their religion.
('75', 67, 1, 6, 125872) The Hindu Mahasabha is, I suppose, supporting the Arya Samaj.
('75', 67, 1, 7, 125934) And, therefore, the struggle has assumed a communal colour.
('75', 67, 1, 8, 125994) If you resume civil disobedience, it will be very difficult for you to retain your nationalistic character.
('75', 67, 1, 9, 126102) You will expose yourselves to needless suspicion.
('75', 67, 1, 10, 126152) Your methods too may not be identical with theirs.
('75', 67, 1, 11, 126203) You will create an embarrassing situation without advancing your cause.
('75', 67, 1, 12, 126275) Thus the situation demands delicate handling.
('75', 67, 1, 13, 126321) It is my conviction that your restraint will largely disarm suspicion, and to that extent you will be making a definite advance towards your goal.
('75', 67, 1, 14, 126468) Meanwhile I can give you the assurance that whatever friendly offices can do is being and will continue to be done.
('75', 67, 1, 15, 126584) Having heard my argument, you will act as may seem best to you.
('75', 67, 1, 16, 126648) You must reject my advice if it does not appeal to your head and heart.
('75', 67, 1, 17, 126720) If you accept it, remember that every member will be expected to devote himself whole heartedly to the constructive programme as I have explained it to you.
('75', 67, 1, 18, 126877) SEGAON, February 12, 1939
('75', 67, 2, 19, 126903) Harijan, 18 2 1939
('75', 67, 3, 20, 126922) 85. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('75', 67, 4, 21, 126952) SEGAON, WARDHA, C. P., February 12, 1939
('75', 67, 5, 22, 126993) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, I duly received your letter of the 5th inst.
('75', 67, 5, 23, 127060) redirected from Bardoli.
('75', 67, 5, 24, 127085) I am grateful for the pains you have taken to explain your position so fully, frankly and fairly.
('75', 67, 5, 25, 127183) After much consideration I felt
('75', 68, 0, 1, 127215) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 69
('75', 68, 1, 2, 127258) that it was a duty to publish the article returned by you.
('75', 68, 1, 3, 127317) Even if Shri Chudgar has been guilty, consciously or unconsciously, of having misreported 1 Sir Beauchamp St. John, the truth could only be ascertained by publication of the correspondence.
('75', 68, 1, 4, 127507) As I have the moral conviction about the accuracy of Shri Chudgar’s report I felt that it would be wrong to withhold it from the public.
('75', 68, 1, 5, 127644) I note in passing that although I asked the Prime Minister of Jaipur, if he denied Shri Chudgar’s version, to give me his own, he would not do so.
('75', 68, 1, 6, 127791) 2 But the question of wisdom or otherwise of publishing the correspondence pales into insignificance in the presence of the tragedy that is going on in Jaipur, Rajkot and Orissa.
('75', 68, 1, 7, 127970) In spite of your letter suggesting the possibility of it being erroneous, what is happening in these places has deepened the belief expressed by me in my letter to you of the 26th ult.
('75', 68, 1, 8, 128155) If you think that by a meeting you could clear my mind of the disquiet and show me that my belief is erroneous, I would be glad to run up to Delhi even though medical friends have enjoined complete rest for some time if I am not to collapse altogether.
('75', 68, 1, 9, 128408) But I would gladly risk my health if I can be shown my error or if I could convince you that delay in action on your part is dangerous.

('75', 70, 1, 2, 130544) 89. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 70, 2, 3, 130573) WARDHA, February 12, 1939
('75', 70, 3, 4, 130599) On reading my Press statement regarding his second expulsion from Jaipur State, Seth Jamnalalji telegraphed to me as follows:
('75', 70, 4, 5, 130725) On the 9th instant I saw that your statement on my version regarding Mr. Young was incorrect owing to confusion in the telephonic message.
('75', 70, 4, 6, 130864) The correct version appeared in The Hindustan Times of the 8th and 9th.
('75', 70, 4, 7, 130936) 2 I hope you will do the needful.
('75', 70, 4, 8, 130970) I had not then seen The Hindustan Times referred to by Sethji.
('75', 70, 4, 9, 131033) I have now seen both issues and I find that I have unconsciously done injustice to Mr. Young, whom, in my Press statement, I accused of having practised deception upon Sethji.
('75', 70, 4, 10, 131209) I made the accusation on the strength of the telephone message received by his son in Wardha, of which I gave a literal translation in my statement.
('75', 70, 4, 11, 131358) Sethji’s son had no doubt whatsoever as to what he received through the telephone.
('75', 70, 4, 12, 131441) But neither his accuracy nor my faithful translation can excuse the error into which I was betrayed.
('75', 70, 4, 13, 131542) I, therefore, tender my unqualified apology to Mr. Young and I shall be extra careful henceforth in making use of telephone messages.
('75', 70, 4, 14, 131676) I see that not only was Mr. Young not guilty of any deception, but that he was careful to say that he was performing a painful duty in obedience to the orders of a superior authority.
('75', 70, 4, 15, 131860) And in the execution thereof he was as courteous and as careful as it was possible for him to be in the circumstances.
('75', 70, 4, 16, 131979) Having made these amends, I must say that The Hindustan Times report, confirmed by Sethji, shows that his ill treatment was much worse than was conveyed in the telephone message.
('75', 70, 4, 17, 132158) All that night journey in the cold of Rajputana winter was a cruel and unnecessary torture.
('75', 70, 4, 18, 132250) Even if expulsion was necessary for the preservation of peace in Jaipur, the night journey could surely have been avoided, as also the use of force.
('75', 70, 5, 19, 132399) The Hindu, 12 2 1939
('75', 70, 6, 20, 132420) 1 Published in Harijan, 18 2 1939, under the title “My Apology”; this also appeared in The Bombay Chronicle, 13 2 1939, and other newspapers.
('75', 70, 6, 21, 132562) 2 It also appeared in The Tribune, 8 2 1939, in the form of a statement by Damodar Das and showed that Young had never given any assurance to Jamnalal Bajaj that he would not be taken outside Jaipur State.
('75', 71, 0, 1, 132768) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 71, 1, 2, 132809) 90. UNTRUTH IN NEWSPAPERS
('75', 71, 2, 3, 132835) A State official writes:
('75', 71, 3, 4, 132860) I have read your several articles in the Harijan about Congress activities in general and those in the States in particular.
('75', 71, 3, 5, 132985) One 1 of these deals with corruption in the Congress ranks and at least, by implication, with other undesirable activities quite inconsistent with the spirit which you have tried to infuse into the mass of Congress workers.
('75', 71, 4, 6, 133209) It has occurred to me to draw your attention to the fact that much violence to truth and, therefore, harm to the cause you have at heart is being done by certain newspapers which live by abuse and which depend upon so called ‘Congress workers’ for the unmitigated falsehoods they publish.
('75', 71, 5, 7, 133498) So far as the States are the targets of attack, legitimate criticism which rests on incontrovertible facts must be wholesome and should be helpful.
('75', 71, 5, 8, 133646) You would, however, agree that nothing but the truth should be published.
('75', 71, 6, 9, 133720) What is happening, in fact, is that some people who nurse a sense of injury against the State to which they belonged or where they lived in the past, finding themselves driven away as a result of their activities to which the Government of the State took objection, are trying to pay off old scores and for such a purpose they imagine their position greatly fortified by their having joined the Congress fold.
('75', 71, 6, 10, 134130) The papers they feed, in their turn, live by their diatribes, while for them those papers are the needed medium for the discharge of stored up venom.
('75', 71, 6, 11, 134280) The unfortunate result is that however these vernacular papers may succeed in inflaming the uninformed public, responsible people remain unaffected by their denunciations.
('75', 71, 7, 12, 134452) It is a pity that things that may be usefully brought to light in the honest spirit of awakening the administrations of the States to their responsibilities are, for want of knowledge, never published.
('75', 71, 7, 13, 134654) What is published is either in the nature of a gross exaggeration of facts of no vital importance or, as is more often the case, some pure inventions and, therefore, an utter lie.
('75', 71, 8, 14, 134834) Your present policy seems to me to be that where the people desire to manage their own affairs, it is the duty of the Congress to help them in the attainment of that aim.
('75', 71, 8, 15, 135005) I venture to think that it is not your policy to replace the contentment of the people with discontent, in pursuit of the ideal of responsible government throughout India.
('75', 71, 9, 16, 135177) Above all, I take your policy to be to disseminate and propagate the
('75', 71, 10, 17, 135246) 1 Vide “Internal Decay”
('75', 72, 0, 1, 135270) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 73
('75', 72, 1, 2, 135313) truth, and to wage a ceaseless war against untruth.
('75', 72, 1, 3, 135365) In that belief, I venture to suggest that an article or two in the Harijan on the responsibility of newspapers that depend for what they publish upon ‘Congress workers’ and that of those workers might help to purge the Congress movement of some destructive germs and thereby make it more effective alike for the uplift of the downtrodden masses and for serving the highest cause of the country.
('75', 72, 1, 4, 135760) I have no difficulty in agreeing with the correspondent that newspapers which indulge in untruth or exaggeration harm the cause they profess to espouse.
('75', 72, 1, 5, 135913) I admit, too, that there is enough untruth in enough newspapers to warrant action.
('75', 72, 1, 6, 135996) But my experience is that no amount of public criticism will affect the policy of newspapers which make their livelihood by such policy.
('75', 72, 1, 7, 136133) I would like, however, to point out to my correspondent and others like him who are connected with States that the public must not be blamed for believing untruths if the State officials, under a false sense of security, will not deign to correct untruths or render explanations.
('75', 72, 1, 8, 136413) And sometimes when they condescend to give explanations they are more untruthful than the untruths of the newspapers.
('75', 72, 1, 9, 136531) The latest instance is that of Talcher.
('75', 72, 1, 10, 136571) The Chief denied even the truth of a telling photograph in The Statesman of the refugees and has received a well deserved snub from its Editor.
('75', 72, 1, 11, 136715) I have a Talcher bulletin sent to me by Thakkar Bapa for me to laugh or weep over.
('75', 72, 1, 12, 136798) Its denial is a shameful perversion of truth.
('75', 72, 1, 13, 136844) I am publishing in this issue startling news about Mewar.
('75', 72, 2, 14, 136902) I would like an authentic contradiction of the news or strong action against the police if they acted in disregard of instructions.
('75', 72, 2, 15, 137034) But I write this in no way to condone untruths in newspapers.
('75', 72, 2, 16, 137096) I am quite clear that if newspapers weighed every word that is printed therein, we should have a speedier removal of abuses whether in the States or elsewhere.
('75', 72, 2, 17, 137256) SEGAON, February 13, 1939
('75', 72, 3, 18, 137282) Harijan, 18 2 1939
('75', 72, 4, 19, 137301) 1Vide “Mewar”

('75', 73, 1, 2, 137356) 91. TARVANCORE
('75', 73, 2, 3, 137371) Though I have been apparently silent about Travancore, the workers may rest assured that I have not been neglectful.
('75', 73, 2, 4, 137488) Sometimes silence is more telling than speech.
('75', 73, 2, 5, 137535) All I am free to say is that I have been usefully silent.
('75', 73, 2, 6, 137593) I am sorry that all has not gone well.
('75', 73, 2, 7, 137632) I had hoped that when the State Congress withdrew the allegations against the Dewan things would run smoothly and the movement for responsible government would be allowed full play.
('75', 73, 2, 8, 137814) 1 But the bulletin 2 reproduced elsewhere shows that there is no such luck for the Travancoreans.
('75', 73, 2, 9, 137912) The unseating of 19 prominent members of the Travancore Assembly seems to be vindictive.
('75', 73, 2, 10, 138001) 3 Have they done anything dishonourable?
('75', 73, 2, 11, 138042) Not that I know of.
('75', 73, 2, 12, 138062) I have before me a letter describing the ill treatment of Shrimati Akkamma Cherian, a political prisoner.
('75', 73, 2, 13, 138168) If what she declared in court is true, her treatment was surely disgraceful.
('75', 73, 2, 14, 138245) She is a cultured woman.
('75', 73, 2, 15, 138270) She gave up the headmistress ship of a school in order to join the struggle for liberty.
('75', 73, 2, 16, 138359) It hurts one to think that in an advanced State like Travancore, which boasts of an enlightened Prince, an equally enlightened Maharani, his mother, and an experienced Dewan, liberty is being choked by rude repression.
('75', 73, 2, 17, 138578) But another letter tells me that this repression is taking place in the name of Hinduism and for the sake of saving a Hindu State !
('75', 73, 2, 18, 138710) It has been suggested that the idea is to repress the Christians who are playing a prominent part in the struggle for freedom.
('75', 73, 2, 19, 138837) It is surely late in the day to talk of Hindu States and Muslim States.
('75', 73, 2, 20, 138909) And what is the test?
('75', 73, 2, 21, 138931) Is Kashmir a Hindu State because a Hindu Prince happens to rule a territory which has an overwhelming majority of Muslims as its inhabitants?
('75', 73, 2, 22, 139073) Or is Hyderabad with its overwhelming Hindu population a Muslim State because a Muslim Prince rules their destiny?
('75', 73, 2, 23, 139188) I regard this kind of talk as a libel on nationalism.
('75', 73, 2, 24, 139242) Is India a Christian State because a Christian king rules over her destiny?
('75', 73, 2, 25, 139318) But if India is Indian no matter who rules, the States are also Indian no matter who happens to be the ruler.
('75', 73, 2, 26, 139428) And the present Rulers and their
('75', 73, 3, 27, 139461) 1Vide “Talk to Travancore State Congress Deputation”, 15 11 1938, and “Travancore” 2 “Travancore Bulletin” by G. Ramachandran 3 These members, all belonging to the State Congress, had been disqualified on the ground of their having been convicted under the Criminal Law Amendment Regulation.
('75', 74, 0, 1, 139753) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 75
('75', 74, 1, 2, 139796) successors will rule only by the grace of an awakened people.
('75', 74, 1, 3, 139858) The awakening that has taken place has come to stay.
('75', 74, 1, 4, 139911) Every day quickens the pace.
('75', 74, 1, 5, 139940) The Rulers and their advisers may succeed for the time being in suppressing the spirit of the people.
('75', 74, 1, 6, 140042) They will never succeed in killing it.
('75', 74, 1, 7, 140081) To succeed would be to kill the spirit of the people of India.
('75', 74, 1, 8, 140144) Is anyone in India so shortsighted as to feel that independence is not coming soon?
('75', 74, 1, 9, 140228) And is it possible to conceive that an independent India will for one moment tolerate repression in any single spot, be it ever so big or ever so small?
('75', 74, 1, 10, 140381) There is room, in my conception of an independent India, for States with Princes as constitutional trustees, as in Aundh.
('75', 74, 1, 11, 140503) 1 There is room for Englishmen as fellow servants of the people, never as masters.
('75', 74, 1, 12, 140586) Therefore, the only way in which the Princes can live in a free India is for them now to recognize the time spirit, bow to it and act accordingly.
('75', 74, 1, 13, 140733) Let it be the boast of the Hindu Prince, his Hindu mother and their Hindu Dewan that they were not afraid of their Christian citizens.
('75', 74, 1, 14, 140868) Supposing there was responsible government in Travancore, what could the Christians or the Hindus or the Muslims do?
('75', 74, 1, 15, 140985) Whoever the legislators, they will be responsible to the voters.
('75', 74, 1, 16, 141050) There is no room for fear, there is no hitch in the process.
('75', 74, 1, 17, 141111) But in the present repression, there is much to fear and there are many hitches.
('75', 74, 1, 18, 141192) SEGAON, February 13, 1939 Harijan, 18 2 1939
('75', 74, 2, 19, 141237) 92. THE ETHICS OF IT
('75', 74, 3, 20, 141258) A friend suggests that I have perhaps departed from correct conduct in publishing the confidential correspondence 2 between Thakore Saheb and Sir Patrick Cadell and extracts from the interview between Thakore Saheb in Council and the Resident.
('75', 74, 3, 21, 141502) I have no such feeling at all.
('75', 74, 3, 22, 141533) I claim to be very sensitive to points of honour.
('75', 74, 3, 23, 141583) My worst critics have credited me with the capacity to respect confidence and bury secrets entrusted to me.
('75', 74, 3, 24, 141691) But I have never regarded it any part of my duty to protect breaches of promises against disclosure or to cover crimes of which I have notice in due course.
('75', 74, 3, 25, 141848) I do protect confessions made to me in confidence as I did when I was asked, on pain of being punished by a court of law, to disclose the names of criminals during the unfortunate riots in Ahmedabad at the time of the Rowlatt Act agitation.
('75', 74, 3, 26, 142089) In the case in question there is no such point
('75', 74, 4, 27, 142136) 1 Vide “Notes”, sub title “Aundh Reforms” 2 Vide “Cold Blooded Breach of A Solemn Covenant”

('75', 75, 1, 2, 142269) of honour.
('75', 75, 1, 3, 142280) Regard for truth and the popular cause demanded publication of the correspondence and the extracts.
('75', 75, 1, 4, 142380) The documents were received by the Sardar in ordinary course.
('75', 75, 1, 5, 142442) They were handed by those who were in legal possession.
('75', 75, 1, 6, 142498) There was, therefore, so far as I can see nothing dishonourable about getting possession of the documents and, as I have said, nothing incorrect, much less dishono urable, about their publication.
('75', 75, 1, 7, 142695) Without such publication the popular case could not be proved.

('75', 75, 4, 10, 142803) 93. MEWAR
('75', 75, 5, 11, 142813) A correspondent sends the following business like note 1:
('75', 75, 6, 12, 142871) First incident: Date of happening: 14th December, 1938. Place of happening: A wayside bridge in the British territory of town Deoli.
('75', 75, 6, 13, 143004) Mewar territory: At a distance of about 12 yards.
('75', 75, 7, 14, 143054) Shri Mathura Prasad Vaidya, a worker of the Mewar Praja Mandal, .
('75', 75, 7, 15, 143120) while distributing Praja Mandal literature .
('75', 75, 7, 16, 143165) was all of a sudden attacked by two constables of Uncha Police in Mewar.
('75', 75, 7, 17, 143238) One of them snatched away the literature .
('75', 75, 7, 18, 143281) The other knocked him down on the ground and then both of them forcibly dragged him in a semi conscious state to the nearby territory of Mewar only at a distance of about 12 yards .
('75', 75, 7, 19, 143463) Vaidya Mathura Prasad was severely beaten by those policemen on the way to Uncha police station.
('75', 75, 7, 20, 143560) He has now been sentenced for nine months.
('75', 75, 8, 21, 143603) Second incident: Date of happening: 2nd February, 1939. Place of happening: On the outskirts of Deoli, British territory.
('75', 75, 9, 22, 143725) Shri Maniklal Varma, secretary of the Mewar Praja Mandal, had gone to Deoli .
('75', 75, 9, 23, 143803) In the evening at about 6.30 p.m., he with four other colleagues of his was all of a sudden attacked on the outskirts of the town by 15 men of Mewar police with lathis.
('75', 75, 9, 24, 143972) All the five persons were badly wounded, and Maniklalji was then forcibly dragged through bushes and thorns in a most inhuman way to the Mewar territory which was at a distance of at least a few hundred yards.
('75', 75, 9, 25, 144182) The Deoli police was informed during the mishap but no notice was taken, and the Dewan of the police station could not be found even after a good search, as if the whole thing was prearranged.
('75', 75, 9, 26, 144375) Maniklalji was arrested
('75', 75, 10, 27, 144399) 1 Of which only extracts are reproduced here

('75', 76, 1, 2, 144487) and taken to the Uncha police station in Mewar.
('75', 76, 1, 3, 144535) The correspondent adds:
('75', 76, 2, 4, 144559) Shri Maniklalji belongs to Bijolia.
('75', 76, 2, 5, 144595) He has been devoting himself to the service of the peasantry for the past 20 years.

('75', 78, 6, 8, 147578) SHARMA, Did you get the wire I sent?
('75', 78, 6, 9, 147615) The reply received here was: “Many Sharmas, wire undelivered.” There is only one point you want answered.

('75', 78, 6, 14, 148007) So keep yourself immersed in your work.
('75', 78, 7, 15, 148047) Blessings from BAPU
('75', 78, 8, 16, 148067) From a facsimile of the Hindi: Bapaki Chhayamen Mere Jivanke Solah Varsh, between pp.
('75', 78, 8, 17, 148153) 278 and 279
('75', 78, 9, 18, 148165) 99. DISCUSSION WITH DR.
('75', 78, 9, 19, 148189) CHESTERMAN 3
('75', 78, 10, 20, 148202) SEGAON, February 13, 1939
('75', 78, 11, 21, 148228) He said he had been overwhelmed with the perplexity of Indian problems and naturally the medical ones had taken first place in his mind.
('75', 78, 11, 22, 148365) When he heard that 2
('75', 78, 12, 23, 148386) 1 On being separated from Kasturba, Manibehn had refused to take food till she was taken back to her.
('75', 78, 12, 24, 148488) 2 ‘Mani’ means a jewel.
('75', 78, 12, 25, 148512) 3 Extracted from Amrit Kaur’s “A Good Samaritan”.
('75', 78, 12, 26, 148562) Dr. Chesterman was the medical secretary of the English Baptist Mission and had come to India to attend the International Missionary Conference at Tambaram and to visit various mission hospitals.
('75', 79, 0, 1, 148758) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 79, 1, 2, 148799) lakhs of women die yearly from child birth, 1 lakh from smallpox, 36 lakhs from indiscriminate fevers, that there are 10 lakhs of lepers and 6 lakhs of blind persons, he confessed he was appalled with the immensity of the task of both preventive and curative medicine.
('75', 79, 1, 3, 149068) He was not sure whether Gandhiji was aware of the fact that there were 266 mission hospitals and 500 dispensaries in India, 254 European and 350 Indian doctors, 300 European and 800 Indian nurses, 2 million patients seen and 5 million treated per annum in these hospitals, that half of the T. B. work and almost the entire work of lepers was in the hands of missions.
('75', 79, 1, 4, 149436) While, of course, the work of conversion was there, and he knew Gandhiji’s opinion on this subject, he wanted to draw attention to the fact that three quarters of their medical work lay in areas where there was no response to religious teaching .
('75', 79, 1, 5, 149683) He would, therefore, much like to have Gandhiji’s opinion on how the work could be most fruitfully developed and how far they could count on support and co operation.
('75', 79, 2, 6, 149850) In reply Gandhiji said that the answer was difficult and yet simple at the same time.
('75', 79, 2, 7, 149936) I hold peculiar views on the function of medicine.
('75', 79, 2, 8, 149987) I expressed these very forcibly years ago, and nothing in all the course of my long experience since has made me change them in essence.
('75', 79, 2, 9, 150124) But there is no need for me to expound these to you now.
('75', 79, 2, 10, 150181) I have visited many mission hospitals, seen the wonderful work of the missionaries among lepers.
('75', 79, 2, 11, 150278) This work may be called their monopoly and speciality, for practically no one else has come in to take it up.
('75', 79, 2, 12, 150388) I know the Leper Home in Cuttack.
('75', 79, 2, 13, 150422) I have spent quite a long time in the Purulia Leper Asylum and been very struck with the work there.
('75', 79, 2, 14, 150523) Then I have seen Mrs. Higginbotham’s work in Allahabad and several other places, too, for I love to visit leper homes.
('75', 79, 2, 15, 150642) But in spite of all this admiration of mine for the work of medical missionaries there has always been mental reservation and criticism within me.
('75', 79, 2, 16, 150789) I have felt that these good and weh intentioned missionaries have not touched the fringe of the question.
('75', 79, 2, 17, 150895) Certainly good work has been done for lepers, for the blind, for sufferers from T. B. and other ailments, but the help has not really touched the suffering millions of this great land.
('75', 79, 2, 18, 151080) Medical aid has been made available in the main to those who live in or near the cities— whereas the bulk of India’s population in our villages has been untouched.
('75', 79, 2, 19, 151244) Provincial Governments, even Congress Governments, are appalled at the need of the villager.
('75', 79, 2, 20, 151337) They do not know what to do and nothing great has yet been done in spite of various experiments.
('75', 79, 2, 21, 151434) Therefore, if I were asked to advise missionaries or Mission Boards, I would ask them not to try to transplant the entire system of Western
('75', 80, 0, 1, 151574) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 81
('75', 80, 1, 2, 151617) medicine into India.
('75', 80, 1, 3, 151638) We cannot afford it.
('75', 80, 1, 4, 151659) There is ever so much to be gleaned and had from the study of indigenous drugs and medicines, but practically very little work has been done in this department.
('75', 80, 1, 5, 151820) No one has made it his business to go out into our fields and search and much of the indigenous talent, simply because it is not considered original or scientific, is running to waste.
('75', 80, 1, 6, 152005) I will give you an incident which happened only today.
('75', 80, 1, 7, 152060) As you may know, I have had a little swelling on one foot for some days now which has alarmed the doctors because they feel that it is a sign denotative of commencing disintegration of the heart and kidneys.
('75', 80, 1, 8, 152268) One of my co workers here— you may call him almost an illiterate man—was very troubled, as all are, about me and tells me he could not sleep last night.
('75', 80, 1, 9, 152421) This morning he brought me a green leaf and told me that it had cured his father of the same trouble and begged of me to try it also.
('75', 80, 1, 10, 152555) I had no hesitation in acceding to his proposal—whereas if I had had a bewildering prescription given me by a highly qualified doctor my reaction would not have been the same.
('75', 80, 1, 11, 152731) I feel, therefore, that in these simple ways lies relief for the villager.
('75', 80, 1, 12, 152806) I do not say that the leaf will answer the purpose.
('75', 80, 1, 13, 152858) But there should be an agency that can say with certainty what these herbs are and what is their quality.
('75', 80, 2, 14, 152964) Gandhiji then went on to explain that he had no prejudice against Western medicine or doctors.
('75', 80, 2, 15, 153059) He had today sent for glucose for Mr. Kallenbach, a South African friend of his who was lying ill with malaria and who was refusing to take quinine, a drug in which Gandhiji himself had implicit faith.
('75', 80, 3, 16, 153261) Here, Dr. Chesterman interposed and said that quinine was an indigenous drug to which Gandhiji replied that though that was so it was a monopoly and therefore very expensive and utterly beyond the reach of the villager.
('75', 80, 3, 17, 153481) I should, therefore, like to see missionaries as medicine vendors for the villages, confining themselves, as far as they can, to indigenous medicines.
('75', 80, 3, 18, 153632) There will certainly not be gold medals or knighthoods from Government forthcoming for them for this valuable research work.
('75', 80, 3, 19, 153757) But, in my opinion, they will obtain what is of far greater value, a knighthood from Jesus Christ.
('75', 80, 4, 20, 153856) Proceeding, Gandhiji said that he had felt for a long time that the medical faculty in India should manufacture a short course of training for village workers, and had told Surgeon General Hooten of Bombay so, many years ago.
('75', 80, 4, 21, 154082) Village school teachers should be utilized for this purpose.
('75', 80, 4, 22, 154143) They should look upon the entire village as under their jurisdiction from the point of view of health and teach the simple laws of hygiene and prevention of disease to the inhabitants.
('75', 80, 4, 23, 154328) Their schools
('75', 81, 0, 1, 154342) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 81, 1, 2, 154383) could be used as dispensaries for the distribution of ordinary medicines for simple ailments.
('75', 81, 1, 3, 154477) He gave the analogy of the useful six weeks first aid training which he himself had had to undergo before he could form and lead the ambulance corps which he did during the Boer War.
('75', 81, 2, 4, 154660) Dr. Chesterman then asked Gandhiji his opinion on expenditure on buildings and elaborate equipment for hospitals.
('75', 81, 2, 5, 154774) Gandhiji replied saying that he had always been opposed to this and was invariably trying to wean people from spending on what was unnecessary when for so much that was urgently needed money was lacking.
('75', 81, 2, 6, 154978) Big hospitals did not help the poor man in the long run for they did not educate him to understand how he ought to look after his health once he left the hospital.
('75', 81, 3, 7, 155142) CHESTERMAN: What contribution can medical missionaries make towards the raising of ethical standards in professional life?
('75', 81, 4, 8, 155265) GANDHIJI: They can help, but I do not feel they can do much according to my measurement.
('75', 81, 4, 9, 155354) You may think me uncharitable, but so long as the mental reservation is there that medical missionaries would like all their patients and co workers to become converts to Christianity, so long will there remain a bar to real brotherhood.
('75', 81, 4, 10, 155592) Then there is the additional handicap that they belong to the ruling race and that is responsible for their aloofness.
('75', 81, 4, 11, 155711) Missionaries have not learnt the maxim ‘When you go to Rome do as Rome does’.
('75', 81, 4, 12, 155789) They retain everything of the West in their daily lives forgetting that clothes and food and modes of life are in response to climate and to surroundings and adjustment, therefore, becomes necessary.
('75', 81, 4, 13, 155989) They have not stooped to conquer.
('75', 81, 4, 14, 156023) The gulf of mutual distrust exists and there is, therefore, no easy passage between the medical missionary and the medical profession in India.
('75', 81, 5, 15, 156167) Dr. Chesterman disputed this statement.
('75', 81, 5, 16, 156207) He maintained that there was any amount of goodwill also.
('75', 81, 5, 17, 156265) He had met a Hindu friend in Bombay who had definitely assured him that there was need for mission hospitals because Indians got greater consideration and greater compassion there than in Government institutions.
('75', 81, 6, 18, 156478) Asked whether mission hospitals were justified in taking fees from those able to afford them, unlike Government institutions where money was generally extracted by the subordinate staff in undesirable ways, Gandhiji said he saw no reason against it.
('75', 81, 7, 19, 156728) The last question Dr. Chesterman asked was whether Gandhiji’s objection to conversion applied to areas like the Kond Hills where the aboriginal races were animists.
('75', 81, 7, 20, 156893) The unhesitating reply was: Yes.
('75', 81, 7, 21, 156926) It does apply, because I know that in spite of being
('75', 82, 0, 1, 156979) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 83
('75', 82, 1, 2, 157022) described as animists these tribes have from time immemorial been absorbed in Hinduism.
('75', 82, 1, 3, 157110) They are, like the indigenous medicine, of the soil, and their roots lie deep there.
('75', 82, 1, 4, 157195) But you can only endorse this if you feel that Hinduism is as true as Christianity.
('75', 82, 1, 5, 157279) I hold that all religions are true but imperfect inasmuch as they are presented through human agency and bear the impress of the imperfections and frailties of the human being.
('75', 82, 1, 6, 157456) My quarrel with missionaries is that they think no religion other than Christianity is true.
('75', 82, 2, 7, 157549) In parting from Gandhiji, while thanking him for the time he had given and hoping the conversation had not unduly tired him, Dr. Chesterman implored Gandhiji to continue to appeal to the best that was in them.
('75', 82, 2, 8, 157759) The feeling answer that greatly touched Dr. Chesterman was: I am making that appeal incessantly from the innermost recesses of my heart.
('75', 82, 2, 9, 157896) That is of far more value than the written word although I have indulged in that also.
('75', 82, 3, 10, 157983) Harijan, 25 2 1939

('75', 85, 2, 3, 161033) SEGAON, WARDHA, February 15, 1939
('75', 85, 3, 4, 161067) VIJAYA, We have already begun feeling lonely without you.
('75', 85, 3, 5, 161125) One misses your voice at the prayer.
('75', 85, 3, 6, 161162) But that is the way of the world.
('75', 85, 3, 7, 161196) Meeting, parting, again meeting, and again parting will go on and we should remain unaffected by them.
('75', 85, 3, 8, 161299) You should now understand your dharma.
('75', 85, 3, 9, 161338) Conjugal dharma is easy as well as difficult.
('75', 85, 3, 10, 161384) It is easy for one who understands it.
('75', 85, 3, 11, 161423) You should become one with Manubhai and Manubhai should become one with you.
('75', 85, 3, 12, 161500) But there is no scope for bargaining.
('75', 85, 3, 13, 161538) There can be no bargaining in dharma.
('75', 85, 3, 14, 161576) Dharma has to be performed by oneself.
('75', 85, 3, 15, 161615) So it is certain that you have to become one with Manubhai who may or may not become one with you.
('75', 85, 3, 16, 161714) This means that your entire spiritual riches should be surrendered to him.
('75', 85, 3, 17, 161789) And so you both should lift each other higher and higher but never bring each other down.
('75', 85, 3, 18, 161879) Brighten up the atmosphere there as you filled the house with joy here.
('75', 85, 3, 19, 161951) If you have understood the Gita you will be cheerful in whatever condition you may be placed.
('75', 85, 3, 20, 162045) Absorb yourself in the school work.
('75', 85, 3, 21, 162081) There can hardly be any news to give, seeing that it is not quite two hours since you left.

('75', 91, 0, 1, 169167) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('75', 91, 2, 5, 169484) SEGAON, February 20, 1939
('75', 91, 3, 6, 169510) TRUE SWADESHI
('75', 91, 4, 7, 169524) If I have to use the adjective ‘true’ before swadeshi, a critic may well ask, ‘Is there also false swadeshi?’ Unfortunately I have to answer ‘yes’.
('75', 91, 4, 8, 169672) As, since the days of khadi, I am supposed to be an authority on swadeshi, numerous conundrums are presented to me by correspondents.
('75', 91, 4, 9, 169806) And I have been obliged to distinguish between the two kinds of swadeshi.
('75', 91, 4, 10, 169880) If foreign capital is mixed with indigenous, or if foreign talent is mixed with indigenous, is the enterprise swadeshi?
('75', 91, 4, 11, 170000) There are other questions too.
('75', 91, 4, 12, 170031) But I had better reproduce the definition I gave to a Minister the other day.
('75', 91, 4, 13, 170109) “Any article is swadeshi if it subserves the interest of the millions, even though the capital and talent are foreign but under effective Indian control.” Thus khadi of the definition of the A. I. S. A. would be true swadeshi even though the capital may be all foreign and there may be Western specialists employed by the Indian Board.
('75', 91, 4, 14, 170445) Conversely, Bata’s rubber or other shoes would be foreign though the labour employed may be all Indian and the capital also found by India.
('75', 91, 4, 15, 170585) The manufacture will be doubly foreign because the control will be in foreign hands and the article, no matter how cheap it is, will oust the village tanner mostly and the village mochi 1 always.
('75', 91, 4, 16, 170781) Already the mochis of Bihar have begun to feel the unhealthy competition.
('75', 91, 4, 17, 170855) The Bata shoe may be the saving of Europe; it will mean the death of our village shoemaker and tanner.
('75', 91, 4, 18, 170958) I have given two telling illustrations, both partly imaginary.
('75', 91, 4, 19, 171021) For in the A. I. S. A. the capital is all indigenous and the whole of the talent also.
('75', 91, 4, 20, 171108) But I would love to secure the engineering talent of the West to give me a village wheel which will beat the existing wheels, though deep down in me I have the belief that the improvements that indigenous talent has made are by no means to be despised.
('75', 91, 4, 21, 171361) But this is a digression.
('75', 91, 4, 22, 171387) I do hope that those Ministers and others who guide or
('75', 91, 5, 23, 171442) 1 Cobbler
('75', 92, 0, 1, 171452) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 93
('75', 92, 1, 2, 171495) serve the public will cultivate the habit of distinguishing between true and false swadeshi.
('75', 92, 1, 3, 171588) SEGAON, February 20, 1939
('75', 92, 2, 4, 171614) Harijan, 25 2 1939
('75', 92, 3, 5, 171633) 118. TRAVANCORE AGAIN
('75', 92, 4, 6, 171655) I take the following from Shri Ramachandran’s letter to the Rajkumari:
('75', 92, 5, 7, 171726) I know there is nothing we can expect unless we burn ourselves out peacefully and truthfully for the cause for which we stand.
('75', 92, 5, 8, 171853) You must have seen how at the last meeting of the Working Committee of the State Congress we laid down a time limit of six weeks before commencing a programme of civil resistance.
('75', 92, 5, 9, 172033) God is witness that we are anxious for peace.
('75', 92, 5, 10, 172079) But there has been no enquiry into shootings which took place in nine places.
('75', 92, 5, 11, 172157) Many lawyers convicted during the last campaign have been debarred from practising for two years.
('75', 92, 5, 12, 172255) 19 members of the State Congress Party in the Legislature have been disqualified just on the eve of the present session now sitting.
('75', 92, 5, 13, 172388) Government had ample time to notify disqualification earlier and order has been made to destroy the State Congress volunteer organization under another iniquitous regulation brought into force for that specific purpose.
('75', 92, 5, 14, 172608) Just now there are over 200 political prisoners.
('75', 92, 5, 15, 172657) Many respectable people have been arrested under section 90 meant for security proceedings against goondas.
('75', 92, 5, 16, 172765) Fresh accommodation has been added in the central jail.
('75', 92, 5, 17, 172821) Over 1,000 special police have been recruited from among bad elements at the astounding monthly salary of Rs. 5. Can anything beat that?
('75', 92, 5, 18, 172958) And as though the Travancore police trusted cannot beto do the dirty work, numerous police constables have been recruited from outside Travancore.
('75', 92, 5, 19, 173105) The Government’s policy of repression has gone on unabated, without fuss and without precipitating a frontal battle.
('75', 92, 5, 20, 173222) That is why we feel compelled to lay down a time limit of six weeks.
('75', 92, 5, 21, 173291) I wish you to study carefully the papers I have sent to Bapu—specially the two resolutions we passed at the last meeting of the Working Committee.
('75', 92, 5, 22, 173438) I am oppressed with the idea that Sir C. P. Ramaswamy Aiyer’s policy will create a gulf between the Ruler and the people.
('75', 92, 5, 23, 173560) I have refrained from giving in these columns the resolutions and the preface referred to in the letters.
('75', 92, 5, 24, 173666) It is well for the reader to have these before him to enable him to judge what the State Congress is doing.
('75', 92, 5, 25, 173774) They will be found elsewhere in this issue.
('75', 92, 5, 26, 173818) The documents make painful reading.
('75', 92, 5, 27, 173854) What has happened since
('75', 93, 0, 1, 173878) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 93, 1, 2, 173919) the amnesty has robbed it of the grace that should accompany generous amnesties as this one on the birthday of the Maharaja was claimed to be.
('75', 93, 1, 3, 174062) It was a spontaneous gesture.
('75', 93, 1, 4, 174092) After events seem to suggest that it was no gesture of generosity, but that it was a part of the tactics adopted by the authorities to allay the agitation that was rising against the Travancore Durbar and to divide the people in Travancore.
('75', 93, 1, 5, 174333) If the information given by Shri Ramachandran is correct, the second object has not been gained and the first was partly achieved.
('75', 93, 1, 6, 174464) For the Indian Press was inclined to believe, after the release of prisoners, that the fight was over.
('75', 93, 1, 7, 174567) I would love to think that there was no sinister motive behind the partial amnesty.
('75', 93, 1, 8, 174651) If so, it seems to me to be quite easy to conciliate the State Congress, unless crushing, not conciliation, is the aim of the authorities.
('75', 93, 1, 9, 174790) Let the amnesty be completed and Reforms Committee be appointed in consultation with the State Congress, and peace between the Prince and the people is assured.
('75', 93, 1, 10, 174951) But there may be no such good fortune either for the people or the Prince.
('75', 93, 1, 11, 175026) In that case the State Congressmen should remember that satyagraha, if it is the greatest force in the world, requires also the capacity for the greatest suffering with a heart without anger or malice.
('75', 93, 1, 12, 175228) Whilst it is right to publish the news about the doings of the oppressor, there must be infinite patience for endless suffering and yet a burning faith in the ultimate success of truth.
('75', 93, 1, 13, 175414) It is well that the Congress has fixed upon a six weeks’ limit.
('75', 93, 1, 14, 175478) But if it is found that six weeks are not enough for ensuring non violence as far as it is humanly possible and for also ensuring continuity of constructive work, there would be no shame but additional credit in taking further postponement.
('75', 93, 1, 15, 175719) If thoughtless persons and unkind critics regard such postponement as a sign of weakness, the fighters need not mind such imputations.
('75', 93, 1, 16, 175854) After all the soldier knows when to stay his hand and when to move on.
('75', 93, 1, 17, 175925) He knows that often there is action in so called inaction and imprudent action is worse than real inaction.
('75', 93, 1, 18, 176033) And weak is not he who is so called but he who feels that he is weak.
('75', 93, 1, 19, 176103) Let the members of the Working Committee realize that the technique of non violent action requires general and effective control over forces of violence, no matter how or by whom instigated.
('75', 93, 1, 20, 176294) If and when the struggle is resumed, I hope that in answer to my wires I will not be told that the State Congress is not responsible for violence if it breaks out.
('75', 93, 1, 21, 176458) Does not responsible government mean that the people,
('75', 94, 0, 1, 176512) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 95
('75', 94, 1, 2, 176555) instead of a dictator appointed by a Paramount Power, are responsible for all the acts of the people?
('75', 94, 1, 3, 176657) Let them realize that if violence breaks out on any appreciable scale, it might, very probably will, be a call for another suspension, even as there was suspension in Bardoli, though violence broke out in far off Chauri Chaura.
('75', 94, 2, 4, 176885) SEGAON, February 20, 1939 Harijan, 25 2 1939
('75', 94, 3, 5, 176930) 119. LAWLESS LIMBDI
('75', 94, 4, 6, 176950) Limbdi is a Kathiawar State.
('75', 94, 4, 7, 176979) It had the reputation of being progressive.
('75', 94, 4, 8, 177023) I have the good fortune to know many of its workers.
('75', 94, 4, 9, 177076) They are wise, self sacrificing and capable of doing hard work.
('75', 94, 4, 10, 177140) In common with many States, Limbdi also had a great awakening among the people.
('75', 94, 4, 11, 177220) The workers used to boast of their progressive Yuvraj.
('75', 94, 4, 12, 177275) But they have now discovered that he has imbibed some curious notions of the dictatorships of the West.
('75', 94, 4, 13, 177379) He would let the reformers have a free run of little Limbdi.
('75', 94, 4, 14, 177440) But they must not go to the villages.
('75', 94, 4, 15, 177478) In the villages he was to make his own experiments unhindered by anybody.
('75', 94, 4, 16, 177552) The Limbdi reformers thought that they had as much right as the Yuvraj to work among the villagers, especially as they had already established connection with them.
('75', 94, 4, 17, 177717) They therefore dared to go to the villages, with the result mentioned in the following telegram:
('75', 94, 5, 18, 177814) At least eighty persons, armed with lathis, dharias, native guns, swords, axes, attacked village Pansina midnight fifth.
('75', 94, 5, 19, 177935) Entrances of village were guarded by batches of three to five persons.
('75', 94, 5, 20, 178006) Two batches of twenty persons went round village and selected houses of Prajamandal workers and sympathizers for dacoity.
('75', 94, 5, 21, 178128) First of all they went to the Prajamandal office and chained it from outside so that volunteers could not go out.
('75', 94, 5, 22, 178242) Then one batch went to house of Chhotalal, prominent merchant and Prajamandal worker, and brutally assaulted him and his wife.
('75', 94, 5, 23, 178369) She received serious injuries including on her sex organs.
('75', 94, 5, 24, 178428) President of local branch attacked with sword and received punctured wound in lungs.
('75', 94, 5, 25, 178513) About thirty persons are seriously injured.
('75', 94, 5, 26, 178557) Ornaments, cash and goods worth about sixty thousand rupees taken away from ten to twelve houses of active members of Prajamandal.
('75', 94, 5, 27, 178688) Dacoits continuously carried on firing in air and at houses for about two hours.

('75', 101, 1, 2, 188922) 129. TALK TO HYDERABAD STATE CONGRESS DELEGATION 1
('75', 101, 2, 3, 188973) SEGAON, February 21, 1939
('75', 101, 3, 4, 188999) A satyagrahi will, like a general, always choose his own time and ground for fight.
('75', 101, 3, 5, 189083) Satyagraha should be kept in reserve until all other means of advancing the cause are exhausted.
('75', 101, 3, 6, 189180) Even in armed warfare, suspensions and withdrawals are the recognized tactics.
('75', 101, 3, 7, 189259) Suspension does not exclude facing imprisonment if in the course of legitimate, peaceful and constructive activities people are arrested.
('75', 101, 3, 8, 189397) These will not constitute civil disobedience.
('75', 101, 3, 9, 189443) Your decision to continue the suspension is a wise one.
('75', 101, 3, 10, 189499) You have lost nothing by suspension.
('75', 101, 3, 11, 189536) There is nothing to prevent you from resuming the satyagraha when the situation again demands it and there is ample cause to compel you to revive satyagraha.
('75', 101, 4, 12, 189694) The Hindu, 22 2 1939
('75', 101, 5, 13, 189715) 130. A MISCHIEVOUS SUGGESTION
('75', 101, 6, 14, 189745) A correspondent sends the following cutting from The Bombay Chronicle:
('75', 101, 7, 15, 189816) Mr. Rushbrook Williams in a letter to The Manchester Guardian declares that during the last few months of last year there was a definite progress by the Right Wing elements of the Congress High Command towards a position in which Mahatma Gandhi would have found it possible to approach the authorities with suggestions in relation to the Central Government, roughly corresponding to those which he so successfully carried through in connection with the Provincial Governments.
('75', 101, 7, 16, 190293) What was then regarded as the approach of Federation compelled the Congress to reckon up its forces.
('75', 101, 7, 17, 190394) It had little Muslim support and without such support, thanks to the Muslim League, and unless it found new allies, it will be unable to form a Government in the Centre.
('75', 101, 7, 18, 190564) Therefore it was necessary to concentrate on Indian States in order to secure that the representations of States should be drawn from elements sympathizing with the Congress programme.
('75', 101, 8, 19, 190749) 1 The Delegation had informed Gandhiji of the State Congress decision to continue suspension of the satyagraha for some time more.
('75', 101, 8, 20, 190880) The satyagraha was suspended on or about 26 12 1938. Vide “Draft of Statement for Hyderabad State Congress”, Before 26 12 1938, and “Letter to Akbar Hydari”, 26 12 1938
('75', 102, 0, 1, 191049) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 103
('75', 102, 1, 2, 191093) He adds: “It is not without significance that Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya is intimately associated with the States Subjects’ Conference, but the election of Mr. Bose has been a blow to the Right Wing and apparently has postponed any rapprochement with the authorities as the High Command had in mind.
('75', 102, 1, 3, 191391) Mr. Bose does not like the States, but he also does not like Federation.
('75', 102, 1, 4, 191464) He can, therefore, have little sympathy with an endeavour to convert States into allies of the Congress in preparation for a Congress domination over the new Central institutions.
('75', 102, 1, 5, 191644) In fact he desires to keep them at arm’s length to secure a settlement of British Indian destinies by British India and eventually no doubt to expel the Princes and absorb the States into the new self governing India he projects.” Mr. Williams is an old ‘enemy’.
('75', 102, 1, 6, 191907) During the non co operation days he edited an official Year Book, in which he drew upon his imagination and gave his own colour to facts which he could not avoid.
('75', 102, 1, 7, 192070) He has played the same role again in his letter to The Manchester Guardian, assuming that he is correctly quoted.
('75', 102, 1, 8, 192184) It is wrong to say that there was a definite or any progress by the Right Wing elements of the Congress High Command towards the position pictured by Mr. Williams’s imagination.
('75', 102, 1, 9, 192362) The suggestion about Muslim support is malicious.
('75', 102, 1, 10, 192412) I know my own mind and so far as I know the Congress mind, neither it nor I ever dreamt that there could be any federation without Muslim support.
('75', 102, 1, 11, 192559) Indeed so long as there is opposition to federation by the Muslims, the Congress has no need to worry about federation coming.
('75', 102, 1, 12, 192686) Therefore, unless there is perfect communal unity, no Congressman can think or talk of federation whether of the Government mint or cent per cent swadeshi mint.
('75', 102, 1, 13, 192847) About Dr. Pattabhi, the whole of India knows that his candidature was thought of at the last moment when Maulana Saheb withdrew and as Dr. Pattabhi was the only candidate left besides Subhas Babu.
('75', 102, 1, 14, 193044) His connection with the States People’s Conference has been a convenient fact for building up Mr. Williams’s case.
('75', 102, 1, 15, 193159) As for the innuendos about Subhas Babu, he is well able to look after himself.
('75', 102, 1, 16, 193238) But throughout one year’s intimate connection with him I never once heard him say of the States what Mr. Williams attributes to him.
('75', 102, 1, 17, 193371) I am quite certain that if the States come to terms with the Congress about the treatment of the people in their jurisdiction, Subhas Babu will be quite as keen as any Congressman to close the bargain but not in anticipation of federation.
('75', 102, 1, 18, 193611) I have come into the States agitation by accident.
('75', 102, 1, 19, 193662) Responsible
('75', 103, 0, 1, 193674) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 103, 1, 2, 193716) government in the States is a goal by itself and independent of federation which may never come.
('75', 103, 1, 3, 193813) It won’t come till the Congress and Muslims are ready for it.
('75', 103, 1, 4, 193875) But liberty of the States people has to Come in any and every case.
('75', 103, 1, 5, 193943) They cannot be in chains and what is called British India become free.
('75', 103, 2, 6, 194014) SEGAON, February 23, 1939
('75', 103, 3, 7, 194040) Harijan, 4 3 1939

('75', 109, 4, 5, 202306) Hear satyagraha prisoners Rajkot jail fasting.

('75', 113, 1, 2, 211136) 145. QUESTION OF HONOUR
('75', 113, 2, 3, 211160) On my way to Rajkot, going via Bombay, I have to wait a whole day for the Kathiawar mail.
('75', 113, 2, 4, 211250) I am passing the time in writing for Harijan.
('75', 113, 2, 5, 211296) And I read the following note:
('75', 113, 3, 6, 211327) Ramdurg—a small State in the Bombay Karnatak, area 169 sq.
('75', 113, 3, 7, 211386) miles, population 33,997, revenue Rs. 2,69,000—was hard hit by famine and scarcity conditions, and also depression due to fall in prices for some years past.
('75', 113, 3, 8, 211544) On 20th March 1938 some agriculturists from villages gathered together in front of the palace and requested the Rajasaheb to grant some concessions in respect of land revenue.
('75', 113, 3, 9, 211720) It was alleged on behalf of those assembled at the Palace that they were dispersed by lathi charge by the Ramdurg police.
('75', 113, 3, 10, 211842) On the other hand these allegations were denied by the State authorities.
('75', 113, 3, 11, 211916) It seems that no definite demands were made on behalf of the people, nor was there any organization to speak for them.
('75', 113, 3, 12, 212035) Some time later some of the people of the State approached Shri Yalgi, a Congressman and one of the Secretaries of the Karnatak Provincial Congress Committee, and requested him to visit Ramdurg and see the situation for himself.
('75', 113, 3, 13, 212264) Accordingly, Shri Yalgi visited Ramdurg in April and advised the people there to organize a committee to place their demands before the authorities.
('75', 113, 3, 14, 212413) In accordance with his advice, a body named Ramdurg Sansthan Praja Sangh was established and on its behalf demands were formulated and submitted to the Rajasaheb.
('75', 113, 4, 15, 212576) A Conference of Deccan States’ People took place at Sangli on 22nd May 1938, presided over by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.
('75', 113, 4, 16, 212696) He left Sangli on the 22nd.
('75', 113, 4, 17, 212724) But the Conference continued under the presidentship of Shri Gangadharrao Deshpande.
('75', 113, 5, 18, 212809) On the 23rd, the question of Ramdurg was taken up and it was decided that a committee, consisting of (I) Shri Gangadharrao Deshpande, President, K. P. C. C., (2) Shri Shankarrao Deo, Member of the Congress Working Committee, (3) Shri Munoli, President, Ramdurg Praja Sangh, (4) Shri Kanabur, Secretary of Deccan States People’s Conference, (5) Shri Andaneppa Doddameti, M. L. A., (6) Shri K. S. Patil, M. L. A., (7) Shri Ari, Pleader, Hubli, a subject of the State, was appointed to investigate and report on the Ramdurg affair.
('75', 113, 5, 19, 213338) In the mean time the Ramdurg Durbar, on their own initiative, had issued a proclamation and announced certain concessions.
('75', 113, 5, 20, 213461) But the people were not satisfied with these concessions and the agitation was assuming a serious turn.
('75', 113, 6, 21, 213565) Then on the 5th June 1938 the Committee appointed at Sangli visited Ramdurg and instituted an enquiry.
('75', 113, 6, 22, 213668) It was felt by the Committee and also by the prominent representatives of the Ramdurg Praja Sangh that a mere enquiry
('75', 114, 0, 1, 213786) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 115
('75', 114, 1, 2, 213830) and report would not serve the purpose.
('75', 114, 1, 3, 213870) Therefore the latter requested the Committee to bring about a settlement in respect of the demands which were submitted to the Ramdurg Durbar.
('75', 114, 2, 4, 214013) The matter was discussed for two hours and on the 6th of June Shri Deo was entrusted with the sole authority of settling the differences.
('75', 114, 2, 5, 214151) Shri Deo, in accepting the responsibility, made clear to the people all the implications of what they were doing.
('75', 114, 2, 6, 214265) Shri Deo, on behalf of the Committee, formulated the demands and submitted them to the Rajasaheb.
('75', 114, 2, 7, 214363) After some discussions the matter was postponed at the desire of the Rajasaheb.
('75', 114, 2, 8, 214443) However, most of the suggestions, with slight modifications, were conceded by the Rajasaheb.
('75', 114, 2, 9, 214536) Shri Deshpande wrote to the Sardar as to what had happened.
('75', 114, 2, 10, 214596) He also informed him of the demands of the Praja Sangh and the offer of Rajasaheb.
('75', 114, 2, 11, 214679) In reply, Sardar wrote to Shri Deshpande on the 11th June 1938 to say that the terms offered by Rajasaheb could not be improved upon, that they were quite good and that the people should be advised to accept them.
('75', 114, 3, 12, 214893) Though Shri Deo was entrusted with full powers to negotiate and settle the terms, he on the 21st June 1938 took Shri Munoli and all the members of the Managing Committee of the Praja Sangh into confidence, and after long discussion secured their assent to the terms settled between himself and Rajasaheb.
('75', 114, 3, 13, 215198) The members of the Committee appointed by the Sangli Conference with the exception of Shri Shastri, who was absent, also agreed.
('75', 114, 3, 14, 215327) The acceptance of the terms was communicated to Rajasaheb.
('75', 114, 3, 15, 215386) The same evening durbar was held in the palace to which the President and representatives of the Praja Sangh and leading men of Ramdurg were invited.
('75', 114, 3, 16, 215536) The Rajasaheb in his opening speech surveyed the history of his rule and gave the outlines of the terms of settlement.
('75', 114, 3, 17, 215655) The Dewan, Rao Bahadur Pradhan, then read out the proclamation embodying the terms of the settlement.
('75', 114, 3, 18, 215757) Thereupon the President of the Praja Sangh, on behalf of the Sangh, thanked the Rajasaheb in suitable terms.
('75', 114, 3, 19, 215866) After the durbar was over, Shri Deo and others went to the public meeting.
('75', 114, 3, 20, 215941) The meeting was attended by more than 12,000 persons.
('75', 114, 3, 21, 215995) The President of the Praja Sangh presided.
('75', 114, 3, 22, 216038) When Shri Gangadharrao Deshpande was explaining the terms of the settlement, a slight disturbance was noticed in one corner of the meeting.
('75', 114, 3, 23, 216178) It was ascertained that they belonged to Sureban and were weavers.
('75', 114, 3, 24, 216245) Shri Andaneppa Doddameti went to that corner and successfully tried to restore peace.
('75', 114, 3, 25, 216331) After Shri Deshpande, Shri Andaneppa spoke for more than one hour and fully explained all the details of the terms and defended them very vigorously.
('75', 114, 3, 26, 216481) He carried conviction to the audience and concluded his speech amongst enthusiastic cheers.
('75', 114, 3, 27, 216573) Shri Deo also made a short speech asking people to organize and strengthen their position by working
('75', 115, 0, 1, 216674) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 115, 1, 2, 216716) the reforms granted.
('75', 115, 1, 3, 216737) Shri Munavalli, the President in his concluding speech, which was very touching, defended all the terms settled and asked the audience whether they had confidence in him.
('75', 115, 1, 4, 216908) The audience with one voice replied in the affirmative.
('75', 115, 1, 5, 216964) He then asked them to accept the terms and they assented.
('75', 115, 1, 6, 217022) At the conclusion of the meeting a paper, containing the terms of the settlement, was brought to the President for his signature by an officer of the State.
('75', 115, 1, 7, 217179) Shri Munavalli, the President, again asked the audience whether he should sign it and with concurrence of not only the large audience but of the representatives of the Praja Sangh, signed the document.
('75', 115, 2, 8, 217381) The Council of the Karnatak Provincial Congress Committee passed the following resolution:
('75', 115, 3, 9, 217472) “The Council congratulates the people of Ramdurg, Jamkhandi, Miraj Sr.
('75', 115, 3, 10, 217543) and Jr.
('75', 115, 3, 11, 217551) and Mudhol for the success they have achieved in their struggle for redress of their grievances and trusts that they will strengthen their organizations by non violent and peaceful means for the attainment of full responsible government in the near future.
('75', 115, 4, 12, 217808) “This Council expresses its sense of appreciation of the Rulers of the above States for readily responding to the demands of their subjects and trusts that the terms of the settlement will be implemented by both the portions without delay.
('75', 115, 4, 13, 218048) It also requests the Rulers of all the States in Karnatak to follow the liberal policy followed by the above mentioned States.
('75', 115, 5, 14, 218175) “This Council, however, notes with extreme pain that anti propaganda is being carried on by some people and especially by some Congressmen on the plea that the settlement was arrived at by the efforts of prominent Congress leaders between the people and the Prince of Ramdurg.
('75', 115, 5, 15, 218452) This Council while requesting them not to carry on anti propaganda is definitely of opinion that the good of the people will advance only by standing by the settlement.” I have omitted some part irrelevant for my purpose.
('75', 115, 5, 16, 218674) It appears that an attempt is now being made on behalf of the Ramdurg Praja Sangh to terrorize the Ruler into making further concessions 1. He refrains from taking action against the mischief mongers for fear of losing Congress sympathy.
('75', 115, 5, 17, 218912) The question I am asked is, “What are Congressmen involved in the settlement to do?” Assuming the correctness of my information, my unequivocal answer is that they have to keep at any cost the plighted word of the Provincial Committee.
('75', 115, 5, 18, 219148) I am going to Rajkot to entreat H. H. the Thakore Saheb of Rajkot to keep his word.
('75', 115, 5, 19, 219232) The breach, as I interpret his action, has
('75', 115, 6, 20, 219275) 1Vide also “Popular Violence in Ramdurg”, 24 4 1939.
('75', 116, 0, 1, 219328) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 117
('75', 116, 1, 2, 219372) shaken me to my depths.
('75', 116, 1, 3, 219396) I can think of no other answer with regard to the Congress.
('75', 116, 1, 4, 219456) Rajkot represents the Princely order.
('75', 116, 1, 5, 219494) Its shame or credit would be the shame or credit of the whole order.
('75', 116, 1, 6, 219563) If a representative Congressman breaks his word, the reputation of the whole Congress is at stake.
('75', 116, 1, 7, 219662) How much more so, if a Provincial Congress Committee cannot redeem its word?
('75', 116, 1, 8, 219739) The Congress claims to represent the whole nation.
('75', 116, 1, 9, 219790) Its transactions must be above reproach.
('75', 116, 1, 10, 219831) In these days of awakening, all kinds of forces must rise up.
('75', 116, 1, 11, 219893) Demands, even extravagant, will be made by new additions to the Congress.
('75', 116, 1, 12, 219967) If they are in excess of Congress commitments and if the Congress credit is to go up day after day, they must be checked.

('75', 116, 3, 19, 220532) 146. KHADI AS FAMINE RELIEF
('75', 116, 4, 20, 220560) This letter 1 shows conclusively what a relief khadi is to famine areas.
('75', 116, 4, 21, 220633) Those, therefore, who buy relief khadi help the famine stricken and themselves.
('75', 116, 4, 22, 220713) In addition they give not doles but wages and these at khadi market rates for spinning which are higher than for any other relief work.
('75', 116, 4, 23, 220849) I hope, therefore, that this appeal will receive a generous response from the public.
('75', 116, 5, 24, 220935) BOMBAY, February 26, 1939
('75', 116, 6, 25, 220961) Harijan, 4 3 1939

('75', 117, 1, 2, 221369) 147. IS NON VIOLENT?
('75', 117, 2, 3, 221390) Below is an extract from a letter from a teacher in the Annamalai University: 1
('75', 117, 3, 4, 221470) Some time in November last, a group of five or six students organizedly assaulted the secretary of University Union, a fellow student.
('75', 117, 3, 5, 221605) Shri Srinivasa Sastri, the Vice Chancellor, took a serious view of it and punished the leader of the group with expulsion from the University and the rest with suspension till the end of this academic year.
('75', 117, 4, 6, 221812) Some sympathizers and friends of these punished students wanted to abstain from attending classes and strike work.
('75', 117, 5, 7, 221927) The next day, about 20 per cent of the students stayed away from the classes; the remaining 80 per cent attended the classes as usual.
('75', 117, 5, 8, 222062) I may add, the strength of this University is about 800.
('75', 117, 6, 9, 222119) The student who was expelled next day came inside the hostel to direct the strike.
('75', 117, 6, 10, 222202) Finding the strike unsuccessful he adopted other methods in the evening, as for example, bodily Iying across the four main outlets from the hostel, locking some gates of the hostel, locking up some of the young boys inside their own rooms.
('75', 117, 6, 11, 222442) In this way in the afternoon, the rest of the students were prevented from coming outside the hostel gates by fifty or sixty people.
('75', 117, 7, 12, 222575) The authorities thus finding the gates closed wanted to make an opening in the fencing.
('75', 117, 7, 13, 222663) But when they started pulling down the fence with the help of servants of the University, the strikers prevented the other students from passing through the breaches to attend college.
('75', 117, 7, 14, 222848) The authorities finding the situation unmanageable requested the police to remove the expelled student from the hostel premises .
('75', 117, 7, 15, 222978) which the police did.
('75', 117, 7, 16, 223000) This naturally irritated some more of the students who began to show sympathy with the strikers.
('75', 117, 7, 17, 223097) Shri Srinivasa Sastri then closed down the University for a long vacation of 1_ months from November 29th to January 16th.
('75', 117, 7, 18, 223220) He gave a statement to the Press appealing to the students to come back from home in a chastened and happier mood for study.
('75', 117, 8, 19, 223345) But the college reopened with renewed activities on the part of the strikers who had extra advice during the vacation from .
('75', 117, 8, 20, 223470) 2 They wentto Rajaji, it appears, but he asked them to obey the Vice Chancellor, and declined to interfere.
('75', 117, 9, 21, 223578) The picketing is still going on.
('75', 117, 9, 22, 223611) The strikers are about 35 to 45 in

('75', 122, 6, 10, 230962) A few minutes prior to his arrival at Rajkot, Mahatma Gandhi told the Associated Press special correspondent travelling with him that he had no specific plans with regard to his “mission of peace in Rajkot”.
('75', 122, 7, 11, 231170) Asked how long he would be at Rajkot, Mahatma Gandhi said: I really don’t know how long I will be here.
('75', 122, 7, 12, 231274) I have to be here till I finish my work.
('75', 122, 8, 13, 231315) QUESTION: Does that mean that you will not be able to go to Tripuri Congress ?
('75', 122, 9, 14, 231394) ANSWER: Well, if my work in Rajkot detains me, I am afraid I will not be able to go to Tripuri.

('75', 125, 1, 2, 235190) 161. DISCUSSION WITH DEPUTATION OF GARASIA MANDAL 1
('75', 125, 2, 3, 235242) February 28, 1939
('75', 125, 3, 4, 235260) As in the case of the Muslim Deputation, Gandhiji set them completely at their ease by telling them at the very start that they would have their one nominee on the Committee.
('75', 125, 3, 5, 235435) In reply to further questions on their part, he told them that if they expected to be confirmed for all time in all the privileges that they had up till now enjoyed, they were doomed to disappointment.
('75', 125, 3, 6, 235637) That was neither right nor feasible.
('75', 125, 3, 7, 235674) If the condition of India’s countless destitute masses was to be ameliorated, the privileged class shall have to divest itself of some of its privileges in favour of Daridranarayana.
('75', 125, 3, 8, 235857) If the Garasias would only understand the spirit of the times, become one with the toiling masses and make the latter’s interests their own, their legitimate interests would be safeguarded.
('75', 125, 3, 9, 236047) He would therefore give them the advice he had given to the Princes, viz., to make themselves true servants of the people and not want to ride on their backs.
('75', 125, 3, 10, 236206) They should hold their wealth as a trust to be used wisely in the interest of the people.
('75', 125, 3, 11, 236296) They were entitled to a reasonable emolument for themselves but only in return for service rendered.
('75', 125, 4, 12, 236397) “We are bitterly attacked by a certain section of Congressmen, we are even called names.
('75', 125, 4, 13, 236486) Would not you protect us?”
('75', 125, 5, 14, 236513) You should know that there is today in the Congress a considerable and growing section that wants to do away with all vested interests altogether, because they have no faith in the possibility of their conversion.
('75', 125, 5, 15, 236727) My capacity to protect you will, therefore, entirely depend on your willingness to adopt and live up to the ideal of trusteeship that I have placed before you.
('75', 125, 5, 16, 236887) I would not be able to help you unless you co operate with me.
('75', 125, 6, 17, 236950) Harijan, 25 3 1939
