('75', 127, 7, 11, 238880) 164. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 3
('75', 127, 8, 12, 238926) RAJKOT, March 1, 1939 In the morning, I saw peasants from Halenda Khari, Hodthali and several other places who had complaints to make about the delivery of the State’s portion of the crops and against lathi charges and the like.
('75', 127, 8, 13, 239155) There were nearly one hundred and fifty of them including about twenty to twenty five women.
('75', 127, 8, 14, 239248) I did not know that I was going to meet them this morning.
('75', 127, 8, 15, 239307) Therefore, I had not informed the Khan Saheb 4. Happily he dropped in after I had proceeded with the conversation.
('75', 127, 8, 16, 239422) He was able to listen to what the peasants had to say and asked them certain questions also.
('75', 127, 8, 17, 239515) At this stage I do not want to go into the details of these allegations.
('75', 127, 9, 18, 239588) 1 This was sent “in response to a request” from the Reception Committee of the 52nd session of the Indian National Congress at Tripuri.
('75', 127, 9, 19, 239724) The telegram was presumably addressed to Shankerlal Banker.
('75', 127, 9, 20, 239784) In “The Rajkot Fast [–I]” (Harijan, 25 3 1939), Pyarelal explains: “There was a desperate S. O. S. from Shankerlal Banker and Seth Govinddas [Chairman, Reception Committee] telling Gandhiji that his presence alone at Tripuri would help to pull the Reception Committee through a number of financial and other difficulties and even if he could reach there by sixth, they would be satisfied.
('75', 127, 9, 21, 240173) .” 2 Gandhiji was to open the Khadi and Village Industries Exhibition on March 3. As Gandhiji could not leave Rajkot, Jawaharlal Nehru opened the exhibition on March 6. 3 The source says that “after the evening prayers Gandhiji reviewed the day’s work”.
('75', 127, 9, 22, 240427) 4 Fateh Mohammed Khan, First Member, Rajkot State Council.
('75', 128, 0, 1, 240486) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 129
('75', 128, 1, 2, 240530) After the talk with the peasants, I had a prolonged conversation with the Khan Saheb, as usual of a friendly character.
('75', 128, 1, 3, 240650) In the afternoon I saw co workers and had a full discussion with them for an hour and a half over the questions agitating the public mind.
('75', 128, 1, 4, 240789) The discussion with the workers was very interesting in that they asked some penetrating questions and I endeavoured to put before them my view of what the implication of true satyagraha were.
('75', 128, 1, 5, 240982) I believe that they are working with a full sense of their responsibility.
('75', 128, 1, 6, 241057) In this connection, I am glad to be able to say that the authorities allowed some leaders, who are in jail, to come to me because I needed their assistance for the purpose of carrying on negotiations.
('75', 128, 1, 7, 241258) They were kept with me for a few hours, and taken back to their respective quarters at about 6·30 p.m.
('75', 128, 2, 8, 241361) Gandhiji told the Associated Press Special Correspondent that his talks tonight with Durbar Virawala 1 were inconclusive and that he was waiting to hear from him tomorrow to resume the talks.

('75', 128, 4, 11, 241605) ANANDKUNJ, RAJKOT, March 2, 1939
('75', 128, 5, 12, 241638) MAHERBAN THAKORE SAHEB 3, I write this letter not without hesitation, but duty compels it.
('75', 128, 5, 13, 241729) You know the reason for my coming here.
('75', 128, 5, 14, 241769) For three days I had conversation with Durbar Virawala.
('75', 128, 5, 15, 241825) He gave me cause for intense dissatisfaction.
('75', 128, 5, 16, 241871) He seems to be incapable of keeping his resolutions from moment to moment.
('75', 128, 5, 17, 241946) Such is my opinion based upon my three days’ contact with him.
('75', 128, 5, 18, 242009) In my opinion, his guidance has harmed the State.
('75', 128, 5, 19, 242059) Now I come to the object of this letter.
('75', 128, 5, 20, 242100) At the time of leaving Wardha I had resolved that I would not leave Rajkot without inducing fulfilment of your promise.
('75', 128, 5, 21, 242220) But I had never thought that I would have to be here for more than one or two days or that I would have to suffer what I have suffered.

('75', 129, 1, 3, 242569) I should hasten to Tripuri if it is at all possible.
('75', 129, 1, 4, 242622) If I do not go, over a thousand co workers will be disappointed and lakhs of poor people will become disconsolate.
('75', 129, 1, 5, 242737) Time, therefore, has a special value for me at this juncture.

('75', 133, 1, 2, 250906) 168.TALK TO SATYAGRAHI VOLUNTEERS 1
('75', 133, 2, 3, 250942) March, 2, 1939
('75', 133, 3, 4, 250957) After the evening prayer Gandhiji gave a talk to satyagrahi volunteers.
('75', 133, 3, 5, 251029) They had distinguished themselves by their bravery and proved their non violent mettle.
('75', 133, 3, 6, 251117) But that was not what had brought him to Rajkot.
('75', 133, 3, 7, 251166) What filled him with concern was the growth and spread of the cult of goondaism.
('75', 133, 3, 8, 251247) In Travancore, in Talcher, in Dhenkanal, and finally in Rajkot itself, he had noticed that the continuance of civil resistance was provoking more and more violence on the part of the authorities and brutalizing them progressively.
('75', 133, 3, 9, 251478) He had therefore called a halt to civil resistance and taken upon himself the entire burden of the fight.
('75', 133, 3, 10, 251584) He hoped through Rajkot to find a remedy for this cult of the cudgel and the hired bravoes with which the civil resister was being confronted.
('75', 133, 3, 11, 251727) [He said:] I see the hand of God in this.
('75', 133, 3, 12, 251769) I could not have chosen a purer or a nobler means for this than the Rajkot issue.
('75', 133, 3, 13, 251851) It is essentially a moral issue.
('75', 133, 3, 14, 251884) Nothing could be clearer, no breach of promise could be more flagrant needing rectification.
('75', 133, 4, 15, 251977) He advised the satyagrahis to be extremely wary and beware of having any truck or making any compromise with violence.
('75', 133, 4, 16, 252096) There could be no ‘united front’ between violence and non violence; the two were incompatible.
('75', 133, 4, 17, 252191) If, therefore, in any place, those who did not believe in non violence were in preponderance, the satyagrahis should isolate themselves from them and refuse to be drawn into civil resistance in conjunction with them.
('75', 133, 5, 18, 252408) One of the satyagrahi volunteers, referring to what some of them had been put through by the State authorities, asked if satyagraha required them to submit to illegal and inhuman treatment to which very often they were subjected.
('75', 133, 5, 19, 252638) For instance, if a police officer put a satyagrahi under arrest and ordered him to enter a prison van, the latter was bound to obey the order.
('75', 133, 5, 20, 252781) But supposing he was ordered to enter a bus in order to be taken to a distant place in the jungle, there to be bundled out after a beating without even a pretext of a trial or legal procedure of any kind, was he still to obey the policeman in question?
('75', 133, 5, 21, 253034) Gandhiji replied: A satyagrahi courts suffering and submits to it willingly and cheerfully in the hope therethrough to melt the heart of the opponent.
('75', 133, 5, 22, 253185) He does nothing out of compulsion.
('75', 133, 5, 23, 253220) Prahlada did not hesitate when ordered by his father to be tied to a red hot iron post.
('75', 133, 5, 24, 253308) On the contrary
('75', 133, 6, 25, 253324) 1 This is extracted from “The Rajkot Fast [–I]”.
('75', 134, 0, 1, 253373) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 135
('75', 134, 1, 2, 253417) he eagerly embraced it and the legend says that he remained unhurt.
('75', 134, 1, 3, 253485) An ideal satyagrahi would as a matter of fact be insensible to all the bodly tortures that might be inflicted upon him and experience nothing but exultation and joy under them.
('75', 134, 1, 4, 253662) I know that I am far from having attained that ideal myself.
('75', 134, 1, 5, 253723) But a worthy heir always adds to the legacy that he receives, and satyagraha presents infinite scope for research and further development.
('75', 134, 1, 6, 253862) A satyagrahi may, however, not obey an order that offends against his moral sense or hurts his self respect even though it may cost him his life.
('75', 134, 1, 7, 254008) Nay more, it may be one’s duty to put an end to one’s life, if that is the only way of protecting one’s honour.
('75', 134, 1, 8, 254120) Such an act would not be termed suicide.
('75', 134, 1, 9, 254161) It would be the triumph of immortal spirit over the ‘muddy vesture of decay’ that our physical body is.
('75', 134, 1, 10, 254265) It has been my unvarying experience that God never tries a satyagrahi beyond his capacity.
('75', 134, 1, 11, 254356) Somehow the strength comes to us when we need it most if we utterly rely on Him.
('75', 134, 1, 12, 254437) But this needs intense preparation and self discipline through ceaseless labour of love.
('75', 134, 1, 13, 254526) Jail going is only a small step and by no means the most important.
('75', 134, 1, 14, 254594) Unaccompanied by the spirit of service, courting imprisonment and inviting beatings and lathi charges becomes a species of violence.
('75', 134, 1, 15, 254727) I would therefore expect every satyagrahi to keep a regular diary and account for every minute of his time in terms of constructive service.
('75', 134, 1, 16, 254868) The path of satyagraha is sharp as a razor’s edge.
('75', 134, 1, 17, 254919) A satyagrahi has to be ever vigilant, always in harness and never for a moment idle.
('75', 134, 1, 18, 255004) Numbers do not matter in satyagraha.
('75', 134, 1, 19, 255041) Even a handful of true satyagrahis, well organized and disciplined through selfless service of the masses, can win independence for India, because behind them will be the power of the silent millions.
('75', 134, 1, 20, 255242) Satyagraha is soul force.
('75', 134, 1, 21, 255268) It is subtle and universal in its action.
('75', 134, 1, 22, 255310) Once it is set in motion it goes forward with gathering momentum and speed till it bursts through all physical barriers and overspreads the whole world.
('75', 134, 2, 23, 255463) At the end of it he suggested to those in charge that the volunteer camp might now be dissolved and such volunteers as were not strictly required for the local work in hand might be sent back to their respective homes.
('75', 134, 2, 24, 255682) Harijan, 25 3 1939

('75', 135, 1, 2, 255743) 169.STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 135, 2, 3, 255772) March 2, 1939 I am sorry to have to say ‘yes’ in answer to your question.
('75', 135, 2, 4, 255846) I am also sorry that the information has leaked out before its time.
('75', 135, 2, 5, 255915) I do not wish as yet to publish my letter.
('75', 135, 2, 6, 255958) 2 All that I would like to say at this critical juncture is that it cost me a night’s rest before I came to the conclusion that if the suspended struggle was not to be revived, and if the atrocities of which I have heard so much and of which I was obliged to make mention in my Press note 3 were also not to be revived, I must adopt some effective remedy to end the agony, and God gave me the remedy.
('75', 135, 2, 7, 256359) The public should not laugh at my connecting God with the proposed step.
('75', 135, 2, 8, 256432) Rightly or wrongly, I know that I have no other resource as a satyagrahi than the assistance of God in every conceivable difficulty, and I would like it to be believed that what may appear to be inexplicable actions of mine are really due to inner promptings.
('75', 135, 2, 9, 256692) It may be a product of my heated imagination.
('75', 135, 2, 10, 256738) If it is so, I prize that imagination as it has served me for a chequered life extending over a period of now nearly over 55 years, because I learned to rely consciously upon God before I was 15 years old.
('75', 135, 2, 11, 256944) One thing more.
('75', 135, 2, 12, 256960) The weapon of fasting, I know, cannot be lightly wielded.
('75', 135, 2, 13, 257018) It can easily savour of violence unless it is used by one skilled in the art.
('75', 135, 2, 14, 257096) I claim to be such an artist in this subject.
('75', 135, 2, 15, 257142) It should be remembered that I am intimately connected with Rajkot and its Rulers.
('75', 135, 2, 16, 257225) Regarding the Thakore Saheb as my own son, I have every right to evoke the best in his nature by means of self suffering.
('75', 135, 2, 17, 257347) If my fast, which I hope will be avoided, is to be interpreted as pressure, I can only say that such moral pressure should be welcomed by all concerned.
('75', 135, 2, 18, 257500) A breach of promise shakes me to my root, especially when I am in any way connected with the author of the breach.
('75', 135, 2, 19, 257615) And if it costs my life, which after all at the age of 70 has no insurance value, I

('75', 137, 0, 1, 260252) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 137, 1, 2, 260294) practical reason of preventing thoughtless imitation, I was most reluctant to undertake this fast.
('75', 137, 1, 3, 260393) But an inner urge brooks no denial.
('75', 137, 1, 4, 260429) I can only therefore warn the people, who may wish hereafter to fast for redress of grievances, real or imaginary, against imitating me.
('75', 137, 1, 5, 260566) Fasting like some very potent medicines can only be taken on rare occasions and under expert guidance.
('75', 137, 1, 6, 260669) It is wrong, it is sinful for everybody to consider himself an expert.
('75', 137, 1, 7, 260740) Let the public know that at a very early age I began fasting for self purification and then I took a prolonged fast 1for an erring son of mine.
('75', 137, 1, 8, 260884) This was soon after followed by a still more prolonged fast 2 for an erring daughter of a very dear friend.
('75', 137, 1, 9, 260992) In both these cases the results justified the fast.
('75', 137, 1, 10, 261044) The first public fast 3 that I undertook was in South Africa in connection with sufferings of the indentured who had joined the satyagraha struggle in South Africa.
('75', 137, 1, 11, 261209) I have no recollection of a single experiment of mine in fasting having been a fruitless effort.
('75', 137, 1, 12, 261306) In addition, I had the experience of priceless peace and unending joy during all those fasts, and I have come to the conclusion that fasting, unless it is the result of God’s grace, is useless starvation, if not much worse.
('75', 137, 1, 13, 261530) The second thing I would like to say is that there should be no bitter speeches or writings either in connection with the Thakore Saheb or his advisers or the Resident.
('75', 137, 1, 14, 261699) I have used strong language in connection with the Resident and actions of State officials.
('75', 137, 1, 15, 261791) If I find that I have in any way wronged them, I know how to make reparations.
('75', 137, 1, 16, 261870) Any harsh language used in connection with the Thakore Saheb or other actors in the tragedy will mar the effect the fast is intended to produce.
('75', 137, 1, 17, 262015) The breach of a solemn pact does not require any harsh or bitter language in order to enhance the enormity of the evil consequences of such breaches.
('75', 137, 1, 18, 262165) What the public and the Press can usefully do is, by a dignified disapproval of the Thakore Saheb’s action, to bring home to him the pressure of enlightened public opinion.
('75', 137, 2, 19, 262338) 1 Presumably, the references are to the week long fast in 1913 for the moral lapse of two inmates at Phoenix Settlement, and the 14 day fast in 1914; vide “An Autobiography”, Fasting As Penance.
('75', 137, 2, 20, 262533) 2 ibid 3 On December 21, 1913, Gandhiji announced his decision to eat only once a day as “mark of inward mourning” for Indians shot dead during the strike by the indentured Indians in Sourth Africa.
('75', 138, 0, 1, 262732) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 139
('75', 138, 1, 2, 262776) All satyagraha and fasting is a species of tyaga 1. It depends for its effects upon an expression of wholesome public opinion, shorn of all bitterness.
('75', 138, 1, 3, 262928) Let there be no impatience to produce the desired result because of fasting.
('75', 138, 1, 4, 263005) He who has urged me to undertake the fast will give me strength to go through it, and if it is His will that I should still live for a while on this earth to carry on the self chosen mission of humanity, no fast, however prolonged, will dissolve the body.
('75', 138, 1, 5, 263261) I am painfully conscious of the fact that my fast 2 in connection with the late Mr. MacDonald’s decision on the communal question induced many persons to act against their will.
('75', 138, 1, 6, 263439) I hope no such thing will happen in connection with this fast.
('75', 138, 1, 7, 263502) If there are public men who think that I have erred in characterizing the Thakore Saheb’s Notification of January 21 as a breach of the promise made by the Notification on December 26, they will perform a friendly act by condemning my characterization, as also the fast.
('75', 138, 1, 8, 263773) It is designed undoubtedly to melt the Thakore Saheb’s heart, but it is in no sense designed to coerce public opinion into bringing pressure to bear upon the Thakore Saheb or those in whose opinion his action may be free of all blame.
('75', 138, 1, 9, 264008) Another thing I would like to mention is the first paragraph of my letter 3 in which I have criticized Durbar Virawala.
('75', 138, 1, 10, 264128) I can truthfully say that I am slow to see the blemishes of fellowbeings, being myself full of them and therefore being in need of their charity.
('75', 138, 1, 11, 264274) I have learnt not to judge anyone harshly and to make allowances for defects that I may detect.
('75', 138, 1, 12, 264370) What has happened about Durbar Virawala is that I have been inundated by very bitter and serious complaints against him.
('75', 138, 1, 13, 264491) In my conversations with him I had even made mention of those complaints, and let me say to his credit that he invited me to investigate those complaints.
('75', 138, 1, 14, 264646) I told him that I would do so, and but for the intervention of the fast it was fully my desire to undertake this investigation.
('75', 138, 1, 15, 264774) I had already invited friends to put me in possession of evidence in support of specific allegations against him; but prolonged conversations with him for three days confirmed the impression that the complaints against him had produced upon me, so much so that I
('75', 138, 2, 16, 265037) 1 Sacrifice 2 In 1932; the “fast unto death”, commenced on September 16, was broken on September 26. 3 Vide “Letter to Dharmendrasinh”
('75', 139, 0, 1, 265172) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 139, 1, 2, 265214) felt that the evidence that the conversations gave me was sufficient proof of the heavy indictment against him.
('75', 139, 1, 3, 265326) What I have said in the first paragraph of my letter is a deliberate understatement of my opinion.
('75', 139, 1, 4, 265425) It gave me much pain to write that paragraph, but it was necessary for my mission to warn the Thakore Saheb of the overpowering influence that he exercises over His Highness.
('75', 139, 1, 5, 265600) Sober and influential persons, not few but many, have repeatedly told me that so long as Durbar Virawala exercises that influence upon the Thakore Saheb there is no peace for the people.
('75', 139, 1, 6, 265787) I myself feel that there is very considerable truth in this statement, and it would be wrong on my part whilst I am embarking upon the fast to suppress this relevant truth from the public.
('75', 139, 1, 7, 265976) I have sent a private and personal letter to him, which, so far as I am concerned, shall never see the light of day.
('75', 139, 1, 8, 266093) But I do make a humble appeal to him, and I would like those who know him to join me in the appeal, that he should refrain from influencing the Thakore Saheb, although the latter may find it difficult to free himself from that influence.
('75', 139, 1, 9, 266331) I can say much more, but I must not.
('75', 139, 1, 10, 266368) Although I have been in exile from Kathiawar for more than a generation and a half, I know how turbid Kathiawar politics is.
('75', 139, 1, 11, 266493) This unfortunate sub province is notorious for its intrigues.
('75', 139, 1, 12, 266555) I have felt its deadly influence even during these four days.
('75', 139, 1, 13, 266617) How I wish that my fast may contribute, be it ever so little, to the purification of Kathiawar politics.
('75', 139, 1, 14, 266722) I therefore invite the Princes and politicians of Kathiawar to use my fast to rid Kathiawar of the deadening influence of the poisonous atmosphere that makes healthy living in Kathiawar so difficult.
('75', 139, 1, 15, 266922) Harijan, 11 3 1939

('75', 141, 0, 1, 269405) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 141, 1, 2, 269447) [It is] agreed seven members of the Committee mentioned in Clause 2 of the State announcement of today’s date 1 are to be recommended by Sardar [Vallabhbhai] Patel and they are to be nominated by us.
('75', 141, 1, 3, 269647) The language is unequivocal and emphatic.
('75', 141, 1, 4, 269689) The Thakore Saheb, in giving that note, divested himself of the responsibility of choosing the nominees.
('75', 141, 1, 5, 269794) The responsibility of nomination rests with the Thakore Saheb, but the nomination is conditioned by the fact that the names had to be recommended by the Sardar.
('75', 141, 1, 6, 269955) Therefore the responsibility for making suitable recommendations devolved upon the Sardar and that devolution took place at the will of the Ruler of Rajkot.
('75', 141, 1, 7, 270112) It was open to the Ruler and his advisers to negotiate with Sardar, if they did not find his recommendations suitable and to induce him to make other recommendations but if the Sardar could not be so persuaded, the Thakore Saheb, having divested himself of the responsibility to choose a nominee, had to accept the Sardar’s recommendations.
('75', 141, 1, 8, 270453) Reason also suggests that if the reference to the committee was to be made good it must be a Committee of the choice of those for whose sake the Notification containing the reference had become necessary.
('75', 141, 1, 9, 270658) Otherwise, what was given with one hand could not be taken away with the other.
('75', 141, 1, 10, 270738) If the choice is left to the Ruler and his advisers, there is nothing to prevent them from appointing a committee which would make recommendations such that they would completely nullify the spirit of the reference.
('75', 141, 1, 11, 270954) However, the matter is past argument.
('75', 141, 1, 12, 270992) If the Thakore Saheb’s letter is the last word, my fast has to continue to the end of my time on this earth.
('75', 141, 1, 13, 271101) I shall undergo the ordeal, I hope, with a cheerful heart, and I know also that what may not take place in my lifetime will take place without the shadow of a doubt after the sacrifice.

('75', 144, 4, 5, 274510) March 3, 1939 There is a misunderstanding about a certain telegram received by me at Segaon, of which I made use in the first Press Note 2 I issued on the eve of my coming to Rajkot.

('75', 144, 5, 10, 275153) There shall be no differentiation in treatment between the Sardhar and Rajkot prisons.
('75', 144, 5, 11, 275240) Glad to inform you that fasting has terminated.
('75', 144, 5, 12, 275288) It will be recalled that one of the telegrams received by me from the First Member made mention of this telegram and said that the telegram received from Shri Nanalal would show that the fasting was unjustified.
('75', 144, 5, 13, 275500) On my coming here I discovered that the omission by me to reproduce this telegram gave rise to the rumour that Shri Nanalal had come to the decision that the fast was not justified.
('75', 144, 5, 14, 275682) There was no mention in this telegram to me to the effect that the fast was not justified.
('75', 144, 5, 15, 275773) It was unnecessary to say in the telegram that the fast was justified because the sender of the telegram and other friends were trying to find out a remedy for dealing with the situation.

('75', 147, 9, 13, 279311) 188. LETTER TO E. C. GIBSON 1
('75', 147, 10, 14, 279341) RASHTRIYASHALA, RAJKOT, March 4, 1939
('75', 147, 11, 15, 279379) DEAR MR. GIBSON, I woke up early this morning and felt like sending to the Press what I am about to write down here.
('75', 147, 11, 16, 279496) I then felt like wiring the contents to H. E. the Viceroy 2. At last the correct thing appeared to me, to pass on my thoughts to you with the request that you should wire them to His Excellency with such remarks as you may choose to make thereon.
('75', 147, 11, 17, 279743) It seems to me that in regarding the Thakore Saheb as a responsible thinking Ruler, I am, or shall I say we are all, giving currency to a fraud.
('75', 147, 11, 18, 279888) I felt this when I sent him day before yesterday my letter 3 embodying my suggestions.
('75', 147, 11, 19, 279975) I do not know if he was allowed even to read it, and if he was, whether he understood it in all its bearings.

('75', 149, 1, 3, 282654) But one omission in my letter to the Thakore Saheb and in the Press statements requires explanation.
('75', 149, 1, 4, 282755) That is in connection with my reference to atrocities in my telegrams which brought me to Rajkot.
('75', 149, 1, 5, 282853) The omission was due to my desire to be absolutely fair to the Khan Saheb and his subordinates, who are primarily responsible for dealing with the actions of civil resisters.
('75', 149, 1, 6, 283028) But the fact that the omission, instead of being appreciated, has been turned against me, 1 compels me to put the actual state of affairs before the public.
('75', 149, 1, 7, 283185) After my visit to the two jails I told the Khan Saheb that I was much moved by the statements made by the prisoners.
('75', 149, 1, 8, 283302) I told him that I was inclined to believe the allegations made by the prisoners, some of whom were personally known to me and many of whom enjoyed in society a status which entitled them to have their evidence believed until it was proved to be untrue.
('75', 149, 1, 9, 283555) I therefore told the Khan Saheb that the allegations were so serious, covered such a wide field, and affected so many persons that the only way I could do justice to the State was to suggest a judicial inquiry by an impartial tribunal.
('75', 149, 1, 10, 283791) For his own part, he at once accepted the suggestion and, at my request, even mentioned the names of certain English officials to conduct the judicial enquiry.
('75', 149, 1, 11, 283951) And it was agreed between us that I should prepare a charge sheet which he would examine and answer and, on his part, he would prepare a counter charge sheet which I would examine and answer.
('75', 149, 1, 12, 284143) After this process had been gone through and agreed charges eliminated, the balance, if any was left, would be referred to the tribunal.
('75', 149, 1, 13, 284280) The Khan Saheb also asked me what reparation I would make if the charges of utter falsehoods which he proposed to make against the civil resisters were found to be true.
('75', 149, 1, 14, 284450) I said that if a representative of the civil resisters was proved to be guilty of falsehoods I would entirely withdraw from the struggle, and so far as I was concerned, I would treat the claim for responsible government by persons capable of falsehoods to have lapsed.
('75', 149, 1, 15, 284719) The Khan Saheb seemed to be more than pleased over the unhesitating reparation that I had offered.

('75', 156, 9, 15, 297194) 197. DISCUSSION WITH AGATHA HARRISON 2
('75', 156, 10, 16, 297233) RAJKOT, March 6, 1939 Somehow I am able to draw the noblest in mankind and that is what enables me to maintain my faith in God and human nature.
('75', 156, 10, 17, 297378) I know Kathiawar, the land of Kathis, very brave soldiers, but full of intrigue and corruption.
('75', 156, 10, 18, 297474) How could I clean these Augean stables except through this vicarious suffering?

('75', 156, 10, 20, 297622) I would not then need to argue with anyone.
('75', 156, 10, 21, 297666) My word would go straight home.
('75', 156, 10, 22, 297698) Indeed, I would not even need to utter the word.
('75', 156, 10, 23, 297747) The mere will on my part would suffice to produce the required effect.
('75', 156, 10, 24, 297818) But I am painfully aware of my limitations.
('75', 156, 10, 25, 297862) That is why I have to undergo all this to make myself heard.

('75', 157, 0, 1, 298090) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 157, 1, 2, 298132) The other way, namely, that of civil resistance, I deliberately ruled out in this case, because from what I could see it would have, under the existing circumstances, only served further to arouse the brute in those in power.
('75', 157, 1, 3, 298358) The aim of a satyagrahi, on the othere hand, always is to put the brute in everyone to sleep.
('75', 157, 1, 4, 298452) By suffering myself I have saved the suffering on the part of the people which would have been inevitable in case civil resistance was revived.
('75', 157, 1, 5, 298596) There is nothing but an indescribable peace and spiritual exultation within me.
('75', 157, 1, 6, 298676) There is no trace of ill will in my heart against anybody.
('75', 157, 1, 7, 298735) I am making a ceaseless, strenuous effort not to be irritated.
('75', 157, 1, 8, 298798) My heart is overflowing.

('75', 158, 2, 3, 299962) RASHTRIYASHALA, RAJKOT March 7, 1939
('75', 158, 3, 4, 299999) DEAR MR. GIBSON, I have received your kind letter, and as I wanted some points to be cleared you were good enough to come to me and discuss them.
('75', 158, 3, 5, 300145) In my present state I want to conserve my energy and therefore I do not want to reduce them to writing.
('75', 158, 3, 6, 300249) I will ask you please to wire the following message to His Excellency: “I am grateful to you for your prompt reply 1 which was delivered to me at 10. 45 today.
('75', 158, 3, 7, 300409) Although naturally it leaves several things unsaid, I regard your kind message as sufficient warrant for breaking the fast and ending the anxiety of millions who are following the fast with their prayers and such effort as they can make to hasten the settlement.
('75', 158, 3, 8, 300672) It is only proper for me to say that those things [which ] are not mentioned in your message are not waived by me but that I should expect satisfaction on them.
('75', 158, 3, 9, 300833) They can however await mutual discussion.
('75', 158, 3, 10, 300875) As soon as the doctors permit me to undertake a journey to Delhi I shall do so.
('75', 158, 3, 11, 300955) I thank you once more for taking up so promptly and so sympathetically the matter that necessitated the fast.
('75', 158, 3, 12, 301065) I hope that the prisoners will be released as soon as possible today.
('75', 158, 3, 13, 301135) I await your reply as to publication before breaking the fast." 2
('75', 158, 4, 14, 301201) Yours sincerely,

('75', 159, 1, 2, 302029) 200. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 159, 2, 3, 302059) March 7, 1939 In my opinion this good ending is an answer to the prayers of millions.
('75', 159, 2, 4, 302145) I claim to know my millions.
('75', 159, 2, 5, 302174) All the 24 hours of the day I am with them.
('75', 159, 2, 6, 302218) They are my first care and last, because I recognize no God except the God that is to be found in the hearts of the dumb millions.
('75', 159, 2, 7, 302349) They do not recognize His presence; I do.
('75', 159, 2, 8, 302391) And I worship the God that is Truth or Truth which is God through the service of these millions.
('75', 159, 2, 9, 302488) But I also know I had the prayers and sympathy of others all the world over.
('75', 159, 2, 10, 302565) And there was a persistent effort of the intelligentsia in order to bring about an honourable understanding and a speedy end of this fast.
('75', 159, 2, 11, 302704) Englishmen have co operated as well as Indians.
('75', 159, 2, 12, 302752) Politically speaking, it is His Excellency the Viceroy who is responsible for the settlement.
('75', 159, 2, 13, 302846) I know Englishmen do not understand the method of fast, especially on what would appear to be a purely political issue.
('75', 159, 2, 14, 302966) They often feel disgusted with such method.
('75', 159, 2, 15, 303010) I know also there are Indians who do not appreciate the method of fast.
('75', 159, 2, 16, 303082) I hope, when I am strong, to write 1 about ‘The Fast Method’, because over 50 years’ experience has convinced me that in the plan of satyagraha it has a definite place.
('75', 159, 2, 17, 303251) The reason why I bring fast here is because I want to give full valuation to the Viceregal gesture, and he represents the English mind.
('75', 159, 2, 18, 303387) It was open to him—and I at least would have justified his action—If he had said: ‘I do not understand this man’s actions.
('75', 159, 2, 19, 303510) There seems to be no end to his fasts.
('75', 159, 2, 20, 303549) There must be a stop somewhere.
('75', 159, 2, 21, 303581) He will give no guarantee that this is his last fast.
('75', 159, 2, 22, 303635) We propose even this time not to parley with him until he has broken his fast.’ I know that, ethically speaking, he would have been wrong if he had taken up that attitude, but, politically speaking and examining the position from the English standpoint, I would have justified his action if he had been unbending.
('75', 159, 2, 23, 303949) I am hoping that such a good ending and appreciation even of a method which the English mind cannot
('75', 159, 3, 24, 304049) 1 This appeared under the title “A Good Ending”.
('75', 159, 3, 25, 304098) In “The Rajkot Fast –IV”, Pyarelal reports : “The fast was broken with the usual ceremonies at 2.20 p.m.
('75', 159, 3, 26, 304203) From 2.30 to 3.20 Gandhiji dictated a long statement to the Press.” 1 Vide “Fasting”
('75', 160, 0, 1, 304288) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 161
('75', 160, 1, 2, 304332) understand will produce not merely the righting of what I have held to be a primary wrong, but it will clear the atmosphere and help also in the general solution of the States’ problem.
('75', 160, 1, 3, 304518) I do not mean to say that all States will have to follow the Rajkot precedent.
('75', 160, 1, 4, 304597) Rajkot is a speciality and must be regarded as an isolated case.
('75', 160, 1, 5, 304662) There are States whose problems must be considered on their merits.
('75', 160, 1, 6, 304730) But public attention is rivetted on the problem of the States.
('75', 160, 1, 7, 304793) I hope it will be recognized that it is a problem which does not brook delay.
('75', 160, 1, 8, 304871) I would like the Princes to believe me when I assure them that I came to Rajkot as their friend and as a cent percent peacemaker.
('75', 160, 1, 9, 305001) I saw that civil resisters in Rajkot were, and could not but be, unyielding.
('75', 160, 1, 10, 305078) Their honour was at stake.
('75', 160, 1, 11, 305105) I had tales of atrocities poured into my ears.
('75', 160, 1, 12, 305152) I felt that the basest human passions would be let loose if I allowed civil resistance to go on from day to day.
('75', 160, 1, 13, 305265) That would have resulted in a bitter feud not merely between Rajkot and the civil resisters but—as the human mind works and even jumps from the particular to the general—there would have been a bitter feud between the Princes and the people.
('75', 160, 1, 14, 305507) I know that, even as it is, there is a growing school of public opinion in India which is convinced that the Princes are beyond reform, and that there would be no free India unless this ‘relic of a barbaric past’ is done away with.
('75', 160, 1, 15, 305739) I honestly differ with them, and, as a believer in non violence and therefore in the goodness of human nature, I could not do otherwise.
('75', 160, 1, 16, 305876) They have a place in India.
('75', 160, 1, 17, 305904) It is not possible to wipe out all the traditions of a hoary past.
('75', 160, 1, 18, 305971) I therefore hold that if the Princes will read from the lessons of the past and will respond to the time spirit, all will be well.
('75', 160, 1, 19, 306102) But it will not do to tinker with the problem.
('75', 160, 1, 20, 306149) They will have to take heroic measures.
('75', 160, 1, 21, 306189) They need not follow the Rajkot model, but they will have to part with real and substantial powers in favour of the people.
('75', 160, 1, 22, 306313) There is, so far as I am aware, no via media of saving the situation and saving India from a terrible blood feud.
('75', 160, 1, 23, 306427) I dare not publish the letters that I have received about the Princes, but of this I shall have to speak more later.
('75', 160, 1, 24, 306544) In my present weak state of health it is an effort to give this statement.
('75', 160, 1, 25, 306619) And yet whilst the effect of the fast is on me and whilst I am full of what I call spiritual exultation, I must give out the best of my thoughts just now.

('75', 161, 1, 2, 306816) Then there are the Bhayats 1 and Garasias 2 .
('75', 161, 1, 3, 306862) They pleaded with me their case.
('75', 161, 1, 4, 306895) I told them that they had my sympathy.
('75', 161, 1, 5, 306934) They could count upon me as their friend.
('75', 161, 1, 6, 306976) I want them also to live as Garasias and Bhayats, but they will also have to march with the times.
('75', 161, 1, 7, 307075) They will have to remodel their lives.
('75', 161, 1, 8, 307114) They will have to feel one with the people over whom they exercise a kind of sway.
('75', 161, 1, 9, 307197) Our Mussalman friends came to me, and I had no hesitation in telling them without any argument that their special interests would be safeguarded, that if they wanted separate electorates in Rajkot with reservation of seats I would see to it that they got them.
('75', 161, 1, 10, 307458) Without their asking they would have had ample guarantees for the fullest protection of their religious freedom.
('75', 161, 1, 11, 307571) And I told them that if they insisted upon their nominations, I would not resist them.
('75', 161, 1, 12, 307658) It is necessary for me to say this in order to ease their minds and to ease the minds of the Mussalmans throughout India.
('75', 161, 1, 13, 307780) I want them to feel that neither I nor the Congress can ever be guilty of diminishing an iota of the safeguards that they may need for their full growth and for the protection of their faith and culture.
('75', 161, 1, 14, 307984) I must explain why I have released for publication only the Viceregal telegraphic message received today at 10·45 a.m.
('75', 161, 1, 15, 308103) and my reply.
('75', 161, 1, 16, 308117) There is an allusion to previous messages in these two communications.
('75', 161, 1, 17, 308188) With the full consent of the Viceroy, I am refraining from publishing those communications.
('75', 161, 1, 18, 308280) His Excellency has not prevented me from publishing them.
('75', 161, 1, 19, 308338) I know that he does not believe in sending secret communications to public men, but, for reasons which I need not go into, I felt the force of the argument that, for the sake of the cause, it is not wise to publish them.
('75', 161, 1, 20, 308559) I hope that it will never be necessary to publish them.
('75', 161, 1, 21, 308615) There are in my communications allusions which were relevant, but they are not for the public.
('75', 161, 1, 22, 308710) Hence the responsibility for withholding previous communications is solely mine.
('75', 161, 1, 23, 308791) One word about the Congress.
('75', 161, 1, 24, 308820) My heart is there, but I see that I will not be able to reach there.
('75', 161, 1, 25, 308889) I am still too weak but, what is more, if I am to give the finishing touch to the Rajkot matter and what it implies, I must not divide my attention between Tripuri and Rajkot.
('75', 161, 1, 26, 309065) I must concentrate my attention solely on Rajkot at present.
('75', 161, 1, 27, 309126) I have work

('75', 162, 1, 2, 309274) to do here.
('75', 162, 1, 3, 309286) I must hasten to Delhi as soon as I am able.
('75', 162, 1, 4, 309331) I only hope that all will go well in Tripuri.
('75', 162, 1, 5, 309377) It is a strange experience for me to miss the Congress session through all these years.
('75', 162, 1, 6, 309465) But it is a good thing.
('75', 162, 1, 7, 309489) Why should I be so proud as to think that nothing serious can be done without me?
('75', 162, 1, 8, 309571) There are leaders in Tripuri who are every whit as courageous, as self sacrificing and as devoted as I am.
('75', 162, 1, 9, 309678) I have no doubt, therefore, that though another policy may be evolved, there will be no acrimony and there will be no violence in their thoughts, in their words and in their deeds.
('75', 162, 1, 10, 309859) The last thing I would like to say is that I want to thank the Press correspondents who have been with me during all these anxious days.
('75', 162, 1, 11, 309996) I have felt proud of them.
('75', 162, 1, 12, 310023) They have carried out the best traditions of good journalism.
('75', 162, 1, 13, 310085) They have not been newsmongers but they have been fellow messengers of peace with me.

('75', 162, 1, 15, 310218) They have never pestered me.
('75', 162, 1, 16, 310247) I should like also publicly to thank my medical friends who have so ungrudgingly attended upon me.

('75', 162, 1, 18, 310420) In a way, my work begins from now.
('75', 162, 1, 19, 310455) I begin to lead an earthly life.
('75', 162, 1, 20, 310488) I have to carry on delicate negotiations.
('75', 162, 1, 21, 310530) I do not want to lose the goodwill with which I am surcharged at the present moment.
('75', 162, 1, 22, 310615) I think of the Thakore Saheb, I think of Durbar Shri Virawala.
('75', 162, 1, 23, 310678) I have criticized them.
('75', 162, 1, 24, 310702) but only as a friend.
('75', 162, 1, 25, 310724) I repeat that I am in the place of a father to the Thakore Saheb.
('75', 162, 1, 26, 310790) I have done no more towards him than I could have done to my truant son.
('75', 162, 1, 27, 310863) I would like them to understand the significance of what has gone on in front of them, and it would be a noble ending to this fast if I discover that they have appreciated all that I have said as from a friend, and that there will be the response from them that I expect.
('75', 162, 1, 28, 311135) Rajkot is the hub of Kathiawar, and if Rajkot is given a popular government, other States in Kathiawar will of their own accord and without any further civil resistance fall in line.
('75', 162, 1, 29, 311318) There is no such thing as perfect coincidences on this earth.
('75', 162, 1, 30, 311380) Its beauty lies in its multitudinous variety.
('75', 162, 1, 31, 311426) There will be, therefore, variety of constitutions in Kathiawar States.
('75', 162, 1, 32, 311498) But let the trunk be true.

('75', 164, 12, 18, 312892) 206. ITS MEANING
('75', 164, 13, 19, 312909) A critic may say: ‘What have you gained to warrant the breaking of your fast?
('75', 164, 13, 20, 312987) Not one of the terms of your ultimatum to the Thakore Saheb has been fulfilled except the release of prisoners.
('75', 164, 13, 21, 313099) But you never took the fast for their release.’ On the surface this argument is perfect.
('75', 164, 13, 22, 313188) It is consistent with a vengeance.
('75', 164, 13, 23, 313223) My answer is, ‘The letter killeth; the spirit giveth life.’ The life giving fact is that Rajkot has become an all India issue and the place of the Thakore Saheb has been taken up by the Viceroy whose word I have no reason to doubt.
('75', 164, 13, 24, 313455) Even if the Thakore Saheb had granted all my terms, I should not have been sure of due fulfilment,
('75', 164, 14, 25, 313554) 1 The telegram was reported under the date line “Madras, March 8”, as released by S. Ambujammal, Honorary Secretary, Women’s Indian Association.
('75', 164, 14, 26, 313699) It was in reply to the Association’s telegram dated March 6, which read : “Women’s Indian Association feels intensely grieved, anxious at decision.
('75', 164, 14, 27, 313847) Prays Almighty to give strength and success.” Vide also the two preceding items.
('75', 164, 14, 28, 313928) 2 ibid 3 The telegram was reported under the date line “Tripuri, March 8”.
('75', 164, 14, 29, 314003) It was in reply to the addressee’s of March 7, which he had sent “on behalf of the Reception Committee”.

('75', 165, 1, 3, 314199) What I have deliberately put in doubt is the meaning of the famous letter 1 given to the Sardar.
('75', 165, 1, 4, 314296) In my ultimatum I had acted on the assumption that it bore only one meaning.
('75', 165, 1, 5, 314373) But as a satyagrahi I must always allow my cards to be examined and re examined at all times and make reparation if an error is discovered.
('75', 165, 1, 6, 314513) Hence my reading of the settlement is that God has given me much more than I had ever expected.

('75', 166, 1, 2, 315516) 209. TALK WITH AGATHA HARRISON 1
('75', 166, 2, 3, 315549) March 8, 1939
('75', 166, 3, 4, 315563) Agatha had an interesting talk with Gandhiji in the morning and then in the afternoon.
('75', 166, 3, 5, 315650) In the course of it she asked him the question, “Now that the Paramount Power has been appealed to intervene, would it be consistent with this attitude to go on with the anti imperialist cry?
('75', 166, 3, 6, 315842) In other words, would it be right from your viewpoint to make use of the machinery set up by the imperialist power whilst you are pledged to the anti imperialist goal ?”
('75', 166, 4, 7, 316012) Gandhiji explained to her that the inconsistency to which she referred was in appearance only.
('75', 166, 4, 8, 316107) Non violent non co operation did not mean mechanical isolation or complete avoidance of contact with the opponent under all conditions.
('75', 166, 4, 9, 316243) In seeking intervention of the Paramount Power he had put the Paramount Power on the trial and given it a chance to do the right thing.
('75', 166, 4, 10, 316379) The Paramount Power has so far constantly been helping the Princes in their misrule.
('75', 166, 4, 11, 316464) But it owes also an obligation to the people.
('75', 166, 4, 12, 316510) The people of Rajkot have now asked the Paramount Power to meet that obligation.
('75', 166, 4, 13, 316591) Not to do so when an opportunity occurs would be not non co operation, it would be folly.
('75', 166, 4, 14, 316681) It may even lead to the strengthening of the Paramount Power.
('75', 166, 4, 15, 316743) Although non co operation is one of the main weapons in the armoury of satyagraha, it should not be forgotten that it is after all only a means to secure the co operation of the opponent consistently with truth and justice.
('75', 166, 4, 16, 316967) The essence of non violence technique is that it seeks to liquidate antagonisms but not the antagonists themselves.
('75', 166, 4, 17, 317083) In non violent fight you have to a certain measure to conform to the traditions and conventions of the system you are pitted against.
('75', 166, 4, 18, 317217) Avoidance of all relationship with the opposing power, therefore, can never be a satyagrahi’s object, but transformation or purification of that relationship.
('75', 166, 4, 19, 317376) The people of Rajkot would never be able to end the dominance of the Paramount Power through non violent means if they said, ‘We shall not touch it even with a pair of tongs; we shall refuse to meet it even for the sake of converting it.’
('75', 166, 5, 20, 317615) The field of co operation between the Paramount Power and the people of the States was likely to grow rather than diminish with the growth of non violent strength and consciousness among the people.
('75', 166, 5, 21, 317814) In fact he foresaw a time when the Residents and Political Agents in Indian States would become true trustees and servants of the people on behalf of the Paramount Power and be made use of by them
('75', 166, 6, 22, 318011) 1 This is extracted from “The Rajkot Fast–V” by Pyarelal.
('75', 167, 0, 1, 318069) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 167, 1, 2, 318111) as such.
('75', 167, 2, 3, 318120) The Congress had advised the country to boycott the reformed legislatures at the beginning of the non co operation movement.
('75', 167, 2, 4, 318245) It regarded them as a trap and a snare.
('75', 167, 2, 5, 318285) But as a result of phenomenal awakening that had taken place among the masses as a result of the schooling they got through successive civil disobedience campaigns, and the ensuing relative transformation of relationship between them and the Government, in 1937 it decided to capture the machinery of Government in the seven provinces where the Congress commanded a majority.
('75', 167, 3, 6, 318661) His seeking the intervention of the Paramount Power in the present case, therefore, did not necessarily imply any fundamental change in his outlook.
('75', 167, 3, 7, 318810) On the contrary it was a further step towards the ending of that system as it exists and functions today.

('75', 170, 4, 16, 324446) March 9, 1939
('75', 170, 5, 17, 324460) One of the workers had admitted in the course of his talk that he accepted non violence as a policy, not as his creed.
('75', 170, 5, 18, 324579) Gandhiji explained to him that he could be satisfied with that provided the acceptance was whole hearted and sincere.
('75', 170, 5, 19, 324697) It must be without any mental reservations.
('75', 170, 5, 20, 324741) The greater danger was that although many people professed to believe in non violence, not all of them meant the same thing by that term.
('75', 170, 5, 21, 324879) Himsa did not merely mean indulgence in physical violence; resort to trickery, falsehood, intrigue, chicanery and deceitfulness—in short, all unfair and foul means—came under the category of himsa, and acceptance of ahimsa whether as a policy or a creed necessarily implied renunciation of all these things.
('75', 170, 6, 22, 325187) A votary of ahimsa had therefore to be incorruptible, fair and square in his

('75', 171, 1, 5, 325605) The controversy about ‘creed’ or ‘policy’ could be put aside if there was a clear, common understanding on this point.

('75', 173, 0, 1, 328171) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 173, 1, 2, 328213) 221. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 173, 2, 3, 328243) RAJKOT, March 11, 1939 Having been out of touch with everything since my leaving Segaon, that is, for nearly a fortnight, I do not feel competent to give a decisive opinion upon the impending resumption of civil resistance in Travancore.
('75', 173, 2, 4, 328481) But I have no difficulty in stating certain general principles.
('75', 173, 2, 5, 328545) The first indispensable condition precedent to any civil resistance is that there should be surety against any outbreak of violence whether on the part of those who are identified with civil resistance or on the part of the general public.
('75', 173, 2, 6, 328785) It would be no answer in the case of an outbreak of violence that it was instigated by the State or other agencies hostile to civil resisters.
('75', 173, 2, 7, 328928) It should be obvious that civil resistance cannot flourish in an atmosphere of violence.
('75', 173, 2, 8, 329017) This does not mean that the resources of a satyagrahi have come to an end.
('75', 173, 2, 9, 329092) Ways other than civil disobedience should be found out.
('75', 173, 2, 10, 329148) The second condition is that disobedience should not be destructive, that is, harmful to the country.
('75', 173, 2, 11, 329250) The laws to be picked up, therefore, should be those which are harmful to the people or laws whose breach will not harm the people but are likely merely to make more work for the authorities.
('75', 173, 2, 12, 329442) Thirdly, it must be a movement in which the largest number of people can take part.
('75', 173, 2, 13, 329526) Fourthly, students should not be invited or allowed to take part in civil resistance.
('75', 173, 2, 14, 329612) There should be no secrecy.
('75', 173, 2, 15, 329640) Civil resisters must conform to the minimum requirements that may be laid down for the sake of discipline or otherwise.
('75', 173, 3, 16, 329760) Asked why he called the students to come out of the colleges and schools in 1921 and to participate in non co operation and why he was opposed now to students’ participation in the civil resistance movement, Gandhiji explained that the position then was different.
('75', 173, 3, 17, 330025) He asked the students to empty the colleges and schools as signifying complete non co operation with the Government.
('75', 173, 3, 18, 330142) The moment a student came out of the college, he became a citizen—when he was free to participate in the movement.
('75', 173, 3, 19, 330257) Gandhiji would have no quarrel if students left the colleges altogether and participated in the movement.
('75', 173, 3, 20, 330363) Harijan 18 3 1939; also The Hindu, 11 3 1939
('75', 173, 4, 21, 330408) 1 In Harijan this appeared under the title “Travancore” with an explanatory note that Gandhiji made this statement when he was shown the report about the Travancore State Congress having resolved on reviving civil resistance on March 25. 2 What follows is from The Hindu.
('75', 174, 0, 1, 330680) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 175
('75', 174, 1, 2, 330724) 222. TALK WITH WORKERS OF RAJKOT PRAJA PARISHAD
('75', 174, 2, 3, 330772) March 12, 1939 I think the initial mistake was made when all Kathiawaris were permitted to join Rajkot Satyagraha.
('75', 174, 2, 4, 330887) That step introduced an element of weakness in the fight.
('75', 174, 2, 5, 330945) Thereby we put our reliance on numbers, whereas a satyagrahi relies solely upon God who is the help of the helpless.
('75', 174, 2, 6, 331062) A satyagrahi always says to himself, ‘He, in whose name satyagraha was launched, will also see it through.’ If the people of Rajkot had thought in these terms, there would have been no temptation to organize big processions or mass demonstrations and probably there would have been no atrocities such as Rajkot has had to experience.
('75', 174, 2, 7, 331396) A genuine satyagrahi proceeds by setting the opponent at his ease.
('75', 174, 2, 8, 331463) His action never creates panic in the breast of the ‘enemy’.
('75', 174, 2, 9, 331524) Supposing as a result of rigid enforcement of the rules of satyagrahis Rajkot satyagraha had been confined to a few hundred or even a few score true satyagrahis and they had carried on their satyagraha in the right spirit till their last breath, theirs would have served as a heroic example.
('75', 174, 2, 10, 331816) I shall soon be going to Delhi as your representative.
('75', 174, 2, 11, 331871) I shall not be able to proceed with my work with self confidence or to speak with authority unless I have the confidence that we shall be able to vindicate and do justice to the devolution of power into the hands of the people that we are fighting for.
('75', 174, 2, 12, 332124) As a lifelong devotee and votary of truth, I know that my pleading will be ineffectual, it will lack power, unless it has the double backing of faith on my part in the inherent justice of the cause that I represent and in the capacity and sincerity of purpose of those who represent this cause.
('75', 174, 2, 13, 332419) The question that you must seriously set yourself to answer is: ‘What shall we do with swaraj, supposing we got it today?’ 1
('75', 174, 3, 14, 332544) You want democracy—the rule of the people, by the people, for the people.
('75', 174, 3, 15, 332618) Surely, all the 75,000 people of Rajkot cannot become rulers or administrators.
('75', 174, 3, 16, 332698) Democracy must in essence, therefore, mean the art and science of mobilizing the entire physical, economic and
('75', 174, 4, 17, 332809) 1 This and the preceding paragraph are extracted from “The Rajkot Fast VI” by Pyarelal; what follows is from “The Rajkot Fast—VII” (Harijan, 27 5 1939).
('75', 175, 0, 1, 332962) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 175, 1, 2, 333004) spiritual resources of all the various sections of the people in the service of the common good of all.
('75', 175, 1, 3, 333108) Service of the family has been the motive behind all our activities hitherto.
('75', 175, 1, 4, 333186) We must now learn to broaden our outlook so as to include in our ambit the service of the people as a whole.
('75', 175, 1, 5, 333295) We are familiar with several conceptions of village work.
('75', 175, 1, 6, 333353) Hitherto it has mostly meant propaganda in the villages to inculcate upon the village masses a sense of their rights.
('75', 175, 1, 7, 333471) Sometimes it has also meant conducting welfare activitiy among them to ameliorate their material condition.
('75', 175, 1, 8, 333579) But the village work that I have now come to place before you consists in educating the villager in his duties.
('75', 175, 1, 9, 333691) Rights accrue automatically to him who duly performs his duties.
('75', 175, 1, 10, 333756) In fact the right to perform one’s duties is the only right that is worth living for and dying for.
('75', 175, 1, 11, 333856) It covers all legitimate rights.
('75', 175, 1, 12, 333889) All the rest is garb under one guise or another and contains in it seeds of himsa.
('75', 175, 1, 13, 333972) The swaraj of my conception will come only when all of us are firmly persuaded that our swaraj has got to be won, worked and maintained through truth and ahimsa alone.
('75', 175, 1, 14, 334140) True democracy or the swaraj of the masses can never come through untruthful and violent means, for the simple reason that the natural corollary to their use would be to remove all opposition through the suppression or extermination of the antagonists.
('75', 175, 1, 15, 334393) That does not make for individual freedom.
('75', 175, 1, 16, 334436) Individual freedom can have the fullest play only under a regime of unadulterated ahimsa.
('75', 175, 1, 17, 334526) We cannot afford to have discord in our midst if we are to educate the people.
('75', 175, 1, 18, 334605) We must all speak with one voice.
('75', 175, 1, 19, 334639) If we want to weld the various sections into one people—and that is the sine qua non of democracy—we may not, in rendering service, make any distinction between those who took part in our struggle and those who did not.
('75', 175, 2, 20, 334859) Harijan, 20 5 1939 and 27 5 1939
('75', 175, 3, 21, 334892) 1 Vide also “Appeal to People of Rajkot”, 13 3 1939
('75', 176, 0, 1, 334944) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 177
('75', 176, 1, 2, 334988) 223. FASTING
('75', 176, 2, 3, 335001) Fasting in an institution as old as Adam.
('75', 176, 2, 4, 335043) It has been resorted to for self purification or for some ends noble as well as ignoble.
('75', 176, 2, 5, 335132) Buddha, Jesus and Mahomed fasted so as to see God face to face.
('75', 176, 2, 6, 335196) Ramachandra fasted for the sea to give way for his army of monkeys.
('75', 176, 2, 7, 335264) Parvati fasted to secure Mahadev Himself as her Lord and Master.
('75', 176, 2, 8, 335329) In my fasts I have but followed these great examples no doubt for ends much less noble than theirs.
('75', 176, 2, 9, 335429) I do not propose to discuss the merits of my recent fast beyond answering a suggestion whether I left Segaon with the knowledge that I was going to fast.
('75', 176, 2, 10, 335583) I have become a coward of late for fasting.
('75', 176, 2, 11, 335627) My fast in August 1933though short lived was a perfect torture to me.
('75', 176, 2, 12, 335697) I had prepared for death the very day I was discharged.
('75', 176, 2, 13, 335753) I had made over many of my medical stores to the nurse in charge.
('75', 176, 2, 14, 335819) Since then I have dreaded fasts.
('75', 176, 2, 15, 335852) The twenty four hour annual fasts of 6th 1 and 13th 2 April have shown me since then that my system is ill able to undergo any protracted fasting.
('75', 176, 2, 16, 335999) Therefore when I left Segaon there could be no question of my light heartedly thinking ahead of any fast in Rajkot.
('75', 176, 2, 17, 336115) Had I made any such resolution, I was bound by a promise to friends that I should give them due notice.
('75', 176, 2, 18, 336219) Thus there could be no pre meditation.
('75', 176, 2, 19, 336258) It came upon me all of a sudden and out of the intense agony of the soul.
('75', 176, 2, 20, 336332) The days preceding the fast were days of deepest prayer.
('75', 176, 2, 21, 336389) The experience of the night before the determination to take the fast had choked me.
('75', 176, 2, 22, 336474) I did not know what to do.
('75', 176, 2, 23, 336501) The morning following told me what I was to do, cost what it might.

('75', 177, 1, 4, 337273) I seem to be made for it.

('75', 177, 3, 13, 338267) 224. APPEAL TO PEOPLE OF RAJKOT 1
('75', 177, 4, 14, 338301) March 13, 1939 In swaraj based on ahimsa people need not know their rights, but it is necessary for them to know their duties.
('75', 177, 4, 15, 338428) There is no duty but creates a corresponding right, and those only are true rights which flow from a due performance of one’s duties.
('75', 177, 4, 16, 338562) Hence rights of true citizenship accrue only to those who serve the State to which they belong.
('75', 177, 4, 17, 338658) And they alone can do justice to the rights that accrue to them.
('75', 177, 4, 18, 338723) Everyone possesses the right to tell lies or resort to goondaism.
('75', 177, 4, 19, 338789) But the exercise of such a right is harmful both to the exerciser and society.
('75', 177, 4, 20, 338868) But to him who observes truth and non violence comes prestige, and prestige brings rights.
('75', 177, 4, 21, 338959) And people who obtain rights as a result of performance of duty, exercise them only for the service of society, never for themselves.
('75', 177, 4, 22, 339093) Swaraj of a people means the sum total
('75', 177, 5, 23, 339132) 1 This appeared under the title “To the People of Rajkot” as “the translation” of Gandhiji’s second appeal.
('75', 177, 5, 24, 339240) For the first appeal, vide “Appeal to People of Rajkot”, 9 3 1939
('75', 178, 0, 1, 339306) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 179
('75', 178, 1, 2, 339350) of the swaraj (self rule) of individuals.
('75', 178, 1, 3, 339392) And such swaraj comes only from performance by individuals of their duty as citizens.
('75', 178, 1, 4, 339478) In it no one thinks of his rights.
('75', 178, 1, 5, 339513) They come, when they are needed, for better performance of duty.
('75', 178, 1, 6, 339578) Whilst I was expounding these views to a meeting of workers it was decided that volunteers should be called for who would go to the villages and tell the people what under swaraj they would be expected to do.
('75', 178, 1, 7, 339787) Thus men or women who would go to the villages would tell the village people that it would be their duty to keep their village clean and make them self supporting.
('75', 178, 1, 8, 339951) They must not expect the swaraj government to do these things for them.
('75', 178, 1, 9, 340023) Our villages are on the verge of destruction owing to the disappearance of village industries.
('75', 178, 1, 10, 340118) They can be revivified only by a revival of village industries.
('75', 178, 1, 11, 340182) Among these industries the spinning wheel occupies the centre.
('75', 178, 1, 12, 340245) The others easily arrange themselves around the wheel.
('75', 178, 1, 13, 340300) If the people of Rajkot realize their duty, they would wear khadi of their own spinning.
('75', 178, 1, 14, 340389) Thus everybody will learn the value of industry, and if all will engage in industries conducive to the welfare of the State, several lakhs of rupees will be saved for the people by the people.
('75', 178, 1, 15, 340582) And it can be shown that by putting into practice the ideal of self help and self sufficiency they will have to pay the lowest taxes and realize a greater degree of happiness in the sum than is possible under any other system.
('75', 178, 1, 16, 340809) Those who labour for the State pay their taxes just as much as those that pay them in coin.
('75', 178, 1, 17, 340901) Coins are but a measure of labour performed.
('75', 178, 1, 18, 340946) They have no other value.
('75', 178, 1, 19, 340972) If I buy a rupee worth of flour, I have paid for the labour of cultivation, carrying and grinding.
('75', 178, 1, 20, 341071) Therefore, the real owner of wealth is one who puts in a certain amount of labour with a conscious productive aim.
('75', 178, 1, 21, 341186) It is the same thing whether I pay the State one rupee or its equivalent of labour as tax.
('75', 178, 1, 22, 341277) Often it will be found that payment in labour is of greater value to the State than payment in coin.
('75', 178, 1, 23, 341378) Payment in labour invigorates the nation.
('75', 178, 1, 24, 341420) Where people perform labour voluntarily for the service of society, exchange of money becomes unnecessary.
('75', 178, 1, 25, 341527) The labour of collecting the taxes and keeping accounts is saved and the results are equally good.
('75', 178, 1, 26, 341626) Every man and woman should be educated along the lines mentioned above.
('75', 178, 1, 27, 341698) The property of the State is the property of the people, the Thakore Saheb is their trustee.
('75', 178, 1, 28, 341791) As trustee the Thakore Saheb and other members of his family should perform their duty.
('75', 178, 1, 29, 341879) Through the performance of their duty to the State they earn the right of taking a certain amount of money from the State.
('75', 178, 1, 30, 342002) If the Ruler and
('75', 179, 0, 1, 342019) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 179, 1, 2, 342061) the ruled perform their duty in this way, there is no room for mutual bitterness.
('75', 179, 1, 3, 342143) Under responsible government everyone, from the king to the poorest citizen, must prosper.
('75', 179, 1, 4, 342234) Under swaraj based on non violence nobody is anybody’s enemy, everybody contributes his or her due quota to the common goal, all can read and write, and their knowledge keeps growing from day to day.
('75', 179, 1, 5, 342434) Sickness and disease are reduced to the minimum.
('75', 179, 1, 6, 342483) No one is a pauper and labour can always find employment.
('75', 179, 1, 7, 342541) There is no place under such a government for gambling, drinking and immorality or for class hatred.
('75', 179, 1, 8, 342642) The rich will use their riches wisely and usefully, and not squander them in increasing their pomp and worldly pleasures.
('75', 179, 1, 9, 342764) It should not happen that a handful of rich people should live in jewelled palaces and the millions in miserable hovels devoid of sunlight or ventilation.
('75', 179, 1, 10, 342919) Hindu Muslim differences, untouchability, vertical differences between high and low, these must not be.

('75', 179, 1, 16, 343386) In a well organized State, usurpation should be an impossibility and it should be unnecessary to resort to force for dispossessing a usurper.

('75', 179, 1, 21, 343835) The conference of the Garasias is in session at Rajkot at the present moment.
('75', 179, 1, 22, 343913) They had an orderly procession today, part of which I witnessed from my bed.

('75', 179, 1, 24, 344059) They are so good as to arrest attention.

('75', 185, 5, 9, 354680) 230. DISCUSSION WITH PHILIPOSE 2
('75', 185, 6, 10, 354713) DELHI, March 15, 1939 Satyagraha does not begin and end with civil disobedience.
('75', 185, 6, 11, 354794) Let us do a little more tapascharya which is the essence of satyagraha.
('75', 185, 6, 12, 354866) Suspension thus conceived can never do harm to the movement.
('75', 185, 6, 13, 354927) The opponent will find that his battery is exhausted when we do not act up to his expectation, refuse to have any firework displays or put ourselves at his disposal for brutal assaults of his goondas.
('75', 185, 6, 14, 355128) We must meet all his provocative and repressive measures with a coolness and an exemplary self restraint even at the risk of being charged with cowardice.
('75', 185, 6, 15, 355283) If there is no cowardice in us, we are safe; ours will ultimately be reckoned an act of rare bravery.
('75', 185, 6, 16, 355385) Meanwhile we should watch how things shaps themselves.
('75', 185, 6, 17, 355440) I am thinking out new plans of conducting the movement in view of the terrorist methods that some States seem to have adopted, We have to develop that technique of rendering futile the employment of hired hooligans against peaceful citizens.
('75', 185, 6, 18, 355682) An able general always gives battle in his own time on the ground of his choice.
('75', 185, 6, 19, 355763) He always retains the initiative in these respects and never allows it to pass into the hands of the enemy.
('75', 185, 6, 20, 355871) In a satyagraha campaign the mode of fight and the choice of tactics, e.
('75', 185, 6, 21, 355944) g., whether to advance or retreat, offer civil resistance or

('75', 188, 6, 17, 360200) But according to Mahatma Gandhi, and the Nationalists, the scheme of Federation evolved by the British Government in 1935 was not the one to give self government to India.
('75', 188, 6, 18, 360372) He said : The present Federation scheme cannot be accepted without damaging the cause of India’s independence.
('75', 188, 6, 19, 360483) The Viceroy will try to have the scheme accepted.
('75', 188, 6, 20, 360533) The Nationalists, many of the Princes, religious fanatics and others will oppose it—for diverse reasons.
('75', 188, 6, 21, 360638) It is a very tense situation.

('75', 189, 6, 9, 361826) Mixing up of motives is damaging in any species of satyagraha, but in religious satyagraha it is altogether inadmissible.
('75', 189, 6, 10, 361948) It is fatal to use or allow religious satyagraha to be used as a cloak or a device for advancing an ulterior political or mundane objective.
('75', 189, 6, 11, 362089) As with regard to the goal so with the means, unadulterated purity is of the very essence in this species of satyagraha.
('75', 189, 6, 12, 362210) The leader in such a movement must be a man of deeply spiritual life, preferably a brahmachari—whether married or unmarried.
('75', 189, 6, 13, 362335) He must be a believer in—as in fact everybody participating in such a movement must be— and practiser of the particular religious observance for which the movement is launched.
('75', 189, 6, 14, 362512) The leader must be versed in the science of satyagraha.
('75', 189, 6, 15, 362568) Truth and ahimsa should shine through his speech.
('75', 189, 6, 16, 362618) All his actions must be transparent through and through.
('75', 189, 6, 17, 362675) Diplomacy and intrigue can have no place in his armoury.
('75', 189, 6, 18, 362732) Absolute belief in ahimsa and in God is an indispensable condition in such satyagraha.
('75', 189, 6, 19, 362819) In religious satyagraha there can be no room for aggressiveness, demonstrativeness, show.
('75', 189, 6, 20, 362909) Those who take part in it must have equal respect and regard for the religious convictions and susceptibilities of those who profess a different faith from theirs.
('75', 189, 6, 21, 363073) The slightest narrowness in their outlook is likely to be reflected magnified

('75', 194, 3, 15, 371911) M. K. GANDHI

('75', 194, 5, 18, 372005) 244. REQUISITE QUALIFICATIONS
('75', 194, 6, 19, 372035) The four days’ fast set me thinking of the qualifications required in a satyagrahi.
('75', 194, 6, 20, 372119) Though they were carefully considered and reduced to writing in 1921 1 they seem to have been forgotten.
('75', 194, 6, 21, 372224) As satyagraha in the form of civil disobedience is being offered or contemplated in several States, it is necessary to reiterate the qualifications and to dispel false ideas that seem to be prevalent
('75', 194, 7, 22, 372424) 1 Vide “Speech at Congress Session, Ahmedabad” I
('75', 195, 0, 1, 372473) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 195, 1, 2, 372515) among many workers.
('75', 195, 1, 3, 372535) Moreover the greatest care is necessary at the present moment when violence, not non violence, seems to pervade the air.
('75', 195, 1, 4, 372656) Indeed it may be reasonably argued that in an atmosphere surcharged with violence there is no scope for non violence.
('75', 195, 1, 5, 372774) This argument may be carried too far, so far that non violence may be made wholly ineffec tive; whereas it is claimed to be the only effective force for counterac ting violence no matter how terrible.
('75', 195, 1, 6, 372975) But when violence pervades the air the expression of non violence may not be through civil disobe dience.
('75', 195, 1, 7, 373081) And if it is to be civil disobedience, it must be hedged in by adequate restrictions.
('75', 195, 1, 8, 373167) In satyagraha, It is never the numbers that count; it is always the quality, more so when the forces of violence are uppermost.
('75', 195, 1, 9, 373295) Then it is often forgotten that it is never the intention of a satyagrahi to embarrass the wrongdoer.
('75', 195, 1, 10, 373397) The appeal is never to his fear; it is, must be, always to his heart.
('75', 195, 1, 11, 373467) The satyagrahi’s object is not to convert, not to coerce, the wrongdoers.
('75', 195, 1, 12, 373541) He should avoid artificiality in all his doings.
('75', 195, 1, 13, 373590) He acts naturally and from inward convictions.
('75', 195, 1, 14, 373637) Keeping these observations before his mind’s eye, the reader will perhaps appreciate the following qualifications which I hold are essential for every satyagrahi in India : 1. He must have a living faith in God, for He is his only Rock.
('75', 195, 1, 15, 373874) 2. He must believe in truth and non violence as his creed and therefore have faith in the inherent goodness of human nature which he expects to evoke by his truth and love expressed through his suffering.
('75', 195, 1, 16, 374079) 3. He must be leading a chaste life and be ready and willing for the sake of his cause to give up his life and his possessions.
('75', 195, 1, 17, 374207) 4. He must be a habitual khadi wearer and spinner.
('75', 195, 1, 18, 374258) This is essential for India.
('75', 195, 1, 19, 374287) 5. He must be a teetotaller and be free from the use of other intoxicants in order that his reason may be always unclouded and his mind constant.
('75', 195, 1, 20, 374433) 6. He must carry out with a willing heart all the rules of discipline as may be laid down from time to time.
('75', 195, 1, 21, 374542) 7. He should carry out the jail rules unless they are specially devised to hurt his self respect.
('75', 196, 0, 1, 374640) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 197
('75', 196, 1, 2, 374684) The qualifications are not to be regarded as exhaustive.
('75', 196, 1, 3, 374741) They are illustrative only.
('75', 196, 1, 4, 374769) NEW DELHI, March 20, 1939 Harijan, 25 3 1939
('75', 196, 2, 5, 374814) 245. DRAFT TELEGRAM TO R. SANKAR 1
('75', 196, 3, 6, 374849) March 20, 1939 R. SANKAR 2
('75', 196, 4, 7, 374876) TRAVELLERS‘ BUNGALOW MADURA

('75', 198, 9, 32, 378403) 1 This is extracted from “The Rajkot Fast—VIII”.
('75', 198, 9, 33, 378452) Pyarelal explains that the Travancore satyagrahis who called on Gandhiji in the afternoon feared that “indefinite suspension of civil disobedience would bring in depression from which it would be difficult for the people to recover”.
('75', 199, 0, 1, 378686) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 199, 1, 2, 378728) violence ensured, and suspension is ordered through a miscalculation of the general, it cannot jeopardize the future of the movement.
('75', 199, 1, 3, 378862) Satyagraha means readiness to suffer and a faith that the more innocent and pure the suffering the more potent will it be in its effect.
('75', 199, 1, 4, 378999) Helplessness is thus ruled out in satyagraha.
('75', 199, 1, 5, 379045) Suspension of civil disobedience, if it resulted in an accentuation of repression, would itself become satyagraha in its ideal form.
('75', 199, 1, 6, 379178) Today the opponent is afraid of your numbers.
('75', 199, 1, 7, 379224) You cannot expect him to show a change of heart while he is filled with panic.
('75', 199, 1, 8, 379303) He senses in your action a spirit of retaliation which irritates him the more.
('75', 199, 1, 9, 379382) It thus becomes a species of violence.
('75', 199, 1, 10, 379421) Your struggle hereafter may have to be restricted to a few men only, but their satyagraha will tell.
('75', 199, 1, 11, 379522) While we are playing with non violence we are only giving a chance to the powers that be in Travancore to organize the brute in man.
('75', 199, 1, 12, 379655) This must not be.
