('75', 199, 3, 14, 379691) 251. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 3
('75', 199, 4, 15, 379721) NEW DELHI, March 20, 1939 I observe that Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar 3 had no better use for the two Travancore stalwarts, Shri Thanu Pillai and Shri Rama chandran, than to send them to prison.
('75', 199, 4, 16, 379913) They will give a good account of themselves in prison as they have done outside.
('75', 199, 4, 17, 379994) But I cannot congratulate the Travancore Durbar on their action.
('75', 199, 4, 18, 380059) When I was in Rajkot I had seen Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar’s statement in condemnation of what he was pleased to term outside interference.
('75', 199, 4, 19, 380198) May the Princes summon whatever outside assistance they may choose, and not the people?
('75', 199, 4, 20, 380286) There is no restriction on the outside help the Princes may take.
('75', 199, 4, 21, 380352) The popular party has put many voluntary restrictions on such help.
('75', 199, 4, 22, 380420) After all, what am I doing except to give advice as an expert in the science of satyagraha?
('75', 199, 4, 23, 380512) By doing so I promote the spirit of non violence and the cause of peace.
('75', 199, 4, 24, 380585) The connection between the people of the States and of the so called
('75', 199, 5, 25, 380654) 1 Vide also “Discussion with Philipose”, 15 3 1939 2 The statement appeared under the title “Read the signs”.
('75', 199, 5, 26, 380764) 3 Dewan of Travancore State
('75', 200, 0, 1, 380792) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 201
('75', 200, 1, 2, 380836) British India is organic, vital and indissoluble.
('75', 200, 1, 3, 380886) There is no such connection between the Princes who are and who pride themselves on being independent of one another.
('75', 200, 1, 4, 381004) The common tie between them is that of subservience to the Paramount Power, without whose permission, implied or explicit, they cannot move a blade of grass.
('75', 200, 1, 5, 381162) But the Paramount Power itself growingly lives on the will of the nation, including the people of the State.
('75', 200, 1, 6, 381271) If the nation realizes that it can develop invincible strength through truth and non violence, the Paramount Power will be voluntarily replaced by the power of the people.
('75', 200, 1, 7, 381443) It, therefore, seems to me that Sir C. P. Ramaswami and those Dewans who think like him are bad advisers of their Princes and ill serve them.
('75', 200, 1, 8, 381585) The effort to ignore the Congress and Congress workers and to prevent its natural influence working in the States is like that of a child who by the little palm of his right hand tries to stop an onrushing flood.
('75', 200, 1, 9, 381798) This attempt to stifle the legitimate aspirations of the people of the States surely sows seeds of bitterness on the one hand between the people of the States and their Princes to whom they want to be loyal, and on the other between the Princes and the Congress which wants to help them if it is allowed to do so.
('75', 200, 1, 10, 382112) I ask the Princes and their advisers to read the signs of the times and march with them.
('75', 200, 1, 11, 382201) They may succeed by frightful measures in sending for a time the freedom movement underground, but they will never be able to crush it altogether.
('75', 200, 1, 12, 382348) I venture to think also that the Paramount Power will have to shed their nervousness and overcau tiousness.
('75', 200, 1, 13, 382456) If they owe a duty to the Princes, surely they owe a duty to their people.
('75', 200, 1, 14, 382531) The days when the people could be ignored are gone.
('75', 200, 1, 15, 382583) If the Princes will not listen, let the Paramount Power tell them in plain terms that they may not expect the latter’s assistance in suppressing their people.
('75', 200, 1, 16, 382742) The Paramount Power who draw Ministers in many Provinces from the Congress may not sit still when neighbour ing states heap insults upon the Congress.
('75', 200, 1, 17, 382893) It is an anomaly that demands quick handling.
('75', 200, 1, 18, 382939) To the people of Travancore I suggest that the cause has benefited by the premature arrests of the two stalwarts.
('75', 200, 1, 19, 383053) The benefit can only accrue if they will use the arrests wisely.
('75', 200, 1, 20, 383118) If there is the slightest risk of violence breaking out, let there be no demonstration by way of processions and the like.
('75', 200, 1, 21, 383241) Let them all devote themselves to constructive work.
('75', 200, 1, 22, 383294) The date of launching out upon civil disobedience must not be anticipated.
('75', 200, 1, 23, 383369) If I am to continue to advise, let me study the
('75', 201, 0, 1, 383417) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 201, 1, 2, 383459) situation and let them await my opinion 1 before resuming civil disobedience.
('75', 201, 1, 3, 383537) Civil disobedience is but a minor part of satyagraha.
('75', 201, 1, 4, 383591) Let the people, including the most illiterate and the downtrodden, be knit in a common bond by silent service.
('75', 201, 1, 5, 383702) In this work even the students can take their due share.
('75', 201, 1, 6, 383759) Let the satyagrahis remember that haste is waste.
('75', 201, 1, 7, 383809) Their freedom was assured when they took the solemn vow of fighting for it through truth and non violence, that is, through enlightened and disciplined self suffering.
('75', 201, 1, 8, 383977) For I know that they will never go back upon their vow.
('75', 201, 1, 9, 384033) Harijan, 25 3 1939
('75', 201, 2, 10, 384052) 252. DICUSSION WITH JAIPUR SATYAGRAHIS 1
('75', 201, 3, 11, 384093) March 20, 1939 Provoking lathi charges or receiving lathi blows on your body in a spirit of bravado is not satyagraha.
('75', 201, 3, 12, 384212) True satyagraha consists in the readiness to face blows if they come in the course of performing one’s duty.
('75', 201, 3, 13, 384321) Today the whole atmosphere in the country is reeking of violence as was evidenced at Tripuri.
('75', 201, 3, 14, 384415) Under violence I include corruption, falsehood, hypocrisy, deceit and the like.
('75', 201, 3, 15, 384495) If our satyagraha is to survive this atmosphere, we ahimsaites shall have to be more strict with ourselves.
('75', 201, 3, 16, 384603) Let only the purest and the most innocent go to jail.
('75', 201, 3, 17, 384657) It does not matter if they have to remain immured behind the prison bars for a whole lifetime.
('75', 201, 3, 18, 384752) Their sacrifice will fill the prison with a sweet fragrance and its influence will even travel outside and subtly transform the entire atmosphere.
('75', 201, 3, 19, 384899) They will never long for their release nor doubt that their sacrifice is being ‘wasted’.
('75', 201, 3, 20, 384988) They will realize that a consecrated resolve is more potent in its action than mere physical action can ever be.
('75', 201, 3, 21, 385101) The discipline that they will be acquiring in prison will help the non violent organization of the people outside and instil fearlessness among them.
('75', 201, 3, 22, 385251) So much for those who are in prison, what about those outside?
('75', 201, 3, 23, 385314) They must engage in constructive work as the embodiment of the active principle of ahimsa.
('75', 201, 3, 24, 385405) If it does not appeal to them, it will only
('75', 201, 4, 25, 385449) 1 Vide “Statement Suspending Travancore Satyagraha”, 23 3 1939 1 This is extracted from “The Rajkot Fast—VIII”.
('75', 202, 0, 1, 385561) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 203
('75', 202, 1, 2, 385605) betray their lack of faith in ahimsa.
('75', 202, 1, 3, 385643) The other thing is internal.
('75', 202, 1, 4, 385672) They must cultivate a living faith in God—an attitude of utter reliance on Him to the exclusion of all external aids.
('75', 202, 1, 5, 385790) A single satyagrahi imbued with such faith will inspire the whole people by his example and may induce a heart change even in the opponent who, freed from fear, will the more readily appreciate his simple faith and respect it.

('75', 205, 1, 2, 391735) 256. STATEMENT SUSPENDING TRAVANCORE
('75', 205, 2, 3, 391772) SATYAGRAHA 1
('75', 205, 3, 4, 391785) NEW DELHI, March 23, 1939 I have had long Chats 2 with Shri Philipose about the situation in Travancore.
('75', 205, 3, 5, 391890) I have also carefully studied the resolution of the last Working committee of the State Congress and the well thought out elaborate plan of action to be taken all over Travancore together with great precautions embodied in it to ensure non violence.
('75', 205, 3, 6, 392140) I have also read the telegram received by Shri Philipose wherein he is told that if civil disobedience is further suspended, there will be much heart burning and disappointment.
('75', 205, 3, 7, 392318) But after having weighed the pros and cons I have come to the conclusion that it will be in the interest of the cause not to start civil disobedience on March 25 and to suspend it till I advise resumption.
('75', 205, 3, 8, 392524) In satyagraha there is no such thing as disappointment or heart burning.
('75', 205, 3, 9, 392597) The struggle always goes on in some shape or other till the goal is reached.
('75', 205, 3, 10, 392674) A satyagrahi is indifferent whether it is civil disobedience or some other phase of the struggle to which he is called.
('75', 205, 3, 11, 392794) Nor does he mind if, in the middle of the civil disobedience march, he is called upon to halt and do something else.
('75', 205, 3, 12, 392911) He must have faith that it is all for the best.
('75', 205, 3, 13, 392959) My own experience hitherto has been that each suspension has found the people better equipped for the fight and for control over forces of violence.
('75', 205, 3, 14, 393108) Therefore in advising suspension, I dismiss from my mind the fear that it may lead to desertion and disbelief.
('75', 205, 3, 15, 393219) If it does, I should not feel sorry, for it would be to me a sign that the deserters did not know what satyagraha was and the movement was better without those who did not know what they were doing.
('75', 205, 3, 16, 393418) The reasons that have prompted me to tender this advice are these: If it is true that the Travancore Durbar have drafted untrained raw men as police in order to strike terror among satyagrahis, it
('75', 205, 4, 17, 393615) 1 The statement appeared under the title “Suspend Civil Disobedience”.

('75', 210, 1, 2, 402097) 262. ‘SUSPENSION SHOULD CONTINUE’
('75', 210, 2, 3, 402131) Shri Philipose has received the following telegram from Trivandrum :
('75', 210, 3, 4, 402200) Arrests continue.
('75', 210, 3, 5, 402218) Kunjukrishna Pillai and others arrested.Kuzhitharai Krishna Pillai, President, arrested today (24th).Korah nominated President.
('75', 210, 3, 6, 402346) Inform Gandhiji.
('75', 210, 3, 7, 402363) I had not expected that arrests would continue even after the suspension of civil disobedience.
('75', 210, 3, 8, 402459) But of course my expectations need not be fulfilled.
('75', 210, 3, 9, 402512) Suspension was advised for reasons publicly stated by me.
('75', 210, 3, 10, 402570) If Travancore authorities consider it necessary to continue arrests, satya grahis may not complain.
('75', 210, 3, 11, 402670) Civil disobedience gives cause for arrest or makes some action by the authorities necessary.
('75', 210, 3, 12, 402763) Therefore, as a rule, suspension without any previous understanding with the State is generally followed not only by discontinuance of arrests but even by discharge of those convicted for disobedience.
('75', 210, 3, 13, 402965) If the Trivandrum wire is correct, authorities in Travancore have adopted an unexpected course.
('75', 210, 3, 14, 403061) Their action need not perturb or perplex satyagrahis.
('75', 210, 3, 15, 403115) Suspension should still continue.
('75', 210, 3, 16, 403149) I have no doubt that such arrests will help the popular cause more than if civil disobedience was continued, assuming, of course, that there was no cause for arrest other than that the arrested persons were satyagrahis.
('75', 210, 3, 17, 403369) Since suspension has been declared I hold it to be unnecessary to appoint a President instead of the one arrested.
('75', 210, 3, 18, 403484) The object of appointing successive Presidents in place of those arrested no longer subsists.
('75', 210, 3, 19, 403578) There must be a provision in the ordinary constitution of the State Congress for conduct of business in the absence of the President.
('75', 210, 3, 20, 403712) I am painfully conscious of the fact that satyagrahis were unprepared for the exigency created by my advice.
('75', 210, 3, 21, 403821) Let them console themselves, if they can, by the fact that though they may not just now appreciate or understand what may to them appear to be new technique, it has been advised by one who claims to know the science of satyagraha.
('75', 210, 3, 22, 404052) It calls for infinite patience and boundless faith in its efficacy.
('75', 210, 3, 23, 404120) Everything comes right for those who watch, wait and pray.
('75', 210, 4, 24, 404179) Since writing the foregoing I have seen the official reaction to suspension.
('75', 210, 4, 25, 404256) An Associated Press message says that official opinion seems to be that civil disobedience is neither given up nor even suspended.

('75', 215, 0, 1, 413595) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 215, 1, 2, 413637) faith in himself and that multiplied to the nth degree is God.
('75', 215, 1, 3, 413700) The sum total of all that lives is God.
('75', 215, 1, 4, 413740) We may not be God but we are of God— even as a little drop of water is of the ocean.
('75', 215, 1, 5, 413825) Imagine it torn away from the ocean and flung millions of miles away.
('75', 215, 1, 6, 413895) It becomes helpless torn from its surroundings and cannot feel the might and majesty of the ocean but if someone could point out to it that it is of the ocean, its faith would revive, it would dance with joy and the whole of the might and majesty of the ocean would be reflected in it.
('75', 215, 1, 7, 414181) Even so it is with all non violent activities.
('75', 215, 1, 8, 414228) Take spinning for half an hour daily.
('75', 215, 1, 9, 414266) It is nothing unless it is tacked on to non violence.
('75', 215, 1, 10, 414320) Take the counting of beads.
('75', 215, 1, 11, 414348) A monkey also can count them but devotees count them to get nearer to God.
('75', 215, 1, 12, 414423) I want everybody to spin as a token of his faith in non violence, as a token of his identification with the dumb millions.
('75', 215, 1, 13, 414546) Then alone shall we feel the upwelling of non violent strength in us.
('75', 215, 1, 14, 414616) 1 The non violence that we have offered hitherto has not been the non violence of the brave.
('75', 215, 1, 15, 414709) As a weapon of the weak, as an expedient, it was good enough.
('75', 215, 1, 16, 414771) It did answer its purpose for a while.
('75', 215, 1, 17, 414810) But how long can the non violence of the weak last?
('75', 215, 1, 18, 414862) I have not been able to answer for Europe because I have not worked it out in India.
('75', 215, 1, 19, 414947) And yet I would not rewrite those chapters in our history.
('75', 215, 1, 20, 415006) God fulfils Himself even through the weakness of His instruments sometimes.
('75', 215, 1, 21, 415082) But if we now do not overhaul the basis of our non violence and if we continue to drift in the old style, It would be nothing short of a catastrophe.
('75', 215, 1, 22, 415232) We shall not have evolved the non violent strength and courage, and, faced with a crisis, might behave like cowards.
('75', 215, 1, 23, 415349) Harijan, 3 6 1939

('75', 216, 5, 9, 416093) 269. LETTER TO SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE
('75', 216, 6, 10, 416128) NEW DELHI, March 30, 1939
('75', 216, 7, 11, 416154) MY DEAR SUBHAS, I have delayed my reply to your letter of 25th 1 instant for the sake of having your reply to my wire 2. I got Sunil’s wire last night.
('75', 216, 7, 12, 416306) I have now got up before morning prayer time to write this reply.
('75', 216, 7, 13, 416372) Since you think that Pandit Pant’s resolution 3 was out of order and the clause relating to the Working Committee is clearly uncons titutional and ultra vires, your course is absolutely clear.
('75', 216, 7, 14, 416565) Your choice of the Committee should be unfettered.
('75', 216, 7, 15, 416616) Your several questions on this head, therefore, do not need any answering.
('75', 216, 7, 16, 416691) Since we met in February, my opinion has becomes streng thened that where there are differences on fundamentals, as we agreed there were, a composite committee would be harmful.
('75', 216, 7, 17, 416869) Assuming, therefore, that your policy had the backing of the majority of the A. I. C. C., you should have a Working Committee composed purely of those who believe in your policy.
('75', 216, 7, 18, 417048) Yes, I adhere to the view expressed by me at Segaon at our February meeting that I would not be guilty of being party to any self suppression by you, as distinguished from voluntary self efface ment.
('75', 216, 7, 19, 417248) Any subordination of a view which you may strongly hold as in the best interests of the country would be self suppression.
('75', 216, 7, 20, 417371) Therefore, if you are to function as President, your hands must be unfettered.
('75', 216, 7, 21, 417450) The situation before the country admits of no middle course.

('75', 219, 3, 4, 421258) QUESTION : What would you do in Allahabad, if you were there?
('75', 219, 4, 5, 421320) ANSWER : I would scrap the existing Congress machinery.
('75', 219, 4, 6, 421376) It is a burden today.
('75', 219, 4, 7, 421398) If there were half a dozen genuine Congressmen only on the Congress register today, they would be real messengers of peace.
('75', 219, 4, 8, 421522) But today their effort is smothered under the weight of numbers.
('75', 219, 4, 9, 421587) If all Congressmen whose names are on the Congress register today were worth their salt, they would offer themselves to be cut to pieces before the communal trouble proceeds any further.
('75', 219, 4, 10, 421774) But today each wants to use the dagger against his fellow.
('75', 219, 4, 11, 421833) We have either to revise everything in terms of non violence or give up non violence and rebuild the organization.

('75', 223, 0, 1, 426802) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 223, 1, 2, 426844) opposed to those of the others and my own that I do not see any possibility of bridging them.
('75', 223, 1, 3, 426938) I think that each school of thought should be able to put forth its views before the country without any mixture.
('75', 223, 1, 4, 427052) And if this is honestly done, I do not see why there should be any bitterness, ending in civil war.
('75', 223, 1, 5, 427152) What is wrong is not the differences between us but loss of mutual respect and trust.
('75', 223, 1, 6, 427238) This will be remedied by time, which is the best healer.
('75', 223, 1, 7, 427295) If there is real non violence in us, there can be no civil war, much less bitterness.
('75', 223, 1, 8, 427381) Taking all things into consideration, I am of opinion that you should at once form your own Cabinet fully representing your views, formulate your programme definitely and put it before the forthcoming A. I. C. C. If the Committee accepts the programme, all will be plain sailing and you should be enabled to prosecute it unhampered by the minority.
('75', 223, 1, 9, 427730) If, on the other hand, your progamme is not accepted you should resign and let the Committee choose its President.
('75', 223, 1, 10, 427845) And you will be free to educate the country along your own lines.
('75', 223, 1, 11, 427911) I tender this advice irrespective of Pandit Pant’s resolution.
('75', 223, 1, 12, 427974) Now for your question.
('75', 223, 1, 13, 427997) When Pandit Pant’s resolution 1 was pro duced, I was on my bed.
('75', 223, 1, 14, 428061) Mathuradas, who happened to be in Rajkot that day, one morning brought me the message that there was to be a resolution expressing confidence in the old horses.
('75', 223, 1, 15, 428222) I had not the text before me.
('75', 223, 1, 16, 428252) I said it would be good so far as it went, for I had been told at Segaon that your election was not so much confidence in you as censure of the old horses, especially the Sardar.
('75', 223, 1, 17, 428431) After this, I saw the actual text only in Allahabad when I went to see the Maulana Saheb.
('75', 223, 1, 18, 428521) My prestige does not count.
('75', 223, 1, 19, 428549) It has no independent value of its own.
('75', 223, 1, 20, 428589) When my motive is suspected or my policy or programme rejected by the country, the prestige must go.
('75', 223, 1, 21, 428690) India will rise or fall by the quality of the sum total of the acts of her many millions.
('75', 223, 1, 22, 428780) Individuals, however high they may be, are of no account except in so far as they represent the many millions.
('75', 223, 1, 23, 428891) Therefore, let us rule it out of consideration.
('75', 223, 1, 24, 428939) I wholly dissent from your view that the country has been never so non violent as now.
('75', 223, 1, 25, 429026) I smell violence in the air I breathe.
('75', 223, 1, 26, 429065) But the violence has put on a subtle form.
('75', 223, 1, 27, 429108) Our mutual distrust is a bad form of violence.
('75', 223, 1, 28, 429155) The widening gulf between Hindus and Mussalmans
('75', 223, 2, 29, 429203) 1Vide footnote 1,”Letter to Subhas Chandra Bose”, 24 3 1939
('75', 224, 0, 1, 429263) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 225
('75', 224, 1, 2, 429307) points to the same thing.
('75', 224, 1, 3, 429333) I can give further illustrations.
('75', 224, 1, 4, 429367) We seem to differ as to the amount of corruption in the Congress.
('75', 224, 1, 5, 429433) My impression is that it is on the increase.
('75', 224, 1, 6, 429478) I have been pleading for the past many months for a thorough scrutiny.
('75', 224, 1, 7, 429549) In these circumstances, I see no atmosphere for non violent mass action.
('75', 224, 1, 8, 429622) An ultimatum without an effective sanction is worse than useless.
('75', 224, 1, 9, 429688) But, as I have told you, I am an old man, perhaps growing timid and over cautious, and you have youth before you and reckless optimism born of youth.
('75', 224, 1, 10, 429838) I hope you are right and I am wrong.
('75', 224, 1, 11, 429875) I have the firm belief that the Congress, as it is today, cannot deliver the goods, cannot offer civil disobedience worth the name.
('75', 224, 1, 12, 430007) Therefore, if your prognosis is right, I am a back number and played out as the generalissimo of satyagraha.
('75', 224, 1, 13, 430116) I am glad you have mentioned the little Rajkot affair.
('75', 224, 1, 14, 430171) It brings into prominent relief the different angles from which we look at things.
('75', 224, 1, 15, 430254) I have nothing to repent of in the steps I have taken in connection with it.
('75', 224, 1, 16, 430331) I feel that it has great national importance.
('75', 224, 1, 17, 430377) I have not stopped civil disobedience in the other States for the sake of Rajkot.
('75', 224, 1, 18, 430459) But Rajkot opened my eyes; it showed me the way.
('75', 224, 1, 19, 430508) I am not in Delhi for my health.
('75', 224, 1, 20, 430541) I am reluctantly in Delhi, awaiting the Chief Justice’s decision.
('75', 224, 1, 21, 430607) I hold it to be my duty to be in Delhi till the steps to be taken, in due fulfilment of the Viceroy’s declaration in his last wire 1to me, were finally taken.
('75', 224, 1, 22, 430766) I may not run any risk.
('75', 224, 1, 23, 430790) If I invited the Paramount Power to do its duty, I was bound to be in Delhi to see that the duty was fully performed.
('75', 224, 1, 24, 430908) I saw nothing wrong in the Chief Justice being appointed the interpreter of the document whose meaning was put in doubt by the Thakore Saheb.

('75', 228, 1, 2, 435075) 288. THE STATES
('75', 228, 2, 3, 435091) A clear understanding of the suspension of civil disobedience in the States is necessary if the people are to reap the full benefit of it.
('75', 228, 2, 4, 435230) One result—not unexpected—seems to have been that some States have stiffened their attitude and are resorting to repression they had not perhaps thought of before suspension.
('75', 228, 2, 5, 435405) Where this happens there is no cause for losing heart.
('75', 228, 2, 6, 435460) Repression itself affords a training in satyagraha, even as an unsought war affords a training for the soldier.
('75', 228, 2, 7, 435572) Satyagrahis should discover the causes of repression.
('75', 228, 2, 8, 435626) They will find that repressed people are easily frightened by the slightest show of force and are unprepared for suffering and self sacrifice.
('75', 228, 2, 9, 435769) This is then the time for learning the first lessons of satyagraha.
('75', 228, 2, 10, 435837) Those who know anything of this matchless force should teach their neighbours to bear repression not weakly and helplessly but bravely and knowingly.
('75', 228, 2, 11, 435987) Thus, for example, a State declares an association illegal.
('75', 228, 2, 12, 436047) The members may submit either because of fear of punishment or knowingly because they do not yet wish to offer civil disobedience.
('75', 228, 2, 13, 436178) In the latter case, they husband their energy and develop the will to resist non violently.
('75', 228, 2, 14, 436270) Individual members of the association will still carry on activities that may not be regarded as in themselves illegal.
('75', 228, 2, 15, 436390) They will also carry on constitutional agitation to secure legal recognition for their organization.
('75', 228, 2, 16, 436491) And if in spite of voluntarily working within the four corners of the local laws workers are arrested or otherwise illtreated, they would cheerfully submit to the sufferings involved.
('75', 228, 2, 17, 436675) So doing they will examine themselves whether they bear any ill will or anger towards their persecutors, they will ask themselves whether they feel the presence of God as their true Helper and Guide in their difficulties.
('75', 228, 2, 18, 436897) Indeed such training if properly and persistently taken will generate in the learners a power of calm, non violent resistance which in itself will become invincible and therefore may render further effort by way of civil disobedience wholly unnecessary.
('75', 228, 2, 19, 437151) I am afraid I must plead guilty to being over confident and hasty in launching previous civil disobedience campaigns.
('75', 228, 2, 20, 437269) No harm seems to have accrued to the country because I had always my hand on the pulse of the country and, thank God, had no hesitation in retracing the step taken if I scented danger or discovered an error of
('75', 229, 0, 1, 437479) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 229, 1, 2, 437521) judgment or calculation.
('75', 229, 1, 3, 437546) This much harm must, however be admitted.
('75', 229, 1, 4, 437588) The people having become used to laxity about previous preparation now find it irksome to conform to the strictness in the observance of the unexciting rules of preparation.
('75', 229, 1, 5, 437762) And yet they are much the most important part of satyagraha training.
('75', 229, 1, 6, 437832) Potent and active non violence cannot be cultivated unless the candidate goes through the necessary stages which require a lot of plodding.
('75', 229, 1, 7, 437972) If, however, I have succeeded in showing the repression, if properly understood, evokes natural and spontaneous resistance in a satyagrahi, perhaps this knowledge will rob 1 the constructive effort and the waiting of their seeming insipidity.
('75', 229, 1, 8, 438215) Indeed the fact that these things appear insipid betrays want of appreciation of satyagraha and the beauty and efficacy of non violence.
('75', 229, 1, 9, 438352) In other words, the spirit of satyagraha has not sunk deep and violence still lurks even though unconsciously in the seeker’s breast.
('75', 229, 1, 10, 438486) I hope, therefore that repression, wherever it is resorted to, will not depress the repressed people but will accelerate the pace of the constructive effort.
('75', 229, 1, 11, 438644) It is necessary so far as it is possible to convince the powers that be of our absolutely non violent intention.
('75', 229, 1, 12, 438757) Such conviction is half the battle won.
('75', 229, 1, 13, 438797) In order to carry this conviction home there must be sufficient curb on our speech and writing as our action must be non violent beyond doubt.
('75', 229, 1, 14, 438940) NEW DELHI, April 3, 1939 Harijan, 8 4 1939

('75', 232, 6, 9, 443060) 295. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 232, 7, 10, 443090) NEW DELHI April 4, 1939 I have read long accounts of a great Parsi meeting in Bombay protesting against prohibition in Bombay.
('75', 232, 7, 11, 443217) I note that Parsi ladies also took part in the meeting.
('75', 232, 7, 12, 443273) I have also some letters from Parsi friends appealing to me, as the author of prohibition as a chief plank in the Congress programme, to ask the Bombay Ministry to desist from their policy of prohibition.
('75', 232, 7, 13, 443478) It is not clear whether the objection is to prohibition as such or to the new taxation.
('75', 232, 7, 14, 443566) All India knows the intimate connection that subsists between the Parsis and me.
('75', 232, 7, 15, 443647) It hurts me to think that this race of the greatest philanthropists in the world should ally itself to a campaign against a cause whose basis is purest philanthropy.
('75', 232, 7, 16, 443813) The hurt is all the greater for the knowledge that even Parsi ladies have allied themselves to the campaign.
('75', 232, 7, 17, 443922) I see that unworthy threats were used at the meeting and the rights of minorities were pleaded.
('75', 232, 7, 18, 444018) I can only hope that all the heat shown at the meeting was due to the momentary passion, and that the innate philanthropy of the Parsis will assert itself.
('75', 232, 7, 19, 444174) I venture to suggest that the Parsis will be among the first to benefit by the prohibition policy.
('75', 232, 7, 20, 444273) It is wrong to suggest that drink has done or is doing no harm to the Parsis.
('75', 232, 7, 21, 444351) The Parsis will be the gainers for the
('75', 232, 8, 22, 444390) 1 This appeared under the title “Prohibition and Parsis”.
('75', 232, 8, 23, 444448) The statement was also published in The Hindustan Times, 5 4 1939.
('75', 233, 0, 1, 444515) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 233, 1, 2, 444557) diversion of Parsi liquor sellers to some other means of livelihood.
('75', 233, 1, 3, 444626) Let me remind the objectors that prohibition does not affect unfermented toddy which is called nira.
('75', 233, 1, 4, 444727) Therefore no Parsi will be deprived of his nira which, I admit, is as healthy as sugarcane juice and perhaps cheaper if a means can be discovered of preventing quick fermentation which nira undergoes more than other sweet juices.
('75', 233, 1, 5, 444957) The objectors departed from truth when they raised the cry of attack on religion.
('75', 233, 1, 6, 445039) I have read the carefully drawn prohibition rules which provide for special permits for the use of spirituous liquors for bona fide religious rites.
('75', 233, 1, 7, 445188) The rules also provide for their use for medicinal purposes.
('75', 233, 1, 8, 445249) And so far as taxation is concerned it ill behoves philanthropists to grumble at taxation for a cause so noble as prohibition which means the welfare of ignorant millions.
('75', 233, 1, 9, 445421) I hope, therefore, that the nobler element, of which there is so much among the Parsis, will assert itself and help the glorious movement which promises to deliver the labouring population from a curse which is destroying them body and soul.

('75', 242, 1, 2, 458892) 314. HAVE I ERRED?
('75', 242, 2, 3, 458911) Some friends have been expostulating with me for involving myself in the Rajkot affair.
('75', 242, 2, 4, 458999) I sum up their argument below: In giving so much attention to Rajkot to the exclusion of all else you seem to have lost all sense of proportion.
('75', 242, 2, 5, 459144) It was your obvious duty to be at Tripuri.
('75', 242, 2, 6, 459187) If you had been there, things would have taken a different turn.
('75', 242, 2, 7, 459252) But you chose to undertake an indefinite fast.
('75', 242, 2, 8, 459299) You had no right thus to disturb national life without notice.
('75', 242, 2, 9, 459362) Why should you fast to make a Prince keep his promise?
('75', 242, 2, 10, 459417) The people of Rajkot were offering civil disobedience.
('75', 242, 2, 11, 459472) They would have become stronger in any case if you had not suddenly stopped the movement.
('75', 242, 2, 12, 459562) Surely, democracy cannot be built by your method.
('75', 242, 2, 13, 459612) And then you, who taught India to shun Viceroys and Governors and such other functionaries who used to fill us with awe, are now found dancing attendance on the Viceroy and awaiting His Excellency’s pleasure when great affairs demand your attention elsewhere.
('75', 242, 2, 14, 459872) You are believed to oppose Federation, but you recognize the Chief Justice of the Federal Court and will not leave Delhi till His Lordship has delivered his Award.
('75', 242, 2, 15, 460036) Truly the ways of mahatmas are strange.
('75', 242, 2, 16, 460076) To the hasty reader this argument must make a forcible appeal.
('75', 242, 2, 17, 460139) But one who goes a little deeper into the subject and knows the working of satyagraha should have no difficulty in seeing the falsity of the argument.
('75', 242, 2, 18, 460290) Nor is there anything new in what I have done and am doing about Rajkot.
('75', 242, 2, 19, 460363) Geographically Rajkot is a tiny spot on the map of India, but the disturbance which I felt called upon to deal with was symptomatic of a universal malady.
('75', 242, 2, 20, 460518) My endeavour in Rajkot was meant to nip the evil in the bud.
('75', 242, 2, 21, 460579) I am of opinion that the result of the endeavour has so far benefited the whole of India.
('75', 242, 2, 22, 460669) I acted the part of a wise general who never disregards the slightest weakness in his defences.
('75', 242, 2, 23, 460765) Kheda and Champaran are but instances in point.
('75', 242, 2, 24, 460813) Whilst they lasted they occupied the attention of the whole of India, and whilst the fight was going on I had to devote the whole of my time and attention to them.
('75', 242, 2, 25, 460977) It is a rare occurrence to have to deal with the whole front at the same time.
('75', 242, 2, 26, 461056) We must distinguish between preparat ions for war and actual outbreak of a skirmish, be it ever so insigni ficant in itself.
('75', 242, 2, 27, 461181) Tripuri was a preparation, Rajkot was a Skirmish.
('75', 242, 2, 28, 461231) The fast is a most efficacious weapon in the armoury of non 
('75', 243, 0, 1, 461292) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 243, 1, 2, 461334) violence.
('75', 243, 1, 3, 461344) That it can be used only by the fewest possible persons is no objection to its use.
('75', 243, 1, 4, 461428) It would be foolish for me not to use the talents given to me by God on the ground that others or all do not possess some of them.
('75', 243, 1, 5, 461559) I have never heard it said that use of special talents placed at the service of democracy can retard its even growth.
('75', 243, 1, 6, 461677) I hold that such use stimulates it as the Rajkot fast undoubtedly has.
('75', 243, 1, 7, 461748) And why is the Rajkot fast to be condemned, if the nation benefited by the previous fasts?
('75', 243, 1, 8, 461839) It is open to the critics to say that the previous ones were also criticized.
('75', 243, 1, 9, 461917) So they were.
('75', 243, 1, 10, 461931) But my point is that the nation gained by every one of them.
('75', 243, 1, 11, 461992) What does arrest the growth of the democratic spirit is the outbreak of violence.
('75', 243, 1, 12, 462074) I must ask the public to believe me when I say that if my fast did nothing else, it prevented much violence.
('75', 243, 1, 13, 462183) I have no sense of shame about going to H. E. the Viceroy.
('75', 243, 1, 14, 462242) I had invited him as the Crown Representative to perform his duty by intervening to enforce performance of a promise by a tributary of the Crown.
('75', 243, 1, 15, 462388) I had not gone as a petitioner depending upon his mercy.
('75', 243, 1, 16, 462445) It would have been churlish on my part to have sought his intervention and yet not to respond to his invitation to see him to discuss things.
('75', 243, 1, 17, 462587) I have already acknowledged the handsome manner in which he acted during the fast.
('75', 243, 1, 18, 462670) It was open to him to disregard it and take his time in deciding whether and when if at all he should intervene.
('75', 243, 1, 19, 462783) But he did not do so.
('75', 243, 1, 20, 462805) He recognized the nation’s anxiety.
('75', 243, 1, 21, 462841) And I have no doubt that his humane instinct, too, had a share in cutting short his tour in Rajputana in order to determine his action with sufficient quickness.
('75', 243, 1, 22, 463003) I have no apology to offer for my attendances on the Viceroy.
('75', 243, 1, 23, 463065) It is part of satyagraha to lose no opportunity of converting one’s opponent or coming to terms with him on strictly honourable lines.
('75', 243, 1, 24, 463200) I repeated on a small scale with Lord Linlithgow what I did with Lord Halifax when as Lord Irwin he was Viceroy of India.
('75', 243, 1, 25, 463322) Lastly, as to my acceptance of the Chief Justice of India as the interpreter of the Thakore Saheb’s letter of 26th December last sent to Sardar Vallabhabhai Patel.
('75', 243, 1, 26, 463486) The Thakore Saheb interpreted it one way, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel another way.
('75', 243, 1, 27, 463566) The Viceroy suggested inter pretation by the Chief Justice of India.
('75', 243, 1, 28, 463635) What was I to do?
('75', 243, 1, 29, 463653) Was I to say he must not because he was Chief Justice of a Court which was a creation of the Government of India Act?
('75', 243, 1, 30, 463771) My sense of propriety would rebel against any such objection.
('75', 243, 1, 31, 463833) Federation has come no nearer by my accepting Maurice Gwyer’s nomination as judge of the meaning of a document.
('75', 243, 1, 32, 463945) If it comes as an imposition, it will come
('75', 244, 0, 1, 463988) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 245
('75', 244, 1, 2, 464032) because of our impotence born of our inability to bring into non violent subjection the forces of violence that are growing in the country and the increasing indiscipline and corruption in the Congress against which I have been raising my voice for the past twelve months.
('75', 244, 1, 3, 464305) It may interest the reader to know that Sir Maurice did not interpret the document in his capacity as Cheif Justice of the Federal Court but as a jurist of established repute.
('75', 244, 1, 4, 464481) He who reads the judgement cannot fail to notice the pains he bestowed upon it.
('75', 244, 1, 5, 464561) ON THE TRAIN FROM DELHI TO RAJKOT, April 8, 1939 Harijan, 15 4 1939

('75', 245, 7, 11, 466007) 318. LETTER TO BRIJKRISHNA CHANDIWALA [April 8, 1939] 3
('75', 245, 8, 12, 466063) BRAJKISAN, Why such a long letter?
('75', 245, 8, 13, 466098) I admit my mistake.
('75', 245, 8, 14, 466118) My nature is responsible for it.

('75', 246, 0, 1, 467015) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 247
('75', 246, 1, 2, 467059) 319. WHAT TO DO?
('75', 246, 2, 3, 467076) Here is an important letter 1 from a Principal who wishes to remain anonymous:
('75', 246, 3, 4, 467155) A troubled conscience seeks the reasoned opinion of others to help to solve the following pressing question: Is the carrying out of the pledge of the Peace Pledge Union (the late Dick Shepard’s organization for opposing war by the refusal to resort to violence under any circumstances whatever) a right and a practicable course of action in the present conditions of our world ?
('75', 246, 4, 5, 467534) On the side of ‘Yea’ there are the following arguments:
('75', 246, 5, 6, 467590) 1. The world’s greatest spiritual teachers have taught and exemplified in their own lives that an evil thing can only be destroyed by good means, and never by evil means, and any sort of violence .
('75', 246, 5, 7, 467788) is undoubtedly an evil means, whatever may be the motive.
('75', 246, 6, 8, 467846) 2.The real causes of the present violence and misery can never be removed by war.
('75', 246, 7, 9, 467928) even if it ends in victory, means.
('75', 246, 7, 10, 467963) destruction of such liberties as remain to us.
('75', 246, 7, 11, 468010) for no modern war can be waged .
('75', 246, 7, 12, 468043) without the complete regimentation .
('75', 246, 7, 13, 468080) It is better to die in conscientiously resisting oppression non violently, than to live as a pawn in the regimented society .
('75', 246, 8, 14, 468206) On the side of ‘Nay’ there are the following arguments:
('75', 246, 9, 15, 468262) 1. Non violent resistance can only be effective in resisting people who are capable of being moved by moral and humanitarian consideratons.
('75', 246, 9, 16, 468402) Fascism .
('75', 246, 9, 17, 468412) has no scruple .
('75', 246, 9, 18, 468429) in employing any degree of brutality .
('75', 246, 10, 19, 468468) 2. To refuse co operation in violent resistance.
('75', 246, 10, 20, 468517) in defence of democratic liberty, is tantamount to helping those who are destroying that liberty.
('75', 246, 10, 21, 468615) Fascist aggression has undoubtedly been encouraged by the knowledge that the democracies contain numbers of people who are unwilling to fight in their defence, and who would even oppose (and thus obstruct) their own Governments ...
('75', 246, 10, 22, 468847) This being so, the conscientious objector to violent means of defence becomes not merely ineffective in promoting peace, but actually helpful to those who are breaking it.
('75', 246, 11, 23, 469019) 3.War may destroy liberty, but if the democracies survive there is at least
('75', 246, 12, 24, 469095) some possibility of regaining part of it, whereas if the Fascists are allowed to
('75', 246, 13, 25, 469176) rule the world, there is no chance at all.
('75', 246, 14, 26, 469219) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('75', 247, 0, 1, 469256) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 247, 1, 2, 469298) The solution of this question is obviously terribly pressing ...
('75', 247, 1, 3, 469363) But is it not really just as pressing for those in other countries, say South Africa, Egypt, or Australia which may have to face the possibility of invasion, or in an India which in the event of ‘complete independence’ might be faced with the possibility of invasion by Japan or by a pan Islamic combination?
('75', 247, 2, 4, 469672) In the face of such possibilities (say rather probabilities), ought not even every keen conscience (whether in a young body or in an old) to be certain exactly what is the right and practical way of action?...
('75', 247, 2, 5, 469882) Nothing need be said about the arguments in favour of the Peace Pledger’s resistance.
('75', 247, 2, 6, 469968) Those against resistance deserve careful examination.
('75', 247, 2, 7, 470022) The first argument, if it is valid, cuts at the very root of the anti war movement.
('75', 247, 2, 8, 470106) It is based on the assumption that it is possible to convert Fascists and Nazis.
('75', 247, 2, 9, 470187) They belong to the same species as the so called democracies or, better still, war resisters themselves.
('75', 247, 2, 10, 470292) They show in their family circles the same tenderness, affection, consideration and generosity that war resisters are likely to show even outside such circles.
('75', 247, 2, 11, 470452) The difference is only of degree.
('75', 247, 2, 12, 470486) Indeed Fascists and Nazis are a revised edition of so called democracies if they are not an answer to the latters’ misdeeds.
('75', 247, 2, 13, 470611) Kirby Page in his brochure on the toll of the late war has shown that both the combatants were guilty of falsehoods, exaggerations and inhumanities.
('75', 247, 2, 14, 470760) The Versailles Treaty was a treaty of revenge against Germany by the victors.
('75', 247, 2, 15, 470838) The so called democracies have before now misappropriated other people’s lands and have resorted to ruthless repression.
('75', 247, 2, 16, 470959) What wonder if Messrs Hitler and company have reduced to a science the unscientific violence their predecessors had developed for exploiting the so called backward races for their own material gain?
('75', 247, 2, 17, 471158) It is therefore a matter of rule of three to find out the exact amount of non violence required to melt the harder hearts of the Fascists and the Nazis, if it is assume, as it is, that the so called democracies melt before a given amount of non violence.
('75', 247, 2, 18, 471413) Therefore, we must eliminate from consi deration the first and the fatal argument if it could be proved to have any content in it.
('75', 247, 2, 19, 471544) The other two arguments are practical.
('75', 247, 2, 20, 471583) The pacifists may not do anything to weaken their own Governments so as to compel defeat.
('75', 247, 2, 21, 471673) But for fear of so doing they may not miss the only effective chance they have of demonstrating their undying faith in the futility of all war.
('75', 247, 2, 22, 471817) If their own Governments go mad and make martyrs of war resisters, they (the Governments) must, suffer the consequence of the unrest of their own creation.
('75', 247, 2, 23, 471973) The democracies must respect the liberty
('75', 248, 0, 1, 472014) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 249
('75', 248, 1, 2, 472058) of individual non violent conscience however it may be.
('75', 248, 1, 3, 472114) From that respect there will spring hope for the world.
('75', 248, 1, 4, 472170) This means that they put their conscience and truth before their country’s so called interest.
('75', 248, 1, 5, 472265) For regard for one’s conscience, if it is really such, has never yet injured any legitimate cause or interest.
('75', 248, 1, 6, 472376) Therefore, it comes to this that a pacifist must resist when he feels strongly that, whether so called democracies live or die, the tug of war will never end war and that it will only end when at the crucial moment a body of pacifists have at any cost testified their living faith by suffering, if need be, the extreme penalty.
('75', 248, 1, 7, 472704) I know the point for me to consider is not how to avoid the extreme penalty but how to behave so as to achieve the object in view.
('75', 248, 1, 8, 472835) Where the very disturbing but potent factor of faith is part of one’s conduct, human calculations are of no avail.
('75', 248, 1, 9, 472950) A true pacifist is a true satyagrahi.
('75', 248, 1, 10, 472988) The latter acts by faith and therefore is not concerned about the result, for he knows that it is assured when the action is true.
('75', 248, 1, 11, 473119) After all, what is the gain if the so called democracies win?
('75', 248, 1, 12, 473181) War certainly will not end.
('75', 248, 1, 13, 473209) Democracies will have adopted all the tactics of the Fascists and the Nazis including conscription and all other forcible methods to compel and exact obedience.
('75', 248, 1, 14, 473370) All that may be gained at the end of the victory is the possiblity of comparative protection of individual liberty.
('75', 248, 1, 15, 473486) But that protection does not depend upon outside help.
('75', 248, 1, 16, 473541) it comes from the internal determination to protect it against the whole world.
('75', 248, 1, 17, 473621) In other words, the true democrat is he who with purely non violent means defends his liberty and therefore his country’s and ultimately that of the whole of mankind.
('75', 248, 1, 18, 473788) In the coming test pacifists have to prove their faith by resolutely refusing to do anything with war whether of defence or offence.
('75', 248, 1, 19, 473921) But the duty of resistance accrues only to those who believe in non violence as a creed—not to those who will calculate and will examine the merits of each case and decide whether to approve of or oppose a particular war.
('75', 248, 1, 20, 474143) It follows that such resistance is a matter for each person to decide for himself and under the guidance of the inner voice, if he recognizes its existence.
('75', 248, 1, 21, 474300) RAJKOT, April 9, 1939 Harijan, 15 4 1939

('75', 252, 3, 7, 479962) 324. LETTER TO AKBAR HYDARI
('75', 252, 4, 8, 479990) SHREE RASHTREEYASHALA, RAJKOT, April 10, 1939
('75', 252, 5, 9, 480036) DEAR SIR AKBAR, Shri Ghanshyamsinh Gupta and Shri Deshbandhu Gupta have followed me to Rajkot to seek my advice after the utter breakdown of negotiations between the Government and the Aryasamaj by reason of H. E. H’s Government’s denial of the reports about negotiations.
('75', 252, 5, 10, 480309) I may state that for some time I have been advising the Aryasamaj friends who have regard for my opinions to suspend the civil disobedience part of their movement and give a chance to negotiations.
('75', 252, 5, 11, 480507) I need not go into the reasons that actuated me to give the advice.
('75', 252, 5, 12, 480575) The friends were seriously considering my advice, when a door seemed to them to open to its acceptance on grounds other than those I had advanced.
('75', 252, 5, 13, 480722) I refer to the negotiations.
('75', 252, 5, 14, 480751) They thought that if their minimum demand could be satisfied they would discontinue the civil disobedience.
('75', 252, 5, 15, 480859) But as stated, their hope was frustrated.
('75', 252, 5, 16, 480901) Now they want me to guide them as to the next step.
('75', 252, 5, 17, 480953) They wanted to issue a manifesto stating their ground for entertaining the opinion that actual negotiations had started.
('75', 252, 5, 18, 481074) On reading the manifesto I felt that before I could give them guidance I should write to you myself and know your own opinion.
('75', 252, 5, 19, 481201) If the information I gather from the manifesto is true, the Nizam Government’s denial is inexplicable.
('75', 252, 5, 20, 481304) Here are the relevant paragraphs from the draft manifesto which has been with held for the time being at my instance:
('75', 252, 6, 21, 481422) About the last week of February, the Divisional Commissioner and the
('75', 252, 7, 22, 481491) 1 The addressee had said: “At Tripuri the Old Guard cleverly dropped out of the picture and more cleverly pitted me against you.”
('75', 253, 0, 1, 481621) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 253, 1, 2, 481663) Collector of Gulburga interviewed Mahatma Narain Swami Maharaj, the leader of the movement, in Jail with a view to ascertain the grievances of the Aryas, and promised to move the higher authorities to explore the possibilities for an amicable settlement.
('75', 253, 2, 3, 481918) On the 27th March, 1939, Mr. S. T. Hollins, the Director General of Police and Jails, Hyderabad State, Nawab Ghos Yarjang Bahadur, Commissioner, Gulburga Division, Mr. Razvi, the Collector, Gulburga District, and the Superintendent, Gulburga Jail, interviewed Mahatma Narain Swamiji Maharaj, Kunvar Chand Karanji Sharda, Lala Khushalchandji and Swami Vivekanandji in the Gulburga Jail and Mr. S. T. Hollins made certain proposals, the substance of which was that H. E. H. The Nizam’s Government would take no objection whatever to the hoisting of the om flags, that no permission would be required for building yajnashalas and havan kundas and all Aryasamajs and Mandirs at present existing without any permission having been obtained would be recognized, and in the matter of building new temples, machinery would be povided to secure the granting of sanction within 15 days of the application, sanction not to be withheld on any ground other than the ground of its location being such as to give rise to communal disturbances and full liberty of preaching religious doctrines (dharma prachar) with due regard to the feelings of the followers of other faiths would be secured.
('75', 253, 3, 4, 483096) Mahatma Narain Swamiji and his colleagues expressed their wilingness to recommend the above proposals as the basis for negotiating the settlement, provided the settlement conformed to the spirit of the Sholapur Resolutions.
('75', 253, 3, 5, 483320) Swamiji made it clear to Mr. Hollins that the authority to call off the satyagraha movement rested with the Serva Deshik Sabha.
('75', 253, 4, 6, 483448) Mr. Hollins thereupon undertook to arrange a meeting of the representatives of the Sarva Deshik Sabha and the Government Officers concerned at Hyderabad and also to arrange for the transfer of Swamiji Maharaj and his three colleagues to Hyderabad for participating in the discussions.
('75', 253, 4, 7, 483733) On the request of the Swamiji, Mr. Hollins and the Commissioner Nawab Ghos Yarjang Bahadur promised that the representatives of Sarva Deshik Sabha would not be molested and their records would not be seized or otherwise interfered with.
('75', 253, 5, 8, 483970) Swamiji Maharaj, having been thus assured, called Swami Swatantranandji, Secretary, Satyagraha Committee, Sholapur, by telegram and also forwarded the notes recording the substance of the above conversation duly countersigned by Jail Superintendent, to the President, Secretary and some other members of the Sarva Deshik Sabha.
('75', 253, 5, 9, 484298) On the 7th instant when I,
('75', 254, 0, 1, 484325) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 255
('75', 254, 1, 2, 484369) Messrs G. S. Gupta and Deshbandhu Gupta saw Narain Swamiji in Gulburga Jail, the Jail Superintendent told us that before putting his own signature he had shown the notes of the conversation contained in Swamiji’s letters to the Talukdar, Gulburga, and had got his approval.
('75', 254, 2, 3, 484643) Swami Swatantranandji went to Gulburga and interviewed Narain Swamiji Maharaj who asked the former that an emergent meeting of the working committee of the Sarva Deshik Sabha should be immediately convened at Sholapur before 10th April 1939.
('75', 254, 3, 4, 484885) Swami Swtantranandji convened the meeting at Sholapur and wrote to Sir Akbar Hydari sending him a copy of the gist of the conversation Narain Swamiji Maharaj had with Mr. Hollins and his colleagues and informing him that the representatives of the Sarva Deshik Sabha would be reaching Hyderabad to meet the state representatives on the 9th April to discuss the question and requesting him to communicate the time and place of the meeting.
('75', 254, 3, 5, 485324) In a letter dated the 1st April, 1939, Swami Swatantranandji also wrote to the Superintendent, Gulburga Jail, informing him that in addition to the members of the Executive body of the Internatinal Aryan League, the gentlemen named in the letter would represent the Sarva Deshik Sabha at the Hyderabad meeting.
('75', 254, 4, 6, 485635) Swami Swatantranandji received a letter No.
('75', 254, 4, 7, 485679) 2697, dated the 3rd April, 1939, from the Superintendent, Central Jail, Gulburga, which is very important, as it throws considerable light on the present controversy; it reads as follows:
('75', 254, 5, 8, 485867) “With reference to your letter No.
('75', 254, 5, 9, 485902) 37060, dated the 31st March, ’39, received today, I write to inform you that it has been decided to hold the meeting of your representatives with Mahatma Narain Swami, Mr. Khushalchand and others at Gulburga but not at Hyderabad.
('75', 254, 5, 10, 486132) Please get all your representatives to Sholapur and send to Gulburga by the morning mail of the 7th April, 1939, so that they may see Mahatma Narain Swami and others beforehand and be ready for the 8th instant to talk with the State officers.”
('75', 254, 6, 11, 486376) “I assure you that your representatives would never be harassed by police nor would your papers be seized here provided there would be no demonstration on your part.
('75', 254, 6, 12, 486542) Kindly let me know the date and time of their arrival at Gulburga by telegram so that necessary arrangements may be made here.
('75', 254, 6, 13, 486669) I am writing this to you with the approval of the First Talukdar, Gulburga.”
('75', 254, 7, 14, 486746) The letter speaks for itself and shows that the Jail Superintendent wrote with full authority because he distinctly states that the deputation was to meet the State officials on the 8th April, 1939.
('75', 254, 8, 15, 486945) While the leaders of the Aryasamaj were on their way to Hyderabad, Hyderabad Government issued the surprising communique that the news
('75', 255, 0, 1, 487080) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 255, 1, 2, 487122) published in certain sections of Press that H. E. H. the Nizam’s Government were negotiating with the International Aryan League with a view to arrive at some settlement or compromise was totally incorrect.
('75', 255, 1, 3, 487329) The letter dated 3rd instant and signed by the Superintendent of the Central Jail, Gulburga, seems to be conclusive.
('75', 255, 1, 4, 487446) I suggest that even if Mr. Hollins and other officials were over enthusiastic and went beyond their authority, their action should be endorsed by H. E. H.’s Government for the sake of the good name if for nothing else.

('75', 263, 2, 3, 500717) April 15, 1939 I have received your letter 1 of the 14th instant.
('75', 263, 2, 4, 500783) I have personally explained to you that you are giving an entirely different meaning to my written promise.
('75', 263, 2, 5, 500891) If the meaning which you have given is the real meaning of it, the result would be that I took a vow to give what I did not possess.
('75', 263, 2, 6, 501024) I was then going to Delhi to obtain a decision from the Chief Justice.
('75', 263, 2, 7, 501095) If that decision was against the Sardar I had nothing to give, because your representative was well protected.
('75', 263, 2, 8, 501206) But if the decision was in favour of the Sardar and if the Sardar raised protest against the appointment of more than seven representatives.
('75', 263, 2, 9, 501347) obviously your representative’s name would vanish.
('75', 263, 2, 10, 501398) Only those persons could be in the list of the Sardar who could work as part of a team.
('75', 263, 2, 11, 501486) Having this fact in view, I wrote a letter to you that you were safe because the Sardar would not protest if his purpose was served, and the Thakore Saheb would keep your name intact.
('75', 263, 2, 12, 501670) The only meaning of my promise was that the Sardar would not raise any protest if his purpose was served.
('75', 263, 2, 13, 501776) Where had I any authority to give a promise to others which would carry a meaning contrary to the above?
('75', 263, 3, 14, 501881) It appears to me to be quite clear as daylight that, if your representative is not prepared to work as one team, it would be very clear to you that he cannot be included in the list of the Sardar.
('75', 263, 3, 15, 502078) Therefore, if you intend to have your representative included in the
('75', 263, 4, 16, 502147) 1 In this.

('75', 264, 3, 5, 503513) 337. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 3
('75', 264, 4, 6, 503543) April 15, 1939 There has been for me unusual delay in sending on behalf of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel names of seven representatives to sit on the Reforms Committee in terms of the Thakore Saheb’s Notification of December 26 last and in terms of the Chief Justice’s Award.
('75', 264, 4, 7, 503814) The delay shows the measure of my anxiety as well as Sardar Patel’s to include in the list the Thakore Saheb’s four nominees whose names he had published in his now defunct Notification of 21st January last.
('75', 264, 4, 8, 504022) In accordance with the Award his nominees automatically dropped out, but the Thakore Saheb could have retained them with the co operation of Sardar Patel.
('75', 264, 4, 9, 504177) My first act on arrival in Rajkot on the 9th was to offer to His Highness in writing the Sardar’s co operation in retaining the names.
('75', 264, 4, 10, 504312) To my regret and to my astonishment the offer was summarily rejected.
('75', 264, 4, 11, 504382) The public knows from the Thakore Saheb’s reply, which was handed to the Press on his behalf, in what terms it was rejected.
('75', 264, 4, 12, 504507) He has allowed to be inferred that the Award left no scope for increasing the number of members of the Committee.
('75', 264, 4, 13, 504621) On the face of it this is not right.
('75', 264, 4, 14, 504658) With mutual consent there is ample scope for adjustment.
('75', 264, 4, 15, 504715) The Thakore Saheb is not bound by the Award not to increase or even decrease the number on the Committee, if in wanting to do so he secures the Sardar’s co operation.
('75', 264, 4, 16, 504882) When this unfortunate decision became known to me, with the fullest co operation of the Sardar I set about exploring means of accommodating at least two Muslim representatives and one Bhayat representative among the seven.
('75', 264, 4, 17, 505105) This could not be done unless they could see their way to agree to work as one team with the Sardar’s other nominees.
('75', 264, 4, 18, 505223) If this condition could not be fulfilled, the very object of giving the Sardar, i.e., the Parishad, the right to select all the
('75', 264, 5, 19, 505351) 1Vide “Letter to Dharmendrasinh”, 14 4 1939 2 According to the source, “in the course of a lengthy reply” the addressee “asserted that Gandhiji’s promise to give one seat to the Bhayats was unconditional.” 3 This is extracted from “Rajkot Events”.
('75', 264, 5, 20, 505599) The statement appeared in The Hindustan Times and The Hindu on April 16.
('75', 265, 0, 1, 505672) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 265, 1, 2, 505714) seven members could be easily frustrated.
('75', 265, 1, 3, 505756) But in spite of making all efforts it was humanly possible both for the Sardar and me to make, we failed and, therefore, the public will find that all the four nominees of the Thakore Saheb have been omitted.
('75', 265, 1, 4, 505965) This, however, does not mean that the Committee will not represent all interests that could have been covered by the four nominees and several other interests, not specifically represented, for I have not known a single such committee in the world which could cover specifically and sectionally all imaginable interests.
('75', 265, 1, 5, 506286) The very essence of democracy is that every person represents all the varied interests which compose the nation.
('75', 265, 1, 6, 506399) It is true that it does not exclude, and should not exclude, special representation of special interests, but such representation is not its test.
('75', 265, 1, 7, 506546) It is a sign of its imperfection.
('75', 265, 1, 8, 506580) I do not claim perfection for the Rajkot committee, but any attempt on the part of the Sardar to accommodate all the special interests,without the indispensable safeguard that I have suggested, would have failed to produce a constitution which could be satisfactorily worked in the interests of the whole of the people of Rajkot.
('75', 265, 1, 9, 506910) I venture to suggest that the Sardar’s nominees have been selected after fulfilling the first indispensable condition of team work, so that they would all make a conscientious effort to represent each in his own person the whole of the interests of the people of Rajkot.
('75', 265, 1, 10, 507181) Therefore, it will be doubly the duty of the seven members to safeguard and protect all the special and legitimate rights of the Muslims, the Bhayats and the Harijans of the Rajkot State.
('75', 265, 1, 11, 507369) As to the Harijan representation, I may say that Shri Mohan Mandan, the fourth nominee of the Thakore Saheb, an estimable citizen of Rajkot though he is, is in no sense a Harijan any more than the seven nominees whose names have now been submitted to the Thakore Saheb on behalf of the Sardar.
('75', 265, 1, 12, 507663) The Garasia Association has accused me in forcible language of a breach of promise in excluding their representative from the list of seven.
('75', 265, 1, 13, 507804) All I can say is that they have hopelessly misread and misunderstood my letter 1 of March 11. I do not propose at present to go into the immediate circumstance in which I hastily penned my reply to their note, but it has got to be read in conjunction with the
('75', 265, 2, 14, 508064) 1Vide footnote 3, “Letter to Garasias”, 13 4 1939
('75', 266, 0, 1, 508114) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 267
('75', 266, 1, 2, 508158) statement 1 with which I left Wardha on what I have described as a mission of peace.
('75', 266, 1, 3, 508243) I then stated, as an indispensable condition of acceptance of any permutation and combination that might be offered for the composition of the Committee, that on it Sardar’s nominees should have at least a bare majority of one.
('75', 266, 1, 4, 508471) The letter of March 11 has got to be read together with that condition.
('75', 266, 1, 5, 508543) Nothing whatsoever happened on March 11 to make me waive that condition.
('75', 266, 1, 6, 508616) Assuming for the moment that I forgot to incorporate the condition in my letter, the Garasia friends would be expected to read my letter with the missing condition.
('75', 266, 1, 7, 508781) But I go a step further, that to read into my letter the meaning that the Garasia Association gives it, is to frustrate the very object which was sought to be secured by the Thakore Saheb’s letter to the Sardar.
('75', 266, 1, 8, 508993) With the meaning that he attached to it and which meaning the Chief Justice’s Award has fully upheld, I had no right to throw away that precious right.
('75', 266, 1, 9, 509145) I should be guilty of a breach of trust if I did so.
('75', 266, 1, 10, 509198) It should be remembered that the fast was taken for the purpose of vindicating the Sardar’s position and, therefore, if you like, to repair the breach of faith which I had imputed to the Thakore Saheb.
('75', 266, 1, 11, 509400) The Award has done it.
('75', 266, 1, 12, 509423) Is it to be expected that at a time when I was proceeding to Delhi in the full expectation of the Sardar’s contention being upheld, I was to undo in advance the effect of such a happy termination of the Delhi visit?
('75', 266, 1, 13, 509639) I have more than fulfilled my promise contained in my letter of March 11 addressed to the Garasia Association by offering to reduce to one the majority of four which the Award gives to the Sardar’s nominees.
('75', 266, 1, 14, 509847) I think I deserved better treatment from the Association.
('75', 266, 1, 15, 509905) All their appeal should have been to the Thakore Saheb to seize the opportunity given by me of rehabilitating his nominees.
('75', 266, 1, 16, 510029) Instead of choosing that obvious course, they have chosen the wrong course.
('75', 266, 1, 17, 510105) I have reminded the Garasias that, when I returned from my self imposed exile, at the end of 1914, I gave them ample proof of my friendship and concern for them.
('75', 266, 1, 18, 510267) They had first met me in Bhavnagar.
('75', 266, 1, 19, 510303) Since then they have been off and on seeking my guidance and advice.
('75', 266, 1, 20, 510372) Many of them know that it has been always at their disposal.
('75', 266, 1, 21, 510433) But no mischief is yet done.
('75', 266, 1, 22, 510462) As I have said, they may rest assured that all their just rights will be respected by the Sardar’s nominees.
('75', 266, 1, 23, 510571) Harijan, 22 4 1939

('75', 269, 1, 2, 514492) 342. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 269, 2, 3, 514522) April 16, 1939 What has hurt me most about this evening’s demonstration 2 is that the demonstrators chose what was for me a solemn hour of the day.
('75', 269, 2, 4, 514670) For years all India knows I have offered without practically a breach my evening prayers in open congregation.
('75', 269, 2, 5, 514781) Why did thay seek my prayer time to molest me, and what had the numerous men, women and children, who at the end of the day had come to offer their humble prayers to the one and only God of us all, done to deserve such inter ference?
('75', 269, 2, 6, 515015) Why was it not enough, seeing that I do not go out except for prayers, to shout their slogans and wave black flags as I entered the prayer ground?
('75', 269, 2, 7, 515162) Even that would have been bad enough.
('75', 269, 2, 8, 515200) But they continued vigorously to shout their slogans throughout the prayers.
('75', 269, 2, 9, 515277) And they were all my countrymen.
('75', 269, 2, 10, 515310) Their cries pierced me like arrows whilst I was trying to concentrate my mind on the words of the prayers.
('75', 269, 2, 11, 515417) I have not attained the power of meditation which makes one impervious to all disturbances from without.
('75', 269, 2, 12, 515522) They knew that if they had invited me to attend their meeting in order to witness their hostile demonstration and their wrath, weak as I have been, I would have gone there and tried to appease them.
('75', 269, 2, 13, 515721) I maintain I have not committed any breach of promise.
('75', 269, 2, 14, 515776) To my knowledge, throughout my public and private career, I have never broken a promise.
('75', 269, 2, 15, 515865) Here the very motive for a breach of promise is lacking.
('75', 269, 2, 16, 515922) But lest I might have made a promise, however hastily, which could bear another meaning than one I had put upon my letter to the Bhayats of March 11, I asked as many legal friends in Rajkot as I could get together and warned them to give their unbiased opinion and told them that their reputation would be lost if they sought to support without full cause my own reading of my letter.
('75', 269, 2, 17, 516307) I have their reasoned and unanimous opinion in my possession, fully supporting my meaning to the exclusion of any other.
('75', 269, 2, 18, 516428) I fear the demonstrators have not served their cause by their unwarranted interference with the prayer of innocent men and women.
('75', 269, 2, 19, 516558) There are tremendous difficulties in the way of getting due
('75', 269, 3, 20, 516618) 1 This is extracted from “Rajkot Events”.
('75', 269, 3, 21, 516660) The statement appeared in The Hind ustan Times and The Hindu on April 17. 2 For Pyarelal’s account of the incident,Vide “The Way of Satyagraha”

('75', 270, 1, 2, 516848) fulfilment of the Award of the Chief Justice.

('75', 270, 2, 8, 517222) 343. UNHAPPY TRAVANCORE
('75', 270, 3, 9, 517246) The following is the substantial translation of the resolutions passed by the Working Committee of the Travancore State Congress in the first week of the month 1:
('75', 270, 4, 10, 517409) The working committee records its appreciation of the decision taken by the Acting President and the Council of Action to suspend civil disobedience pursuant to the advice 2 of Mahatma Gandhi.
('75', 270, 4, 11, 517602) The working Committee desires to emphasize the need at this juncture for local and taluk committees to concentrate on the constructive work and strengthen the organizational side of the movement....
('75', 270, 5, 12, 517801) Khadi: The working Committee appoints a sub committee consisting of Sjts.
('75', 270, 5, 13, 517875) Elankath Ramakrishna Pillai(Convener), G. Ramachandran and K. M. Bhoot halingam Pillai to submit an exhaustive report on the facilities available in the State for the spinning and weaving of khadi and to submit a scheme for the same.
('75', 270, 5, 14, 518109) This committee is further directed to choose and recommend further centres where work can be immediately commenced.
('75', 270, 6, 15, 518225) Indigenous weaving: For the purpose of encouraging indigenous weaving (which is an important industry in the State), the Working Committee constitutes Sjts.
('75', 270, 6, 16, 518382) R. Shankar (Convener), K.S. Thangal and M.G. Koshi as a sub committee to submit scheme for the same.
('75', 270, 7, 17, 518483) Official goondaism: The Working Committee view with deep concern the rowdyism that is being inspired to suppress the State Congress activities.
('75', 270, 7, 18, 518627) The Committee recalls the hooliganism instigated by the police in the State Congress meetings during the months of May and June last year.
('75', 270, 7, 19, 518766) Until the release of political prisoners in November last, State Congress meetings were sought to be prevented either by prohibitory orders or by hooliganism or by declaring the State Congress illegal.
('75', 270, 7, 20, 518968) After the release, though numerous
('75', 270, 8, 21, 519003) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('75', 270, 8, 22, 519040) 2 Vide “Statement Suspending Travancore Satyagraha”, 23 3 1939
('75', 271, 0, 1, 519103) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 271, 1, 2, 519145) meetings were held before the middle of January, there were no disturbances whatever.
('75', 271, 1, 3, 519231) In the mean time the Government began recruiting what is called the special police.
('75', 271, 1, 4, 519315) These special policemen have no uniform and their pay was fixed at Rs. 5 per month.
('75', 271, 1, 5, 519399) Towards the middle of January 1939, these special policemen commenced attending meetings at Neyyattinkara and Parurtaluks.
('75', 271, 1, 6, 519522) These so called policemen and the rowdies under them have since been endeavouring to break up State Congress meetings.
('75', 271, 1, 7, 519641) Even after annonucing on the 22nd the suspension of satya graha,volunteer jathas and meetings for constructive work have been subjected to goondaism.
('75', 271, 2, 8, 519791) Exhortation to workers: Last November, when the political prisoners were released, it was believed that we had at least secured the liberty to hold public meetings.
('75', 271, 2, 9, 519956) The present situation, however, is worse than what existed in August last when the State Congress was declared illegal.
('75', 271, 2, 10, 520076) The committee deeply appreciates the firm faith in non violence evinced by those who attended the recent State Congress meetings.
('75', 271, 2, 11, 520206) This rowdyism is the result of the persistent policy of repression continued by Government even after the suspension of satyagraha.
('75', 271, 2, 12, 520338) Not only is the Government unwilling to grant any of the demands of the State Congress but it is continuing to arrest State Congress workers on some pretext or other and endeavouring to obstruct even the carrying out of the constructive programme of the Congress.
('75', 271, 2, 13, 520602) Whatever be the force of the repression and the extent of rowdyism that the Government may release, the State Congress will continue its work awaiting further instructions from Gandhiji.
('75', 271, 2, 14, 520789) While protesting against the hooliganism inspired and encouraged by the Government the Committee exhorts the people to carry on the work of the Congress with courage and with non violence.
('75', 271, 2, 15, 520978) I would like the workers to realize that events there have more than justified suspension of civil disobedience.
('75', 271, 2, 16, 521091) The authorities have provided them with ample opportunity for the exercise of patience and restraint.
('75', 271, 2, 17, 521193) They have also provided them with opportunity for suffering without civil disobedience.
('75', 271, 2, 18, 521281) If, therefore, the workers can go through the ordeal without losing faith or heart and prosecute quietly and resolutely the constructive programme, swaraj will come automatically.
('75', 271, 2, 19, 521461) This is a bold statement; some will call it ridiculous.
('75', 271, 2, 20, 521517) Nevertheless it comes from the deepest conviction.
('75', 271, 2, 21, 521568) What worries me, however, is the statement in the concluding paragraph that “the State Congress will continue its work awaiting further instructions from Gandhiji.” This declaration of faith in me is both touching and embarrassing.
('75', 271, 2, 22, 521800) Let the workers know that whilst my
('75', 272, 0, 1, 521836) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 273
('75', 272, 1, 2, 521880) advice and guidance are always at their disposal, I have no further instructions to give till new light dawns on me.
('75', 272, 1, 3, 521997) I have prescribed a well tried remedy.
('75', 272, 1, 4, 522036) And I am quite capable of saying, “Go on repeating it, for it is never failing.’ I am not likely easily to advise resumption of civil disobedience.
('75', 272, 1, 5, 522184) There is too much violence and untruth in the air to warrant resumption anywhere.
('75', 272, 1, 6, 522266) And in the case of Travancore, as I have said resumption is superfluous.
('75', 272, 1, 7, 522339) With reference to the alleged goondaism by the State, the public are bound to put implicit faith in the allegations, unless there is an impartial inquiry made.
('75', 272, 1, 8, 522499) Surely the mere denial by the authorities, no matter how often repeated, can carry no conviction.
('75', 272, 1, 9, 522597) Nor will it serve the intended purpose if a local white washing commission is appointed.
('75', 272, 1, 10, 522686) Confidence can be restored and truth brought to light only if the inquiry is made by outside judges of unimpeachable impartiality.
('75', 272, 1, 11, 522817) RAJKOT, April 17, 1939 Harijan, 22 4 1939

('75', 274, 5, 9, 525382) 348. LETTER TO RANJITSINH
('75', 274, 6, 10, 525408) April 17, 1939 I notice in the papers that you intend to obtain the interpretation of my letter through the Chief Justice and that you have appealed to the Viceroy for it.
('75', 274, 6, 11, 525580) I do not think that this is a fit case for the Chief Justice to be bothered with.
('75', 274, 6, 12, 525662) Nor is there any room for persuasion on the part of the Viceroy in this behalf so far as I am concerned.
('75', 274, 6, 13, 525767) If you people should desire it and the Chief Justice is agreeable, I, on my part, am always ready.
('75', 274, 6, 14, 525866) My suggestion is that we may place this case before any Judge in Bombay.
('75', 274, 6, 15, 525939) If reference to an arbitrator will satisfy you, I am quite game for it.
('75', 274, 6, 16, 526011) But, there is one more condition and that is that, pending the reference to and decision by the arbitrator, the work of the Committee should not be held up.
('75', 274, 6, 17, 526168) If your interpretation is accepted, I shall accept your representative by withdrawing one of the Sardar’s nominees from the Committee.
('75', 274, 6, 18, 526303) [PS.] While I was writing this letter, I received your second letter.
('75', 274, 6, 19, 526373) The answer to it is included in the foregoing.
('75', 274, 6, 20, 526420) But even if the Chief Justice takes up your reference, would it not be necessary to have an arbitrator to go into the allegations made in your handbill?
