('75', 276, 6, 24, 529904) The Hindu, 2 5 1939
('75', 276, 7, 25, 529924) 353. THE TRAGEDY OF TALCHER The reader will recall the twenty to twenty five thousand refugees of Talcher State in Orissa 2. They are, living under great difficulties in the forests of Angul in British Orissa.
('75', 276, 7, 26, 530134) I rely upon these figures because they are vouched for by Thakkar Bapa and Shri Harekrushna Mahtab.
('75', 276, 7, 27, 530234) Both of them have a reputation to lose.
('75', 276, 7, 28, 530274) Moreover Thakkar Bapa is purely a humanitarian and social reformer of long standing.
('75', 276, 7, 29, 530359) He does not dabble in politics.
('75', 276, 8, 30, 530391) 1 Inferred from the reference to Maurice Gwyer; vide letters to the addressee, The telegram appeared under the date line “Rajkot, May I”.
('75', 276, 8, 31, 530529) 2 Vide “Interview to Deputation of Victualers Association”, 2 6 1939
('75', 277, 0, 1, 530598) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 277, 1, 2, 530640) Only a few days ago it was announced in the Press that a settlement had been arrived at and that the refugees were about to return to their homes.
('75', 277, 1, 3, 530787) This news was immediately contradicted and it was stated that the Raja of Talcher had refused to honour the pact entered into by Major Hennessey, Assistant Political Agent for Orissa States North.
('75', 277, 1, 4, 530984) This was the pact signed on 21st March last:
('75', 277, 2, 5, 531029) 1. Reduction of the Miscellaneous Cess from five annas to three annas per rupee of rent, and an undertaking that after the settlement to be started about next November, the combined rent and cesses will not be higher than the Angul rent and cesses with the same classes of land.
('75', 277, 3, 6, 531308) 2. The abolition of monopolies on the necessaries of life except hides, skins, horns, ganja, opium, bhang and liquors.
('75', 277, 4, 7, 531427) 3. State administrative machinery should not be used for enforcing fines, etc., levied by Ecclesiastical Courts and Panchayats.
('75', 277, 5, 8, 531555) 4. Compulsory labour (bethi ) should be abolished except when necessary for public purposes and then on payment of wages at ordinary rates.
('75', 277, 6, 9, 531695) 5. The abolition of special taxes (poll tax) on industrial castes.
('75', 277, 7, 10, 531762) 6. There should be no victimization of refugees on their return to the States.
('75', 277, 8, 11, 531841) 7. Constitutional Reforms enabling the people to participate in the administration through their representatives will be introduced as soon as the schemes are approved by the Political Department.
('75', 277, 9, 12, 532038) 8. There shall be no interference with freedom of speech and meeting provided that there is nothing subversive or disloyal to the Ruler or his administration in those speeches or meetings.
('75', 277, 10, 13, 532227) 9. People should be allowed to kill wild animals in the State on their own property without any penalties or fees.
('75', 277, 10, 14, 532342) There were present at the time Major Hennessey, F.R.S.A., I.A., BAR 
('75', 277, 11, 15, 532411) AT LAW, Major Gregory of the Military Intelligence Department, Shri Harekrushna Mahtab, Adjutant Woods of the Salvation Army, and the Revenue Commissioner representing the Orissa Government.
('75', 277, 11, 16, 532602) Major Hennessey, I understand from Thakkar Bapa, was quite confident that he had the authority of the Raja of Talcher to sign the pact.
('75', 277, 11, 17, 532738) How the Raja can now refuse to endorse it is difficult to understand.
('75', 277, 11, 18, 532808) But the mystery deepens when on recalls the terms of the sanad under which the Raja holds Talcher.
('75', 277, 11, 19, 532907) Here are the relevant clauses of
('75', 278, 0, 1, 532940) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 279
('75', 278, 1, 2, 532984) the sanad issued to the small Orissa States by the present Viceroy on 26th February 1937 :
('75', 278, 2, 3, 533075) 3. That you shall do your utmost to suppress crime of all kinds in your State.
('75', 278, 3, 4, 533154) 4. That you shall administer justice fairly and impartially to all alike.
('75', 278, 4, 5, 533228) 5. That you shall recognize and maintain the rights of all your people and on no account oppress, or suffer them in and way to be oppressed, and that, in particular, you shall charge yourself personally with the welfare of the aboriginal population of your State.
('75', 278, 5, 6, 533492) 6. That you shall act in accordance with such advice as may be given to you by the Agent to the Governor General, Eastern States, or such other Political Officer as may be vested with authority in this behalf by H. E. the Viceroy.
('75', 278, 5, 7, 533723) Under Clause 6 of the sanad the Raja is bound to act in accordance with such advice as may be given to him “by the Agent to the Governor General, Eastern States, or such other Political Officer as may be vested with authority in this behalf by H. E. the Viceroy”.
('75', 278, 5, 8, 533987) The Raja has therfore no option but to carry out the wishes of the Assistant Political Agent.
('75', 278, 5, 9, 534081) The question is, why is there all this delay in carrying out the pact?
('75', 278, 5, 10, 534152) The interests of over 20,000 refugees living on sparse food and practically without shelter are at stake.
('75', 278, 5, 11, 534258) Delay is not only dangerous; it is criminal.
('75', 278, 5, 12, 534303) RAJKOT, April 18, 1939 Harijan, 22 4 1939

('75', 281, 1, 2, 536874) 360. LETTER TO E. C. GIBSON
('75', 281, 2, 3, 536902) ANANDKUNJ, RAJKOT, April 19, 1939
('75', 281, 3, 4, 536936) DEAR MR. GIBSON, I am lying on my back with severe headache and slight temperature which has up to now been diagnosed as gastric flu which seems to be raging about in Rajkot and especially in the house in which I am accommodated.
('75', 281, 3, 5, 537166) I came here on the 9th instant.
('75', 281, 3, 6, 537198) It is the 19th today.
('75', 281, 3, 7, 537220) A matter which need not have taken more than a day has taken ten days.
('75', 281, 3, 8, 537291) Unfortunately, we hold different view about the cause.
('75', 281, 3, 9, 537346) I become confirmed in my opinion that Durbar Virawala is at the back of all this delay.
('75', 281, 3, 10, 537434) I have proof enough which may not hold water in a court of law but it is enough for all practical purposes and certainly enough for me.
('75', 281, 3, 11, 537570) I have no grudge against Durbar Virawala.
('75', 281, 3, 12, 537612) I would love to convert him.
('75', 281, 3, 13, 537641) It would be a triumph of non violence if I could do so.
('75', 281, 3, 14, 537697) And I could, if I had your active co operation.
('75', 281, 3, 15, 537745) But I know you cannot give it so long as you hold the very high opinion you do of his ability, efficiency and straight forwardness.
('75', 281, 3, 16, 537877) I send you herewith copy of the latest letter 1 from the Thakore Saheb.
('75', 281, 3, 17, 537949) It speaks for itself.
('75', 281, 3, 18, 537971) If the proposition laid down in the letter were to be acted upon, there would never be a committee formed in terms of the Award of the Chief Justice of India.
('75', 281, 3, 19, 538130) The whole plan laid out in Delhi bids fair to be completely frustrated if you, as the local representative of the Paramount Power, do not actively intervene.
('75', 281, 3, 20, 538288) I invite your attention to the fact that in the Thakore Saheb’s letter to the Sardar dated the 12th January four out of the seven names were accepted.
('75', 281, 3, 21, 538439) In an Appendix to the voluminous papers attached to the Thakore Saheb’s case, signed by Durbar Virawala as his political adviser, occurs the analysis of all the seven names recommended by the Sardar.
('75', 281, 3, 22, 538639) Only two have been objected to because of their residential disqualification.
('75', 281, 3, 23, 538717) How is it that now suddenly the qualifications of all but one have been challenged?
('75', 281, 3, 24, 538801) And if I am to bear the burden that is sought to be placed upon me, there will be no end to the preliminaries and there will be no enquiry.
('75', 281, 3, 25, 538941) I do not like the idea of troubling you or seeking the intervention of the Paramount Power.
('75', 281, 3, 26, 539033) But I see there is no way out of
('75', 281, 4, 27, 539066) 1Vide footnote 1, “Letter to Chandan Parekh”, 14 4 1939
('75', 282, 0, 1, 539122) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 283
('75', 282, 1, 2, 539166) the difficulty.
('75', 282, 1, 3, 539182) The Bhayats and Garasias Association has also taken up what I consider to be a most unreasonable attitude.
('75', 282, 1, 4, 539289) As soon as I read in the papers that they wanted my so called promise to be submitted to impartial scrutiny, I wrote 1 at once accepting the proposal.
('75', 282, 1, 5, 539440) But as I sensed danger of interminable delay I said the proceedings ought not to interfere with the Committee’s work and that if their contention was upheld, the Bhayats’ nominee would immediately be accepted and one name withdrawn.
('75', 282, 1, 6, 539673) The Association, however, would not listen to my proposal.
('75', 282, 1, 7, 539732) They would hold up the formation of the Committee till the Judge was selected and his award was available.
('75', 282, 1, 8, 539839) Acceptance of my proposal would not have resulted in the Committee functioning before the award but it would certainly have resulted in the case being decided expeditiously enough.
('75', 282, 1, 9, 540020) I have given the opinion that the Chief Justice of India ought not to be troubled over the issue though I should have no objection to Sir Maurice adjudicating if the Government of India could be induced to invite him to do so and if he accepted the invitation.
('75', 282, 1, 10, 540281) I have suggested instead a Judge of the Bombay High Court.
('75', 282, 1, 11, 540340) I have no doubt that you could manage this thing easily.
('75', 282, 1, 12, 540397) I suppose the Judge could fly here tomorrrow or the day after.
('75', 282, 1, 13, 540460) I have not much to submit to him nor can the Bhayats have much either.
('75', 282, 1, 14, 540531) The Judge need not take long to give his judgement.
('75', 282, 1, 15, 540583) What I fear and suspect is that there is no desire anywhere to play the game.
('75', 282, 1, 16, 540661) You do not mind my thinking aloud before you.
('75', 282, 1, 17, 540707) I would be less than just to you if I suppressed my innermost thoughts whilst I looked up to you as the local Crown Representative to see that the Committee was properly set up and its work proceeded with, smoothly and without delay.
('75', 282, 1, 18, 540941) I must leave Rajkot on the 24th instant by the 1.10 afternoon train and hasten to Calcutta, thence to Brindaban.
('75', 282, 1, 19, 541054) I would return here at the earliest possible moment which cannot be before the 7th proximo.
('75', 282, 1, 20, 541146) Meanwhile Shri Dhebarbhai will be acting on my behalf.
('75', 282, 1, 21, 541201) But I hope that during the five days that I am here, much work will have been done.
('75', 282, 1, 22, 541285) May I remind you that my fast was only suspended and if all my efforts fail and no headway is made I must resume it?
('75', 282, 1, 23, 541402) It won’t be without serious reflection.
('75', 282, 1, 24, 541442) I do not want to do so.
('75', 282, 1, 25, 541466) I have not the
('75', 282, 2, 26, 541481) 1Vide “Letter to Ranjitsinh”, 17 4 1939
('75', 283, 0, 1, 541521) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 283, 1, 2, 541563) physical energy for it.
('75', 283, 1, 3, 541587) But a peremptory call of duty knows no mundane difficulty.
('75', 283, 1, 4, 541646) The matter is so serious that I would like you to convey at least the substance of this letter to His Excellency.
('75', 283, 1, 5, 541760) I am loath to interfere with his much needed rest.
('75', 283, 1, 6, 541811) If you think that there is substance in my complaint and that you have the will and the powers to deal with it I would much rather that His Excellency were kept undisturbed.

('75', 284, 6, 9, 543313) 363. LETTER TO E. C. GIBSON
('75', 284, 7, 10, 543341) ANANDKUNJ, RAJKOT, April 20, 1939
('75', 284, 8, 11, 543375) DEAR MR. GIBSON, This is the offer which you admitted as sporting, and which I made at our interview.
('75', 284, 8, 12, 543477) I must confess that it was born of despair.
('75', 284, 8, 13, 543521) I am tired of fighting unseen forces in Rajkot—a situation I have never been obliged to face throughout my life.
('75', 284, 8, 14, 543634) The offer is that Parishad should withdraw from the proposed committee altogether and that the Thakore Saheb should nominate his own committee in terms of the Notification, that this committee should be formed at once and should present its report to the Thakore Saheb within one month and four days from its formation.
('75', 284, 8, 15, 543954) If the Constitution that will be framed by the committee is not in terms of the Notification, the Rajkot Rajya Praja Parishad, represented by the seven nominees, should have the right to dissent from it and the Committee’s report, and the dissenting report should be submitted to the Chief Justice of India as if the Parishad was represented on the Committee in terms of the Award.
('75', 284, 8, 16, 544336) I had expected to send the note at once but as I told you my offer might create consternation among the Parishad people and so it did.
('75', 284, 8, 17, 544471) The method I have adopted is a novel method.

('75', 288, 4, 7, 550139) 370. SPEECH AT PRAJA PARISHAD WORKERS’ MEETING, RAJKOT 2
('75', 288, 5, 8, 550196) April 23, 1939 As you know for the last fifteen days I have striven hard to find a solution to the Rajkot tangle.
('75', 288, 5, 9, 550310) But I am sorry to have to confess to you that in this I have failed.
('75', 288, 5, 10, 550379) I am most grieved over our failure to arrive at a settlement with the Bhayats and the Mussalmans.
('75', 288, 5, 11, 550477) But I have the conviction, and I want you to share that conviction with me, that our labour has not been wasted.
('75', 288, 5, 12, 550590) Providence has its appointed hour for everything.
('75', 288, 5, 13, 550640) We cannot command results ; we can only strive.
('75', 288, 5, 14, 550688) And so far as I am concerned it is enough satisfaction for me to know that I have striven my utmost to dicharge the duty that rested on me.
('75', 288, 5, 15, 550828) In making my ‘sporting offer’ to Mr. Gibson yesterday 3, I know I was making a big surrender; I could have demanded that the Thakore Saheb be made to implement his promise in full, and if I had insisted on it, the Paramount Power would have probably been forced to intervene.
('75', 288, 5, 16, 551104) But I felt that such a course, though legitimate, would under the circumstances not be the best course for any of the parties concerned.
('75', 288, 6, 17, 551241) 1 Vide also the two preceding items.
('75', 288, 6, 18, 551278) 2 This appeared under the title “Heart searching” in Harijan, which reported only “a gist of Gandhiji’s talk” at the meeting held in the evening.
('75', 288, 6, 19, 551424) The Harijan version used here has been collated with the Gujarati test published in Harijanbandhu.
('75', 288, 6, 20, 551523) 3 Harijanbandhu has “day before yesterday”.
('75', 288, 6, 21, 551567) However, Gandhiji appears to have made the “sporting offer” at an interview with Gibson in the evening of April 20. Vide footnote on “Letter to E. C. Gibson”, 19 4 1939; also “Letter to E. C. Gibson”, 20 4 1939
('75', 289, 0, 1, 551778) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 289, 1, 2, 551820) And so I chose instead the alternative of putting your head into the lap of the ‘enemy’.
('75', 289, 1, 3, 551909) Let me explain to you the working of my mind in making that offer.
('75', 289, 1, 4, 551976) I hold it to be an axiomatic truth that true ahimsa never fails to impress itself on the opponent.
('75', 289, 1, 5, 552075) If it does, to that extent it is imperfect.
('75', 289, 1, 6, 552119) All the time that I have been engaged in the Rajkot question, this question has been forcing itself upon me: ‘Why has our ahimsa failed to gain recognition from the State authorities ?’ In South Africa whatever the Indians had won as a result of satyagraha did not leave any ill feeling behind it.
('75', 289, 1, 7, 552417) For eight long years General Smuts fought uncompromisingly against the claims of the Indian community.
('75', 289, 1, 8, 552520) But in the end he recognized the justice of the claims and became my lifelong friend.
('75', 289, 1, 9, 552606) He helped me a great deal even in London during the Round Table conference and had he his way he would have helped me to get everything.
('75', 289, 1, 10, 552743) When the final settlement was arrived at in South Africa he had said: “I on my part had inflicted severe hardships on Gandhi’s men but they had borne them silently.
('75', 289, 1, 11, 552908) How long could I inflict severities on such people ?” Do not believe that it is more difficult to win over Virawala than it was to win over General Smuts.
('75', 289, 1, 12, 553063) Time and again the question arises in my mind: ‘Why should what was possible in South Africa be not possible here?
('75', 289, 1, 13, 553178) Why can’t Virawala say the same thing which General Smuts had said?’ What was possible in South Africa should be possible in Rajkot too.
('75', 289, 1, 14, 553315) There we were a handful of Indians pitted against the entire Boer population.
('75', 289, 1, 15, 553393) Here numbers are on your side.
('75', 289, 1, 16, 553424) There our fight was against a Government and the governments are always fettered by rigidity.
('75', 289, 1, 17, 553518) But here you have only to gain entrance into the heart of one man.
('75', 289, 1, 18, 553585) Surely there must be something seriously wrong about us and our ahimsa if we cannot do even that.
('75', 289, 1, 19, 553683) I want you to put your supreme effort into this.
('75', 289, 1, 20, 553732) To say that there can be no peace in Rajkot so long as Durbar Virawala is there, is to speak not the language of ahimsa but of himsa.
('75', 289, 1, 21, 553866) The attribute of ahimsa is to run straight into the mouth himsa.
('75', 289, 1, 22, 553931) If the cows had wisdom they would in full understanding run straight into the mouth of a lion and if they did so it is possible that the lion would lose the taste for cow’s flesh.
('75', 289, 1, 23, 554111) I have been holding a silent court of enquiry within myself.
('75', 289, 1, 24, 554172) How is it that I came to Rajkot on a mission of peace but have ended by antagonizing Durbar Virawala and the State authorities?
('75', 289, 1, 25, 554300) I had banked upon the ancestral family relationship existing between me
('75', 290, 0, 1, 554372) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 291
('75', 290, 1, 2, 554416) and the Thakore Saheb, but instead I had to seek the intervention of the Paramount Power.
('75', 290, 1, 3, 554506) ‘What a lapse from grace is this?’ I said to myself.
('75', 290, 1, 4, 554559) I feel crestfallen and humbled.
('75', 290, 1, 5, 554591) Should I absolve the Paramount Power altogether from its promise?
('75', 290, 1, 6, 554657) Or should I confess my folly from the house tops?
('75', 290, 1, 7, 554707) I have been thinking furiously on these lines.
('75', 290, 1, 8, 554754) But my self confidence seems to have deserted me for the moment.
('75', 290, 1, 9, 554819) However, I leave the thoughts with you for what they are worth to ponder and think over.
('75', 290, 1, 10, 554908) Capacity to convert the heart of Durbar Virawala is the acid test of your ahimsa as it is of mine.
('75', 290, 1, 11, 555007) The discovery I have made after introspection is this.
('75', 290, 1, 12, 555062) No matter what concessions you succeed in getting from the State authorities, it is only to the extent they are the result of a true heart conversion on their part that you will be able to enjoy or digest them.
('75', 290, 1, 13, 555273) But if you wish to launch a successful satyagraha to win your rights, your speech must improve.
('75', 290, 1, 14, 555369) If you do so, your actions and general behaviour will take a different form.
('75', 290, 1, 15, 555446) Ahimsa is not the weapon of the coward.
('75', 290, 1, 16, 555486) It is the highest manly effort.
('75', 290, 1, 17, 555518) It is the dharma of the brave.
('75', 290, 1, 18, 555549) If you wish to be a satyagrahi you should get rid of ignorance, indolence and the like.
('75', 290, 1, 19, 555637) You must cultivate constant vigilance.
('75', 290, 1, 20, 555676) There should not be any trace of inertia in you.
('75', 290, 1, 21, 555725) Only then can ahimsa function.
('75', 290, 1, 22, 555756) When you have imbibed true ahimsa, your speech, action and general behaviour will reflect love and willy nilly your enemies will have to recognize it.
('75', 290, 1, 23, 555907) Let me explain my meaning further by an illustration.
('75', 290, 1, 24, 555961) Yesterday I was engaged for five hours in a talk with Durbar Virawala.
('75', 290, 1, 25, 556032) He was the same as before.
('75', 290, 1, 26, 556059) But I had gone there with the dawn of a fresh spirit, as a result of my heart searching, upon me.
('75', 290, 1, 27, 556157) My reaction to him this time was different.
('75', 290, 1, 28, 556201) ‘We are after all what nature has made us, and it is no use quarrelling with nature’, I said to myself, and I tried to get as much as I could to get under his skin, to view questions from his own angle.
('75', 290, 1, 29, 556404) I did not mince matters and even told him some home truths.
('75', 290, 1, 30, 556464) Gently, in my own language, I gave him a glimpse of his crookedness.
('75', 290, 1, 31, 556533) But there was no irritation on my part or resentment on his.
('75', 290, 1, 32, 556594) It was a different atmosphere.
('75', 290, 1, 33, 556625) He said: “ It is my bad luck that I cannot convince you of my inability to give you more than this”.
('75', 290, 1, 34, 556726) I replied; “ I agree that I am prejudiced against you.
('75', 290, 1, 35, 556781) I am afraid of you.
('75', 290, 1, 36, 556801) But I am prepared to be locked up with you in a room till we arrive at unanimity Please remove my fears.” Khan Saheb Fateh Mohammad Khan was also present on the occasion.
('75', 290, 1, 37, 556972) He also joined the discussion and pressed Durbar Virawala somehow or other “ to find a solution for the agitation.
('75', 290, 1, 38, 557087) People are tired of it.”
('75', 291, 0, 1, 557112) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 291, 1, 2, 557154) I have not the time to share with you all the pleasant recollections of this interview.
('75', 291, 1, 3, 557242) But there was one thing in this interview that galled me and to which I draw your attention.
('75', 291, 1, 4, 557335) He had an unmixed contempt for the Parishad people.
('75', 291, 1, 5, 557387) I had noticed that before too but I had laughed it away.
('75', 291, 1, 6, 557444) But now it hurt me.
('75', 291, 1, 7, 557464) Why should your satyagraha excite his contempt of all things?
('75', 291, 1, 8, 557526) I can understand ahimsa inspiring a kind of fear, the sort of fear that a mother feels when her child gets offended and goes to sleep hungry.
('75', 291, 1, 9, 557668) But genuine satyagraha should never excite contempt in the opponent even when it fails to command regard or respect.
('75', 291, 1, 10, 557785) This is not super refinement on my part.
('75', 291, 1, 11, 557826) Satyagr aha is nothing if not a ceaseless quest after perfection.
('75', 291, 1, 12, 557892) A satyagrahi therefore turns the searchlight inward relentlessly to weed out the defects that may be lying hidden there still.
('75', 291, 1, 13, 558019) Thereby he increases his capacity to serve the cause he has espoused a thousand fold.
('75', 291, 1, 14, 558105) Tell me if this definition of ahimsa is beyond you and you are free to choose your own path.
('75', 291, 1, 15, 558198) I will render all possible help from outside.
('75', 291, 1, 16, 558244) I have asked you always to rely upon your own inner strength instead of banking upon outside help.
('75', 291, 1, 17, 558343) But I now want you to go a step further and wish to see a different kind of strength in you.
('75', 291, 1, 18, 558436) you must now cease to look for guidance from without.
('75', 291, 1, 19, 558490) Satyagraha should become to you an independent inspiration.
('75', 291, 1, 20, 558550) It should be intolerable for you and me both that you should depend in every little thing on my advice.
('75', 291, 1, 21, 558654) I am therefore going away, throwing the whole burden on you.
('75', 291, 1, 22, 558715) You must make a firm resolve that you will now arrive at a settlement according to your inner light and conviction and that, too, with Durbar Virawala, not without him.
('75', 291, 1, 23, 558884) Now you will have to make your choice between ahimsa and himsa.
('75', 291, 1, 24, 558948) You may drop ahimsa if you find that it does not suit you or is likely to make cowards of you.
('75', 291, 1, 25, 559043) I only wish that you should never become cowards.
('75', 291, 1, 26, 559093) It is possible that some day you will come to learn pure ahimsa from disciplined himsa.
('75', 291, 1, 27, 559181) But it is a dangerous condition if you, like Trishanku, keep on hanging in mid air between himsa and ahimsa.
('75', 291, 1, 28, 559290) The country is also faced with this same problem as you are.
('75', 291, 1, 29, 559351) You should solve it for yourself immediately.
('75', 291, 1, 30, 559397) If you cling to ahimsa, that ahimsa should not be the one bequeathed by me but should orginate from independent inspiration.
('75', 291, 1, 31, 559522) But if you decide to follow the path of ahimsa, then you should know that it will be an empty name unless it aims at the conversion of the heart of the opponent.
('75', 292, 0, 1, 559684) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 293
('75', 292, 1, 2, 559728) Let me offer you a few concrete suggestion in this connection.
('75', 292, 1, 3, 559791) If you accept the approach that I have indicated, I would like all the seven of you, whom the Sardar has nominated, to go to Durbar Virawala and tell him that you have decided to relieve me of all responsibility in connection with Rajkot, that you would also like to relieve the Paramount Power too of its responsibility in this behalf and rely instead entirely on your capacity to induce him to implement the Notification of December 26. Ask him to tell you as to what you should do to win his heart.
('75', 292, 1, 4, 560293) Hold yourself in readiness to drain to the last the bitter cup of personal indignities and humiliations.
('75', 292, 1, 5, 560398) It was only when I had learnt to reduce myself to a zero that I was able to evolve the power of satyagraha in south Africa.
('75', 292, 1, 6, 560522) Ahimsa must express itself through acts of selfless service of the masses.
('75', 292, 1, 7, 560597) I cannot think of a better symbol of it or medium for its expression than the spinning wheel.
('75', 292, 1, 8, 560691) Ahimsa is a science.
('75', 292, 1, 9, 560712) The word ‘failure’ has no place in the vocabulary of science.
('75', 292, 1, 10, 560774) Failure to obtain the expected result is often the precursor to further discoveries.
('75', 292, 1, 11, 560859) It is in that spirit that you should approach and pursue your present mission.

('75', 294, 4, 5, 562653) 375. LETTER TO VIJAYA GANDHI
('75', 294, 5, 6, 562682) ANANDKUNJ, RAJKOT, April 24, 1939
('75', 294, 6, 7, 562716) VIJAYA, 1
('75', 294, 7, 8, 562726) Which birthday of yours will it be?

('75', 294, 11, 18, 563098) ON THE TRAIN TO BOMBAY, April 24, 1939 Rajkot seems to have robbed me of my youth.
('75', 294, 11, 19, 563181) I never knew that I was old.
('75', 294, 11, 20, 563210) Now I am weighed down by the knowledge of decrepitude.
('75', 294, 11, 21, 563265) I never knew what it was to lose hope.
('75', 294, 11, 22, 563304) But it seems to have been cremated in Rajkot.
('75', 294, 11, 23, 563350) My ahimsa has been put to a test such as it has never been subjected to before.
('75', 294, 11, 24, 563430) I have given fifteen precious days to have the Committee, contemplated in the Award of the Chief Justice of India.
('75', 294, 11, 25, 563545) But I seem to be as far from it as ever.
('75', 294, 11, 26, 563586) I have found unexpected difficulties in my path.
('75', 294, 11, 27, 563635) The Award was acclaimed throughout India as a complete victory for the Sardar.
('75', 294, 11, 28, 563714) But it has been effectively used against me for accusing me of a breach of promise to the Muslims and the Bhayats.
('75', 294, 12, 29, 563829) 1 Narandas Gandhi’s daughter in law and wife of Purushottam Gandhi 2 This appeared under the title “I Am Defeated”.
('75', 294, 12, 30, 563945) The statement was published in The Hindustan Times and The Hindu on April 25.
('75', 295, 0, 1, 564023) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 295, 1, 2, 564065) The promise that the Thakore Saheb had made was on my return from Delhi transferred to my poor shoulders.
('75', 295, 1, 3, 564171) The plain meaning of all I had said could only be that I should help the Thakore Saheb to carry out his promise, though, according to the Award, I need not.
('75', 295, 1, 4, 564328) Whatever the reason might be, both the Muslims and the Bhayats relieved the Thakore Saheb of the duty of fulfilment of the promise.
('75', 295, 1, 5, 564460) Failing to placate the Muslims and the Bhayats, I sent the Thakore Saheb seven names of the Parishad.
('75', 295, 1, 6, 564562) In reply I was called upon to prove that six out of the seven names were Rajkot State subjects.
('75', 295, 1, 7, 564658) One would have thought that I would at least be given an inkling of the objections.
('75', 295, 1, 8, 564742) If every statement made by men presumed to be fairly honourable could be challenged, it might take a year to finish an inquiry into the facts of each case.
('75', 295, 1, 9, 564898) But I have sent the required proofs.
('75', 295, 1, 10, 564935) When I seemed to have come to the end of my resources and my patience, I sent a letter of complaint to the Resident as the local representative of the Paramount Power seeking his aid in terms of the Viceregal assurances given to me.
('75', 295, 1, 11, 565168) He invited me to an interview.
('75', 295, 1, 12, 565199) And whilst we were discussing the ways and means an idea flashed across my mind that I should end the agony by forgoing the right of nomination of members of the Committee, and so I made what I thought, and the Resident admitted, was a sporting offer.
('75', 295, 1, 13, 565451) It was that the whole Com mittee should be selected by the Thakore Saheb to report in accordance with the terms of the Notification of 26th December last, provided that its report should be shown to the Parishad, and that if they found that the report did not carry out the terms of the Notification, their dissenting note and the original report should be sent to the Chief Justice for his decision.
('75', 295, 1, 14, 565852) The Resident sent my offer to Durbar Shri Virawala, but H. H. the Thakore Saheb has turned it down.
('75', 295, 1, 15, 565952) Agonizing experiences of the fifteen days have resulted in my making the discovery that my ahimsa should be voted down as failure if the Thakore Saheb and Durbar Shri Virawala were to feel that they had to give anything under pressure from above.
('75', 295, 1, 16, 566199) My ahimsa demanded that I should remove that feeling.
('75', 295, 1, 17, 566253) And so when the opportunity came to me, I tried to assure Durbar Shri Virawala that I took no delight in invoking the assistance of the Paramount Power.
('75', 295, 1, 18, 566406) Apart from ahimsa, my connection with Rajkot should impose that restraint on me.

('75', 296, 1, 10, 567380) But with the sudden consciousness of my imperfect handling of ahimsa, instead of carrying the blow, I recognized the force of his argument as showing want of faith in the essential goodness of human nature and littleness of my own belief in ahimsa.
('75', 296, 1, 11, 567629) And so our conversation went on and covered many proposals.

('75', 296, 1, 13, 567714) I was no nearer solution of the tangle.

('75', 296, 1, 15, 567911) And so I presented 1 this new line of approach to my co workers.
('75', 296, 1, 16, 567976) They had more than once told me that Durbar Shri Virawala was the source of all the evil that had descended upon Rajkot and that his removal would mean for them full swaraj.
('75', 296, 1, 17, 568150) I had no difficulty in showing them that what they were thinking of was good government, not self government.
('75', 296, 1, 18, 568260) At this meeting, which only took place yesterday, I told them that if they accepted my explanation of ahimsa, they would have to set their heart not on getting rid of Drubar Shri Virawala, but on converting him.
('75', 296, 1, 19, 568472) This they could do only if they would set about finding his good points and working at them.
('75', 296, 1, 20, 568565) They must develop infinite faith in the capacity of ahimsa to neutralize every person of himsa.
('75', 296, 1, 21, 568661) True ahimsa lay in running into the mouth of himsa.
('75', 296, 1, 22, 568713) If cows could be credited with intelligence, it is conceivable that given a sufficient number of such cows who would run into the tiger’s mouth, the latter would lose the relish for cow flesh and change his nature.
('75', 296, 1, 23, 568928) They must, therefore, shed their fear of Durbar Shri Virawala and their disbelief in the power of ahimsa to achieve the seemingly impossible.

('75', 297, 5, 26, 571270) But though there was provocation, we do not think that it was so great as to arouse the brute in man and it must be laid at the door of the highly inflammable temper of the people.

('75', 298, 2, 5, 571783) That being our ideal we cannot defend any the slightest violence under any circumstances.

('75', 298, 2, 8, 572117) It is a clear warning to all workers in the field and everyone must realize that before one feels sure that the people are rightly trained and disciplined in non violence it is unwise to begin any great mass movement.

('75', 301, 6, 14, 577588) QUESTION: Had Mr. Gandhi come to Calcutta on a peace mission seeing that he had advised Sardar Patel not to come to Calcutta?
('75', 301, 7, 15, 577714) ANSWER : Yes.
('75', 301, 7, 16, 577728) The reason for Sardar Patel not coming was that it was in the best interests of the country to absent himself from Calcutta.
('75', 301, 8, 17, 577853) Q. Had Mr. Gandhi found a way out of the conflicting demads?
('75', 301, 9, 18, 577914) I have not come with a solution in my pocket.
('75', 301, 9, 19, 577960) I have no pocket.
('75', 301, 9, 20, 577978) I cannot say what will be the result of my talks with Mr. Subhas Chandra Bose.
('75', 301, 9, 21, 578057) What is the use of forecasting when the result will be known soon ?

('75', 301, 11, 26, 578317) I have no reason to believe that Mr. Bose is “undesirable”.

('75', 301, 14, 31, 578613) I did not count them.

('75', 303, 6, 8, 581174) A. They have not regained it.
('75', 303, 6, 9, 581204) The President is there with as much power as the old Board had.
('75', 303, 7, 10, 581268) Q. Apart from purging the Congress of corruption, what would he suggest as necessary to set up the Congress as a well knit party organization?
('75', 303, 8, 11, 581411) A. The purging of corruption is the first indispensable condi tion to the smooth running of the Congress.
('75', 303, 8, 12, 581517) Once the corruption is banished the Congress will carry on its great work.
('75', 303, 9, 13, 581592) Q. Would it be better for the Congress to have a really democratic constitution, or to be entirely subject to a leader?
('75', 303, 10, 14, 581712) A. The Congress does not lack democracy.
('75', 303, 10, 15, 581753) The Congress is dem ocratic.
('75', 303, 11, 16, 581782) Mr. Gandhi then gave the following special message to the Statesman readers : I can assure them all that we are not going to discuss personalities but policies.
('75', 303, 11, 17, 581943) Mr. Bose discussed principles only in his correspondence with me.
('75', 303, 11, 18, 582009) So far as I recollect, there were no person alities or grievances in his communications to me.
('75', 303, 11, 19, 582104) But I have vivid recollections of seeing principles and policies in the letters.
('75', 303, 12, 20, 582185) Mr. Gandhi then repeated his Rajkot statement : Ahimsa accrues only to the courageous and so I have left Rajkot empty handed with body shattered and hope cremated.
('75', 303, 12, 21, 582349) I have told Mr. Virawala: “I am defeated.
('75', 303, 12, 22, 582391) May you win.
('75', 303, 12, 23, 582404) Placate the people by giving as much as possible and inform me so as to revive the hope which I seem to have lost for the moment.” Rajkot seems to have robbed me of my youth.
('75', 303, 12, 24, 582579) I never knew that I was old.
('75', 303, 12, 25, 582608) Now I am weighed down by the knowledge of decrepitude.
('75', 303, 12, 26, 582663) I never knew what it was to lose hope.
('75', 303, 12, 27, 582702) But it seems to have been cremated in Rajkot.
('75', 303, 13, 28, 582748) Mr. Gandhi went on to say : I am broken down.
('75', 303, 13, 29, 582794) I am now conscious of old age.
('75', 303, 13, 30, 582825) It was useful when people said, “Hello, 70 years—no, 17”.
('75', 303, 13, 31, 582883) Now I feel myself to be even 80.
('75', 303, 14, 32, 582916) 1 In October 1934
('75', 304, 0, 1, 582934) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 305
('75', 304, 1, 2, 582978) Mr. Gandhi has developed a cough and, commenting on this, said: I am a stranger to a cough.
('75', 304, 1, 3, 583070) Yet this has been persisting for 15 days.
('75', 304, 2, 4, 583112) The reporter then asked Mr. Gandhi if there was going to be a war.
('75', 304, 2, 5, 583179) His reply was to the effect that the journalist would probably know more about that than he himself.
('75', 304, 2, 6, 583280) However, Mr. Gandhi went on to say in his opinion the best way for peace was to disarm.
('75', 304, 2, 7, 583368) [He said:] If I could get the three great nations.
('75', 304, 2, 8, 583419) Great Britain, France and the U.S.A with a tithe of my faith in non violence there would be no war.
('75', 304, 3, 9, 583519) He did not agree that in the event of the nations disarming, Germany and Italy would march into other countries and even take British colonies.
('75', 304, 3, 10, 583663) The people of Germany and Italy would not want war.
('75', 304, 3, 11, 583715) Their leaders would realize that too.
('75', 304, 3, 12, 583753) The leaders dare not go to war.
('75', 304, 3, 13, 583785) Peace will reign in the universe.
('75', 304, 3, 14, 583819) If I were a leading statesman in England, I would shudder at the prospect of war.
('75', 304, 3, 15, 583901) At the close of the interview, Mr. Gandhi gave the following message: I am fighting for peace, I shall die for peace, peace in the Cong ress, peace in the States, peace on earth and goodwill amongst men.
('75', 304, 3, 16, 584105) To set the seal upon that, if I feel the power, I am quite capable of fasting unto death to prevent Western humanity, which is getting ready to embark upon suicide on a scale hitherto unknown to the history of the world.
('75', 304, 4, 17, 584326) Referring to his talks with Mr. Bose, he said: All India hopes and I hope that there will be no rupture.
('75', 304, 4, 18, 584431) The Statesman, 28 4 1939

('75', 307, 6, 15, 588629) 388. JAIPUR PRISONERS
('75', 307, 7, 16, 588651) The Jaipur Durbar communique on the treatment of Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj and the other prisoners reads like a laboured defence of the status quo.
('75', 307, 7, 17, 588794) The question about Sheth Jamnalalji is simple.
('75', 307, 7, 18, 588841) It is admitted that he is locked up in an out of the way place 2 where the water is said to be ‘heavy’ according to the Indian notion.
('75', 307, 7, 19, 588976) It is admitted that the place is difficult of access.
('75', 307, 7, 20, 589030) He has been given no companion.
('75', 307, 7, 21, 589062) Why this isolation?
('75', 307, 7, 22, 589082) Is he a dangerous character?
('75', 307, 7, 23, 589111) Is he an intriguer?
('75', 307, 7, 24, 589131) One can understand detention as he chose to defy the ban on his entry into his own birth place.
('75', 307, 7, 25, 589227) The Authorities know that Shethji is an ideal prisoner.
('75', 307, 7, 26, 589283) He believes in meticulous observance of Jail discipline.
('75', 307, 7, 27, 589340) It is cruel to isolate him as he has been isolated from the outside world.
('75', 307, 7, 28, 589415) The greatest want of prisoners is the companionship of their equals in thought, manners and customs.
('75', 307, 7, 29, 589516) I suggest that without much ado he be transferred to a place which is easily accessible and healthy and where he is allowed company.
('75', 307, 8, 30, 589649) 1 This was presumably addressed to Krishnachandra’s mother;vide “Letter to Krishnachandra”, 8 5 1939 2 Moransagar
('75', 308, 0, 1, 589763) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 309
('75', 308, 1, 2, 589807) The special pleading with reference to the satyagrahi prisoners in Lamba is much worse.
('75', 308, 1, 3, 589895) They admit that the place selected for their incarceration is an old snake infested fort.
('75', 308, 1, 4, 589985) But they point out that in spite of the place being snake infested no one has as yet been bitten by the reptiles!
('75', 308, 1, 5, 590099) Must the Jaipur Durbar’s cosnscience wait for snake bites before it is stirred to action?
('75', 308, 1, 6, 590189) It should be remembered that these pris oners were transferred to Lamba because they had the presumptuousness to hunger strike for better treatment.
('75', 308, 1, 7, 590338) The strike would have continued but for my intervention.
('75', 308, 1, 8, 590395) The much larger question of the object of satyagraha still remains unsolved.
('75', 308, 1, 9, 590472) And yet it is not at all large.
('75', 308, 1, 10, 590504) It is aimed at getting the Praja Sangh recognized.
('75', 308, 1, 11, 590555) The Durbar have laid down the impossible condition of recognition.
('75', 308, 1, 12, 590622) viz., that its officials should not be members of any political organization out side the State.
('75', 308, 1, 13, 590719) Thus Sheth Jamnalalji himself could not remain President of the Sangh because he is connected with the National Congress.
('75', 308, 1, 14, 590841) Satyagraha has been suspended at my instance 1 in Jaipur as in many other States.
('75', 308, 1, 15, 590923) It would not remain suspended for ever.
('75', 308, 1, 16, 590963) I entertain the hope that the States concerned will placate the advanced and awakened section of their people.
('75', 308, 1, 17, 591074) And I suggest to the Jaipur Durbar that they are going the wrong way by keeping them locked up even though their satyagraha has been suspended.
('75', 308, 1, 18, 591218) In any case what I must call the inhuman treatment of the prisoners, including Sheth Jamnalalji, might surely stop at once.
('75', 308, 1, 19, 591342) SODEPUR, April 30, 1939 Harijan, 6 5 1939

('75', 328, 9, 16, 634818) 405. SPEECH AT TEACHERS’ TRAINING CAMP, BRINDABAN 2
('75', 328, 10, 17, 634870) May 4, 1939 I should like to tell you what I saw today.
('75', 328, 10, 18, 634926) First I visited the exhibition.
('75', 328, 10, 19, 634958) 3 It is very good.
('75', 328, 10, 20, 634977) They say in size it is one fourth of the Tripuri exhibition.
('75', 328, 10, 21, 635038) The one fourth that I saw pleased me immensely.
('75', 328, 10, 22, 635086) It does not mean that my happiness would have been four time as much if I had seen the whole exhibition.
('75', 328, 10, 23, 635191) In the Tripuri exhibition, the major contribution was from the Jamia Millia of Delhi, while here they have contributed nothing.
('75', 328, 10, 24, 635319) Their contribution was indeed very large.
('75', 328, 10, 25, 635361) I was able to visit the exhibition today only for a few minutes.
('75', 328, 10, 26, 635426) It is certainly very large.
('75', 328, 10, 27, 635454) If I had a whole day I would have seen the whole of it and could have gained much.
('75', 328, 10, 28, 635537) I would have seen to what point
('75', 328, 11, 29, 635569) 1Vide the preceding item.
('75', 328, 11, 30, 635595) 2 The camp was organized by the All India Talimi Sangh to prepare teachers under the Wardha Scheme of Education.
('75', 328, 11, 31, 635708) 3 This was organized by Ashadevi Aryanayakam to demonstrate the various aspects of basic education.
('75', 329, 0, 1, 635808) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 329, 1, 2, 635850) they have taken basic education, how much they have succeeded in planning education through a craft and how they correlate the craft with other subjects.
('75', 329, 1, 3, 636004) I would like you to study this exhibition.
('75', 329, 1, 4, 636047) Observe everything very carefully.
('75', 329, 1, 5, 636082) Let me give you only one example.
('75', 329, 1, 6, 636116) We did not know that a carding bow made from munj grass can be so efficient.
('75', 329, 1, 7, 636193) It is so good that in some respects it is even better than the bow made of catgut.
('75', 329, 1, 8, 636276) For fine carding it is excellent.
('75', 329, 1, 9, 636310) Every fibre of the cotton is separated.
('75', 329, 1, 10, 636350) Besides it is not harmful to health.
('75', 329, 1, 11, 636387) Even a person like me whose heart has become weak can comfortably card his cotton with it.
('75', 329, 1, 12, 636478) It is also nice to look at.
('75', 329, 1, 13, 636506) No effort is required in plying it.
('75', 329, 1, 14, 636542) One derives only pleasure.
('75', 329, 1, 15, 636569) This is just an example to show what progress we can make in such small things.
('75', 329, 1, 16, 636649) It is the invention of someone who has devoted all his mind and inventive genius to it.
('75', 329, 1, 17, 636737) I should like you to study and assess the exhibition from this point of view.
('75', 329, 1, 18, 636815) There is no limit to the progress we can make.
('75', 329, 1, 19, 636862) We are not good teachers if we are not able to develop originality in us through this kind of education.
('75', 329, 1, 20, 636967) Education through a craft is the pivot of basic education.
('75', 329, 1, 21, 637026) You must cultivate your creative instinct to be able to develop your mind through various crafts and teach innumerable things by putting your creative genius and resourcefulness to use and discover new things.
('75', 329, 2, 22, 637236) Today we are dependent on only two crafts.
('75', 329, 2, 23, 637279) Let us take these.
('75', 329, 2, 24, 637298) We have found two men who could develop their minds through these crafts.
('75', 329, 2, 25, 637372) That is why Ashadevi and Aryanayakam could carry on their work.
('75', 329, 2, 26, 637436) We found Vinoba for the takli.
('75', 329, 2, 27, 637467) And we have found another gentleman to show us how one can develop one’s mind through cardboard making.
('75', 329, 2, 28, 637571) These two men showed us how full of possibilities the two crafts are.
('75', 329, 2, 29, 637641) If you cannot do as they did you will never develop creative instinct.
('75', 329, 2, 30, 637712) If such men were not there neither Zakir Saheb nor Ashadevi could have achieved anything.
('75', 329, 2, 31, 637802) I would like you to see the exhibition with a view to developing creative instinct through this system of education.
('75', 329, 2, 32, 637919) It is not our aim to teach industry and handicraft in the traditional way.
('75', 329, 2, 33, 637994) We want to make crafts a living medium of education.
('75', 329, 3, 34, 638047) I then went to the school.
('75', 329, 3, 35, 638074) I found the teacher quite intelligent.
('75', 329, 3, 36, 638113) All the boys were plying taklis.
('75', 329, 3, 37, 638146) I claim that I know the science of the takli, the charkha and the loom very well.
('75', 329, 3, 38, 638228) Although I lack skill in working them, I know much about them.
('75', 329, 3, 39, 638291) I immediately noticed that
('75', 330, 0, 1, 638318) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 331
('75', 330, 1, 2, 638362) there was something wrong somewhere.
('75', 330, 1, 3, 638399) Either the teacher himself did not know how to spin on the takli or the boys were taught wrong.
('75', 330, 1, 4, 638495) I detected the flaw immediately.
('75', 330, 1, 5, 638528) The boys were taking four times as long over an operation that should take half a minute.
('75', 330, 1, 6, 638618) They kept on twisting the takli.
('75', 330, 1, 7, 638651) when they drew the thread.
('75', 330, 1, 8, 638678) That is not the right method of drawing yarn.
('75', 330, 1, 9, 638724) The yarn should get the twist as we draw it.
('75', 330, 1, 10, 638769) There is no need to give any further twist.
('75', 330, 1, 11, 638813) The yarn instead of becoming strong becomes useless if it is twisted even just a little more than necessary.
('75', 330, 1, 12, 638922) And also one can never increase one’s speed.
('75', 330, 1, 13, 638967) I also noticed a few more shortcomings which I do not mention here.
('75', 330, 1, 14, 639035) I have told Nayakamji that a teacher who is not doing well in his craft should be considered useless, however intelligent he may be.
('75', 330, 1, 15, 639168) However much he may have read of the science of the charkha and the loom, he is not fit to be a teacher if he cannot spin well.
('75', 330, 1, 16, 639296) He cannot even become a clerk.
('75', 330, 1, 17, 639327) He is utterly useless.
('75', 330, 1, 18, 639350) It is our claim that the mind can be developed through a craft and that is our yardstick.
('75', 330, 1, 19, 639440) That is the central point of our scheme.
('75', 330, 1, 20, 639481) I will therefore first see the quality of the teacher’s yarn— whether it is even or not, whether it is strong or not.
('75', 330, 1, 21, 639599) If it has these qualities I will say that he is a good artisan but if his proficiency in the craft does not help him to develop his intellect, he will not have originality.
('75', 330, 1, 22, 639772) He will go on plying the charkha and the loom for generations and never make any improvements.
('75', 330, 1, 23, 639867) That has been the history of India.
('75', 330, 1, 24, 639903) That is so because there was no correlation between the hand and the mind.
('75', 330, 1, 25, 639978) Artisans never paid any attention to the improvement of their tools and methods of work and those who did mental work were not concerned with the crafts.
('75', 330, 1, 26, 640132) So both lost their creative instinct.
('75', 330, 1, 27, 640170) I will test the intelligence of the teachers also from this point of view.
('75', 330, 1, 28, 640245) They should learn their craft in this way and take pleasure in it.
('75', 330, 1, 29, 640312) The scheme will come to naught if teachers do not train themselves in this manner.
('75', 330, 1, 30, 640395) If it gets known that the scheme has failed in this manner, the people will laugh at them.
('75', 330, 1, 31, 640486) However, that is not what I am afraid of.
('75', 330, 1, 32, 640528) I will be satisfied only when I see that things are happening as I had wished.
('75', 330, 1, 33, 640607) If they are not, then even if the whole world praises us for our work I will not be deceived.
('75', 330, 1, 34, 640701) I am feeling apprehensive although the basic education scheme is much admired today.
('75', 330, 1, 35, 640786) The teachers working under the scheme are feeling Jubilant.
('75', 330, 1, 36, 640846) But maybe we are deceiving ourselves.
('75', 330, 1, 37, 640884) I should like you to learn the art of gaining
('75', 331, 0, 1, 640930) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 331, 1, 2, 640972) knowledge through a craft.
('75', 331, 1, 3, 640999) That art and knowledge is a rare thing.
('75', 331, 1, 4, 641039) You must utilize your knowledge of B. A. and M. A. degrees to this end.
('75', 331, 1, 5, 641111) It should be your duty to make education, which is a dull and drab affair today, a lively and fascinating subject.
('75', 331, 1, 6, 641226) It is my claim that by the method I have suggested a rare enlightenment will be produced.
('75', 331, 1, 7, 641316) To me intellectual education and bookish education are not the same thing.
('75', 331, 1, 8, 641391) In my opinion a man whose intellect is not correlated with his hands is not intelligent.
('75', 331, 1, 9, 641480) Would you call a man an authority on the Vedas if he has memorized words from the Vedas and has learnt by heart its commentaries?
('75', 331, 1, 10, 641610) What I would ask is how far he has assimilated the real meaning of the Vedas.
('75', 331, 1, 11, 641688) His conduct will be an indication.
('75', 331, 1, 12, 641723) I have set before you the main idea behind this scheme.

('75', 331, 7, 21, 642030) 407. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS AT GANDHI SEVA SANGH MEETING, BRINDABAN–I
('75', 331, 8, 22, 642098) May 5, 1939 Here are some questions received from Annada Babu.
('75', 331, 8, 23, 642161) He says he is asking the questions not for himself but for others.
('75', 331, 9, 24, 642228) QUESTION: Your statement 1 after Subhas Babu’s election has somewhat changed the situation.
('75', 331, 9, 25, 642320) Why did you not issue any statement at the time of the election?
('75', 331, 9, 26, 642385) Some people are of the view that the present situation would not have arisen if you had issued a statement at the time of the election.
('75', 331, 10, 27, 642521) ANSWER: It is true that I did not issue any statement.
('75', 331, 10, 28, 642576) According to Annada Babu that has changed the situation.
('75', 331, 10, 29, 642633) What he means is that the
('75', 331, 11, 30, 642659) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 31 1 1939
('75', 332, 0, 1, 642701) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 333
('75', 332, 1, 2, 642745) situation would not have taken the turn it did if I had issued a statement earlier.
('75', 332, 1, 3, 642829) But the statement issued by Sardar Vallabhbhai and others contained a small sentence which suggested that I too was connected with it.
('75', 332, 1, 4, 642964) Moreover, there was no particular occasion then.
('75', 332, 1, 5, 643013) I saw no need to issue a statement at the time.
('75', 332, 1, 6, 643061) It became necessary subsequently.
('75', 332, 1, 7, 643095) It is a long story.
('75', 332, 1, 8, 643115) I shall not go into it.
('75', 332, 1, 9, 643139) It was not a question of my having been sluggish.
('75', 332, 1, 10, 643189) Nor was there any mistake in explaining the situation to the country.
('75', 332, 1, 11, 643259) I had conveyed to Subhas Babu what I felt.
('75', 332, 1, 12, 643302) That is the way I work.
('75', 332, 1, 13, 643326) In the end all that remains is for me to put up with any misunderstanding that may have arisen.
('75', 332, 1, 14, 643422) If there are any more questions from anyone on the point they will be welcome.
('75', 332, 2, 15, 643501) Some people are under the impression that you were not in favour of the Pant resolution.
('75', 332, 2, 16, 643590) What was your reaction when you first knew about the resolution?
('75', 332, 2, 17, 643655) Why did you write to Subhas Babu that the more you thought of it the more you disliked it?
('75', 332, 2, 18, 643746) Kindly explain.
('75', 332, 2, 19, 643762) First of all, you are all aware that I was confined to bed at the time.
('75', 332, 2, 20, 643834) It is not my way to interfere in something with which I am not concerned.
('75', 332, 2, 21, 643908) That is why I remained indifferent to the developments at Tripuri.
('75', 332, 2, 22, 643975) So much so that I even avoided reading the newspapers in those days.
('75', 332, 2, 23, 644044) My mind was preoccupied with Rajkot.
('75', 332, 2, 24, 644081) Someone reported to me that Pantji intended to move some such resolution.
('75', 332, 2, 25, 644155) I understood at the time that the resolution would express confidence in the old Working Committee.
('75', 332, 2, 26, 644255) I stated that while expression of confidence was all right I would have done something more if I was there.
('75', 332, 2, 27, 644363) I had said even at Wardha that if they had the courage they should bring a motion of no confidence against Subhas Babu.
('75', 332, 2, 28, 644483) It would have been a straightforward thing to do.
('75', 332, 2, 29, 644533) If the delegates to the Congress felt that they had made a mistake in electing Subhas Babu, this was the only civilized way open to them.
('75', 332, 2, 30, 644671) But probably the atmosphere was not quite favourable then.
('75', 332, 2, 31, 644730) I had a feeling that Subhas Babu would form his own Working Committee.
('75', 332, 2, 32, 644801) But that did not happen.
('75', 332, 2, 33, 644826) Then it was that the Pant resolution came up.
('75', 332, 2, 34, 644872) All I heard was that the resolution expressed confidence in the people who had gone out.
('75', 332, 2, 35, 644961) I said if that was all there was in the resolution it was all right.
('75', 332, 2, 36, 645030) But I had nothing to do with it.
('75', 332, 2, 37, 645063) I saw the resolution later.
('75', 332, 2, 38, 645091) Then followed an exchange of letters with Subhas Babu.
('75', 332, 2, 39, 645146) The letter to which Annada Babu has referred is not before you.
('75', 332, 2, 40, 645210) When I read the Pant resolution, I found that it contained a suggestion that Subhas Babu should be guided by me.
('75', 332, 2, 41, 645323) I thoroughly disapproved of the idea.
('75', 332, 2, 42, 645361) So much so that I refused
('75', 333, 0, 1, 645387) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 333, 1, 2, 645429) to do anything of the kind.
('75', 333, 1, 3, 645457) I stuck to my refusal to the end.
('75', 333, 1, 4, 645491) It is possible that this may lead to some misunderstanding.
('75', 333, 1, 5, 645551) I shall have to put up with it.
('75', 333, 1, 6, 645583) How can I do a thing which I consider wrong?
('75', 333, 1, 7, 645628) I told him that he should form a Working Committee of his choice, formulate a programme and implement it.
('75', 333, 1, 8, 645734) I would clear the atmosphere if I could.
('75', 333, 1, 9, 645775) If not, the work would go on and gradually we would be able to change the atmosphere.
('75', 333, 1, 10, 645861) That is why when at Calcutta I was asked to name the Working Committee I found the idea repugnant.
('75', 333, 1, 11, 645960) There I had some material, in view of which I felt it would be wrong to do so.
('75', 333, 1, 12, 646039) Nobody had such material at Tripuri.
('75', 333, 1, 13, 646076) Subsequent exchange of letters further confirmed me in my opinion.
('75', 333, 1, 14, 646143) Later on I also came to know about the ill feeling generated.
('75', 333, 1, 15, 646205) How could I announce any names under those conditions?
('75', 333, 1, 16, 646260) It would be subjecting Subhas Babu to coercion.
('75', 333, 1, 17, 646308) Can the ship of the nation sail smoothly if I subject Subhas Babu to coercion?
('75', 333, 1, 18, 646387) It would be like sinking it.
('75', 333, 1, 19, 646416) I said I would not do it.
('75', 333, 1, 20, 646442) I also said that if they wanted to have the old members of the Working Committee back, they should consult among themselves and if they were agreeable both sides could work together.
('75', 333, 1, 21, 646625) But I would not be party to imposing any names on Subhas Babu.
('75', 333, 1, 22, 646688) The more I think about that resolution, the more I dislike it.
('75', 333, 1, 23, 646751) I cannot serve the nation according to the terms of that resolution.
('75', 333, 1, 24, 646820) However much anyone may insist, I just cannot choose names for the Working Committee.
('75', 333, 1, 25, 646906) My doing so would be coercion against Subhas Babu.
('75', 333, 1, 26, 646957) And coercion is violence.
('75', 333, 1, 27, 646983) How can I resort to it?
('75', 333, 1, 28, 647007) I have told you of my feelings as to the Pant resolution.
('75', 333, 1, 29, 647065) Even if people think that I have served the country well it surely does not give me the right to use coercion against anybody !
('75', 333, 2, 30, 647193) What was the difficulty in giving the names when Subhas Babu himself had agreed to accept any names you suggested?
('75', 333, 2, 31, 647308) What the question means is that through the Pant resolution Tripuri ordered me to do a certain thing and ordered Subhas Babu to do a certain thing.
('75', 333, 2, 32, 647456) Subhas Babu was willing to do as ordered, then why did I defy it?
('75', 333, 2, 33, 647522) Where was the question of coercion in giving the names for the Working Committee in pursuance of that order?
('75', 333, 2, 34, 647631) Seemingly the argument is attractive.
('75', 333, 2, 35, 647669) But it is fallacious.
('75', 333, 2, 36, 647691) Supposing somebody were to come to me tomorrow and say that I had been ordered to abuse him and hit him as I please?
('75', 333, 2, 37, 647808) When there was such a gulf between me and Subhas Babu, would it have been civilized behaviour to inflict some names on him merely by virtue of that right?
('75', 333, 2, 38, 647963) Having a right surely does not mean that I should exercise that
('75', 334, 0, 1, 648027) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 335
('75', 334, 1, 2, 648071) right in utter disregard of my sense of proportion.
('75', 334, 1, 3, 648123) If someone were to behave with me thus I would not like it.
('75', 334, 1, 4, 648183) Supposing tomorrow I am given the right to abuse everybody, would it then become my duty to exercise that right?
('75', 334, 1, 5, 648296) There is a distincion between right and duty.
('75', 334, 1, 6, 648342) The exercise of right depends on one’s sense of duty.
('75', 334, 1, 7, 648396) It is my duty to follow dharma.
('75', 334, 1, 8, 648428) I do not think only of my own importance.
('75', 334, 1, 9, 648470) It is of no consequence to me.
('75', 334, 1, 10, 648501) I think in terms of the nation.
('75', 334, 1, 11, 648533) I do what I consider my duty.
('75', 334, 2, 12, 648563) Cannot your correspondence with Subhas Babu be published?
('75', 334, 2, 13, 648621) If not, will you please explain why?
('75', 334, 2, 14, 648658) At one stage it had been decided to publish the correspondence.
('75', 334, 2, 15, 648722) Later on, after Jawaharlal’s arrival it was decided to withhold the publication.
('75', 334, 2, 16, 648803) It was also decided that I should not issue any statement.
('75', 334, 2, 17, 648862) It would not be in the interest of the nation.
('75', 334, 2, 18, 648909) In this my attitude was that Subhas Babu should do only what suited him.
('75', 334, 2, 19, 648982) This should be our only attitude if we are non violent.
('75', 334, 2, 20, 649038) It is none of our concern to publish any correspondence.

('75', 343, 6, 24, 671548) 410. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS AT GANDHI SEVA SANGH MEETING, BRINDABAN–II
('75', 343, 7, 25, 671617) May 6, 1939 I have here some slips which the President has passed on to me.
('75', 343, 7, 26, 671693) One of them is from Appasaheb Patwardhan.
('75', 343, 7, 27, 671735) I shall first deal with his question .
('75', 343, 8, 28, 671774) QUESTION: In what way can the members try to put into practice the principle of a living wage?
('75', 343, 9, 29, 671869) °ANSWER: There is no harm in adopting any means which is morally proper.
('75', 343, 9, 30, 671942) One individual may take to carpentry for a living.
('75', 343, 9, 31, 671993) He can earn Rs. 15 from this work.
('75', 343, 9, 32, 672028) Or, he can take to carding or tailoring.
('75', 343, 9, 33, 672069) A member of the Gandhi Seva Sangh would choose only
('75', 343, 10, 34, 672121) 1 Presumably Purushottamdas Tandon 2 Vallabhbhai Patel 3 According to the source Gandhiji misunderstood the question and interpreted “living wage” as work for a living.
('75', 344, 0, 1, 672290) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 345
('75', 344, 1, 2, 672334) those occupations which are available to thousands of people earning their livelihood by doing manual work.
('75', 344, 1, 3, 672442) But he will not work merely to earn his livelihood.
('75', 344, 1, 4, 672494) He is aware of the hardships people have to undergo while earning their livelihood.
('75', 344, 1, 5, 672578) But as far as he himself is concerned, as he earns his livelihood he also renders some service.
('75', 344, 1, 6, 672674) Apart from these occupations, members can also supplement their income through teaching.
('75', 344, 1, 7, 672763) Anyone who requires more and who also has Appa’s knowledge of mathematics can even become a professor 1
('75', 344, 2, 8, 672867) But these are exceptions as far as I am concerned.
('75', 344, 2, 9, 672918) I would always prefer manual work for a livelihood.
('75', 344, 3, 10, 672970) I am either unable to understand your theory of trusteeship or my reason cannot grasp it.
('75', 344, 3, 11, 673060) Will you kindly explain it ?
('75', 344, 3, 12, 673089) It is the same thing whether you are unable to understand it or your reason does not accept it.
('75', 344, 3, 13, 673185) How can I explain such an important principle in a few minutes?
('75', 344, 3, 14, 673249) Still I shall try to explain it in brief.
('75', 344, 3, 15, 673291) Just imagine that I have a crore of rupees in my possession.
('75', 344, 3, 16, 673352) I can either squander the amount in dissipation or take up the attitude that the money does not belong to me, that I do not own it, that it is a bequest, that it has been put in my possession by God and that only so much of it is mine as is enough for my requirements.
('75', 344, 3, 17, 673621) My requirements also should be like those of the millions.
('75', 344, 3, 18, 673680) My requirements cannot be greater because I happen to be theson of a rich man.
('75', 344, 3, 19, 673759) I cannot spend the money on my pleasures.
('75', 344, 3, 20, 673801) The man who takes for himself only enough to satisfy the needs customary in his society and spends the rest for social service becomes a trustee.
('75', 344, 3, 21, 673947) Ever since the idea of socialism became popular in India, we have been confronted with the question as to what our attitude should be towards the Princes and millionaires.
('75', 344, 3, 22, 674119) The socialists say that the Princes and the millionaires should be done away with, that all must become workers.
('75', 344, 3, 23, 674232) They advocate confiscation of the properties of all these people and say that they should be given the same wages as everyone else—from Rs. 5 to eight annas a day or Rs. 15 a month.
('75', 344, 3, 24, 674414) So much for what the socialists say.
('75', 344, 3, 25, 674451) We too assert that the rich are not the owners of their wealth whereas the labourer is the owner of his labour.
('75', 344, 3, 26, 674563) He is, therefore.
('75', 344, 3, 27, 674581) from our point of view, richer than the rich.
('75', 344, 3, 28, 674627) A zamindar can be recognized as the owner of one, two or ten bighas of land.
('75', 344, 3, 29, 674704) That is to say, of as much as may be necessary for his livelihood.
('75', 344, 4, 30, 674771) 1 Gandhiji has used the English term.
('75', 345, 0, 1, 674809) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 345, 1, 2, 674851) We also want that his wages should not be higher than those of the labourer, that he should maintain himself on eight annas a day and use the rest of his wealth for the welfare of society.
('75', 345, 1, 3, 675040) But we would not take away his property by force.
('75', 345, 1, 4, 675090) This is the most important point.
('75', 345, 1, 5, 675124) We also wish that the Princes and the millionaires too should do manual work and maintain themselves on eight annas a day, considering the rest of their property as national trust.
('75', 345, 1, 6, 675305) At this point it may be asked as to how many trustees of this type one can really find.
('75', 345, 1, 7, 675393) As a matter of fact, such a question should not arise at all.
('75', 345, 1, 8, 675455) It is not directly related to our theory.
('75', 345, 1, 9, 675497) There may be just one such trustee or there may be none at all.
('75', 345, 1, 10, 675561) Why should we worry about it?
('75', 345, 1, 11, 675591) We should have the faith that we can, without violence or with so little violence that it can hardly be called violence, create such a feeling among the rich.
('75', 345, 1, 12, 675750) We should act in that faith.
('75', 345, 1, 13, 675779) That is sufficient for us.
('75', 345, 1, 14, 675806) We should demonstrate through our endeavour that we can end economic disparity with the help of non violence.
('75', 345, 1, 15, 675916) Only those who have no faith in non violence can ask how many trustees of this kind can be found.
('75', 345, 1, 16, 676014) You may say that such a thing can never happen.
('75', 345, 1, 17, 676062) You may consider it as something not in keeping with human nature.

('75', 345, 2, 19, 676226) I fully endorse your view about varnadharma.
('75', 345, 2, 20, 676271) But putting it into practice is a really complicated matter.
('75', 345, 2, 21, 676332) Will you please elucidate ?
('75', 345, 2, 22, 676360) Today castes have become mongrelized.

('75', 345, 2, 25, 676494) This is what this question implies.

('75', 354, 3, 6, 698665) 412. IS NIRA OBJECTIONABLE ?
('75', 354, 4, 7, 698694) Among the fourteen points that Parsi friends have raised against the prohibition campaign, there occurs this strange passage :
('75', 354, 5, 8, 698821) Mahatamaji persuades the Parsis to drink nira.
('75', 354, 5, 9, 698868) (sweet, unfermented toddy), but the Parsis very well know the properties of nira.
('75', 354, 5, 10, 698950) Moreover the British Government had already tried this nira drinking experiment free of tree tax, but it failed because nira produces cold, flatulence, diarrhoea, etc.
('75', 354, 5, 11, 699118) The experiment was already tried in Mahatmaji’s Ashram at Segaon and there fatal results were pronounced.
('75', 354, 5, 12, 699224) I do not know what the Bombay Government tried.
('75', 354, 5, 13, 699272) But I do know what nira is doing and has done to those who are trying it.
('75', 354, 5, 14, 699346) It is wholly wrong to say that the experiment at Segaon Ashram failed and that it produced fatal results.
('75', 354, 5, 15, 699452) It has never been known to have produced any of the bad results ascribed to it by the writer.
('75', 354, 5, 16, 699546) On the contrary nira is still being freely drunk by many in Segaon and that with profit to their health.
('75', 354, 5, 17, 699651) Moreover it is turned into syrup or gur, and in that condition I and many others use it almost daily.
('75', 354, 5, 18, 699753) As gur it is sold in large quantities.
('75', 354, 5, 19, 699792) It is better relished than sugar cane gur because of its being less sweet.
('75', 354, 5, 20, 699867) As to the deaths that occurred in Wardha, not in Segaon, the investigations have clearly showed that the deaths were due not to nira drinking but to cholera.
('75', 354, 5, 21, 700025) Nothing has been shown to establish any connection between the deaths and nira.
('75', 354, 5, 22, 700105) Supposing the patients had developed cholera without drinking nira, would it have been right to say that cholera was induced by the ordinary food that they had eaten?
('75', 354, 5, 23, 700272) I may mention that several people had taken in Segaon with impunity the same nira that had been taken in Wardha.
('75', 354, 5, 24, 700385) If the thirteen other points are based on as weak a foundation as this (No.
('75', 354, 5, 25, 700461) 13) is, surely there is no case against prohibition.
('75', 354, 5, 26, 700514) And I make bold to say that the rest are no stronger.
('75', 354, 5, 27, 700568) I have picked out the thirteenth in the hope that my personal testimony may put the
('75', 355, 0, 1, 700652) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 355, 1, 2, 700694) opponents on their guard againt making statements they cannot substantiate.
('75', 355, 1, 3, 700770) Opposition based on reason must always command respect.
('75', 355, 1, 4, 700826) This one seems to me to lack that essential quality.

('75', 356, 6, 11, 702363) 416. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS AT GANDHI SEVA SANGH MEETING, BRINDABAN–III
('75', 356, 7, 12, 702433) May 7, 1939 Let me begin with Radhakrishna’s question which I took up yesterday 1 but could not finish.
('75', 356, 7, 13, 702537) The question about God had been more or less dealt with.
('75', 356, 7, 14, 702594) A discussion on it was going on.
('75', 356, 7, 15, 702627) Shri Krishnan Nair had raised a subtle point.
('75', 356, 7, 16, 702673) But it does not allow much scope for discussion.
('75', 356, 7, 17, 702722) I am indifferent about the names or attributes which a man may apply to God.
('75', 356, 7, 18, 702799) I had made a general statement that any man who had no faith in God could not stay a satyagrahi to the end.
('75', 356, 7, 19, 702907) What I had meant was that so long as the satyagrahi is not convinced that there is some great subtle Power that would give him strength in all situations, he cannot face tyranny, strife and humiliations and sustain his non violence.

('75', 373, 1, 2, 738591) 428. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('75', 373, 2, 3, 738622) ON THE WAY TO BENARES, May 9, 1939
('75', 373, 3, 4, 738657) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, I purposely restrained myself from troubling you whilst you were touring and taking part holiday.
('75', 373, 3, 5, 738777) Many thanks for your prompt reply 1 about Talcher.
('75', 373, 3, 6, 738828) The condition there defies analysis.
('75', 373, 3, 7, 738865) One day hope rises high and then it is dashed to pieces.
('75', 373, 3, 8, 738922) It is not now the Raja’s plighted word, it is that of the represe ntative of the Paramount Power that is being weighed.
('75', 373, 3, 9, 739042) The people won’t understand the fine distinctions as to when an official speaks with authority and when he speaks without.
('75', 373, 3, 10, 739165) I know you are watching and feel confident that you will see that the people of Talcher are freed from harassment well before the rains begin.
('75', 373, 3, 11, 739308) The very simple affair of Jaipur still hangs fire.
('75', 373, 3, 12, 739359) I just understand that some prisoners have been discharged.
('75', 373, 3, 13, 739419) Civil disobedience having been discontinued there seems to be no cause for keeping any prisoners and that too in a snake infested old fort.
('75', 373, 3, 14, 739559) Nor is there any meaning in keeping Sheth Jamnalalji practically in solitary confinement, the cause for his detention having disappeared.
('75', 373, 3, 15, 739697) The authorities were afraid that he was entering Jaipur State to promote civil disobedience.
('75', 373, 3, 16, 739790) And the demand of the people is less than elementary.
('75', 373, 3, 17, 739844) They would be satisfied if they have the guarantee of civil liberty.
('75', 373, 3, 18, 739913) I should have thought that Jaipur would present no difficulty.
('75', 373, 4, 19, 739976) Lastly, Rajkot.
('75', 373, 4, 20, 739992) The Award has been a halter round my neck.
('75', 373, 4, 21, 740035) This situation has taxed and is still taxing all my resources.
('75', 373, 4, 22, 740098) I am applying what appears to me to be a new and difficult technique.
('75', 373, 4, 23, 740168) Though I am not giving up the support of the Paramount Power, I am keeping it as much as I am able in the background and am trying to woo Durbar Shri Virawala.
('75', 373, 4, 24, 740328) On going back to Rajkot from Delhi I saw that I had a mountain of difficulties to face owing to the Award itself.
('75', 373, 4, 25, 740442) They are all still there.
('75', 373, 4, 26, 740468) And they are piling up.
('75', 373, 4, 27, 740492) But I see that even for decency’s sake I must not run to you or your representative on every pretext.
('75', 373, 4, 28, 740594) I shall come when I must.
('75', 373, 4, 29, 740620) Meanwhile, I shall try to woo Durbar Shri Virawala and see if I can get anything approaching the
('75', 373, 5, 30, 740717) 1 Vide footnote 1, “Telegram to Lord Linlithgow”, 18 4 1939 2 Vide also“Jaipur Prisoners”

('75', 374, 3, 11, 741660) 429. A MESSAGE [On or After May 9, 1939] 2
('75', 374, 4, 12, 741703) I observe that Senapati Bapat is reported to have said that I approved of his plan of drowning himself because India had not attained swaraj within the time stipulated or expected by him.
('75', 374, 4, 13, 741891) When I saw the report I gave no credence to it.
('75', 374, 4, 14, 741939) But I am overwhelmed by correspondents asking me whether I was consenting party and, If I was, on what grounds.
('75', 374, 4, 15, 742051) I must say that I have no recollection whatsoever of having approved of the contemplated step.
('75', 374, 4, 16, 742146) I do remember his having discussed the proposal among many other things.
('75', 374, 4, 17, 742219) But I cannot conceive of my consenting to anybody drowning himself for the sake of winning swaraj.
('75', 374, 4, 18, 742318) If I have any influence over Senapati Bapat I would urge him not to take the fatal step, assuming that he is correctly reported.
('75', 374, 4, 19, 742447) I would urge him and his disciples to live for swaraj and embrace death when it comes to them naturally and in due course.

('75', 377, 6, 14, 745551) 435. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 377, 7, 15, 745581) May 11, 1939
('75', 377, 8, 16, 745594) To one of the Pressmen who enquired about his health Gandhiji said: I am so so.
('75', 377, 8, 17, 745674) I can’t say my cough has left me.
('75', 377, 9, 18, 745708) QUESTION: What is your next step with regard to Rajkot?
('75', 377, 10, 19, 745764) GANDHIJI: Naturally it would be to take up the threads where I left them and where they are left.
('75', 377, 11, 20, 745862) Knowing that the last words of the sentence were significant, one of the Pressmen repeated: “Where you left them and where they are left?” Gandhiji clarified the words without delay.
('75', 377, 11, 21, 746045) You are all aware that something has happened between the time I left Rajkot and the present moment.
('75', 377, 12, 22, 746146) 1 The source says: “Resting on a cot covered with khadi in a spacious room in Birla House, Mahatma Gandhi received a batch of Pressmen this afternoon, with a pleasant smile on his face, remarking with a twinkle in his eye: “Here comes the gang.’ In spite of a strenuous journey last night, Mahatma Gandhi looked exceedingly fit and cheerful.
('75', 377, 12, 23, 746488) He was busy reading a bundle of letters as the pressmen were ushered in.

('75', 378, 2, 4, 746934) It was asked if this scheme of reforms suggested by Durbar Virawala did not amount to a breach of promise made by the Thakore Saheb in his Notification of December 26 last, according to which the conferring of the widest powers on the people had been promised.
