('75', 379, 5, 7, 748950) May 12, 1939 I wonder why my statement of 24th 2 April should have perturbed some of you.
('75', 379, 5, 8, 749040) I said nothing new in it.
('75', 379, 5, 9, 749066) It was a summary of what I had told 3 you in detail just before I left Rajkot.
('75', 379, 5, 10, 749145) So far as Vajubhai 4 and his colleagues’ statement is concerned, let me tell you I have rather liked it inasmuch as it has served to bring out in clear relief the fundamental differences between his group and me.
('75', 379, 5, 11, 749358) The Council of Action, it is stated, was constituted by the Parishad for the specific purpose of conducting the civil disobedience fight.
('75', 379, 5, 12, 749496) Now that it has been called off sine die, its function has lapsed.
('75', 379, 5, 13, 749563) I can quite understand the objection to negotiating a settlement in its name.
('75', 379, 5, 14, 749641) But I am not conducting the negotiations in the Council’s name.
('75', 379, 5, 15, 749705) Let me explain my own position in this matter.
('75', 379, 5, 16, 749752) When the Award was first announced, under the exultation of the moment I allowed myself to say that the result of my Rajkot fast had exceeded my expectations.
('75', 379, 5, 17, 749911) But I now find that the Chief Justice’s Award has become a halter round my neck .
('75', 379, 5, 18, 749993) I did not come here at your invitation.
('75', 379, 5, 19, 750033) I came here because Rajkot is the home of my childhood and because I felt I would be able to keep its Ruler to his promises.
('75', 379, 5, 20, 750158) In the various steps which I have taken since my arrival here, I had been guided solely by my inner

('75', 380, 1, 2, 750966) light and the logic of circumstances.
('75', 380, 1, 3, 751004) Nobody is under any obligation to join me in my present experiment.
('75', 380, 1, 4, 751072) Anybody who feels differently from me is perfectly free to go his way, and if the people of Rajkot decide to carry on the fight by following different methods, I would not mind it.
('75', 380, 1, 5, 751253) I am humble enough to know that there may be a different way and a better way than mine of doing a thing.
('75', 380, 1, 6, 751359) In no case do I want to see our people turn into cowards.

('75', 380, 1, 10, 751833) The Rajkot issue is not so simple or superficial as it might appear at first sight.

('75', 380, 1, 15, 752323) Such impatience reflects little credit on my ahimsa.
('75', 380, 1, 16, 752376) My legal position was correct.
('75', 380, 1, 17, 752407) But ahimsa does not go by legal rights.
('75', 380, 1, 18, 752447) I have now realized that I must be content to plod on with infinite patience.
('75', 380, 1, 19, 752525) It is no mango trick that can be performed in the twinkling of an eye.
('75', 380, 1, 20, 752596) It calls for a more potent force even than civil disobedience, viz., the application of the active principle that lies at the core of ahimsa.
('75', 380, 1, 21, 752738) This is the new light that I sense I have seen.
('75', 380, 1, 22, 752786) I see it but dimly.
('75', 380, 1, 23, 752806) And I am therefore unable to define it.

('75', 380, 1, 25, 752997) But that requires courage, fearlessness and ample faith.

('75', 380, 1, 27, 753123) But such faith cannot come by mechanical means.

('75', 381, 1, 2, 753513) it become to me like a palace, a sanctuary, a place of pilgrimage, where I learnt things which probably I would not have outside.
('75', 381, 1, 3, 753643) If I had to act only for myself, I would not probably have hesitated to take the plunge.
('75', 381, 1, 4, 753732) But as a custodian of the people’s interests I wonder if I should run any risks.
('75', 381, 1, 5, 753813) Thus has conscience turned me into a coward and I am vacillating between doubt and faith.
('75', 381, 1, 6, 753903) My ahimsa tells me that I must tear up the Award.
('75', 381, 1, 7, 753953) But the reason is not yet fully convinced.
('75', 381, 1, 8, 753996) ‘What is the meaning of not seeking aid from the Paramount Power,’ I argue to myself , ‘when you are trying to secure the co operation of Durbar Shri Virawala and the Thakore Saheb?
('75', 381, 1, 9, 754178) Are they not all parts of one and the same system?’ Thus I am caught in the net of my own reasoning.
('75', 381, 1, 10, 754279) All this I know is a sign of lack of faith on my part.
('75', 381, 1, 11, 754334) I cannot, while there is this conflict between the head and the heart within me , offer to take you along with me or be of much use to you as a ‘guide’.
('75', 381, 1, 12, 754487) I have no set theory to go by.
('75', 381, 1, 13, 754518) I have not worked out the science of satyagraha in its entirety.
('75', 381, 1, 14, 754583) I am still groping.
('75', 381, 1, 15, 754603) You can join me in my quest if it appeals to you and you feel the call.
('75', 381, 1, 16, 754675) A representative is bound to consult his principals and take his instructions from them at every step.
('75', 381, 1, 17, 754778) But a physician cannot afford to do so regarding his patients.
('75', 381, 1, 18, 754841) He must be guided solely by his instinct and vary his treatment according to his reading of the symptoms as they might develop from moment to moment.
('75', 381, 1, 19, 754991) He cannot accept dictation of the patient.
('75', 381, 1, 20, 755034) I stand in a dual capacity in relation to you.
('75', 381, 1, 21, 755081) I am your spokesman whom you have also accepted as your physician.
('75', 381, 1, 22, 755148) You must implicitly follow the treatment laid down by your physician so long as you have faith in him.
('75', 381, 1, 23, 755251) If he no longer commands your confidence, you must appoint in his place another who does.
('75', 381, 1, 24, 755341) Only a prospective mother knows what it is to carry, The onlookers notice her illness and pity her.
('75', 381, 1, 25, 755441) But she alone knows the travail.
('75', 381, 1, 26, 755474) It is I who have conceived satyagraha.
('75', 381, 1, 27, 755513) Mine alone, therefore, must be the travail and the suffering.
('75', 381, 1, 28, 755575) I am not joking.
('75', 381, 1, 29, 755592) I am in dreadful earnest.
('75', 381, 1, 30, 755618) I shall enter the fiery gates and pursue my mission even if I am the only person left to do so—I am resolved to try and exhaust every resource of satyagraha to convert Durbar Virawala.
('75', 381, 1, 31, 755803) If I succeed, you will all share the fruit.
('75', 381, 1, 32, 755847) If I fail, the responsibility will be entirely mine and what I do will in no way affect you.
('75', 381, 1, 33, 755940) When I was little child, there used to be two blind master performers in Rajkot.
('75', 381, 1, 34, 756021) One of them was musician.
('75', 381, 1, 35, 756047) When he played on his instrument, his fingers swept the strings with an unerring instinct
('75', 382, 0, 1, 756137) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 383
('75', 382, 1, 2, 756181) and everybody listened spellbound to his playing.
('75', 382, 1, 3, 756231) Similarly there are chords in every human heart.
('75', 382, 1, 4, 756280) If we only know how to strike the right chord, we bring out the music.
('75', 382, 1, 5, 756351) Durbar Virawala in no exception to the rule.
('75', 382, 1, 6, 756396) Have I set Durbar Virawala completely at his ease?
('75', 382, 1, 7, 756447) Have I applied truth and ahimsa only in my dealings with him?
('75', 382, 1, 8, 756509) Have I not threatened him with the Award?
('75', 382, 1, 9, 756551) We want to set up democracy in Rajkot.
('75', 382, 1, 10, 756590) A born democrat is a born disciplinarian.
('75', 382, 1, 11, 756632) Democracy comes naturally to him who is habituated normally to yield willing obedience to all laws, human or divine.
('75', 382, 1, 12, 756749) I claim to be a democrat both by instinct and training.
('75', 382, 1, 13, 756805) Let those who are ambitious to serve democracy qualify themselves by satisfying first this acid test of democracy.
('75', 382, 1, 14, 756920) Moreover, a democrat must be utterly selfless.
('75', 382, 1, 15, 756967) He must think and dream not in terms of self or party but only of democracy.
('75', 382, 1, 16, 757044) Only then does he acquire the right of civil disobedience.
('75', 382, 1, 17, 757103) I do not want anybody to give up his convictions or to suppress himself.
('75', 382, 1, 18, 757176) I do not believe that a healthy and honest difference of opinion will injure our cause.
('75', 382, 1, 19, 757264) But opportunism, camouflage or patched up compromises certainly will.
('75', 382, 1, 20, 757334) If you must dissent, you should take care that your opinions voice your innermost convictions and are not intended merely as a convenient party cry.
('75', 382, 1, 21, 757483) Today our democracy is choked by our internecine strife.
('75', 382, 1, 22, 757540) We are torn by dissensions—dissensions between Hindus and Mussalmans, Brahmins and non Brahmins, Congressmen and non Congressmen.
('75', 382, 1, 23, 757670) It is no easy task to evolve democracy out of this mobocracy.
('75', 382, 1, 24, 757732) Let us not make confusion worse confounded by further introducing into it the virus of sectionalism and party spirit.
('75', 382, 1, 25, 757850) I value individual freedom but you must not forget that man is essentially a social being.
('75', 382, 1, 26, 757941) He has risen to this present status by learning to adjust his individualism to the requirements of social progress.
('75', 382, 1, 27, 758057) Unrestricted individualism is the law of the beast of the jungle.
('75', 382, 1, 28, 758123) We have learnt to strike the mean between individual freedom and social restraint.
('75', 382, 1, 29, 758206) Willing submission to social restraint for the sake of the well being of the whole society enriches both the individual and the society of which one is a member.
('75', 382, 1, 30, 758368) Harijan, 27 5 1939.

('75', 387, 1, 2, 763835) 446. INTERVIEW TO TRAVANCORE NATIONAL CONGRESS DEPUTATION 1
('75', 387, 2, 3, 763895) May 13/14, 1939
('75', 387, 3, 4, 763911) The deputationists first explained to Mahatmaji in detail the changes introduced by the Government in the electoral system of Travancore.
('75', 387, 4, 5, 764049) Mahatmaji said that he understood the system as it existed and also the present change, and asked : Is this all that you have to discuss with me?
('75', 387, 5, 6, 764195) Mr. Kainikkara said that they would like to discuss everything concerning the political situation in Travancore.
('75', 387, 6, 7, 764308) GANDHIJI: Do you know the charge against you?
('75', 387, 7, 8, 764354) KAINIKKARA: We know there is a great deal of misrepresentation about us and that we are under a cloud.
('75', 387, 8, 9, 764457) G. It is said that your organization, the Travancore National Congress, is a bogus organization, that you are not an independent body and that you are an instrument of the Government.
('75', 387, 8, 10, 764641) What do you say to this?
('75', 387, 9, 11, 764666) KAINIKKARA: We repudiated the charge.
('75', 387, 9, 12, 764704) We need only say that most of us in the Travancore National Congress have been in the political field from the days of the Non co operation Movement.
('75', 387, 9, 13, 764854) That cannot be said of many of the members of the State Congress.
('75', 387, 10, 14, 764920) G. If that be so, what have you to say regarding the treatment of the lady, Miss Annie Mascarene?
('75', 387, 10, 15, 765018) Why is it that Sir C.P. Ramaswami Aiyar refuses to enquire into that matter?
('75', 387, 11, 16, 765095) KAINIKKARA: Regarding Miss Mascarene, we do not wish to say anything.
('75', 387, 11, 17, 765165) We would rather not discuss her .
('75', 387, 11, 18, 765199) We could not demand an enquiry for we know from actual experience the outrages perpetrated by the followers of the State Congress .
('75', 387, 12, 19, 765331) Mahatmaji asked us whether therefore we are justifying all the arrests, etc., made by the Government.
('75', 387, 13, 20, 765433) KAINIKKARA: We are not.
('75', 387, 13, 21, 765457) Some arrests may be right and some may be wrong.
('75', 387, 13, 22, 765506) But how can we throw the whole blame on the Government?
('75', 387, 13, 23, 765562) It is well known that Chengannoor is a State Congress stronghold.
('75', 387, 13, 24, 765628) There .
('75', 387, 13, 25, 765636) huge banyan trees were cut
('75', 387, 14, 26, 765663) 1 Extracted from a report of the statement which, according to the source, was issued by the deputationists, Kainikkara Padmanabha Pillai, M. L. A., Kottoor Kunju krishna Pillai, M. L. C., and K. P. Kayyalakkal, “with the approval of Gandhiji”.
('75', 387, 14, 27, 765908) E. John Philipose of Travancore State Congress was also present.
('75', 388, 0, 1, 765973) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 389
('75', 388, 1, 2, 766017) down to obstruct traffic, and culverts and bridges were broken .
('75', 388, 1, 3, 766082) Can it be said that none of the State Congress workers saw this?
('75', 388, 1, 4, 766147) Why did they not at least help to find out the culprits?
('75', 388, 1, 5, 766204) It may be better for Sir C.P. Ramaswami Aiyar to institute an enquiry .
('75', 388, 1, 6, 766276) but we who know the actual facts by experience cannot make the demand.
('75', 388, 2, 7, 766347) G. Do you say that it is the measures adopted by the Government that re established peace?
('75', 388, 3, 8, 766438) KAINIKKARA : No.
('75', 388, 3, 9, 766455) You did it.
('75', 388, 3, 10, 766467) Peace was established with the stopping of civil disobedience.
('75', 388, 3, 11, 766530) If civil disobedience were to be started again all the disturbances would recur.
('75', 388, 4, 12, 766611) G. Then you admit that, at the worst, the mistake on the part of the State Congress was that they had no control over their followers.
('75', 388, 5, 13, 766746) KOTTOOR : No, not only that.
('75', 388, 5, 14, 766775) Their first fault is that they started civil disobedience without assuring themselves of their control.
('75', 388, 5, 15, 766879) Their next fault is that they did not stop it even when they found their real position, and their gravest fault is that they never seriously checked their followers for the fear that they would lose their followers .
('75', 388, 6, 16, 767096) Then Mahatmaji asked us what our fundamental difference was with the State Congress.
('75', 388, 7, 17, 767181) We told him that we had been demanding Responsible Government for the last twenty years .
('75', 388, 7, 18, 767271) At that time, the Christians opposed the demand for Responsible Government.
('75', 388, 7, 19, 767347) In 1932, the Christian Ezhava Muslim agitation for communal representation gave a new turn to Travancore politics.
('75', 388, 7, 20, 767462) Now that the legislature is decidedly based on communal representation and the Christians dominate the communal clique, they are demanding Responsible Government.
('75', 388, 8, 21, 767625) G. Therefore you question the good faith of the Christians.
('75', 388, 9, 22, 767685) KAINIKKARA : We do.
('75', 388, 10, 23, 767705) G. At the beginning I put a sharp question about you.
('75', 388, 10, 24, 767759) Now I put another question about them.
('75', 388, 10, 25, 767798) We are trying to reach the truth.
('75', 388, 11, 26, 767832) KAINIKKARA : Yes, we do question the good faith of the Christians.
('75', 388, 12, 27, 767899) G. Suppose they agree to nationalize the legislature, then what objection do you have?
('75', 388, 13, 28, 767986) KAINIKKARA : Then we have no objection.
('75', 388, 14, 29, 768026) On the next day we met at 8 p.
('75', 388, 14, 30, 768057) after prayers.
('75', 388, 14, 31, 768072) Mahatmaji then explained the position of the State Congress as he had understood it.
('75', 388, 14, 32, 768157) He said that the State Congress, including the Christian section in it, was not anti national.
('75', 388, 14, 33, 768252) The far seeing Christians, even those that might have been at one time communal, have seen that communal arrangement and pacts will not serve them in the end.
('75', 388, 14, 34, 768411) He illustrated it by
('75', 389, 0, 1, 768432) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 389, 1, 2, 768474) the experience of the Muslims in Bengal.
('75', 389, 1, 3, 768515) He said that therefore the sinister motives that they alleged against the Christians were not real and the State Congress was national and would be prepared to nationalize the constitution of the legislature.
('75', 389, 1, 4, 768724) Mr. Philipose explained that the attitude of the Christians in the State Congress was entirely national.
('75', 389, 1, 5, 768829) He also said that the organization was not communal and that all communities were in it.
('75', 389, 2, 6, 768918) KAINIKKARA : It is enough that we make our position clear and definite, Our position is this: We object to communal representation and Responsible Government going together.
('75', 389, 2, 7, 769092) We insist on the reorganization of the legislature on purely national lines.
('75', 389, 2, 8, 769169) By nationalizing we mean the removal of nominations and reservations and the application of a common principle in respect of franchise, delimitation and system of voting.
('75', 389, 3, 9, 769340) G. That is reasonable.
('75', 389, 3, 10, 769363) Now my task will be to wait for the others.
('75', 389, 3, 11, 769407) How I wish to have at least one of you with me till they arrive.
('75', 389, 4, 12, 769472) KOTTOOR : But Mahatmaji, you have not told us your opinion about the change in the voting system.
('75', 389, 5, 13, 769570) G. It does not very seriously concern me.
('75', 389, 5, 14, 769612) For, after all, it does not solve the difficulties.
('75', 389, 6, 15, 769664) KOTTOOR: I hope, however, that you do not consider the change anti national.
('75', 389, 7, 16, 769741) G. The position is this.
('75', 389, 7, 17, 769766) The arrangement that subsisted was anti national.
('75', 389, 7, 18, 769816) You think that by this change at least one evil is removed.
('75', 389, 7, 19, 769876) But in my view what is left is still anti national .
('75', 389, 7, 20, 769929) The whole thing must be changed.
('75', 389, 7, 21, 769962) It must be made national.
('75', 389, 8, 22, 769988) PHILIPOSE : It would be good, if it came before the elections.
('75', 389, 9, 23, 770051) KAINIKKARA : We have no illusions about Responsible Government coming within three weeks.
('75', 389, 10, 24, 770141) G. Let Responsible Government take its own time.
('75', 389, 10, 25, 770190) If the present anti national system could be changed before that, even that would be a great thing.
('75', 389, 11, 26, 770290) Mr. Kayyalakkal said that for the last many years they, the Ezhavas, had been trying to remove social and religious inequalities.
('75', 389, 11, 27, 770420) Realizing that temple entry alone could solve the problem, his brother in law, Mr. T. K. Madhavan, placed the matter at Gandhiji’s feet.
('75', 389, 11, 28, 770557) By the grace of H. H. the Maharaja and the blessings of Mahatmaji, they had got it now.
('75', 389, 11, 29, 770645) Now Gandhiji must bless them and help them to live as one with the rest of the Hindu and to contribute their share for the prosperity and well being of the Hindu community as a whole.
('75', 389, 12, 30, 770829) G. Blessings you always have in plenty.
('75', 389, 12, 31, 770869) Help I have given.
('75', 389, 12, 32, 770888) Now you have to help yourselves.
('75', 390, 0, 1, 770921) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 391
('75', 390, 1, 2, 770965) Just then the clock struck and Gandhiji smilingly said: “The curfew tolls”, and Mr. Kainikkara completed, “the knell of parting day”.
('75', 390, 1, 3, 771099) Gandhiji repeated : Yes, exactly, the knell of parting day.
('75', 390, 1, 4, 771159) The Hindu, 2 6 1939.
('75', 390, 2, 5, 771180) 447. LETTER TO AKBAR HYDARI
('75', 390, 3, 6, 771208) ANANDKUNJ, RAJKOT, May 15, 1939
('75', 390, 4, 7, 771240) DEAR SIR AKBAR, I have to acknowledge your kind letters of 11th and 25th ultimo.
('75', 390, 4, 8, 771321) As you are aware, during the eighteen days before the 12th instant, Calcutta and Brindaban in Champaran claimed my attention.
('75', 390, 4, 9, 771447) I was unable to see the Aryasamaj friends during those days.
('75', 390, 4, 10, 771508) But they waylaid me on the 10th as I was journeying back to Rajkot.
('75', 390, 4, 11, 771576) This accounts for the unavoidable delay in acknowledging and dealing with your important letters.
('75', 390, 4, 12, 771674) I don’t propose to go into the past nor into the replies the Aryasamaj friends have favoured me with.
('75', 390, 4, 13, 771776) The minimum requirements of the Aryasamajists are: 1. Absolute freedom for the practice and preaching of the Vedic religion and culture, with due regard to the feelings of the followers of other faiths.
('75', 390, 4, 14, 771979) 2. Full freedom for starting new Aryasamajas and building of new Aryasamaj mandirs yajnashalas, havankundas and the repairing of the old ones without obtaining any premission from the Ecclesiastical or any other department of the State.
('75', 390, 4, 15, 772216) Your letters lead me to think that you have no serious objections to conceding these.
('75', 390, 4, 16, 772302) If my reading is correct, why wait for the reforms or the establishment of the ecclesiastical court?
('75', 390, 4, 17, 772403) You will considerably enhance the cause of peace, if you could possibly make the suggested gesture.
('75', 390, 4, 18, 772503) The Aryasamajist civil disobedience will then stop at once.
('75', 390, 5, 19, 772563) Yours sincerely, BAPU From a photostat: G. N. 8016

('75', 392, 9, 18, 774644) [May 15, 1939] 2
('75', 392, 10, 19, 774661) What is it that prevents me from throwing the Award overboard?
('75', 392, 10, 20, 774724) It is not only faint heartedness but it smacks of diplomacy.
('75', 392, 10, 21, 774785) If I want Durbar Virawala to act on the square I must relieve his fears too.
('75', 392, 10, 22, 774862) Why should he have to remain in fear of the Paramount Power and not do what he can of his own free will?
('75', 392, 10, 23, 774967) I am talking so much of ahimsa, but I am not walking fearlessly into the mouth of himsa.
('75', 392, 10, 24, 775056) A satyagrahi seeks no adventitious aid—not of worldly forces, not of the Paramount Power.
('75', 392, 10, 25, 775146) He deals directly wih his opponent and wins him by love and utter self surrender to God.
('75', 392, 10, 26, 775235) The very difficulty of implementing the Award, the very fact that it has proved a Pandora’s box shows that God wants me to throw it away, however seemingly fruitful of future good it may be.
('75', 392, 10, 27, 775426) God seems to be speaking to me in strident tones; ‘Your victory was no victory.
('75', 392, 10, 28, 775506) Throw it away !’ You want me to go on with the work of the Award, because it belongs to

('75', 393, 1, 2, 775987) But how can I go on with it when my courage fails me, my hands are shaking and I am faltering?
('75', 393, 1, 3, 776082) It is a moral issue with me.

('75', 393, 3, 8, 776420) 453. TALCHER
('75', 393, 4, 9, 776433) Talcher promises to be much worse than Rajkot.
('75', 393, 4, 10, 776480) In Rajkot it was the Ruler’s word that was broken.
('75', 393, 4, 11, 776531) In Talcher it is the Paramount Power’s.
('75', 393, 4, 12, 776571) In Rajkot the State atrocities were not the subject of scrutiny.
('75', 393, 4, 13, 776636) In Talcher the sorry condition of the numerous refugees is almost everything.
('75', 393, 4, 14, 776714) Hence delay is criminal and may mean loss of one year’s crop to several thousand cultivators.
('75', 393, 4, 15, 776808) The other relief promised by the Political Agent, Major Hennessey, relates to paltry things so far as the Ruler of Talcher is concerned but they are serious enough for the people.
('75', 393, 4, 16, 776988) It has been whispered to me that I have been guilty of injustice to Major Hennessey and hence to the Paramount Power by attributing to them breach of promise; for, it is said, Major Hennessey promised nothing, he merely undertook to convey to the Ruler the wishes of the people concerned.
('75', 393, 4, 17, 777277) It is further said that even if it is proved that he made any such promise he did so without authority.
('75', 393, 4, 18, 777381) I cannot admit either of the pleas.
('75', 393, 4, 19, 777417) Major Hennessey signed the document without any reservations.
('75', 393, 4, 20, 777479) Shri Harekrushna Mahtab described the tragedy with a wealth of detail which compels conviction.
('75', 393, 4, 21, 777575) He has been an eye witness of the events narrated by him.
('75', 393, 4, 22, 777633) So far as I am aware Major Hennessey himself has never denied or has not been given an opportunity of denying the allegations made about him.
('75', 393, 4, 23, 777775) There seems to be no doubt that the Ruler of Talcher is in no mood to do justice to his people unless he is made to act according to the sanad I have already reproduced 1 in these columns.
('75', 393, 4, 24, 777964) The representative of the Paramount Power can even require the smaller

('75', 394, 0, 1, 778066) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 395
('75', 394, 1, 2, 778110) States of Orissa to perform acts in the interest of their people.
('75', 394, 1, 3, 778176) Can there be any doubt as to the necessity of redressing every one of the injustices mentioned in the memorandum signed by Major Hennessey?
('75', 394, 1, 4, 778316) Indeed redress has been long overdue.
('75', 394, 1, 5, 778354) Why is the Ruler being humoured by the Political Department in his wholly indefensible attitude?
('75', 394, 1, 6, 778451) Why is the welfare of several thousand refugees being lightly regarded?
('75', 394, 1, 7, 778523) Is not the prestige of the Paramount Power being used to sustain the admitted evils?

('75', 394, 5, 15, 778868) 455. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('75', 394, 6, 16, 778898) RAJKOT, May 17, 1939 I said 2 at Calcutta on the 24th ultimo that Rajkot had proved a laboratory for me.
('75', 394, 6, 17, 779003) The latest proof of the fact lies in the step I am now announcing.
('75', 394, 6, 18, 779070) After an exhaustive discussion with my co workers I have come to the conclusion at 6 o’clock this evening that I should renounce the advantages accruing from the Award of the Chief Justice.
('75', 394, 6, 19, 779260) I recognize my error.
('75', 394, 6, 20, 779282) At the end of my fast I had permitted myself to say that it had succeeded as no previous fast had done.
('75', 394, 6, 21, 779386) I now see that it was tainted with himsa.
('75', 394, 6, 22, 779428) In taking the fast I sought immediate intervention of the Paramount Power so as to induce fulfilment of the promise made by the Thakore Saheb.
('75', 394, 6, 23, 779571) This was not
('75', 394, 7, 24, 779584) 1 This appeared under the title “Confession and Repentance”.
('75', 394, 7, 25, 779645) The statement was also published in The Hindustan Times and The Hindu of May 18. 2 Vide “Popular Violence in Ramdurg”.
('75', 394, 7, 26, 779764) Gandhiji was on his way to Calcutta.
('75', 395, 0, 1, 779801) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 395, 1, 2, 779843) the way of ahimsa or conversion.
('75', 395, 1, 3, 779876) It was the way of himsa or coercion.
('75', 395, 1, 4, 779913) My fast to be pure should have been addressed only to the Thakore Saheb and I should have been content to die if I could not have melted his heart or rather that of his adviser, Durbar Shri Virawala.
('75', 395, 1, 5, 780113) My eyes would not have been opened if I had not found unexpected difficulties in my way.
('75', 395, 1, 6, 780202) Durbar Shri Virawala was no willing party to the Award.
('75', 395, 1, 7, 780258) Naturally, he was in no obliging mood.
('75', 395, 1, 8, 780297) He therefore took advantage of every opportunity to cause a delay.
('75', 395, 1, 9, 780364) The Award, instead of making my way smooth, became a potent cause of angering the Muslims and Bhayats against me.
('75', 395, 1, 10, 780478) Before the Award we had met as friend.
('75', 395, 1, 11, 780517) Now I am accused of having committed a breach of promise, voluntarily and without any consideration, made by me.
('75', 395, 1, 12, 780630) The matter was to go to the Chief Justice for decision as to whether I was guilty of the alleged breach of promise.
('75', 395, 1, 13, 780746) The statements of the Muslim Council and the Garasia Association are before me.
('75', 395, 1, 14, 780826) Now that I have taken the decision to renounce the Award, there is no occasion for me to answer the two cases.
('75', 395, 1, 15, 780937) So far as I am concerned, the Muslims and Bhayats can have anything the Thakore Saheb may be pleased to give them.
('75', 395, 1, 16, 781052) I must apologize to them for having put them to the trouble of preparing their cases.
('75', 395, 1, 17, 781138) I owe an apology to the Viceroy for the unnecessary strain I have put upon him in my weakness.
('75', 395, 1, 18, 781233) I apologize to the Chief Justice for having been the cause of putting him to the labour which had I known better, he need not have gone through.
('75', 395, 1, 19, 781378) Above all, I apologize to the Thakore Saheb and Durbar Shri Virawala.
('75', 395, 1, 20, 781448) So far as the latter is concerned, I must also own that, in common with my co workers, I have harboured evil thoughts about him.
('75', 395, 1, 21, 781577) I do not here pause to consider whether the charges made against him were true or not.
('75', 395, 1, 22, 781664) This is not the place to discuss them.
('75', 395, 1, 23, 781703) Suffice it to say that the way of ahimsa was not and had not yet been applied to him.
('75', 395, 1, 24, 781789) And let it be said to my discredit that I have been guilty of playing what may be called a double game, i.
('75', 395, 1, 25, 781896) e., hanging the sword of the Award over his head and wooing him and expecting him of his own free will to advise the Thakore Saheb to grant liberal reforms.
('75', 395, 1, 26, 782053) This method I admit is wholly inconsistent with ahimsa.
('75', 395, 1, 27, 782109) When all of a sudden I made what is known as a sporting offer to Mr. Gibson on 19th April, I discovered my weakness.
('75', 395, 1, 28, 782226) But I had not the courage then and there to say, ‘I do not want to have anything to do with the Award.’ Instead I said,‘Let the Thakore Saheb appoint his own Committee and then the Parishad people will examine the report
('75', 396, 0, 1, 782447) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 397
('75', 396, 1, 2, 782491) in terms of the Award, and if it is found defective it can go to the Chief Justice.’ Durbar Shri Virawala detected a flaw and very properly rejected the offer, saying: ‘You are still hanging the Award over my head and want to become a court of appeal over the Thakore Saheb’s Committee.
('75', 396, 1, 3, 782778) If such is the case, you must take your pound of flesh and no more’.
('75', 396, 1, 4, 782847) I saw the force of his objection.
('75', 396, 1, 5, 782881) I told him, too, that I lacked the courage then to throw the Award overboard, but I would still plead with him to come to terms with the people as if the Award was not in existence and as if the Sardar and I had also withdrawn.
('75', 396, 1, 6, 783109) He promised to try.
('75', 396, 1, 7, 783129) He tried in his own fashion but not with a large heart.
('75', 396, 1, 8, 783185) I do not blame him.
('75', 396, 1, 9, 783205) How could I expect large heart when he knew my faint heartedness in clinging to the Award?
('75', 396, 1, 10, 783296) Only trust can beget trust.
('75', 396, 1, 11, 783324) I lacked it myself.
('75', 396, 1, 12, 783344) But at last I have regained my lost courage.
('75', 396, 1, 13, 783389) My faith in the sovereign efficacy of ahimsa burns brighter for my confession and repentance.
('75', 396, 1, 14, 783483) I must not do an injustice to my co workers.
('75', 396, 1, 15, 783528) Many of them are filled with misgivings.
('75', 396, 1, 16, 783569) My exposition of ahimsa is new to them.
('75', 396, 1, 17, 783609) They see no cause for my repentance.
('75', 396, 1, 18, 783646) They think that I am giving up a great chance created by the Award.
('75', 396, 1, 19, 783714) They think too that as a political leader I have no right to play fast and loose with the fortunes of 75,000 souls, maybe of the whole of the people of Kathiawar.
('75', 396, 1, 20, 783877) I have told them that their fears are unjustified, and that every act of purification, every accession of courage, adds to the strength of the cause of a people affected by a movement of satyagraha.
('75', 396, 1, 21, 784076) I have told them, too, that if they regard me as the general and expert of satyagraha, they must put up with what may appear to them to be my vagaries.
('75', 396, 1, 22, 784228) Having now freed the Thakore Saheb and his adviser from the oppression of the Award, I have no hesitation in appealing to them to appease the people of Rajkot by fulfilling their expectations and dispelling their misgivings.
('75', 396, 1, 23, 784453) Harijan, 20 5 1939.

('75', 397, 1, 2, 784515) 456. DISCUSSION WITH MAHADEV DESAI 1
('75', 397, 2, 3, 784552) [May 17, 1939] 2
('75', 397, 3, 4, 784569) MAHADEV DESAI: How was it wrong to ask the Paramount Power to intervene?
('75', 397, 3, 5, 784642) You did not insist on the letter of your vow.
('75', 397, 3, 6, 784688) Otherwise you might have said you could not break the fast until your demand was satisfied.
('75', 397, 3, 7, 784780) But you were content with the arbitration of the Chief Justice.
('75', 397, 3, 8, 784844) Even so in 1918 3 when you fasted during the Ahmedabad labour strike you did not insist on the 35 percent increase in wage but you contented yourself with the mill owners consenting to an arbitration.
('75', 397, 3, 9, 785045) In fact, if the Thakore Saheb had yielded to your demand without the intervention of the Paramount Power, he might have charged you with having coerced him.
('75', 397, 3, 10, 785202) But here the arbitration which was the result of the fast ought to have been given [to] you even without the fast.
('75', 397, 4, 11, 785317) GANDHIJI: You are right.
('75', 397, 4, 12, 785342) But why don’t you see that in 1918 4 the arbitration was offered by the mill owners?
('75', 397, 4, 13, 785427) If the Thakore Saheb had offered arbitration of his own accord, it would have been splendid.
('75', 397, 4, 14, 785520) But here I appealed to the Paramount Power.
('75', 397, 4, 15, 785564) That is why the arbitration has been infructuous.
('75', 397, 4, 16, 785614) I had no business to be impatient.
('75', 397, 4, 17, 785649) Instead of waiting on God and allowing my fast to work itself I sought outside aid.
('75', 397, 4, 18, 785733) It was a grave blunder.
('75', 397, 5, 19, 785757) But why not wait until Sir Maurice Gwyer gives his decision on the new reference?
('75', 397, 5, 20, 785839) Let not the Mussalmans and Bhayats have the pretext of saying you fought shy of the Chief Justice’s decision.

('75', 397, 5, 23, 786028) I know that the reference is mischievous and we must win.
('75', 397, 5, 24, 786086) That might give greater value to the renunciation.
('75', 397, 5, 25, 786137) But I am not renouncing the Award in order that the world may acclaim the act.
('75', 397, 5, 26, 786216) By no means.
('75', 397, 5, 27, 786229) I am freeing myself from a terrible oppression .
('75', 397, 5, 28, 786278) I have made my decision and am feeling free as a bird.
('75', 397, 5, 29, 786333) Harijan, 27 5 1939.

('75', 398, 1, 2, 786681) 457. TALKS WITH CO WORKERS, RAJKOT 1
('75', 398, 2, 3, 786718) [ Afrer May 17, 1939] 2
('75', 398, 3, 4, 786742) I proved myself of little faith.
('75', 398, 3, 5, 786775) If I had staked my all on my faith in God and on the efficacy of my fast in melting the Thakore Saheb’s and Durbar Shri Virawala’s heart, the worst that could have happened would have been my death.
('75', 398, 3, 6, 786974) But it would have been a worthy death.
('75', 398, 3, 7, 787013) And if the Thakore Saheb and Virawala had not let me die, they would have come to me as friends and given me what I wanted.
('75', 398, 3, 8, 787137) In any event the result would have been better than the breach of my faith in God and making Durbar Virawala my enemy by appealing to the Viceroy to intervene and even to turn him out.
('75', 398, 3, 9, 787322) I am amazed at my own folly in thus antagonizing him and still expecting to convert him.
('75', 398, 3, 10, 787411) His own generosity is, I think, out of proportion to the provocation I had given him.
('75', 398, 3, 11, 787497) My hands are shaking and my steps faltering.
('75', 398, 3, 12, 787542) The very possession of this Award has made me a coward, and I am afraid if I were to retain it, it would make cowards of you too.
('75', 398, 3, 13, 787672) A satyagrahi does not depend for his strength on external means.
('75', 398, 3, 14, 787737) His strength comes from within, from his reliance on God.
('75', 398, 3, 15, 787795) God becomes his shield when he throws down all his earthly weapons.
('75', 398, 3, 16, 787863) But if he were to hide a fire arm in his pocket, his inner strength would go and he would cease to feel invulnerable.
('75', 398, 3, 17, 787981) The Award was very like a fire arm in the pocket of a votary of ahimsa like me.
('75', 398, 3, 18, 788061) It stood between me and my God.
('75', 398, 3, 19, 788093) It shamed me and made a coward of me.
('75', 398, 3, 20, 788131) I have thrown it away as Christian did his load of sin, and I am feeling again free and invulnerable and one with my Maker.
('75', 398, 3, 21, 788255) You ought to understand and appreciate the rejection of the Award.
('75', 398, 3, 22, 788322) It was well nigh impossible for you to have (to use the legal language) that decree executed.
('75', 398, 3, 23, 788416) I could have got it done, but at the cost of enormous labour and time and the legal talent that I still possess.
('75', 398, 3, 24, 788529) Meanwhile your energies would have been rusting, and your hands would have been crippled.
('75', 398, 3, 25, 788619) You would have learnt nothing from

('75', 399, 1, 3, 789203) I have saved you from the burden of my sin.
('75', 399, 1, 4, 789247) You are, at worst,‘as you were’.

('75', 399, 1, 10, 789511) You may not tolerate a general who changes his tactics every now and then.

('75', 399, 1, 12, 789641) I have not yet known a general who has not altered time and again the plans of his campaign and made eleventh hour alterations in his orders.
('75', 399, 1, 13, 789783) The ordinary fighting soldier knows nothing of these plans.

('75', 414, 1, 2, 821828) 472 THE JEWISH QUESTION
('75', 414, 2, 3, 821852) The Managing Editor of Jewish Frontier, published at 275 Seventh Avenue, New York City, was good enough to send me a copy of the March number of the magazine with the request that I should deal with its reply to my article 1 on the Jews in Germany and Palestine.
('75', 414, 2, 4, 822115) The reply is very ably written.
('75', 414, 2, 5, 822147) I wish I had space for reproducing the whole of it.
('75', 414, 2, 6, 822199) The reader will, however, find the main argument reproduced 2 in this issue of Harijan.
('75', 414, 2, 7, 822287) Let me say that I did not write the article as a critic.
('75', 414, 2, 8, 822344) I wrote it at the pressing request of Jewish friends and correspondents.
('75', 414, 2, 9, 822417) As I decided to write, I could not do so in any other manner.
('75', 414, 2, 10, 822479) But I did not entertain the hope when I wrote it that the Jews would be at once converted to my view.
('75', 414, 2, 11, 822581) I should have been satisfied if even one Jew had been fully convinced and converted.
('75', 414, 2, 12, 822666) Nor did I write the article only for today.
('75', 414, 2, 13, 822710) I flatter myself with the belief that some of my writings will survive me and will be of service to the causes for which they have been written.
('75', 414, 2, 14, 822855) I have no sense of disappointment that my writing had not to my knowledge converted a single Jew.
('75', 414, 2, 15, 822953) Having read the reply more than once, I must say that I see no reason to change the opinion I expressed in my article.
('75', 414, 2, 16, 823072) It is highly probable that, as the writer says, “a Jewish Gandhi in Germany, should one arise, could function for about five minutes and would be promptly taken to the guillotine”.
('75', 414, 2, 17, 823253) But that will not disprove my case or shake my belief in the efficacy of ahimsa.
('75', 414, 2, 18, 823334) I can conceive the necessity of the immolation of hundreds, if not thousands, to appease the hunger of dictators who have no belief in ahimsa.
('75', 414, 2, 19, 823477) Indeed the maxim is that ahimsa is the most efficacious in front of the greatest himsa.
('75', 414, 2, 20, 823565) Its quality is really tested only in such cases.
('75', 414, 2, 21, 823614) Sufferers need not
('75', 414, 3, 22, 823633) 1Vide “The Jews” 2 In his reply entitled “We Are Treated as Subhumans : We Are Asked to be Superhuman”, Hayim Greenberg had said: “.

('75', 417, 2, 4, 829114) 474. MESSAGE TO INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA 1
('75', 417, 3, 5, 829156) RAJKOT, May 23, 1939 It has been a matter of grief to me that the Union Government have not respected their own agreement regarding their treatment of British Indians.
('75', 417, 3, 6, 829324) There has been a policy of progressive stringency in their anti Asiatic drive.
('75', 417, 3, 7, 829403) One had hoped that what is known as the Smuts Gandhi Agreement of 1914 was the last word in this matter.
('75', 417, 3, 8, 829508) It was also hoped that with virtual restriction of Indian immigration, there would be progressive amelioration in the condition of domiciled Indians.
('75', 417, 3, 9, 829658) But that hope was dashed to pieces.
('75', 417, 3, 10, 829694) Much deterioration has taken place since.
('75', 417, 3, 11, 829736) There have been Round Table and other conferences, agreements have been reached, but never has any finality been felt by the Indians.
('75', 417, 3, 12, 829870) Evidently the Union Government would not be happy till they have either driven away Indians whom they have given legislative protection or reduced their status to such an extent that no self respecting Indian would care to remain in South Africa.
('75', 417, 3, 13, 830117) I have therefore not discount enanced their reported decision to fight this latest menace of segregation through civil resistance, if necessary.
('75', 417, 3, 14, 830262) There must be perfect cohesion and union among the Indians who are divided into groups.
('75', 417, 3, 15, 830350) And their resistance will be vain if they are not resolute in self suffering.
('75', 417, 3, 16, 830428) Public opinion in India including that of Europeans will, I hope, back the Indians in their unequal fight and call upon the Indian Government to exert its influence with the Union Government.
('75', 417, 3, 17, 830620) Lastly, I appeal to the best mind of South Africa to see that simple justice is not denied to the Indian settlers who have done no wrong to the country of their adoption.
('75', 417, 4, 18, 830791) Harijan, 27 5 1939.
('75', 417, 5, 19, 830811) 1 This appeared under the title “The Latest Menace”.
('75', 417, 5, 20, 830864) The message was also published in The Hindu, 24 5 1939. 2 Vide also “Interview to Associated Press of India”, 12 5 1939

('75', 419, 4, 9, 833471) 477. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, RAJKOT 1
('75', 419, 5, 10, 833511) May 23, 1939 I have come here to give an account of myself.
('75', 419, 5, 11, 833571) I want to render account not before the Parishad alone, but before all the people of Rajkot belonging to all groups.
('75', 419, 5, 12, 833688) I came to Rajkot with no good thoughts about Mr. Virawala.
('75', 419, 5, 13, 833747) I believed that the Thakore Saheb had broken his promise and from within I was prompted to undertake the fast.
('75', 419, 5, 14, 833858) But my mind weakened and the very next day I wrote to the Viceroy for intervention.
('75', 419, 5, 15, 833942) Now I see that it was an act of sin.
('75', 419, 5, 16, 833979) Its outcome was the Award, and its consequences are known to you.
('75', 419, 5, 17, 834045) As time went on, I realized my error and immediately renounced the Award.
('75', 419, 5, 18, 834119) I believe I have opened a new page in the history of Rajkot by my repentance and by the frank admission of my failure.
('75', 419, 5, 19, 834238) In this I require your help.
('75', 419, 5, 20, 834267) I cannot go on single handed.
('75', 419, 5, 21, 834297) If the ruler and the ruled both join hands and do their duty, this apparent failure would turn into a victory.
('75', 419, 5, 22, 834408) This necessitates unity among the people.
('75', 419, 5, 23, 834450) Unity is the root of strength and progress.
('75', 419, 5, 24, 834494) The Parishad must embrace and convert every section of the people.
('75', 419, 5, 25, 834561) Some may not join hands with the Parishad owing to their weakness and others due to differences of opinion, even then they are with us.
('75', 419, 5, 26, 834697) I want the Parishad people to realize the implications of ahimsa.
('75', 419, 5, 27, 834763) Ahimsa trusts the opponent, ahimsa does not attribute motives, it harbours no evil thoughts as I did in the case of Durbar Shri Virawala.
('75', 419, 5, 28, 834901) Whether he really answered to the description that was being given of him or not, was beside the point.
('75', 419, 5, 29, 835005) I shamed my ahimsa by suspecting him; whereas if I wanted to convert him, my love for him should have

('75', 432, 6, 14, 855498) 498. TO PARSI FRIENDS
('75', 432, 7, 15, 855520) Parsi friends continue to favour me with their letters, some of which do not err on the side of politeness.
('75', 432, 7, 16, 855628) Some are affectionate and so simple that they believe me to be capable of performing wonders.
('75', 432, 7, 17, 855722) Among these writers there is one who writes with a lacerated heart and sends me cuttings which contain palpable falsehoods.
('75', 432, 7, 18, 855846) He asks me to appeal to the Parsis with a view, at least to purging the opposition of indecency.
('75', 432, 7, 19, 855943) The language used in the cuttings is not translatable.
('75', 432, 7, 20, 855998) The families of those who have incurred their ill will have not been left alone.
('75', 432, 7, 21, 856079) Vulgarity is too mild a term for characterizing some of the writings.
('75', 432, 7, 22, 856149) One writer uses language of violence which certainly brings him within penal laws.
('75', 432, 7, 23, 856232) But the writers have no fear of the law.
('75', 432, 7, 24, 856273) The writings before me are in fair sample of ‘civil’ liberty.
('75', 432, 7, 25, 856335) I call these writings terrorism of minorities.
('75', 432, 7, 26, 856382) One writer has given the prohibition campaign of communal turn and has not hesitated to say that Congress Hindus have plotted to ruin the Parsis !
('75', 432, 7, 27, 856529) Surely abuse is no argument.
('75', 432, 7, 28, 856558) Let the Parsis who are interested opposing prohibition carry on whatever agitation they like.
('75', 432, 7, 29, 856652) But let it be decent, non violent and within bounds.
('75', 432, 7, 30, 856705) Must one hundred thousand Parsis hold up an overdue reform which promises to bring a ray of hope in the dungeons of the labouring population which far outnumbers the whole of the Parsi
('75', 432, 8, 31, 856890) 1 Daughters of Jaisukhlal Gandhi, a nephew of Gandhiji
('75', 433, 0, 1, 856945) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 433, 1, 2, 856987) population?
('75', 433, 1, 3, 856999) Every legitimate ground of complaint has been removed by Dr. Gilder.
('75', 433, 1, 4, 857068) No Parsi whose health requires the use of spirituous liquors will be deprived of them.
('75', 433, 1, 5, 857155) If Parsi religious rites really demand the use of the fiery liquid, they shall be supplied.
('75', 433, 1, 6, 857247) Then there is the economic question.
('75', 433, 1, 7, 857284) Many poor liquor dealers will be hard hit by the deprivation of their means of livelihood.
('75', 433, 1, 8, 857375) I understand that the Ministers are taxing themselves to devise some legitimate method of dealing with them.
('75', 433, 1, 9, 857484) But it will surely be very difficult, if not impossible, for them to do anything, if the wild ferment is kept up and terrorism short of physical violence is applied.
('75', 433, 1, 10, 857650) Not that the Ministers should not do justice because of terrorism, but it incapacitates them for taking effective action.
('75', 433, 1, 11, 857772) For instance, it is necessary for the heads of the Parsi Panchayat to confer with the Ministers and in consultation with them think out a plan whereby prohibition in Bombay can be inaugurated with the least possible hardship.This can be done only if all parties recognize that prohibition has come to stay.
('75', 433, 1, 12, 858079) My correspondents have asked me to use my influence with the Ministers for withdrawing their measure.
('75', 433, 1, 13, 858181) They should know that I have my limitations.
('75', 433, 1, 14, 858226) If I have any influence, it is due to my never crossing the boundary line.
('75', 433, 1, 15, 858301) Let all concerned know that I have never interfered with the Congress Ministers although many of them have been and are my valued co workers.
('75', 433, 1, 16, 858443) Having withdrawn from the Congress, it would ill become me to interfere with their work.
('75', 433, 1, 17, 858532) The very purpose of my withdrawal would be defeated.
('75', 433, 1, 18, 858585) What is more, I am most interested in prohibition.
('75', 433, 1, 19, 858636) No one in India perhaps knows its beneficial effect as well as I do and therefore no one feels its necessity as keenly as I do.
('75', 433, 1, 20, 858764) I have seen with my own eyes people otherwise sane lying in the gutter.
('75', 433, 1, 21, 858836) Having indentified myself with labour, I know what ruin drink has brought to the homes of labourers given to drink.
('75', 433, 1, 22, 858952) I know that they will not touch liquor if it was not within reach.
('75', 433, 1, 23, 859019) We have contemporaneous evidence that drinkers themselves are in many cases asking for prohibition.
('75', 433, 1, 24, 859119) Have I not my eldest son who was intelligent, brave, patriotic and capable of sacrifice, and who has been ruined by the drink habit and who is today lost to his parents and lost to society and exists on the misplaced charity of generous donors?
('75', 433, 1, 25, 859364) This is not an exception.
('75', 433, 1, 26, 859390) It is a typical case, as I can say from a knowledge of sons of persons in the so called higher walks of life.
('75', 433, 1, 27, 859500) As I write these lines, illustrations of unimpeachable authenticity crowd on my memory.
('75', 433, 1, 28, 859588) I can therefore only ask my Parsi correspondents and others like them in return to help the Ministers in their noble and
('75', 434, 0, 1, 859709) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 435
('75', 434, 1, 2, 859753) philanthropic mission; for I feel convinced that whatever may be said for or against Congress Ministers about their popular measures, their prohibition programme, if they are able to put it through to the end, will go down to posterity as unquestionably the noblest measure of all.
('75', 434, 1, 3, 860035) It is no vote catching device.
('75', 434, 1, 4, 860066) Prohibition is an integral part of the programme of national self purification.
('75', 434, 1, 5, 860146) Twice has it been demon strated what was possible in the shape of closing of liquor shops even through voluntary efrort.
('75', 434, 1, 6, 860267) Let the great Parsi community, men and women, discarding the unbecoming vituperation, rise to the occasion and help the great reform movement which, if it succeeds, will not only enrich India morally and materially but will serve as an impetus to similar effort in the Western world.
('75', 434, 1, 7, 860551) Many eyes outside India are watching this experiment anxiously and prayerfully.
('75', 434, 1, 8, 860631) I grant that many Parsis drink moderately and without any visible bad effect.
('75', 434, 1, 9, 860709) That is an argument not for opposing prohibition but for ensuring that they get their drink if it is proved to be a medical necessity.
('75', 434, 1, 10, 860844) They should be patriotic enough to recognize that as against their limited experience is the universal exprience of the deadly effect of the drink habit.
('75', 434, 2, 11, 860998) RAJKOT, May 30, 1939 Harijan, 3 6 1939

('75', 435, 3, 4, 861103) COLD BLOODED BREACH OF A SOLEMN COVENANT
('75', 435, 4, 5, 861144) Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel issued the following statement on January 25th:
('75', 435, 5, 6, 861217) It is with the deepest regret that I have to announce resumption of the struggle in Rajkot which seemed to have ended so happily.
('75', 435, 5, 7, 861347) Resumption has become a duty in order to vindicate the honour of the State and the self respect of the people of Rajkot.
('75', 435, 6, 8, 861468) The public will recall that the settlement announced in the Rajkot State Gazette of 26th December was a result of discussions between the Thakore Saheb and his Council consisting of Sir Patrick Cadell, Rao Saheb Maneklal Patel and Shri J. Jobanputra.
('75', 435, 6, 9, 861719) The discussions which took place on the evening of December 25th lasted for nearly eight hours ending at 1.42 a.m.
('75', 435, 6, 10, 861834) On the day of the settlement the Thakore Saheb gave me the following note:
('75', 435, 7, 11, 861909) AMARSINHJI SECRETARIAT, RAJKOT STATE, December 26, 1938
('75', 435, 8, 12, 861965) It is agreed that seven members of the Committee mentioned in Clause 2 of the State announcement of today’s date are to be recommended by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and they are to be nominated by us.
('75', 435, 9, 13, 862164) (Sd.) DHARMENDRASINH
('75', 435, 10, 14, 862185) THAKORE SAHEB, RAJKOT
('75', 435, 11, 15, 862207) It should be remembered that I had gone to Rajkot at the Thakore Saheb’s invitation.
('75', 435, 12, 16, 862292) Soon after the settlement Sir Patrick Cadell retired....
('75', 435, 13, 17, 862349) I must state with the greatest reluctance that the Thakore Saheb has been ill served by those who have eaten his salt.
('75', 435, 13, 18, 862468) Among the worst of these advisers has been Durbar Virawala who has ruined the State and drained it empty by his hopeless mismanagement.
('75', 435, 13, 19, 862604) He has cast a spell over the Thakore Saheb which the latter cannot resist even if he would.
('75', 435, 13, 20, 862696) It was he who brought Sir Patrick Cadell.
('75', 435, 13, 21, 862738) When the latter realized that Durbar Virawala was the evil genius of the State, almost his first act was to have him banished from Rajkot with the help of the Agency.
('75', 435, 13, 22, 862905) Sir Patrick Cadell might not have been obliged to leave if he had not traded upon his prestige as a member of the ruling race.
('75', 435, 13, 23, 863032) Durbar Virawala would not brook the presence of a Dewan who had brought about his banishment.
('75', 435, 14, 24, 863126) 1Vide “Speech at Meeting of Peasants”, 29 1 1939
('75', 436, 0, 1, 863175) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 437
('75', 436, 1, 2, 863219) Though he was banished he pulled the wires from Bagasra.
('75', 436, 1, 3, 863276) His son Bhojvala and his nephew Valeravala are still with the Thakore Saheb.
('75', 436, 1, 4, 863353) Realizing that he could not successfully resist the contemplated settlement, he played the role of a friend and seemed to assist the settlement.
('75', 436, 1, 5, 863498) Soon after the settlement, when Sir Patrick Cadell was about to go, Durbar Virawala found himself in Rajkot and began his operations which have never ceased.
('75', 436, 1, 6, 863656) The Resident’s note and the Political Agent’s note will be read with interest.
('75', 436, 2, 7, 863735) I needed a few days to enable me to select, in consultation with those who were in charge of the movement, seven names of the committee that had to be given in terms of the settlement.
('75', 436, 2, 8, 863920) I sent the following seven names on the 4th January:
('75', 436, 3, 9, 863973) 1. Shri Popatlal Dhanjibhai Malaviya
('75', 436, 4, 10, 864010) 2. Shri Popatlal Purushottam Anada
('75', 436, 5, 11, 864045) 3. Shri Mullan Valiji Abdulalli
('75', 436, 6, 12, 864077) 4. Dr. D. J. Gajjar
('75', 436, 7, 13, 864097) 5. Shri Jamnadas Khushalchand Gandhi
('75', 436, 8, 14, 864134) 6. Shri Vrajlal Mayashanker Shukla
('75', 436, 9, 15, 864169) 7. Shri Uchharangray Navalshanker Dhebar
('75', 436, 10, 16, 864210) Notification of the appointment of the committee should have followed at once.
('75', 436, 10, 17, 864289) But nothing happened for some days.
('75', 436, 11, 18, 864325) On the 28th December there was a consultation between the Resident and the Thakore Saheb in Council.
('75', 436, 11, 19, 864426) I have authentic notes of that interview taken by one of those present.
('75', 436, 11, 20, 864498) The remarks made by the Resident about the Congress and me will be read with interest.
('75', 436, 11, 21, 864585) He could not conceal his dislike of the settlement, the Congress or me.
('75', 436, 12, 22, 864657) It seems that the Resident and Durbar Virawala are responsible for the breach of the solemn undertaking the Thakore Saheb gave to his people As evidence of Durbar Virawala’s influence over the Thakore Saheb, the letter of thanks received by me from him makes interesting reading.
('75', 436, 13, 23, 864937) It is necessary to compare the present one sided arbitrary notification with the one which was issued in terms of the settlement.
('75', 436, 13, 24, 865067) The second notification cancels four of my nominees.
('75', 436, 13, 25, 865120) It also cancels the terms of reference and is vague, whereas the first was precise.
('75', 436, 13, 26, 865204) The former contemplates publication of the report before the 31st instant and effect being given to it by the Thakore Saheb.
('75', 436, 13, 27, 865329) The latter fixes no time limit for the report.
('75', 436, 14, 28, 865376) Before the last announcement I received a letter from Rao Saheb Maneklal Patel.
('75', 436, 14, 29, 865456) It is noteworthy that whereas that letter had accepted four of my nominees the notification has only three.
('75', 436, 14, 30, 865564) To this I sent a reply in Gujarati of which the translation will be found.
('75', 437, 0, 1, 865639) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 437, 1, 2, 865681) I had heard so much of Durbar Virawala’s influence on the Thakore Saheb and his interference that I had to say in my said letter that Durbar Virawala could not in any event be accepted on the committee.
('75', 437, 1, 3, 865884) I wanted no loophole left.
('75', 437, 2, 4, 865911) This flagrant breach of a solemn settlement leaves but one course open before the people of Rajkot.
('75', 437, 2, 5, 866011) It now remains for me to invite the people of Rajkot to resume the self chosen course of suffering for vindicating their liberty and saving Rajkot and the Thakore Saheb from utter ruin.
('75', 437, 2, 6, 866197) It is best to anticipate and provide for the worst.
('75', 437, 2, 7, 866249) The worst that can happen is frightfulness of the extreme type, including torture not unknown in Kathiawar and setting up of internal quarrels.
('75', 437, 2, 8, 866393) Of the latter we have evidence in inspired agitation from some Muslim brethren.
('75', 437, 2, 9, 866473) We have to show them by our conduct that they have at least as much to gain as the rest of us by settled government under their own control.
('75', 437, 2, 10, 866614) Rajkot has been made bankrupt through hopeless mismanagement and corruption.
('75', 437, 2, 11, 866691) These dissensions, if they persist, can prolong the struggle, never defeat the end in view, if the people at large cohere, show capacity for enduring suffering, no matter how great or protracted, and also show capacity, in spite of pecuniary losses, for going through the items of non violent non co operation.
('75', 437, 2, 12, 867002) On no account must students take part in civil disobedience or strikes.
('75', 437, 2, 13, 867074) They can and should do constructive work if they believe in it.
('75', 437, 2, 14, 867138) They can by house to house visits alleviate suffering which is bound to be inevitable as the struggle proceeds.
('75', 437, 3, 15, 867250) Non violence has to be observed in thought, word and deed.
('75', 437, 3, 16, 867309) It has to be observed as well among co workers as with opponents and neutrals, as well in the jail as outside it.
('75', 437, 3, 17, 867423) The measure of our non violence will be the measure of our success.
('75', 437, 3, 18, 867491) We must have faith in the possibility of our non violence turning the Thakore Saheb’s face in the direction of his people.
('75', 437, 3, 19, 867614) Today he is a Ruler in name only; it must hurt every one of his people to find the young Prince committing a deliberate breach of the solemn covenant he made with his people.
('75', 437, 4, 20, 867789) I have said seemingly bitter things about Durbar Virawala.
('75', 437, 4, 21, 867848) But truth has to be sometimes bitter and harsh.
('75', 437, 4, 22, 867896) I have said nothing that I do not believe about him.
('75', 437, 4, 23, 867949) We must love him in spite of his glaring blemishes and expect our love to convert him and those who are working under his influence and direction.
('75', 437, 5, 24, 868096) I am sorry the Resident resents my intervention and the influence of the Congress in shaping the policy and programme of the people of Rajkot.
('75', 437, 5, 25, 868239) The people of the States have always been guided by the Congress.
('75', 437, 5, 26, 868305) They owe allegiance to it.
('75', 437, 5, 27, 868332) Indeed in the early stages the Princes also looked to the Congress for its support.
('75', 437, 5, 28, 868416) The Congress adopted the policy of non intervention in the sense of direct participation in the matters affecting questions arising between the people and the Princes.
('75', 437, 5, 29, 868584) This was nothing but recognition of the limitations of the Congress.
('75', 437, 5, 30, 868653) But when the people became conscious of their strength and were prepared to suffer, the Congress would be
('75', 438, 0, 1, 868759) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 439
('75', 438, 1, 2, 868803) untrue to its mission if it failed to help them to the best of its ability.
('75', 438, 1, 3, 868879) As for poor me I happen to have been a President of the Kathiawar Rajkiya Parishad and as such owe a duty to the people of Kathiawar as also to the Princes and dare not refuse help when they need it.
('75', 438, 1, 4, 869079) In Rajkot the people in the first instance and then the Ruler sought my assistance which I claim has been unstintingly given.
('75', 438, 1, 5, 869205) I fail to see anything wrong in this or to be resented by the Resident or the Imperial Power.
('75', 438, 1, 6, 869299) This is a question which it would incidentally be Rajkot’s proud privilege to be the cause of having decided.
('75', 438, 2, 7, 869409) For the time being the civil resistance will be confined to Kathiawaris only.
('75', 438, 2, 8, 869487) The people of Kathiawar are so inter related that for practical purposes it would be difficult to exclude any Kathiawari from participation on moral grounds.

('75', 439, 0, 1, 870615) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('75', 439, 1, 4, 870806) I cannot allow it to be continued.
('75', 439, 2, 5, 870841) I had intended to tell you last night that in any case the present situation cannot go on.
('75', 439, 2, 6, 870932) The condition of affairs in the State is very serious.
('75', 439, 2, 7, 870987) Many of the complaints against the State are based on your behaviour.
('75', 439, 2, 8, 871057) It is believed that you spend too large a share of the State’s revenue, that most of your expenditure is on unworthy objects, and that you take no part in the administration of the State.

('75', 439, 2, 10, 871358) But it is certainly true that you take no part in the administration and show no interest in the welfare of your people.
('75', 439, 2, 11, 871479) This is all the more noticed because it is so different from the system which your father followed.
('75', 439, 2, 12, 871579) It is not fair to your officers to expect them to bear the burden of repressive methods while you do nothing.

('75', 439, 13, 28, 872497) and you will promise on your word of honour not to be

('75', 440, 5, 6, 873327) LETTER FROM THAKORE SAHEB TO SIR PATRICK CADELL
('75', 440, 6, 7, 873375) Confidential RANJIT VILAS PALACE,
('75', 440, 7, 8, 873409) RAJKOT, October 2, 1938
('75', 440, 8, 9, 873433) DEAR SIR PATRICK,
('75', 440, 9, 10, 873451) I am exceedingly sorry to receive your letter of yesterday, and I must say that I do not like the tone of it.
('75', 440, 9, 11, 873561) I cannot accept that the complaints against me are based on facts.
('75', 440, 9, 12, 873628) The present agitation is only a wave spread by the Congress for the initiation of responsible government in the States, and I believe that to be the reason why they have selected Rajkot in Kathiawar, as they have done with Mysore, Travancore, etc., as States in which people already enjoy greater share of public liberties.
('75', 440, 10, 13, 873952) It was with a view to put down the situation that I had requisitioned your services I have still a wish to smoothen your task as much as possible and will come to the office any day at my convenience after Dasera.
('75', 440, 11, 14, 874166) I strongly object to your remarks that if you have to go it may have unfortunate consequences both for my State and myself, and that the Government of India are not likely to look with favour on my conduct.
('75', 440, 11, 15, 874373) In this connection I must definitely let you understand that it is I who has appointed you as my Dewan, and that if as a result of any disagreement with you I have to ask you to be relieved, neither the Hon.
('75', 440, 11, 16, 874581) the Resident nor H. E. the Viceroy will have any cause to look upon me with disfavour.
('75', 440, 11, 17, 874668) Whatever information you may be able to gather with regard to my State and myself is made available to you because you enjoy my confidence, and I need hardly say that you cannot utilize any of my State records without my permission, and much less against myself.
('75', 440, 11, 18, 874931) Any information which the Hon.
('75', 440, 11, 19, 874962) the Resident has thought it necessary to receive about anything relating to my State has been sought for through my Dewan, only if I am agreeable to give it.
('75', 440, 11, 20, 875120) I might also tell you that I have done nothing to lose any share of the confidence which I enjoy both with the Hon.
('75', 440, 11, 21, 875236) the Resident and H. E. the Viceroy to its fullest extent.
('75', 440, 11, 22, 875294) I would therefore wish you to reconsider your decision and express your agreement to act in a manner consonant with my dignity and policy.
('75', 440, 12, 23, 875433) Yours sincerely,
('75', 440, 13, 24, 875450) DHARMENDRASINH

('75', 441, 1, 2, 875507) LETTER FROM THAKORE SAHEB TO SIR PATRICK CADELL
('75', 441, 2, 3, 875555) RAJKOT,
('75', 441, 3, 4, 875563) October 16, 1938
('75', 441, 4, 5, 875580) DEAR SIR PATRICK,
('75', 441, 5, 6, 875598) You are, I am sure, fully aware of the present situation.
('75', 441, 5, 7, 875656) It has not been improved in any way and so far as I can see it is getting worse every day and has reached a climax by now.
('75', 441, 5, 8, 875779) The other day when we called a meeting we agreed to give the people certain concessions, but it failed to ease the situation and bring about any desired result.
('75', 441, 5, 9, 875940) I am myself getting convinced that we failed to take proper steps at the proper time, which should have removed my anxiety.
('75', 441, 5, 10, 876064) The situation, in short, is decidedly getting out of control and adding immensely to my troubles.
('75', 441, 5, 11, 876162) The agitation is getting more and more intense with little hope of its being brought under control in the near future.
('75', 441, 5, 12, 876281) My people feel and are led to believe that you have been sent by the Government and that I have lost the position which I had hitherto enjoyed.
('75', 441, 5, 13, 876425) They now refuse to extend to me the same love and loyalty which they used to extend before your arrival.
('75', 441, 5, 14, 876530) Nay they even seem to think and carry the impression that not I but you are the Ruler.
('75', 441, 6, 15, 876617) I should say that though this feeling is not created by you but I must say that anyway it is there which they are not in a mood to shake off obviously.
('75', 441, 6, 16, 876769) Diwali holidays are drawing nearer and Ijaras must as usual be given but the people have boycotted them.
('75', 441, 6, 17, 876874) They are further determined to boycott sales of grain also, and it is possible that no sale of grain could be made this year due to their non co operation.
('75', 441, 6, 18, 877030) This would mean a financial ruination of the State and a crisis which had better be imagined than stated.
('75', 441, 6, 19, 877136) This state of things, I feel, I, as the Ruler, am bound to prevent at any cost or sacrifice in the interests of the State and its subjects.
('75', 441, 7, 20, 877276) The people, as you know, have now adopted a defiant attitude and are suffering.
('75', 441, 7, 21, 877356) I must, therefore, see that this unfortunate situation must be thoroughly eased and some sort of definite settlement should be arrived at between them and me at the earliest possible opportunity.
('75', 441, 7, 22, 877552) I feel I am unable to do anything in this matter so long as my people do not recognize me as their de facto Ruler.
('75', 441, 7, 23, 877667) As a well wisher of the State you would also wish and agree that such state of things should not be permitted to continue any more.
('75', 441, 7, 24, 877799) It is therefore my bounden duty to see that I must have my position as the real and benevolent Ruler re established in the eyes of my people, in order that I may be able to carry conviction and settle with them and win their love and confidence.
('75', 441, 8, 25, 878045) I had asked D. S. Virawala to know your views in this matter.
('75', 441, 8, 26, 878107) He tells me that he saw you on the 13th instant and you told him that in your view the fight should be
('75', 442, 0, 1, 878210) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 443
('75', 442, 1, 2, 878254) continued as long as the State’s finances would permit and we should see whether they or we would ultimately win.
('75', 442, 2, 3, 878368) Besides, your letter dated 1st October 1938 gives me to understand that in so far as you are concerned you are definitely of the view that I am myself, more or less, the cause of these troubles.
('75', 442, 2, 4, 878563) I have denied the charges by my reply.
('75', 442, 2, 5, 878602) Considering the allegations made in your letter and your attitude, I have little doubt in my mind that we would not be able to pull on together in the interests of my State and its subjects and also my rights, dignity and position of the Ruler, as nobody realizes the extremely disastrous situation more than I do.
('75', 442, 3, 6, 878917) It is my definite desire to myself settle the domestic dispute between my State and its subjects as early as possible and before the Diwali holidays.
('75', 442, 3, 7, 879067) This would not, in my view, be possible unless we part at the earliest.
('75', 442, 3, 8, 879139) This is a very unfortunate position and no one would be more sorry than myself, but it could not be helped as the interests of myself and my State are at stake.
('75', 442, 3, 9, 879300) I need hardly assure you that it is not my desire to make your position awkward in any way, and hence I leave it to you to decide how you should arrange to leave and retire, as I am anxious to see that just as you came as a friend you should also part as a friend.
('75', 442, 3, 10, 879565) I had engaged your services for six months certain and hence I am instructing the State Treasury to pay your salary accordingly.
('75', 442, 3, 11, 879694) I am also instructing Mr. Bhat, the Revenue Secretary, to relieve you at your convenience.
('75', 442, 4, 12, 879785) Yours sincerely,
('75', 442, 5, 13, 879802) DHARMENDRASINH

('75', 443, 11, 15, 882136) I am very anxious that proper steps should be taken as soon as possible and have decided to form a strong council consisting of Sir Patrick Cadell and two of my officers to carry on the State, so that peace and tranquillity and respect for law is properly maintained.
