('75', 448, 1, 2, 889873) LETTER FROM MANEKLAL PATEL TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('75', 448, 2, 3, 889921) Confidential RANJIT VILAS,
('75', 448, 3, 4, 889948) RAJKOT,
('75', 448, 4, 5, 889956) January 12, 1939
('75', 448, 5, 6, 889973) DEAR SARDAR SAHEB,
('75', 448, 6, 7, 889992) I am desired by H. H. Thakore Saheb to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, recommending the seven names to be nominated by him to the proposed Reforms Committee.
('75', 448, 7, 8, 890173) You must have learnt from the newspapers that the names suggested by you were already out by the time your letter was received by His Highness, He regrets that it should have been so, because such an exposure places you and His Highness in somewhat awkward position.
('75', 448, 8, 9, 890440) While H. H. would very much wish to select all the names suggested by you, you would also appreciate that he cannot ignore the requests made by important classes of his subjects, and should see that the committee consists of such persons as would command the confidence of all important groups of his subjects.
('75', 448, 8, 10, 890751) In fact, His Highness has received representations from the Bhayats and Muslim Council and a petition from the Depressed Class, and has therefore desired me to write to you as under.
('75', 448, 9, 11, 890934) While here, you very rightly said to H. H. that you did not know who the real leaders were and therefore postponed suggesting names until after you had consulted others.
('75', 448, 10, 12, 891104) His Highness approves of the gentlemen numbered 1, 2, 4 and 5.
('75', 448, 11, 13, 891167) While number three owns immovable property and resides here since about 40 years and is a respectable citizen, he could hardly be expected to be useful with independent opinion to work on a committee of this nature.
('75', 448, 12, 14, 891383) You would agree that the Mahomedans form a very important unit and are now too well organized to be ignored so lightly.
('75', 448, 12, 15, 891503) In their representation submitted as a result of the unanimous resolution of the Muslim Council, they have requested that three out of seven should be Mahomedans.
('75', 448, 12, 16, 891666) This demand of theirs is of course unreasonable, but including the Bohras they should be given two seats and the President of their Council should be one of them.
('75', 448, 12, 17, 891829) In view of your vast experience in British India, you will appreciate that if their legitimate request were not met, they may make a row and may create unhealthy atmosphere, which we all wish to avoid.
('75', 448, 12, 18, 892031) There is no doubt that we all want a committee which would represent all sections of
('75', 449, 0, 1, 892116) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 449, 1, 2, 892158) the people, be impartial and work harmoniously and with sagacity.
('75', 449, 2, 3, 892224) As regards numbers six and seven, it appears that they would not come strictly within the scope of the definition of the “subject” as referred to in the notification.
('75', 449, 3, 4, 892391) Mr. V. M. Shukla was neither born in the State nor has he been staying within the jurisdiction of the State since his birth for as many as about forty years.
('75', 449, 3, 5, 892549) Possession by his ancestors of some property in Sardhar Pati does not entitle him, according to the definition, to be considered as a Rajkot State subject.
('75', 449, 3, 6, 892705) He is neither born, nor domiciled, nor naturalized in the State.
('75', 449, 4, 7, 892770) As regards Mr. U. N. Dhebar, His Highness feels that the same objection would come in the way.
('75', 449, 4, 8, 892865) As is understood, he originally belongs to the Jamnagar State and his father spent the major portion of his life in Bombay.
('75', 449, 4, 9, 892989) He himself is said to have received his schooling in Rajkot and was residing in the Civil Station when he started practice as a pleader.
('75', 449, 4, 10, 893126) He has been living within the State limits since about two years.
('75', 449, 4, 11, 893192) He has also purchased land in the State last year.
('75', 449, 4, 12, 893243) His Highness feels that he should restrict his nomination to the definition, so as not to create any ill feeling amongst other leading gentlemen, who have always been recognized by the State, since the time of the late Thakore Saheb, as leaders of the public.
('75', 449, 5, 13, 893503) It may also be brought to your notice that the Bhayats have also approached His Highness, and very rightly,with a request that at least one of them should be on the committee, as they represent a very important and considerable unit in the State.
('75', 449, 5, 14, 893750) His Highness therefore considers it essential that one of them should be on the committee.
('75', 449, 6, 15, 893841) It is His Highness’s wish, as you will readily understand, that the committee should consist of the best brains who would also be representative of all important classes of his subjects.
('75', 449, 7, 16, 894028) If any suggestions are to be made in the light of what has been said above, His Highness will then declare the personnel of the committee, inclusive of three officials besides the President of the committee.
('75', 449, 8, 17, 894236) Yours sincerely,
('75', 449, 9, 18, 894253) M. C. PATEL
('75', 449, 10, 19, 894265) LETTER FROM VALLABHBHAI PATEL TO MANEKLAL PATEL
('75', 449, 11, 20, 894313) CAMP, BARDOLI, January 15, 1939
('75', 449, 12, 21, 894345) DEAR SHRI MANEKLAL PATEL,
('75', 449, 13, 22, 894371) I have your letter of the 12th instant.
('75', 449, 13, 23, 894411) It has pained me.
('75', 449, 13, 24, 894429) It is indeed regrettable that the names I proposed were published, but it is not always possible to keep
('75', 450, 0, 1, 894534) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 451
('75', 450, 1, 2, 894578) anything private in which a number of persons are concerned.
('75', 450, 1, 3, 894639) And then in spite of publication, alteration can certainly be made therein if there are valid reasons.
('75', 450, 2, 4, 894742) I am afraid I cannot accept your recommendation regarding the names of Bhayats and Mussalmans on the committee.
('75', 450, 2, 5, 894854) There was a definite intelligible object behind the settlement entitling me to suggest the names.
('75', 450, 2, 6, 894952) That object would be frustrated if I were to accept your recommendation.
('75', 450, 2, 7, 895025) The names have been suggested to achieve the object which can be fulfilled only by having on the committee men of integrity holding particular views.
('75', 450, 2, 8, 895175) The seven members whose names I have suggested will surely bear in mind the interests of Bhayats and others.
('75', 450, 2, 9, 895284) More than this may not be expected.
('75', 450, 3, 10, 895320) I regret you have seen fit to object to certain names on the ground of their not being State subjects.
('75', 450, 3, 11, 895423) But you have a right to do so; If on further consideration you should adhere to the view that Shri Dhebazbhai does not come within the definition, rather than argue with you I am prepared to withdraw his name and to suggest instead the name of Shri Gajanan Joshi Vakil.
('75', 450, 3, 12, 895693) I maintain that Shri Vajubhai Shukla comes within the definition.
('75', 450, 4, 13, 895759) H. H. the Thakore Saheb’s notification can only mean that the chairman of the committee had to be from the committee of ten, and I must say that Darbar Virawala may not be appointed chairman.
('75', 450, 4, 14, 895951) He has sent me word that he does not intend to hold any office, but in order to avoid any possible accident I have thought it proper to mention this.
('75', 450, 5, 15, 896101) I cannot help saying that the appointment of the committee has been greatly delayed.
('75', 450, 5, 16, 896186) Their report has got to be published by the 31st January.
('75', 450, 5, 17, 896244) I therefore hope that the committee will be appointed immediately on receipt of this letter.
('75', 450, 5, 18, 896337) If unfortunately the appointment continues to be delayed, there is every fear of the struggle being resumed by the people.
('75', 450, 5, 19, 896460) I must also add that I have in my possession copies of correspondence that has taken place between H. H. the Thakore Saheb and Sir Patrick Cadell, and of the summary of an interview with the Resident.
('75', 450, 5, 20, 896661) If the settlement breaks down, I am afraid it will be my duty to publish, in public interest, these and other documents in my possession.
('75', 450, 5, 21, 896799) But I hope I may have to do nothing of the kind, and the committee will be appointed and begin work immediately.
('75', 450, 6, 22, 896912) May I expect a wire from you in reply?
('75', 450, 6, 23, 896951) Yours sincerely, VALLABHBHAI PATEL

('75', 451, 0, 1, 897004) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 451, 1, 2, 897046) APPENDIX II
('75', 451, 2, 3, 897058) GOVERNMENT OF INDIA’S STATEMENT ON RAJKOT1
('75', 451, 3, 4, 897101) NEW DELHI,
('75', 451, 4, 5, 897112) February 1, 1939
('75', 451, 5, 6, 897129) 1. Attention has been drawn to Mr. Gandhi’s statement to the Press in regard to the recent events in the Rajkot and Jaipur States.
('75', 451, 6, 7, 897260) 2. In the case of Rajkot, Mr. Gandhi states that “an honourable understanding arrived at between the Thakore Saheb in Council and Sardar Patel, representing the people, has been undone by the Resident”, and he expresses the opinion that “it is the duty of the Viceroy to ask the Resident in Rajkot to restore the pact.”
('75', 451, 7, 8, 897580) 3. The facts are that the Thakore Saheb in Council reached an agreement with Sardar Patel that a committee should be appointed to investigate and make recommendations for constitutional reform.
('75', 451, 7, 9, 897774) The terms of this agreement were published on December 26, in the State Gazette.
('75', 451, 7, 10, 897855) The number of official and non official members who were to serve on the committee were stated in this announcement.
('75', 451, 7, 11, 897972) No further indication was given as to the committee’s composition or the basis of its selection.
('75', 451, 7, 12, 898069) It appears that simultaneously a private exchange of letters took place between the Thakore Saheb personally and Sardar Patel, to which no publicity was given.
('75', 451, 7, 13, 898229) In this correspondence, the Thakore Saheb wrote to Sardar Patel as follows:
('75', 451, 8, 14, 898305) AMARSINHJI SECRETARIAT,
('75', 451, 9, 15, 898329) RAJKOT STATE,
('75', 451, 10, 16, 898343) 26 12 ‘38
('75', 451, 11, 17, 898353) It is agreed that seven members of the Committee mentioned in Clause 2 of the State Announcement of today’s date are to be recommended by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and they are to be nominated by us.
('75', 451, 12, 18, 898552) (Sd.) DHARMENDRASINH,
('75', 451, 13, 19, 898574) Thakore Saheb, Rajkot
('75', 451, 14, 20, 898596) The Thakore Saheb claims that this letter was intended to leave him at liberty to accept or not the names put forward by Sardar Patel.
('75', 451, 14, 21, 898731) Sardar Patel contends that its intention was to bind the Thakore Saheb to accept whatever names he put forward.
('75', 451, 15, 22, 898843) REFORMS COMMITTEE PERSONNEL
('75', 451, 16, 23, 898871) Of the names put forward by Sardar Patel, the Thakore Saheb accepted three.
('75', 451, 17, 24, 898947) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 31 1 1939
('75', 452, 0, 1, 898989) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 453
('75', 452, 1, 2, 899033) the interests of securing adequate representation for the Mohammedans and the Bhayats in the State, both of which parties submitted their claims to be represented, he found himself unable to accept the remaining four names.
('75', 452, 1, 3, 899257) On his instructions, his Minister so informed Sardar Patel.
('75', 452, 1, 4, 899317) Sardar Patel, however, in his reply, did not address himself to the merits and refused to acquiesce in the Thakore Saheb’s proposals for the representation of the interests mentioned above, and merely intimated that he would be content with nothing less than the names which he had put forward irrespective of the considerations advanced by the Thakore Saheb, in acting as he has acted of his own free will.
('75', 452, 1, 5, 899725) The Resident has no knowledge of the correspondence which had passed and was not a party to it.
('75', 452, 2, 6, 899821) Mr. Gandhi’s suggestion is that the Thakore Saheb should now be required to accept a different construction which Sardar Patel has placed on his letter.
('75', 452, 2, 7, 899974) It would clearly be most improper to bring pressure on the Thakore Saheb to accept a construction which he evidently did not intend and is not now prepared to accept.
('75', 452, 3, 8, 900141) Mr. Gandhi states that the Resident is reported to be resorting to “organized goondaism”.
('75', 452, 3, 9, 900231) Mr. Gandhi has not indicated the source of this report, which has no foundation whatever in fact.
('75', 452, 4, 10, 900329) In the case of Jaipur, the Jaipur Government will no doubt issue whatever statement they see fit in answer to Mr. Gandhi’s observations.

('75', 453, 16, 21, 902192) APPENDIX IV
('75', 453, 17, 22, 902204) STATEMENT OF SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE 1
('75', 453, 18, 23, 902239) I have read the statement of Mahatma Gandhi on the recent presidential election with all the attention that it deserves.
('75', 453, 18, 24, 902360) It grieves me to find that Mahatma Gandhi has taken it as a personal defeat.
('75', 453, 18, 25, 902437) I would respectfully differ from him on this point.
('75', 453, 18, 26, 902489) The voters, that is the delegates, were not called upon to vote for or against Mahatma Gandhi.
('75', 453, 18, 27, 902584) Consequently the result of the contest does not in my view and in the view of most people affect him personally.
('75', 453, 19, 28, 902697) 1Vide “Letter to Subhas Chandra Bose”, 5 2 1939
('75', 454, 0, 1, 902745) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 455
('75', 454, 1, 2, 902789) Much has been said in the Press during the last few days about the Right and Left wings in the Congress.
('75', 454, 1, 3, 902894) Several persons have interpreted the result of the election as a victory for the Leftists.
('75', 454, 1, 4, 902985) The fact is that I placed before the public two main issues, namely, the fight against Federation and free and unfettered choice for the delegates in the matter of choosing their president.
('75', 454, 1, 5, 903175) These issues must have greatly influenced the voting, and over and above these, the personality of the candidates might have had some effect.
('75', 454, 1, 6, 903317) In the circumstances, I feel that while analysing the significance of the election we should not draw on our imagination nor should we read into it more than it contains.
('75', 454, 2, 7, 903488) Assuming for argument’s sake that the result of the election implies a victory of the Left, we should stop to consider what the Leftists’ programme is.
('75', 454, 2, 8, 903640) For the immediate future the Leftists stand for national unity and unrelenting opposition to the Federal scheme.
('75', 454, 2, 9, 903753) In addition to this, they stand for democratic principles.
('75', 454, 2, 10, 903812) Leftists will not take the responsibility of creating a split within the Congress.
('75', 454, 2, 11, 903895) If a split does come, it will come not because of them, but in spite of them.
('75', 454, 3, 12, 903973) Personally I am definitely of the opinion that there is neither reason nor justification for a split within the ranks of the Congress.
('75', 454, 3, 13, 904108) I, therefore, earnestly hope that there will be no occasion now or in the near future for the so called minority party to non co operate with the so called majority party.
('75', 454, 3, 14, 904280) I need hardly add that I shall try till the last to avert a split whenever any such likelihood appears before us.
('75', 454, 4, 15, 904394) A certain amount of apprehension has been caused in the minds of many as to the policy which people like myself will follow in future.
('75', 454, 4, 16, 904529) Let me make it quite clear that there will be no violent break with the past in the parliamentary or in the extra parliamentary sphere.
('75', 454, 4, 17, 904665) So far as the parliamentary programme is concerned, we shall only try to implement our election pledges and our parliamentary programme with greater speed than in the past.
('75', 454, 4, 18, 904838) In the extra parliamentary sphere, we shall endeavour to rally all our strength and resources for combating Federation and for pushing on towards purna swaraj.
('75', 454, 4, 19, 904998) And we shall, of course, act in accordance with the principles and policy of the Indian National Congress.
('75', 454, 5, 20, 905105) In this connection I should also like to say that I have on some occasions felt constrained to differ from Mahatma Gandhi on public questions, but I yield to none in my respect for his personality.
('75', 454, 5, 21, 905303) If I have understood him correctly, he too would like to see people think for themselves, even though they may not always agree with him.
('75', 454, 5, 22, 905441) I do not know what sort of opinion Mahatmaji has of myself.
('75', 454, 5, 23, 905501) But, whatever his view may be, it will always be my aim and object to try and win his confidence for the simple reason that it will be a tragic thing for me if I succeed in winning the confidence of other people but fail to win the confidence of India’s greatest man.
('75', 454, 6, 24, 905769) The Hindustan Times, 5 2 1939
('75', 455, 0, 1, 905799) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 455, 1, 2, 905841) APPENDIX V
('75', 455, 2, 3, 905852) SRI RAMANA MAHARSHI’S COMMENTS ON GANDHIJI’S DESCRIPTION OF HIS STATE OF MIND 1
('75', 455, 3, 4, 905932) The Maharshi referred to the following passage of Gandhiji’s in the Harijan of the 11th instant:
('75', 455, 4, 5, 906029) “How mysterious are the ways of God !
('75', 455, 4, 6, 906067) This journey to Rajkot is a wonder even to me.
('75', 455, 4, 7, 906114) Why am I going, whither am I going?
('75', 455, 4, 8, 906150) What for?
('75', 455, 4, 9, 906160) I have thought nothing about these things.
('75', 455, 4, 10, 906203) And if God guides me, what should I think, why should I think?
('75', 455, 4, 11, 906266) Even thought may be an obstacle in the way of His guidance.
('75', 455, 5, 12, 906326) “The fact is, it takes no effort to stop thinking.
('75', 455, 5, 13, 906377) The thoughts do not come.
('75', 455, 5, 14, 906403) Indeed there is no vacuum—but I mean to say that there is no thought about the mission.”
('75', 455, 6, 15, 906492) He remarked how true the words were and emphasized each statement in the extract.
('75', 455, 6, 16, 906574) Then He cited Thayumanavar in support of the state which is free from thoughts:
('75', 455, 7, 17, 906654) “Bliss will reveal itself if one is still.
('75', 455, 7, 18, 906697) Why then is this illusory yoga practice ?
('75', 455, 7, 19, 906739) Can it (i.
('75', 455, 7, 20, 906750) e., bliss) be revealed by directing the intellect in a particular way?”
('75', 455, 8, 21, 906822) D. Is not what Gandhiji describes the state in which thoughts themselves become foreign?
('75', 455, 9, 22, 906911) M. Yes.
('75', 455, 9, 23, 906919) It is only after the rise of the ‘I’ thought that all other thoughts arise.
('75', 455, 9, 24, 906995) The world is seen after you have felt “I am”.
('75', 455, 9, 25, 907041) The ‘I’ thought and all other thoughts had vanished for him.
('75', 455, 10, 26, 907102) D. Then the body sense must be absent in that state.
('75', 455, 11, 27, 907155) M. The body sense also is a thought whereas he describes the state in which “thoughts do not come”.
('75', 455, 12, 28, 907255) D. He also says, “It takes no effort to stop thinking”.
('75', 455, 13, 29, 907311) M. Of course no effort is necessary to stop thought whereas one is necessary for bringing about thoughts....
('75', 455, 13, 30, 907420) D. Gandhiji adhered to Satya (Truth) so long and won realization of the Self.
('75', 455, 13, 31, 907498) M. What is Satya except the Self ?
('75', 455, 13, 32, 907533) Satya is that which is made up of sat.
('75', 455, 13, 33, 907572) Again sat is nothing but the Self.
('75', 455, 13, 34, 907607) So Gandhiji’s Satya is only the Self....
('75', 455, 13, 35, 907648) The Upanishadic Text is the eternal Truth to which everyone who has realized owes his experience.
('75', 455, 13, 36, 907746) After hearing the Self to be the Brahman the person finds the true import of the Self and reverts to it whenever he is diverted from it.
('75', 455, 13, 37, 907883) Here is the whole process of Realization.
('75', 455, 14, 38, 907925) Talks with Sri Ramana Maharshi, pp.
('75', 455, 15, 39, 907961) 1Vide “Letter to Mahadev Desai”, 27 2 1939
('75', 456, 0, 1, 908004) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 457

('75', 456, 3, 4, 908089) AMARSINHJI SECRETARIAT RAJKOT STATE March 3, 1939
('75', 456, 4, 5, 908139) MY DEAR MAHATMA GANDHIJI, I received your letter yesterday and noted the contents with greatest regret.
('75', 456, 4, 6, 908243) As you have already been assured that the Notification No.
('75', 456, 4, 7, 908302) 50 which I published on 26th December will stand good, the suggestions you make regarding personnel of the Committee are not in accordance with the terms of that Notification, and I do not feel justified in accepting them or your other suggestions.

('75', 456, 4, 9, 908782) In the best interests of my State and my people it is impossible for me to allow anyone else to have the final decision in a matter of such vital importance.
('75', 456, 4, 10, 908940) As I have previously assured, it is my earnest hope that the Committee may be able to start work in a calm atmosphere at the earliest possible moment so that there may be no delay in introducing such reforms as may be found to be necessary Yours sincerely, DHARMENDRASINH Harijan, 11 3 1939

('75', 458, 3, 10, 913808) DISCUSSION WITH AGATHA HARRISON1
('75', 458, 4, 11, 913841) March 5, 1939 I raised the question of “next steps” and asked what was being done to explore a way out of the impasse.
('75', 458, 4, 12, 913960) Since the correspondence that was passed between the parties concerned, it would appear that nothing was being done officially—the general opinion being that any move now must come from Delhi.
('75', 458, 4, 13, 914153) In answering, Gandhiji took up the question of the Sardar.
('75', 458, 4, 14, 914212) He said if there was definite proof given to him by an impartial enquiry that the Sardar had employed dishonourable means to obtain the Thakore Saheb’s consent to the agreement he would repudiate the Sardar and drop his demands.
('75', 458, 4, 15, 914441) He spoke of the character of the
('75', 458, 5, 16, 914474) 1Vide “discusstion with Agatha Harrison”.
('75', 458, 5, 17, 914516) The talk has been extracted from the notes made by Agatha Harrison.
('75', 459, 0, 1, 914584) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 459, 1, 2, 914626) Sardar and said he was not a diplomat and was often misunderstood.
('75', 459, 1, 3, 914693) We then dropped this matter and went on to the main question of the conditions that would enable him to break his fast.
('75', 459, 1, 4, 914813) I asked Gandhiji if Zetland’s statement in England and the Viceroy’s here changed the situation in any way.
('75', 459, 1, 5, 914921) If in view of these statements the Paramount Power undertook responsibility for seeing the agreement was implemented, and appointed a Committee without reference to the Present controversy on personnel, would this satisfy him?
('75', 459, 1, 6, 915148) Gandhiji said “Yes”; if the Paramount Power gave the assurance that they would see he got the constitution in terms of the December 26th Notification and selected a Committee he could accept, he would not insist on the personnel named in his letter to Thakore Saheb.
('75', 459, 1, 7, 915415) But this assurance would have to be given publicly and in writing.
('75', 459, 1, 8, 915482) Alternatively, Gandhiji suggested that he would, with a nominee of the Thakore Saheb’s choice, who was trusted and respected, undertake to draft a constitution.
('75', 459, 1, 9, 915643) If any points of difference arose they could be referred to an umpire.
('75', 459, 1, 10, 915714) I asked Gandhiji if, in the event of some move being made as above, he would drop the point he made in his letter to Gibson yesterday for the removal of Virawala.
('75', 459, 1, 11, 915877) He replied this was possible, if the Paramount Power made itself hostage, not only for the production of the constitution in terms of the December 26th agreement, but also that the recommendations of the Committee would be carried out in full.

('75', 459, 3, 14, 916185) LETTER FROM S. SATYAMURTI TO MAHADEV DESAI 1
('75', 459, 4, 15, 916230) NEW DELHI, March 20, 1939
('75', 459, 5, 16, 916256) MY DEAR MAHADEO, I told Mahatmaji that I would send him a note on the amendments to the Congress constitution.
('75', 459, 5, 17, 916367) I am sending that note herewith.
('75', 459, 5, 18, 916400) I also want that, on the lines we discussed this matter when we last met at Birla House, you should place before Mahatmaji my views on the urgent and important need of the anti Hindustani agitation in Madras being met by the Government of Madras.
('75', 459, 5, 19, 916647) I recognize that the agitation is factitious, is unreal in the sense in which it is fighting for something which it need not fight for and is being exploited by unscrupulous persons against the Ministry.
('75', 459, 5, 20, 916851) At the same time, I am of the opinion, which you expressed in the columns of the Harijan, that from the point of view of truth and non violence compulsion in
('75', 459, 6, 21, 917009) 1Vide “Letter to Jawahralal Nehru”, 20 3 193
('75', 460, 0, 1, 917054) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 461
('75', 460, 1, 2, 917098) any matter of this kind might well be postponed for the present, and till public opinion is more universally in favour of it.
('75', 460, 1, 3, 917224) If a conscience clause were granted, I am sure that not more than ten percent will take advantage of it, and only in some districts, and that ten percent may be soon reduced to one percent by continuous and vigorous propaganda.
('75', 460, 1, 4, 917452) As a matter of fact, the Madras Government have made a concession in that students taking up Hindi are not compelled to sit for an examination.
('75', 460, 1, 5, 917596) This, I think, practically takes away the value of compulsion; rather I would insist on an examination passing which will alone enable a student to be promoted to a higher class, and we may give this conscience clause.
('75', 460, 1, 6, 917815) Moreover I do not like the use of the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1 in view of our definite election pledge that the Congress stands for the repeal of all repressive laws.
('75', 460, 1, 7, 917986) This Act was placed on the Statute Book by the fiat of the Governor General against the express wishes of the Indian Legislative Assembly.
('75', 460, 1, 8, 918125) This matter is very urgent, and I should like you to place it before Mahatmaji before he leaves Delhi.
('75', 460, 1, 9, 918228) If he wants to discuss it further with me, I shall be glad to discuss it with him.
('75', 460, 1, 10, 918311) There is just one other matter of extreme urgency which I am sure is already exercising Mahatmaji’s mind.
('75', 460, 1, 11, 918417) The present deadlock in the Congress ought not to be allowed to continue.
('75', 460, 1, 12, 918491) The Working Committee must be formed and formed at once.
('75', 460, 1, 13, 918548) There are several provinces in which the Congress work is at a standstill and the Working Committee starting functioning alone will solve all these provincial and other problems.
('75', 460, 1, 14, 918727) I hope that Mahatmaji will be able to get Srijut Subhas Chandra Bose to nominate the members of the Working Committee according to his wishes.
('75', 460, 1, 15, 918870) But if there be any difficulty in the matter, I suggest that a very early meeting of the All India Congress Committee may be summoned, which according to the constitution is entitled to meet the new situation and will meet it by appointing a Working Committee recommended by Mahatmaji.
('75', 460, 1, 16, 919156) I am sending you this letter just now and I shall be at Birla House this evening (Monday, 20th) at 6.30 p.
('75', 460, 1, 17, 919263) Any other hour between 5.30 and 8 p.
('75', 460, 1, 18, 919300) will suit me.
('75', 460, 1, 19, 919314) Please send a line in reply per bearer who will wait for the same, to meet you and have a few words with you.
('75', 460, 1, 20, 919424) I trust you will find it possible to meet me at that time.

('75', 461, 1, 2, 919724) APPENDICES XI
('75', 461, 2, 3, 919738) LETTERS FROM SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE 1
('75', 461, 3, 4, 919773) JEALGORA P. O., March 29, 1939
('75', 461, 4, 5, 919804) MY DEAR MAHATMAJI, I received your letter of the 24th instant from the train, along with the enclosures.
('75', 461, 4, 6, 919909) Firstly, my brother, Sarat, wrote to you on his own.
('75', 461, 4, 7, 919962) You will see from his letter that he got your telegram on his return to Calcutta from here and then he wrote to you.
('75', 461, 4, 8, 920079) If he had not got your telegram, I doubt if he would have written.
('75', 461, 4, 9, 920146) There are, of course, certain things in his letter which echo my feelings.
('75', 461, 4, 10, 920221) But that is a different matter.
('75', 461, 4, 11, 920253) The main problem appears to me as to whether both parties can forget the past and work together.
('75', 461, 4, 12, 920350) That depends entirely on you.
('75', 461, 4, 13, 920380) If you can command the confidence of both parties by taking up a truly non partisan attitude, then you can save the Congress and restore national unity.
('75', 461, 4, 14, 920533) I am temperamentally not a vindictive person and I do not nurse grievances.
('75', 461, 4, 15, 920609) In a way, I have the mentality of a boxer, that is, to shake hands smilingly when the boxing bout is over and take the result in a sporting spirit.
('75', 461, 4, 16, 920757) Secondly, in spite of all the representations that I have been receiving, I take the Pant resolution as it has been passed by the Congress.
('75', 461, 4, 17, 920897) We must give effect to it.
('75', 461, 4, 18, 920924) I myself allowed the resolution to be moved and discussed, despite the ultra vires clause in it.
('75', 461, 4, 19, 921021) How can I go back on it ?
('75', 461, 4, 20, 921047) Thirdly, there are two alternatives before you: (1) Either to accommodate our views with regard to the composition of the new Working Committee, or (2) to insist on your views in their entirety.
('75', 461, 4, 21, 921242) In the case of the latter, we may come to the parting of the ways.
('75', 461, 4, 22, 921309) Fourthly, I am prepared to do all that is humanly possible for me to expedite the formation of the new Working Committee and the summoning of the Working Committee and A. I. C. C. But I am so sorry that it is not possible for me to come to Delhi now.
('75', 461, 4, 23, 921560) (Dr. Sunil has wired to you this morning on this point.

('75', 462, 3, 16, 923303) I have been pondering over the various points in your letter of the 24th instant to me (from the train) and your letter to Sarat of the same date and over the situation in general.
('75', 462, 3, 17, 923484) It is really unfortunate for me that I fell ill at such a critical time.
('75', 462, 3, 18, 923557) But events have so moved in rapid succession that I have not had a chance of quick recovery.
('75', 462, 3, 19, 923650) Besides, both before Tripuri and after, I have not been treated in certain influential quarters (there is no reference to you at all in this—let me make it clear) with the consideration that was due to me.
('75', 462, 3, 20, 923856) But there is no reason for me to resign on account of my illness.
('75', 462, 3, 21, 923922) As I stated in my letter 2 of yesterday (my second letter to you), no President, to my knowledge, resigned when he was in prison, even for a long time.
('75', 462, 3, 22, 924074) It may be that I shall have to resign after all, but if that takes place, it will be due to quite different reasons.
('75', 462, 3, 23, 924191) I think I said in my second letter that though pressure was being brought to bear on me to resign, I was resisting.
('75', 462, 3, 24, 924307) My resignation would mean the beginning of a new phase in Congress politics which I want to avoid till the last .

('75', 463, 1, 2, 924551) parting of the ways, a bitter civil war will commence and—whatever be the upshot of it—the Congress will be weakened for some time to come and the benefit will be reaped by the British Government.
('75', 463, 1, 3, 924748) It is in your hands to save the Congress and the country from the calamity.
('75', 463, 1, 4, 924824) People who are bitterly opposed for various reasons to Sardar Patel and his group, still have confidence in you and believe that you can take a dispassionate and non partisan view of things.
('75', 463, 1, 5, 925015) To them you are a national figure— above parties and groups—and you can, therefore, restore unity between the warring elements.
('75', 463, 1, 6, 925143) If for any reason that confidence is shaken—which God forbid—and you are regarded as a partisan, then God help us and the Congress.
('75', 463, 1, 7, 925275) There is no doubt that there is today a wide gulf between the two parties (or blocs) in the Congress.
('75', 463, 1, 8, 925377) But the gulf can yet be bridged—and that by you.
('75', 463, 1, 9, 925426) I cannot say anything about the mentality of our political opponents.
('75', 463, 1, 10, 925496) Tripuri has given us a very bad experience of them, but I can speak for our side.
('75', 463, 1, 11, 925578) We are not vindictive and we do not nurse grievances.
('75', 463, 1, 12, 925632) We are prepared to “forgive and forget”—as they say—and join hands once again for the sake of the common cause, viz., the political and economic emancipation of India.
('75', 463, 1, 13, 925800) When I talk of ‘our side’, I exclude the official Congress Socialist Party.

('75', 463, 1, 16, 926177) A large section of the Congress Socialist Party will move with us in future, in spite of what the top leadership may do.
('75', 463, 1, 17, 926298) If you have any doubts on this score, you have only to wait and see.

('75', 463, 1, 20, 926571) Naturally, he knows more about the happenings at Tripuri than I do, because he could move about freely, meet people and obtain information.
('75', 463, 1, 21, 926711) But though I was confined to bed, I got enough information from several independent sources regarding the attitude of responsible circles politically opposed to us, to make me feel thoroughly sick of the whole affair.
('75', 463, 1, 22, 926929) I may say further that when I left Tripuri, I felt such a loathing and disgust for Congress politics as I have not done for the last nineteen years.
('75', 463, 1, 23, 927078) Thank God, I have got over that feeling now and have recovered my composure.

('75', 467, 13, 24, 938789) As stated above it is certainly most essential that the important Mahomedan and Bhayat communities should, like other communities, have proper representation.

('75', 467, 13, 26, 939041) 61 dated 21 1 1939 the names of two suitable representatives of Mahomedan community and one of Bhayats.
('75', 467, 13, 27, 939145) That you shared this view is clearly evident from the assurances

('75', 473, 9, 22, 955722) THE WAY OF SATYAGRAHA 1
('75', 473, 10, 23, 955746) At the end of five days' heart to heart talks with the Muslim friends, often continuing till midnight, and shorter talks with the Bhayats and having failed with them, Gandhiji put his signature to the letter 2 to the Thakore Saheb submitting seven names of the Sardar's representatives.
('75', 473, 10, 24, 956033) His hand shook as he did so.
('75', 473, 10, 25, 956062) He never dreamt at that time that within thirty six hours of the despatch of his letter, his faith in God and ahimsa would be put to test.
('75', 473, 10, 26, 956201) Ever since his arrival here on his mission of peace, Gandhiji had made it a point to hold daily the congregational evening prayer on the
('75', 473, 11, 27, 956338) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”,16 4 1939 2 Vide “Letter to Dharmendrasinh”, 14 4 1939
('75', 474, 0, 1, 956425) VOL. 75 : 30 JANUARY, 1939 30 MAY, 1939 475
('75', 474, 1, 2, 956469) Rashtriyashala grounds.
('75', 474, 1, 3, 956493) The practice was kept up during the fast.
('75', 474, 2, 4, 956535) On the evening of the 16th instant a report was brought to Gandhiji that the Bhayats and Mussalmans of Rajkot were going to hold a black flag demonstration at the evening prayer.
('75', 474, 2, 5, 956714) There was also a report that a garland of shoes had been got ready for the occasion.
('75', 474, 2, 6, 956799) He made light of the fears of those who brought the report.
('75', 474, 2, 7, 956859) He had full faith in the Mussalman and the Bhayat leaders who had friendly discussions with him during the last five days.
('75', 474, 2, 8, 956982) But in case the worst came to the worst he would welcome it.
('75', 474, 2, 9, 957043) Accordingly, he gave peremptory instructions that anybody approaching him, no matter with what intent, should be given free access and not obstructed in any way.
('75', 474, 3, 10, 957205) He motored as usual to the Rashtriyashala prayer ground.
('75', 474, 3, 11, 957262) Almost simultaneously with it the demonstrators, too, numbering about 600, arrived on the scene with black flags and placards bearing inscriptions some of which were highly offensive.
('75', 474, 3, 12, 957446) They lined the fence enclosing the prayer ground from the main road.
('75', 474, 3, 13, 957515) The Sardar happened to be away at Amreli that day and so missed the show.
('75', 474, 4, 14, 957589) Gandhiji bowed to the demonstrators, as is his wont, before he sat down to prayer, which was conducted as usual.
('75', 474, 4, 15, 957702) All the time the prayer was going on, the processionists kept on an unseemly demonstration of shouting and yelling.
('75', 474, 4, 16, 957818) The creation of disturbance at the prayer time under the very eyes of the Bhayats and Mussalman representatives who had sat with him in conference only the other day was for him the "unkindest cut of all".
('75', 474, 4, 17, 958024) The prayer over, he rose to go.
('75', 474, 4, 18, 958056) The demonstrators had by now begun to pour in through the entrance of the narrow passage leading to the prayer ground.
('75', 474, 4, 19, 958175) Gandhiji, instead of going by car as usual, decided to walk through the crowd so as to give the demonstrators full chance to say or do to him whatever they pleased.
('75', 474, 4, 20, 958340) At the entrance the crush was too great to allow further progress.
('75', 474, 4, 21, 958407) The pushing and jostling by the demonstrators at the rear on either side of the gangway was growing apace.
('75', 474, 4, 22, 958514) The dust and the din added to the confusion.
('75', 474, 4, 23, 958559) Friends tried to form a protective cordon.
('75', 474, 4, 24, 958602) But Gandhiji waved them off.
('75', 474, 4, 25, 958631) “I shall sit here or go alone in their midst,” he told them.
('75', 474, 4, 26, 958692) All of a sudden he was seized by an attack of indescribable pain in the region of the waist, and felt as if he would faint.
('75', 474, 4, 27, 958816) This is an old symptom in his case that seizes him whenever he receives an acute mental shock.
('75', 474, 4, 28, 958911) For a time he stood in the midst of that jostling crowd motionless and silent, his eyes shut, supporting himself on his staff, and tried to seek relief through silent prayer, a remedy that has never failed him on such occasions.
('75', 474, 4, 29, 959140) As soon as he had sufficiently recovered, he reiterated his resolve to go through the demonstrators all alone.
('75', 474, 4, 30, 959251) He addressed a Bhayat, who stood confronting him and who, he subsequently learned, was besides a police officer in plain clothes, “I wish to go under your sole protection, not co workers'.” Some Bhayats had already noticed his condition.
('75', 474, 4, 31, 959489) They now bade the rest to make way for him, and leaning on the shoulder of the Bhayat
('75', 475, 0, 1, 959575) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 475, 1, 2, 959617) friend in question, Gandhiji walked to the waiting car.
('75', 475, 1, 3, 959673) “This is the way of satyagraha,” he remarked as the car drove off, “to put your head unresistingly into the lap of your ‘enemy’, for him to keep or make short work of just as he pleases.
('75', 475, 1, 4, 959860) It is the sovereign way, and throughout my half a century of varied experience it has never once failed me.”
('75', 475, 2, 5, 959969) Two Mussalman representatives from the Civil Station came to see him soon after, according to previous appointment.
('75', 475, 2, 6, 960085) “You were less than fair to yourself and to us in exposing yourself to such a risk.
('75', 475, 2, 7, 960169) Anything may happen in a motley crowd,” they remarked to him with reference to the happenings of the evening.
('75', 475, 3, 8, 960279) Gandhiji in reply described to them how such risk taking had become a part and parcel of his life.
('75', 475, 3, 9, 960378) There were at least half a dozen occasions in South Africa and in India when he had risked his life like that, and he had never regretted doing so.
('75', 475, 3, 10, 960526) In all cases the assailant or the would be assailants had ended by becoming his friends.
('75', 475, 3, 11, 960615) “But should the worst happen after all,” he concluded, “what privilege can be greater for a satyagrahi than to fall with a prayer in your heart for those whom you wanted to serve but who under a delusion took you for an ‘enemy’?”

('75', 476, 10, 16, 963042) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('75', 476, 11, 17, 963059) Many thanks for your friendly letter of 9th May which I appreciate all the more because I realize the pressure under which you have been working and the fact that you were writing on the train.
('75', 476, 11, 18, 963253) Let me thank you, too, for leaving me free from business so far as you are concerned during my holiday.
('75', 476, 12, 19, 963357) 2. ('75', 476, 13, 20, 963792) 3. I have been watching events in Talcher very closely.
('75', 476, 13, 21, 963848) I am satisfied myself that the Assistant Political Agent, when he interviewed the refugees in Angul, made it clear that he was not in a position to give them any promises or come to any agreement.
('75', 476, 13, 22, 964045) That, however, is now past history, and as you will have heard, the Raja
('75', 476, 14, 23, 964118) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Linithgow”, 9 59 1939 and “Letter to Lord Limithow” 23 24 1939
('75', 477, 0, 1, 964204) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('75', 477, 1, 2, 964246) recently made an announcement which appeared to me satisfactorily to meet the remaining grievances of any importance of which the refugees complained.
('75', 477, 1, 3, 964397) I am no less disappointed than you are that this should have failed to produce the desired result, but further enquiries have been set on foot and I hope that the trouble will soon be at an end.
('75', 477, 2, 4, 964592) 4. As regards Jaipur, you will no doubt have heard that conversations have recently taken place between the Jaipur authorities and Seth Jamnalal Bajaj, and here again I hope that a suitable solution of the difficulties will soon be forthcoming.
('75', 477, 3, 5, 964837) 5. As regards Rajkot, I have been very sorry to learn of the difficulties with which you have to contend.
('75', 477, 3, 6, 964943) Owing to the various conflicting interests involved, the matter appears to have become highly complicated, but I hope that in the absence of any other solution, the Committee will be set up without any further considerable delay.
('75', 477, 3, 7, 965173) I understand that the question whether certain of the Sardar's nominees are state subjects has now been decided by the Judicial Commissioner, and that the only other preliminary point to be settled is whether the assurances which you gave to the Muslims and the Bhayats were conditional or unconditional.
('75', 477, 3, 8, 965478) I understand that it has been agreed that this should be referred to an independent judicial authority, and that it now remains only to decide who the judicial authority is to be and what should be the precise terms of reference.
('75', 477, 3, 9, 965708) I will, I need not assure you, continue to watch developments in Rajkot with close attention.
('75', 477, 4, 10, 965802) 6. I do not in the least misunderstand your sympathetic reference, and we both of us have our troubles!
('75', 477, 4, 11, 965906) But it is only fair to say I have no misgivings as to the loyalty of the Political Department in carrying out my instructions.
('75', 477, 5, 12, 966033) With all good wishes,
('75', 477, 6, 13, 966055) Yours sincerely,
('75', 477, 7, 14, 966072) LINLITHGOW
